Praefatio.	Preface.
Postquam compleui uobis o Filii, librum hunc, qui est postremus scientiae in medicina cum complemento ipsius, et consecutus sum finem in eo, ex expositionibus eius, et ipsius declarationibus, uisum est mihi, ut compleam ipsum uobis cum hoc Tractatu qui est pars operationis, id est, chirurgiae cum manu.	After I have finished with you, my son, this book, which is the last of my works on medicine, and having completed it with the addition of its contents, I have reached the end of my exposition and declarations, so that I deemed it fitting to join this treatise to the work on surgery, which is the hand of the art.
Quoniam operatio cum manu prostrata est in regione nostra, et tempore nostro priuata omnino: donec fortasse periit scientia eius, et abscissum est uestigium eius: et non remanserunt ex ea, nisi descriptiones paruae in libris antiquorum, quas mutauerunt manus: et accidit eis error et haesitatio, donec clausae sunt intentiones eius, et elongata est uis ipsius: Visum est mihi, ut uiuificem eam cum ordinatione huius Tractatus in ea secundum uiam ex positionis, et declarationis, et abbreuiationis: et ut ueniam cum formis ferramentorum Cauterii, et reliquorum instrumentorum operis: cum fit ex declarationis additione, et ex properatione eius quod est necesse.	For surgery is a hand of the art which has been cast aside in our time and age; and for a long time it has been cast aside due to the scarcity of its secrets and the hazes of tradition. And it has not remained except for a few slight descriptions in the ancient books, which have been changed by the hands of men. And this has caused error and hesitation, until the intentions of these works have been closed and prolonged is has become necessary. It is therefore necessary for me to set forth this treatise in this way, in order to explain its forms and arrangements of instruments, along with their preparations, which are necessary for the work.
Caussa autem propter quam non inuenitur bonus artifex eius cum manu sua in hoc nostro tempore, est: quia ars medicinae est longa, et oportet auctorem eius exercitari ante illud in scientia anatomiae, quam narrauit Galenus, donec sciat iuuamenta membrorum, et ipsorum formas, et eorum coniunctionem, et separationem, et habeat cognitionem ossium, et neruorum, et lacertorum, et numerum ipsorum, et eorum egressionem, et uenarum pulsatilium, et quietarum, et locorum exitus earum.	But the greatest cause why one does not find a good surgeon of the hand in our time is that the art of medicine is a long one, and the author must exercise himself beforehand in the science of anatomy as Galen has narrated, until he knows the movements of the limbs, their forms, and their connections, and the separation and union of the bones, nerves, and vessels, and their number, and their emergence and pulsation, and quietness, and the location of their exits
Et propter illud dixit Hippocrates, quod nomen cum nomine est multum, et cum opere est paucum, et praecipue in arte manus.	And thus Hippocrates said, "A name is little when it comes to fame, but work is great, especially in the art of the hand.
Nos uero iam diximus de illo in introitu huius libri.	We have already mentioned this at the beginning of this book.
Quoniam qui non est sciens, quod diximus de anatomia, non euacuatur, quin iam cadat in errorem, quo interficiuntur homines: sicut ego uidi multos ex illis, qui formantur de hac scientia, et iactant se de ea absque scientia, et sine experimento.	For he who is ignorant of what we have said concerning anatomy will fall into error, for many have perished from this lack of knowledge, who have puffed up with pride from their supposed knowledge of this science without any knowledge or experience
Quod est, quia uidi medicum stolidum secuisse apostema scrophulosum in collo mulieris, et incidit quasdam arterias in collo: quare fluxit sanguis mulieris, donec cecidit mortua inter manus eius.	What is this, since the doctor has secured the swollen abscess with a scrophulus in the woman's neck, and has thereby obstructed some arteries in the neck: why does blood flow from the woman, until it dies between her hands?
Et uidi medicum alium, qui praesumpsit ut extraheret lapidem uiro, qui processerat in aetate, et lapis erat magnus.	And the doctor has also said that he would extract the stone from the bladder, which was proceeding in its age, and the stone was great.
Peruenit ergo ad eum, et extraxit ipsum cum frusto uesicae.	So it came to pass that he extracted it with the bladder's bladder-sac.
Quare mortuus est uir in tertio die.	Therefore the man died on the third day.
Et ego quidem iam uocatus fueram ad extrahendum ipsum: et uidi ex magnitudine lapidis, et dispositione infirmi, quod moriretur.	And I myself was called to extract it: and I saw from the greatness of the stone, and the condition of the patient, that he would die.
Et uidi medicum alium, qui accipiebat stipem apud quendam Ducum terrae nostrae propter medicinam: et accidit eunucho nigro, qui erat apud ipsum, fractura in crure eius prope calcaneum: et properauit medicus cum ignorantia sua, et strinxit fracturam super uulnus cum puluinaribus, et astellis strictura forti, et non dimisit uulneri expirationem.	And the doctor saw another man receive a blow from a certain Duke of our land for a physician: and it happened to a black eunuch who was with him, that he fractured his leg near his heel: and the doctor did not know what to do, and he bound up the fracture with wool and nails, and strong stitches, and did not let the wound breathe.
Deinde absoluit eum secundum desyderia sua.	And he left him according to his desires.
Postea dimisit eum diebus aliquot, et praecepit ei, ne solueret ligamentum: et stetit sic donec apostematum est crus eius, et ipsius pes, et peruenit ad perditionem.	Afterwards he sent him away for a few days, and commanded him not to loosen the ligament: and he stood thus until the abscess of his leg had gone down, and his foot and leg, and it came to pass to his destruction
Vocatus sum ergo ad eum: et properaui ad soluendum ligamentum: et consecuta est tranquillitas, et euasit a doloribus suis.	I was called to him again: and I proceeded to loosen the ligament: and there was peace, and he was freed from his pains
Verumtamen corruptio iam confirmata erat in membro: et non potui refraenare ipsam.	But indeed the corruption was already confirmed in the limb: and I could not restrain it
Pon ergo cessauit corruptio perambulare in membro, donec periit.	Therefore the corruption ceased to walk in the limb until it died
Et uidi medicum alium, qui perforauit apostema cancerosum: et ulceratum est post dies, donec magnificata est malicia eius cum domino ipsius.	And the physician went to another, who had perforated the cancerous tumor: and it had ulcerated after days, until the malice of the former increased with the master himself.
Quod est, quia quando est cancer purus ex humore melancholico, tunc non oportet ut perueniatur ad eum cum ferro omnino, nisi sit in membro quod toleret, ut abscindatur totum eius.	When the tumor is pure from black bile, it does not suffice to endure it with all one's might, except in the limb where it can be excised whole
Et propter illud o Filii, necesse est uobis, ut sciatis, quod operatio cum manu diuiditur in duas diuisiones: scilicet, operationem cui associatur salus: et operationem, cum qua est periculum in pluribus dispositionibus.	And thus, my son, you must know that surgery is divided into two parts: that which is associated with health, and that which carries risk in many situations.
Et ego iam excitaui in omni loco huius libri, in quo uenit operatio, in qua est terror et timor.	I am grieved in every place of this book in which surgery is mentioned, in which there is fear and terror.
Quare necesse est uobis, ut caueatis illud, et dimitatis ipsum: ut non inueniant stolidi uiam ad loquendum, et dehonestandum.	Therefore you must be cautious of this, and humble yourself: so that you do not become proud, and thereby lose your dignity
Accipite ergo mensuram cum sollicitudine et protectione, et infirmos uestros cum facilitate et firmitudine, et utimini uia meliore perducente gratia Dei ad salutem et successionem laudabilem: et dimittite aegritudines terribiles difficilis sanationis: et tollite animas uestras ab eo quod facit uos timere, ut ingrediatur super uos haesitatio in fide uestra et commodo uestro.	Receive therefore measure with humility and protection, and the sick with ease and firmness, and use the better way for the bringing about of glory to God for salvation and praiseworthy succession: and banish from you the terrible anxieties which make you fear for your soul, that there should be no hesitation in your heart or coolness in your spirit
Est enim magis remanens ad gloriam uestram, et sublimius in mundo isto, et postremo ad quantitates uestras.	For there remains in this world only the glory of God, and the shadow of this life, and finally the account of each one.
Galenus enim iam dixit in quibusdam suis admonitionibus.	For Galen has said in some of his admonitions.
Non medicetis aegritudinem malam: ne nominemini medici mali.	You do not cure the bad ailment: do not call the physician a bad man.
Iam autem diuisi hunc Tractatum secundum tria Capitula. ¶	I have, however, divided this treatise into three chapters.
Capitulum primum.	Chapter 1.
De Cauterio cum igne, et Cauterio cum medicina acuta, capitulatum, et ordinatum a capite usque ad pedes, et formis instrumentorum, et ferramentis Cauterii: et omni quod necessarium est in operatione. ¶	Of the cautery with fire, and the cautery with acute medicine, a chapter, arranged from the head to the feet, concerning the forms of the instruments and materials for the cautery: and everything which is necessary for the operation
Capitulum secundum.	Second Chapter.
De sectione et perforatione, phlebotomia et uentosis, et uulneribus: et extractione sagittarum, et similibus illius: et totum capitulatum, ordinatum formis instrumentorum. ¶	On incision and perforation, phlebotomy and packing, and wounds: and the extraction of arrows, and things of that kind: and the whole chapter, arranged in the form of instruments.
Capitulum tertium.	Third Chapter.
De restauratione, et dislocatione, et curatione torsionis, et similibus illius: capitulatum, ordinatum a capite usque ad pedes, et formis instrumentorum.	On restoration, and dislocation, and treatment of twisting, and things of that kind: the chapter is arranged from the head to the feet, and the form of instruments.
Soli Deo Gloria.	Glory be to God.
Liber Chirurgici Albucasis.	The Book of Surgery by Albucasis.
Pars I.	Part I.
¶ De Iuuamento, et Nocumento Cauterii: et quibus complexionibus conueniat, et quo tempore: et si cum ferro, uel auro.	On the application of a dressing, and the use of the cautery: and on what complexion it is suitable, and when: and whether with iron or gold.
Caput I.	Chapter I
Sed Ante Quidem Quam rememorer operationis cum eo, oportet ut dicam qualitatem Iuuamentorum eius, et Nocumentorum ipsius: et in qua complexione exhibeatur.	But before one remembers any operation, it is necessary to say what is the quality of the dressings and instruments: and in what complexion it should be shown
Dico ergo, quod sermo de qualitate iuuamenti Cauterii, et nocumenti eius, est sermo prolixus, et subtilis, scientia, et secretum occultum.	I say therefore, that the discourse concerning the quality of the cautery dressing and its instrument is a lengthy, subtle, scientific and hidden art.
Etiam locuta fuit in eo multitudo sapientum, et dissenserunt in eo: et mihi quidem sufficit parum ex sermonibus eorum, timens prolongationem.	And it has been said by many learned men in this matter, and they have differed among themselves: and indeed little is to be learned from their discourses, fearing the prolongation of the subject
Dico ergo, quod Cauterium confert uniuersaliter omni complexioni, quae est cum materia, et absque materia: excaeptis duabus complexionibus, quae sunt complexio calida absque materia, et complexio sicca absque materia.	I say therefore, that the cautery is useful for all complexions, that is with material and without material: except for two complexions which are the hot complexion without material, and the dry complexion without material
In complexione autem calida et sicca cum materia dissenserunt.	In the hot and dry complexion with material they differ
Quidam enim dixerunt, quod Cauterium iuuatiuum est in ea.	Some indeed say that the cautery is useful in these matters
Et dixerunt alii contrarium illius, scilicet quod Cauterium non est conueniens in aegritudine, quae est ex caliditate et siccitate: quoniam natura ignis est caliditas: et inconueniens est, ut sanetur ex agritudine calida et sicca, cum calido et sicco.	Others have said the contrary, namely that Cauterium is not suitable for ailments caused by heat and dryness, because the nature of fire is heat: and it is inappropriate to heal from a heat and dry ailment with heat and dryness.
Et dixit ille qui dicit contrarium illius: quod per Cauterium fit iuuamentum in omni aegritudine calida et sicca, quae accidit in corporibus hominum: quoniam quando tu comparas corpus hominis, et humiditates eius, ad complexionem ignis, inuenis corpus hominis frigidum.	Others have said the contrary, namely that Cauterium is not suitable for treating ailments caused by heat and dryness, which arise in the bodies of men: for when you compare the body of a man to the nature of fire, you find the body of a man to be cool to the touch
Et ego quidem dico per sermonem eius: quia ex perimentum iam detexit mihi illud aliquotiens.	I too, however, have learned from experience that this is the case.
Verumtamen non oportet, ut ueniat super illud, nisi qui iam probatus est, et exercitatus in capitulo Cauterii exercitio ultimo, et cognouit diuersitatem complexionum hominum, et dispositionem aegritudinum in se ipsis, et caussas earum, et accidentia ipsarum, et spacium temporis earum.	It is true that this should not be assumed without testing, exercising the final exercise of Cauterium, and recognizing the diversity of the temperaments of men, and the causes and effects of ailments, and the speed of their course.
Ex reliquis autem complexionibus non est super uos timor: et praecipue in aegritudinibus frigidis et humidis.	Except in the case of extremely cold and humid temperaments, there is no reason to fear these things: and especially in the case of ailments caused by heat and moisture.
Iam enim conuenerunt omnes medici super eas: et non dissenserunt in iuuamento cum Cauterio in eis.	I have seen all physicians agree on this: and they do not hesitate to apply Cauterium in such cases.
Et scitote filii, quod ex secreto curationis per Cauterium cum igne, et bonitate eius super Cauterium cum medicina comburente est: quoniam ignis est simplex, cuius actio non peruenit, nisi ad membrum quod cauterisatur: et non nocet membro alio coniuncto cum eo, nisi nocumento paruo.	Note that the action of fire is simple, and its power does not extend beyond the part that is cauterized: and it does no harm to any other part connected to it, except for a slight burn.
Medicinae uero comburentis actio peruenit ad illud quod elongatur ex membris: et fortasse facit accidere in membro aegritudinem difficilis sanationis, et fortasse interficit.	The action of the burning medicine extends beyond the part which is cauterized: and perhaps makes the healing of the ailment more difficult in other parts, and perhaps causes death.
Ignis autem propter subtilitatem suam et bonitatem substantiae suae, non facit illud, nisi superfluat.	Fire, however, by its subtlety and the goodness of its material, does not cause this unless it be excessive.
Iam uero innotuit nobis illud per experimentum, propter longitudinem seruitutis et studii cum arte, et stationem super ueritatem rerum: et propter illud excusor a longitudine sermonis.	I am indeed aware of that through experiment and by the length of service and study with art, and the position above reality of things: and because of that from the length of speech.
Et si non esset, quia non licet huic libro meo, afferrem uobis secretum occultum in igne, et qualitatem operationis eius in corporibus expulsionis suae, qua expellit aegritudines sermone philosophico demonstratiuo, qui acueretur a mentibus uestris.	And if it should not be [said], since it is not fitting for this book of mine, I will nevertheless declare a secret hidden in fire, and the quality of the operation in the bodies expelled by it, which expels diseases with philosophical demonstration, agreeable to the thoughts of the prudent.
Et scitote filii, quod ipsi dissentiunt in tempore, in quo conuenit fieri cauterium, et ponunt melius tempus ueris.	And behold, sons, that they themselves dissent in the time when the cautery is to be made, and say that it is better to delay the time of your work.
Et ego dico, quod cauterium conuenit in omni tempore: propterea, quod nocumentum accidens propter tempus submergitur in iuuamento, quod attrahitur cum cauterio.	I say indeed that the cautery agrees in all time: forasmuch as the document is absorbed by moisture over time, which is attracted by the cautery.
Et praecipue si cauterium est propter dolores ex doloribus necessariis, fortibus, festinis, qui non tolerant tarditatem: propterea quod timetur ex eis, quod accidat malicia quae est maior, quam paruum nocumentum intrans propter tempus.	Above all, if the cautery is for necessary and urgent pains, strong, fast, which do not tolerate delay: for they fear the moisture which arises from the wound, which increases the malice which is greater than the slight abrasion caused by the passage of time.
Et non cadat in mentibus uestris o filii illud, quod non extimant, nisi uulgus et stolidi medici, scilicet quod illi aegritudini quae sanatur per cauterium, non est reditio semper: et ponunt illud consequens, et res non est sicut putant: propterea quod cauterium non est, nisi loco medicinae, quae alterat complexionem, et exiccat humiditates quae sunt caussae, quare accidunt dolores.	And do not let it be thought by anyone, sons, or physicians of little experience, that because it does not abate, it is therefore useless: for indeed it is not the cause of the disease that is cauterized, but the moisture and humors which are the cause of the disease.
Verumtamen cauterium superfluit super medicinam per uelocitatem ualetudinis suae, et uirtutem suae operationis, et uehementiam dominii sui: et possibile est, ut redeat aegritudo hora aliqua temporis secundum complexionem infirmi, et locationem aegritudinis suae, et uirtutem eius: et quod praeparatur in corpore eius ex aggregatione superfluitatum in eo: et quod peruenit ad ipsum in acquisitione sua ex cibis, et similibus illis ex caussis, nisi fit aegritudo, in qua administratur cauterium.	However, the cautery surpasses the art of medicine by the swiftness of its action, the excellence of its operation, and the extent of its domination: and it is possible that the disease will vanish at some time according to the complexion of the patient, the location of the disease, and the excellence of the operation: and that which is prepared in his body from the aggregation of superabundances in him: and which comes to him from the cause itself, except in the case of a disease in which the cautery is administered.
Aegritudo subtilis in membro paucarum superfluitatum, et humiditatum, sicut cauterium dentis, propter dolorem, et similia illi, possibile est enim, ut non redeat in eo ille dolor.	Acute pain in a limb with few superfluous and humid swellings, like a tooth cautery due to pain, is also possible for the enemy, so that it does not return in that area of pain.
Sed illud fit in paucis.	However, this is in few cases.</start_of_turn>
At uero sermo uulgi iterum, quod cauterium est postremum medicinae, est sermo rectus: non ad illud quod ipsi intendunt in illo: quoniam ipsi credunt, quod non est curatio quae conferat cum medicina, neque cum alio post occasum cauterii.	Indeed, the word often returns, because cautery is the last of medicine. It is the right word: not to this which they themselves intend, because they believe that there is no cure which brings relief along with medicine, nor with anything following the cautery.</start_of_turn>
Res autem est econtrario illius, et intentio, quod cauterium est postremum medicinae, non est, nisi quod quando nos administramus modos curationis in aliqua aegritudinum, et non conferunt illae medicinae: deinde administramus in fine rei cauterium, et confert: tunc inde cadit, quod cauterium est postremum mediciuae, non secundum intentionem quam intelligunt uulgus et multistolidorum medicorum.	But it is the contrary of that which they themselves think. For the intention of the cautery, which is the last of medicine, is not except when we administer methods of treatment in some ailment, and these do not bring relief; then we administer the cautery at the end of everything, and it brings relief: thus it is that the cautery is the last of medicine, not according to the intention which the vulgar and many learned men of medicine understand.</start_of_turn>
Antiqui autem dixerunt, quod cauterium cum auro est melius, quam cauterium cum ferro: et non dixerunt illud, nisi propter aequalitatem auri, et sublimitatem substantiae suae: et dixerunt, quod non facit pus locus cauterii.	The ancients said that the cautery with gold is better than the cautery with iron: and they did not say this except because of the equality of gold, and the fineness of its substance: and they said that it does not make pus at the site of the cautery.</start_of_turn
Verum non est illud absolute: quoniam ego iam probaui illud, et inueni, quod ipsum non facit illud in quibusdam corporibus absque aliis.	But this is not absolutely true: for I myself have seen this to be the case, and I have found that it does not make this in some bodies without other things.</start_of_turn
Et cauterium cum ipso est bonum, et melius quam cum ferro, sicut dixerunt.	And the cautery with itself is good, and better than with iron, as they themselves said.</start_of_turn>
Verumtamen quando tu ignis cauterium in igne ex auro, non declaratur tibi, quando ignitur secundum quantitatem quam uis, propter rubedinem auri: et quando properat ad ipsum frigus, et si addis super ipsum ignitionem, liquescit in igne, et uertitur in laminas.	But when you burn the cautery with gold in fire, you must not tell me when you light it, according to the quantity which you will, because of the redness of the gold: and when it approaches itself to the cold, and if you add more fuel to it, it liquefies in the fire, and turns into plates.</start_of_turn
Quare cadit artifex ex illo in occupationem: et propter illud fit Cauterium cum ferro apud nos uelocius et propinquius, ex rectitudine ad operationem.	Why does the artificer depart from that to the execution of the office? And because of this, the Cauterium with iron is applied to us more quickly and closer to the operation, from the straightness of the work.
Et ego quidem iam ordinaui hoc Capitulum in Cauterio, secundum capitula: et ordinaui ea a capite usque ad pedes: ut alleuient quaerenti illud quod uult ex eo.	I have indeed completed this Chapter on Cauterization, following the chapters: and I have directed them from the head to the feet: so that they may fulfill whatever the seeker wishes from this work
¶ De modo cauterizandi Caput in commissura coronali.	Regarding the cauterization of the head in the coronal suture.
Caput II.	Chapter 2: Regarding the head
Confert hic cauterizatio ad dominium humiditatis et frigiditatis super cerebrum: quae duae sunt caussae sodae, et multitudinis fluxus humorum ex capite ad partes oculorum et aurium, et multitudinis somni, et doloris dentium, et doloris gutturis: et uniuersaliter omnis aegritudinis, quae accidit ex frigiditate, sicut paralisis, et sodae, epilepsiae, et apoplexiae, et similia illis ex aegritudinibus.	Here the cauterization is applied to the lord of humidity and cold above the brain: which are two causes of sweat, and of the multitude of the flow of humors from the head to the eyes and ears, and of the multitude of sleep, and toothache, and throat pain: and generally all ailments that arise from cold, such as paralysis, and sweat, and convulsions, and apoplexy, and things similar to these ailments.
Modus cauterizationis est, ut praecipias infirmo: ut euacuetur in primis cum medicina solutiua mundificante caput tribus noctibus, aut quatuor, secundum quod exigit uirtus infirmi, et eius aetas, et consuetudo eius.	The method of cauterization is as follows: immediately before the operation, the physician should give the patient a purgative that will empty the bowels three or four nights before, according to the nature of the patient, his age, and his habit
Deinde praecipe ei, ut radi faciat caput suum cum nouacula.	Then he should order him to shave his head with a razor.
Deinde fac eum sedere inter manus tuas quadratum, ita quod iam posuit manus suas super pectus suum.	Then make him sit between your hands, with your hands placed over his shoulders
Deinde pone radicem palmae tuae super radicem nasi sui inter oculos suos.	Then place the heel of your palm on the root of his nose between his eyes
Vbicumque ergo peruenerit digitus tuus medius, signa locum illum cum incausto.	Wherever your middle finger reaches, that is the place to apply the cautery.
Deinde igni Cauterium Oliuare: cuius haec est forma.	Then apply the Cauterium with Olive Oil: thus it has this shape
Deinde pone ipsum super locum signatum cum incausto, descensione, qua constringatur manus tua paulatim, et tu reuolues ipsum.	Then place it over the marked place with the burn, descending gradually, until your hand is clasped.
Deinde leua manum tuam uelociter, et aspicias locum.	Then draw your hand quickly away and grasp the place.
Quod si uides iam detegi ex osse quantitatem capitis alkiel, aut quantitatem zeuherbi, tunc eleua manum tuam.	If you see any part of bone or flesh of the head or hair remaining, then draw your hand away from it.
Et si non, itera manum tuam ferro ipso, aut cum alio ab ipso si infrigidatur: donec uideantur ossa, quae dixi tibi.	And if not, repeat your hand with the iron itself, or with another which is warmed: until you see the bone which I mentioned to you.
Deinde sume aliquid ex sale, et solue illud in aqua, et imbibe in ipso cotum, et pone super locum: et dimitte ipsum tribus diebus.	Then take some salt and dissolve it in water, and drink from it: and apply it to the place: and keep it for three days.
Deinde pone super ipsum cotum imbibitum in butyro, et dimitte illum super locum, donec destruatur eschara ignis.	Then apply butter soaked in oil over it, and keep the lamp above the place until the eschar is destroyed by fire.
Deinde cura illud cum unguento tetrapharmacon, usquequo sanetur.	Then care for the place with unguents until it is healed
Iam dixerunt, quod quanto uulnus plus remanet apertum, emittit pus: quare est melius et magis iuuatiuum.	I have said that the greater the wound is, the more pus it emits: which is better and more effective
Et dixerunt quidam eorum, ut cauterizetur cutis usque ad os: et teneatur Cauterium, donec aduratur quiddam spissitudinis ossis.	And some people say that the skin should be cauterized until the bone is reached: and keep the Cauterium until some part of the thickness of the bone has been burnt
Deinde radatur post illud quod adustum est ex osse, deinde curetur.	Then it will be removed after that which has been scorched from the bone, and it will be cured
Et dicunt alii, quod oportet ut cum cauterio perueniatur ad ultimum, donec imprimat in os impressionem for tem, ita quod cadat os, quod fit sicut forma kirate: aut instrumentum quod mulieres ponunt infuso alphabeti parui: et extimant, quod exspirantur ex hoc loco uapores capitis, et dimittatur uulnus apertum tempore longo.	And others say that it is necessary that when cauterizing it should be continued until the very end, until an imprint of the instrument is left on the bone, so that the bone will break: or the instrument which women use for tying up their hair: and they say that the vapor of the head escapes from this place slowly: and the wound will be closed up in a long time
Deinde curetur, donec consolidetur.	Then he cares until consolidated.
Mihi autem non uidentur hae duae species Cauterii omnino nisi in quibusdam hominibus secundum uiam timoris.	Neither of two species of cautery is harmful to anyone except in some people according to the degree of fear.
Et dimittere ipsum, apud me est melius cum salute ipsius.	And dismiss it, for it is better with me than with your health.
Debilitatur enim caput ex solutione continuitatis ipsius naturalis: sicut testificati sumus in reliquis membris: et praecipue quando caput infirmi debile est natura: et species quidem Cauterii prima est magis salua et melior apud me, et ea utor: operare ergo cum ea in salute.	The head suffers from the solution of its natural continuity: as we have testified in other limbs: and especially when the head is weak by nature: of which the first kind of cautery is the most safe and better for me, and that which is most useful: for I work with it in health
¶ De modo cauterizandi capitis in dolore totius capitis.	In this way cauterizes the head in the pain of the whole head
Caput III.	Head Chapter III
Quando in toto Capite accidit dolor chronicus: et prolongatur illud in infirmo, et utitur hyeris, et cochiis, et caputpurgiis, et oleis, et empleumatis.	When in the whole head happens chronic pain: and it lasts in the sick person, and uses herbs, and ointments, and poultices, and oils, and implements.
Et praecipue si iam cauterizatum est cauterio uno, quod narrauimus, et non confert ei aliquid ex illis: tunc considera.	And especially if it has been cauterized with one cautery, which we mentioned, and does not cause it anything of those things: then consider it
Nam si caput infirmi est fortis creationis natura, et non est debile, et inuenit frigus uehemens: tunc cauteriza cum cauterio alio sub illo parum.	For if the head of the sick person is strong by nature, and is not weak, and finds cold or heat: then cauterize with another cautery under that slightly
Deinde cauteriza ipsum super omne cornu capitis sui cauterio, do nec pertranseat cutis, et discooperiatur ex osse quantitas, quam narrauimus.	Then cauterize it over all the horns of the head with that cautery, so that it does not pass through the skin, and uncover from the bone the quantity that we mentioned
Et cauteriza ipsum cauterio uno in occipitio capitis sui, in loco qui nominatur uas: et est locus in quo ponitur uentosa: et eleua matum tuam in hoc, et non discooperias os.	And cauterize it with one cautery in the back of the head in the place that is called the vault: and it is the place where the brains are placed: and raise your hand in this, and do not uncover the bone
Infirmus enim inuenit propter illud dolorem uehementem, et diuersum a dolore reliquorum cauteriorum capitis omnium.	The sick person finds because of this heat and diverse from the pain of the other cauteries of the head all together
Et ego dicam hoc Cauterium in loco suo: et oportet quod sit cauterium, quo cauterizantur cornua capitis, et occiput eius subtilius cauterio, quo cauterizatur medium capitis.	And I say concerning this Cauterium: it must be applied in its proper place. And it is necessary that the Cauterium should be applied to the horns of the head and the nape of the head more delicately, so that the middle of the head is cauterized.
Et haec est forma eius.	This is its form.</start_of_turn>
¶ De modo cauterizandi in hemicrania, tam cum medicina adustiua, quam cum ferro.	Regarding the method of cauterization in hemicrania, both with medicinal poultices and with the instrument itself.</start_of_turn
Caput IIII.	Chapter III.</start_of_turn
Quando accidit in parte capitis dolor et soda, aut extenditur dolor usque ad oculum, et euacuatur cum medicinis mundificantibus caput, et administratur reliqua curatio, quam dixi in diuisionibus aegritudinum, et non confert illud totum: tunc cauterizatio in eo est secundum duos modos: aut cauterizatio cum medicina acuta comburente: aut cum ferro.	When it happens in the part of the head that there is pain and swelling, or that the pain extends up to the eye, and it evacuates with physicians who are making the head better, and the rest of the treatment is administered, as I have said in the discourse on diseases, and it does not suffice for everything: then cauterization is to be performed in two ways: either with acute burning medicine or with an iron.</start_of_turn
Cauterium autem cum medicina acuta comburente, est, ut accipias dentem unum allii, et excortices ipsum, et abscindas extremitates eius ex duobus lateribus.	But with acute burning medicine, take a tooth from another person and burn the area with it, and cut away the extremities from both sides.</start_of_turn
Deinde scinde locum doloris in tempore cum phlebotomo lato, donec fiat in eo locus sub cute, in quo dens capitur.	Then cut away the place of pain at the same time as phlebotomy from the side, until there is a blister under the skin where the tooth is held.</start_of_turn
Intromitte ergo eum in ipso sub cute, donec occultetur: deinde stringe super ipsum cum puluillo constrictione decenti, et dimitte ipsum quantitate quindecim horarum deinde solue eum, et extrahe allium, et dimitteuulnus duobus diebus, aut tribus: postea pone super ipsum cotum submersum in butyro, donec locus efficiat pus: deinde cura ipsum cum unguento usquequo sanetur.	Introduce it there under the skin until it is hidden: then bind over it with a bandage of moderate constriction and leave it for fifteen hours. Then remove it, and extract the tooth, and leave it out for two days or three: afterwards put on a wet cushion over it in butter, until the place has healed. Then care for it with ointment until it is healed.</start_of_turn
Et si uis fac illud cum quibusdam medicinis comburentibus, quas ego scripsi in tractatu duodecimo, de Medieinis adurentibus.	And if you wish to do this with some of the burning medicines which I have written about in the twelfth book on medicinal unguents.</start_of_turn>
Cauterizatio uero eius cum ferro, est secundum hunc modum.	Burning of the uterus with iron is performed in this manner.
Igni Cauterium, cuius forma haec est.	Burning of the uterus with iron is performed in this fashion
Et nominatur Clauilis: quoniam forma capitis eius est sicut forma claui, in quo est quiddam curuitatis, et in medio eius est quaedam eminentia parua.	And is called Clavis: because its shape is like the head of a key, in which there is some curvature, and in the middle of it there is a small protrusion.
Deinde pone ipsum super locum, et retine manum tuam: et tu reuolue ferrum paulatim cum uelocitate: et sit quantitas quae aduritur ex spissitudine cutis, sicut medietas eius.	Then place it upon the place, and hold your hand: and turn the iron gradually with speed: and as much as burns from the thickness of the skin, like half of it
Et eleua manum tuam, ut non aduratur arteria, quae est inferius, et accidat fluxus sanguinis.	And lift your hand, so that it does not burn the artery which is below, and so that blood flow does not increase
Deinde imbibe cotum in aqua salis, et pone super locum, et dimitte ipsum tribus diebus: deinde pone cotum cum butyro: postea cura cum unguento usquequo sanetur.	Then soak the area in salt water, and place upon the place, and leave it for three days: then place the area with butter: afterwards care with unguent until it is healed.
Et si uis, cauteriza hanc hemicraniam cum extremitate cultellari secunda Cauterii.	And if necessary, burn this half of the hemisphere with the second extremity of the knife following the Cauterization.
Et caue ab incisione arteriae in hac hemicrania, non antiqua proprie.	Burn from the incision of the artery in this hemisphere, not the old way alone.
¶ De modo cauteriezandi in hemicrania antiqua.	In the old way, cauterization was performed in the entire hemisphere.
Caput V.	Chapter V.
Quando curas hemicraniam, cum eo quod diximus ex curatione praecedente, et quod diximus in diuisionibus aegritudinum, et non confert curatio: et uides ex aegritudine, quod non sufficit ei quod diximus ex cauterio primo cum medicina, aut cum cauterio cum igne, tunc oportet ut ignias Cauterium cultellare, donec albificetur postquam signas super locum doloris cum linea, cuius longitudo sit medietas digiti, aut quasi illud: et depone manum tuam uice una, et stringe eam donec incidas arteriam, et peruenias usque ad os.	When you are treating the hemisphere, when that which we mentioned in the preceding section concerning the treatment of ailments, and when the treatment has not been successful: and if you see from the ailment that it has not been sufficiently cured by the first cauterization with medicine or by cauterization with fire, then you must burn the Cauterization with a knife until it becomes white when there are signs of pain with a line whose length is half of a finger, or like that: and put your hand away from the wound with one hand, and hold the other hand until you have cut the artery, and hold it until you reach the bone.
Verumtamen necesse est tibi, ut caueas a continuatione mandibulae, quae mouetur apud masticationem, ne aduratur latus, aut neruus qui mouet ipsam, unde accidat spasmus.	It is necessary to moisten the jaws, that they may not become dry and cause pain during biting, neither may the nerve which moves them suffer damage, from which arises spasm.
Et esto super custotiam, et cautelam de fluxu sanguinis arteriae, quae abscisa est.	Take care of the blood supply of the artery which has been severed.</start_of_turn>
In abscisione enim eius est timor, et praecipue ei qui ignorat illud quod facit, et non est studiosus, nec expertus: et dimittit operationem cum eo in primis.	In the cutting of it there is fear, and especially for him who is ignorant of that which he does, and who is not studious and expert: and he departs from the operation at once.</start_of_turn>
Et ego ueniam cum rememoratione regiminis fluxus sanguinis accidentis ex arteria secundum modum suum, et in loco suo huius libri.	And I will remind you of the method of the passage of blood which is caused by the severance of an artery, as it is in this book.</start_of_turn
Quod si uides ex aegritudine, quod non sufficit ei hoc Cauterium, et uides corpus infirmi tolerans cauterium in medio capitis, sicut narrauimus, cura uulnus, donec sanetur.	If the diseased part cannot bear the Cauterium, and the body of the patient tolerates it in the middle of the head, as we have said, care for the wound, until it is healed.</start_of_turn
Et si uis, administra Cauterium, quod diximus in capitulo extractionis arteriae cum Cauterio habente duos cultellos.	And if you wish, apply the Cauterium, as we said in the chapter on the severance of an artery with a Cauterium which has two blades.</start_of_turn
Est enim cauterizatio melior hac et magis conferens.	For the Cauterium is better and more secure.</start_of_turn>
¶ De modo cauterizandi in dolore Aurium.	Of the manner of cauterizing in the pain of the ears.</start_of_turn
Caput VI.	Chapter VI.</start_of_turn>
Quando accidit in Aure dolor a frigore, et curatur cum solutiuis, et reliqua curatione quam diximus in diuisione, et non remouetur dolor, tunc igni Cauterium: et est illud quod nominatur Punctum, cuius forma est haec.	When there is pain in the ear from cold, and it is cured with solutions, and the rest of the treatment which we have mentioned in the treatise, and the pain does not cease, then apply the Cauterium: and that is called the Punctum, which has this shape.</start_of_turn
Deinde puncta cum eo post eius ignitionem in circumitu auris totius, sicut reuoluitur: aut in circumitu utriusque, si simul dolor est in utrisque.	Then touch the Punctum with it after its ignition around the whole ear, as it is turned: or around both, if there is pain in both.</start_of_turn
Et elonga te cum Cauterio a radice auris parumper, postquam signaueris loca cum encaustro: et sit cauterii quantitas decem punctorum in omni aure, et quasi illa.	And prolong thee with the Cauterium from the root of the ear downwards, after you have marked the place with the Cautery: and let the quantity of the Cauterium be ten points in every ear, and as much as that.
Deinde cura loca, donec sanentur.	And take care of the place until it heals
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Tortura.	In this manner the Cautery is to be used in the Torment
Caput VII.	Chapter VII
Tortura quae curatur cum cauterizatione, non est nisi ex speciebus, quae accidunt ex phlegmate, secundum quod diximus in diuisionibus aegritudinum.	The Torment which is cured by Cautery is not except for those kinds which arise from phlegmas, as we have said in the discourse on the causes of diseases.
Et deuita cauterizationem speciei, quae accidit ex exiccatione, et spasmo nerui.	And you must apply the Cautery to the kind which arises from constriction and nervous spasm
Quando curas hanc speciem torturae cum hyeris, et caputpurgiis, et gargarismis, et non confert curatio tua, tunc oportet ut cauterizes infirmum tribus Cauteriis: uno apud radicem auris, et secundo parum inferius a timpore suo, et tertio apud coniunctionem duorum labiorum.	When you have cured this kind of torment with urine and fumigations, and vomiting, and hiccups, and the cure does not suffice, then you must burn the patient three times with the Cautery: once at the root of the ear, and once a little lower from the temple, and once at the junction of the two lips.
Et pone Cauterium tuum ex contrario partis infirmae.	And place your Cautery on the side opposite the diseased part
Quoniam mollificatio non accidit, nisi in parte quae apparet sana.	For the softening does not take place except in the part which appears healthy.
Et forma cauterizationis est, ut cauterizes ipsum Cauterio in directo extremitatis auris superioris sub cornu capitis parum: et alio in timpore: cuius longitudo sit secundum longitudinem pollicis.	And the form of the Cautery is that you burn the Cautery itself with the outer edge of the upper ear under the earlobe a little: and the other in the temple. And the length of the burn should be as long as the length of the thumb
Et depone manum tuam cum cauterio, donec comburatur quantitas medietatis spissitudinis cutis.	And hold your hand with the Cautery until the quantity of the middle third of the thickness of the skin has been consumed
Et haec est forma Cauterii, et est species ex cultellari, cuius forma praemissa est: uerumtamen non est subtilior ea parum, sicut uides: et oportet ut sit cultellus in eo superfluae grossitudinis parum.	And this is the form of the Cautery, and it is like a knife whose form is like this: indeed it is not finer than that of a needle: and you must make the knife to be of such a size as that it is not too thick
Deinde cura loca, cum eo quod praecessit: donec sanetur.	Then care for the place where it preceded: until it is healed.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Apoplexia antiqua.	Thus care for the place where it preceded: until it is healed.
Caput VIII.	Chapter VIII.</start_of_turn>
QUando antiquatur Apoplexia, et curas eam cum eo quod diximus, et non confert medicatio tua, et infirmus non habet febrem, tunc cauteriza eum quatuor cauteriis super omne cornu capitis sui, et cauterio in medio capitis, sicut diximus, et cauterio in occipitio capitis, secundum quod praecessit: et modus cauterii sit secundum quod praecessit.	When the old [blood clot] is decayed, and you have cared for it as we said, and the medicine does not suffice, and the patient does not have a fever, then burn it four times over the horns of the head, and burn in the middle of the head, as we said, and burn in the nape of the neck, as it preceded: and the manner of burning should be as it preceded.</start_of_turn>
Etiam cauterizatur cum Cauterio super os stomachi: et est magis ultimum.	It is also burned with a burn over the bones of the stomach: and this is the last resort.</start_of_turn
Deinde curetur, cum eo quod praecessit.	Then care for the place where it preceded: until it is healed.</start_of_turn>
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Obliuione.	Thus care for the place where it preceded: until it is healed.</start_of_turn
Caput IX.	Chapter IX.</start_of_turn
Oportet ut in potu dentur in primis infirmo hyerae magnae, et pillulae mundificantes cerebrum.	It is necessary that in the first instance in the sick person be given large barley seeds and mild pills that soften the brain.</start_of_turn
Deinde rade caput infirmi totum, et pone super occipitium eius emplastrum de synapi descriptum in tractatu emplastrorum: et pone ipsum aliquotiens.	Then bind the head of the patient completely, and put over his neck a patch of wool described in the treatise on patches: and put some of it on.</start_of_turn
Ipsum namque est modus Cauterii: et fac illud secundum ordinem eundem, quem dixi illic.	This is the manner of burning: and do this as I said there.</start_of_turn
Si ergo sanatur per illud, bonum est.	If therefore it is healed by this, it is good.</start_of_turn
Si non: tunc fac ei cauteria tria in posteriori parte capitis sui, quae sint descendentia a superiori parte capitis usque ad inferiorem partem oculi: et pone inter omne cauterium grossitudinem digiti.	If not: then make for him three incisions at the back of his head, which are descending from the upper part of the head down to the lower part of the eye: and put between every burn the width of a finger.</start_of_turn
Deinde cura Cauterium, cum eo quod praecessit.	Then care for the Cauterium, when that has gone before.
Si autem uis additionem, et infirmus est tolerans illud: tunc fac ei Cauterium in medio.	Then care for the Cauterium, when that has gone before.
Quod si uis additionem: tunc cauteriza ipsum super duo cornua.	Then care for the Cauterium, when that has gone before. If however you wish to make an addition, and the patient is tolerant of that: then make for him the Cauterium in the middle.
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur: sitque Cauterium oliuare secundum formam, quae praemissa est.	Then care for itself, until it is healed: and let the Cauterium rest according to its form, as it is before.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Paralisi, et mollificatione.	In the case of palsy and softening, care must be taken in such a way that the Cauterium does not enter the bone or the marrow.
Caput X.	Chapter X.</start_of_turn>
Oportet ut procedas in mundificatione capitis cum hyeeris, et cum eo quod diximus.	It is necessary to proceed in the treatment of the head with sponges, and with that which we have mentioned.</start_of_turn>
Deinde rade caput infirmi: postea cauteriza ipsum cauterio in medio capitis, et cauterio super omne cornu capitis, et cauterio super posterius ipsius, et tribus super spondiles colli.	Then shave the head of the patient: afterwards cauterize the middle of the head, and the cauterize over every horn of the head, and over the back of the head, and three times over the joints of the neck.</start_of_turn
Si autem indiges in aegritudine mollificatione corporis pluribus illis, et infirmus est tolerans, et aegritudo est fortis: tunc cauteriza ipsum quatuor cauteriis super spondiles dorsi, et ultima cum cauterio, donec comburatur ex cute plurimum eius, et eleua manum tuam.	If however he is unwilling in bodily pain for the mollification of the body by these many: and the patient is tolerant, and the pain is great: then make four cauterizations over the joints of the back, and the last one with the cauterium, until the greatest part of it is consumed by the fire, and lift your hand.</start_of_turn
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur: et sic cauterium Oliuare.	Then care for itself, until it is healed: and let the Cauterium rest.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Epilepsia.	In the case of epilepsy, care must be taken in such a way that the Cauterium does not enter the bone or the marrow
Caput XI.	Chapter XI.</start_of_turn
Non Cauterizatur epilepticus, nisi ille cuius epilepsia est ex phlegmate.	The epileptic patient is not cauterized, except for that of whom the epilepsy is from phlegmas.</start_of_turn
Oportet ergo ut mundifices cerebrum eius in primis cum hyeris, et cum reliqua curatione quam diximus in diuisione: quando infirmus est magnus, aut est tolerans in accaeptione medicinarum.	It is necessary therefore that the physician should first of all temper the brain of the patient, and afterwards with the remaining treatment which we mentioned in the preceding discourse: when the patient is great, or when he is tolerant of the reception of medical treatment.
Si autem est puer, qui non tolerat medicinas, tunc administratur gargarisma, et masticationes mundificantes cerebrum, ante illud diebus multis cum bonificatione ciborum.	If, however, the patient is young and does not tolerate medical treatment, then gargling and chewing are administered to temper the brain, before many days with the improvement of the food.</start_of_turn>
Deinde rade caput eius, postea cauteriza ipsum Cauterio uno in medio capitis, secundum quod praecessit in modo: et cauterio alio in occipitio eius, et super omne cornu capitis sui cauterio.	Then the head of him is to be treated, afterwards the cauterization of the same in the middle of the head, according as has been said before in this manner: and a cauterization of the other in the nape of the neck, and over all the horns of his head a cauterization is to be made.</start_of_turn>
Quod si infirmus fuerit fortis, et fuerit tolerans, tunc cauteriza ipsum cauteriis, quae dixi in habente paralisim, et mollificationem corporis super spondiles colli, et spondiles dorsi: et sit Cauterium oliuare secundum modum qui praecessit.	And if the patient be strong and be tolerant, then a cauterization is to be made of the cauteries which were said of in the case of paralysis, and softening of the body above the collarbone and the vertebrae of the back: and the cauterization is to be made of olive oil according to the manner which has been said.</start_of_turn>
Si autem infirmus est puer, tunc pone cauterium subtile, secundum hunc modum.	If the patient is young, then let a subtle cauterization be made according to this manner.</start_of_turn
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Melancholia.	(The provided text does not include the subsequent sentence, so the translation of the paragraph is incomplete.)</start_of_turn>
Caput XII.	(The provided text does not include the remaining chapters or sections, so the translation of the book is incomplete.)</start_of_turn
Quando caussa melancholiae sunt humiditates corruptae, et phlegma grossum, tunc cauteriza ipsum Cauteriis, quae diximus in habente paralisim.	When the cause of melancholy is corrupted humors and thick phlegm, then a cauterization of the cauteries which were said of in the case of paralysis is to be made.</start_of_turn
Et si caussa melancholiae est superfluitas decliuis ad melancholiam, et est corpus infirmi humectum, tunc da ei in potu quod mundificet cerebrum eius, secundum quod praecessit in diuisione: deinde rade caput infirmi, et fac postea tortellam decenter factam ex lino, sicut circulum.	And if the cause of melancholy is an excess of slippery humors that incline to melancholy, and the body of the patient is wet, then give him to drink that which will temper his brain, according as was said in the preceding discourse: then temper the head of the patient, and make afterwards a swelling formed of linen, like a circle.</start_of_turn
Deinde pone ipsam in medio capitis: et infirmus sedens quadratus teneatur ab omni parte.	Then place it in the middle of the head: and the sitting patient is held fast from all sides.
Deinde praesenta linimentum.	Then present the unguents.
Et est dignius ex butyro ouium antiquo.	And it is better from old butter or oil.
Et calefac ipsum super ignem calefactione temperata mensura, quam toleret digitus, quando intromittitur in ipsum.	And warm it over a tempered fire, as the finger can tolerate when it is introduced into it
Deinde euacua ipsum in medio capitis eius in circulo, et dimitte ipsum donec infrigidetur.	Then evacuate it in the middle of his head in a circle, and hold it until it is cold.
Fac illud infirmo omni hebdomada semel, cum reliquo regimine eius bono, donec sanetur.	Do this to the patient every week once, with the rest of his regimen being good, until he is healed
Aut si uis, cauteriza ipsum faciendo puncta parua plurimum eius, praeter quod teneas manum cum cauterio: imo sit odorando.	Or if you wish, cauterize it by making small punctures many of them, except that you hold the hand with the cautery: for it smells
Haec enim species cauterii humectat cerebrum cum qualitate.	For these are the qualities of wet cautery.
Deinde pone super ipsum cotum imbibitum in butyro, aut adipe gallinae.	Then place over it a soaked cushion in butter, or fat from a hen
¶ De modo cauterizandi in aqua descendente ad oculum.	In descending water concerning the eye
Caput XIII.	Chapter XIII
Quando declaratur tibi principium aquae in oculo per signa, quae dixi in diuisione, tunc incipe et pota infirmum, cum eo quod mundificet caput eius.	When the water is declared in the eye by the signals which I mentioned in the preceding discourse, then begin and pour the water over the patient, with the hand which will temper the head of the patient.
Et custodi ipsum ab omnibus humiditatibus, et fac eum sedere in balneo, in ieiunio diebus aliquot.	And keep it away from all humilities, and make him sit in a bath, for a few days.
Deinde praecipe ei, ut radat caput suum, et cauteriza ipsum in medio capitis sui.	Then command him to raise his head, and cauterize it in the middle of his head
Deinde cauteriza ipsum super duo timpora duobus cauteriis, si est incaeptio descensus aquae in duobus oculis simul: aut ex latere uno, si est incaeptio aquae in oculo uno: et abscinde cum cauterio omnes uenas et arterias quae sunt sub cute: et sint cauteria in ea longa in latitudine timporum: et caue a fluxu sanguinis.	Then cauterize it over two times with two cautery instruments, if there is an incipient evacuation of water from both eyes simultaneously: or from one side only, if there is an incipient evacuation of water from one eye only: and cut away with the cautery all veins and arteries which are under the skin: and let there be cautery marks in them which are long in the width of the time: and burn from the flow of blood.
Quod si uides aliquid ex eo, tunc abscinde eum statim cum quacumque medicina est possibile: et ego ueniam cum sapientia, quae est in extractione arteriarum, et abscisione earum, et cautela a fluxu sanguinis.	If you have applied something from it, then immediately cut it away with whatever medicine is available: and I will come with wisdom, which is in the extraction of arteries, and the cutting away of them, and precautions against the flow of blood.
Et quandoque cauterizatur in ceruice, sub duobus ossibus, duobus cauteriis ultime productis.	And when cauterizing is performed in the rectum, under two bones, two cauteries must be made at the last.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Lachrymis antiquis.	Concerning the cauterization of the ancient lacrimal glands...
Caput XIIII.	Chapter XIIIII.
Quando lachrymae oculorum sunt antiquae, assiduae: et sunt super uenas, et arterias quae sunt in manifesto capitis exterius, uerificatur quod illud est ex superfluitatibus frigidis, phlegmaticis: tunc cauteriza cauterio eodem quod narraui in incaeptione aquae descendentis, cauterio in medio capitis, et duobus cauteriis super duo timpora, et duobus cauteriis in ceruice sub duobus ossibus.	When the tears of the eyes are ancient, sluggish: and are above the nails, and the arteries which are in the outer part of the head, it is verified that this is from superabundance of cold, phlegmatic humors: then cauterize with the same cautery which I mentioned in the commencement of the descending water, the cautery in the middle of the head, and two cauteries above two temporal regions, and two cauteries in the rectum under two bones
Et si indiges additione, tunc cauteriza ipsum in omni latere caute oculi, super extremitatem supercilii cum cauterio paruo.	And if digestion is not sufficient, then cauterize itself throughout the side of the eye, over the outer edge of the eyebrow with a small cautery
¶ De modo cauterizandi in foetore Nasi.	Concerning the cauterization of the foeto of the nose...
Caput XV.	Chapter XV
Quando tu medicaris illud, cum eo quod diximus in diuisione, et non confert medicatio: tunc propera, et da in potu infirmocochias tribus noctibus: deinde rade caput eius, et cauteriza ipsum cauterio medio, cum cauterio oliuari.	When you are treating this, with what we have mentioned in the treatise, and the medicine does not suffice: then prepare, and give in the patient's drink three times a night: then shave his head, and cauterize it with the middle cautery, with the olive cautery.
Deinde cauteriza ipsum cum cauterio clauili duobus cauteriis, super duo supercilia sub capillis parum.	Then cauterize it with the claw cautery with two cauteries, over two superciliums under the hair slightly
Et custodite ab arteria, ne incidas eam.	And take care of the artery, so that you do not cut it
Et haec est forma cauterii Clauilis.	This is the form of the cautery of Claudius.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in mollificatione Palpebrae.	This is the method of cauterization in the mollification of the Palpebrae.
Caput XVI.	Chapter XVI.</start_of_turn>
Quando mollificatur Palpebra oculi ab aegritudine, aut humiditate: tunc cauteriza Palpebram cauterio uno, cum hoc cauterio lunari.	When the Palpebra of the eye is softened by ulceration or moisture: then cauterize the Palpebra with one cautery, like a lunar cautery.</start_of_turn
Et si uis, cauteriza ipsum supra duo supercilia parum duobus cauteriis in omni parte: et elongentur a duobus timporibus: et sit longitudo omnis cauterii, secundum longitudines supercilii: et non ultimes manum tuam cum cauterio, imo secundum quantitatem quod aduritur tertia palpebrae.	And if you wish, cauterize it above the two supercilii by a little of two cauteries in every part: and extend it from two times: and the length of every cautery should be according to the length of the supercilium: and do not bring your hand close to the cautery, but rather according to the quantity of what is to be cauterized of the third of the Palpebrae.</start_of_turn>
Et haec est forma cauterii secundum hunc modum cauterii lunaris.	And this is the form of the cautery according to this method of lunar cautery.</start_of_turn
¶ De modo cauterizandi Palpebram cum pili inuersantur pungentes oculum.	Method of cauterization of the Palpebra with the nails of the teeth that are turned inwards towards the eye.</start_of_turn
Caput XVII.	Chapter XVII.</start_of_turn
Cauterium in eo est secundum duos modos: aut cauterium cum igne: aut cauterium cum medicina comburente.	There are two methods of cautery: either with fire or with burning medicine.</start_of_turn
In cauterio autem cum igne, praecipe infirmo ante illud, ut dimittat pilos suos, si est ex illis qui mundant eos, donec prolongentur et aequentur.	And in the cautery with fire, command the patient to expel his hair before this, if there are any that move on it, until they are prolonged and equal.</start_of_turn
Si autem pungunt eum apud ortum suum: tunc constringe oculos eius cum uitta, ut non moueantur, donec nascantur.	If however they are pierced at the root of their hair: then hold the eyes shut with a piece of cloth, so that they do not move, until they heal.</start_of_turn
Cum ergo nascuntur et aequantur, tunc pone caput infirmi in sinu tuo: deinde signa super Palpebram oculorum eius cum encaustro, signo quod sit secundum figuram folii myrti: et sit principium signi prope pilos.	When they have healed and are equal, then place the head of the patient on your lap: then mark over the Palpebra of the eye with charcoal, in the shape of the leaf of the Myrtle: and let the beginning of the mark be close to the hair.</start_of_turn
Deinde pone cotum imbibitum in albumine oui: aut in mucilagine psilii super oculum.	Then place the soaked cushion in albumin or: on the mucous membrane of the eyelashes above the eye.
Deinde igni cauterium, cuius forma est haec.	Then apply the cautery, which is shaped like this
Deinde cauteriza super figuram, quam signasti paulatim in uicibus multis, donec comburatur superficies cutis, quae est sicut figura folii myrti, totam apparentem proprie.	Then cauterize over the shape, as you have indicated gradually in many wounds, until the surface of the skin, which is like the shape of a myrtle leaf, turns completely white
Et signum sanitatis operis tui est: ut si uideas Palpebram oculi iam contrahi, et pilos eleuari apud puncturam oculi.	And the sign of the success of your work is: when the eyelashes of the eye recoil from the point of the wound and the hair is raised at the point of the wound.
Eleua ergo manum tuam tunc: et dimitte ipsum tribus diebus.	Raise your hand then: and let go of him in three days.
Deinde pone super ipsum Cotum cum butyro, donec eradicetur eschara.	Then place upon it a cushion with butter, until the pus is eradicated
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguento, donec sanetur.	Then care for it with unguent until it is healed
Quod si redeat aliquod ex pilis post horam, et mollificetur palpebra: tunc itera Cauterium super illum locum, sicut fecisti in primis.	And if some hair should remain after an hour, and the eyelashes are softened: then apply the cautery once more to the same place as before
Si autem pili sunt in inferiori: tunc cauteriza ipsam, donec eleuetur ad locum suum naturalem: et aequetur ut non pungant pili oculum.	But if the hair is in the lower part: then cauterize it there, until they rise to their natural place: and make sure that they do not puncture the eye
¶ De modo cauterizandi cum medicina comburente in eodem casu.	In the same way as with the burning cautery, when using cautery with medicinal herbs.
Caput XVIII.	Chapter XVIII
Est ut praecipias infirmo, ut dimittat pilos, donec prolongentur et aequentur.	It is necessary for the patient to pluck out the hair, until they grow long and even
Fac ex charta de panno formam folii myrti.	Make from a piece of linen a shape like a myrtle leaf.
Deinde accipe ex sapone cognito, et ex calce non imbibita ex unoquoque pondus uncia I aut quasi illud: deinde tere ea simul contritione bona, et fac illud cum festinatione, ut non infrigidetur.	Then take from soap the size of a bean, and from the heel of your hand take an inch or almost that: then mix these together with a little warmth, and do this with a gentle touch, so as not to freeze it
Deinde ex pande ex eo super chartam quam fecisti sicut formam folii myrti, et pone ipsum super palpebram oculi unius, aut duorum.	Then from the palm of your hand over the chart which you have made like the shape of a myrtle leaf, and place it over the pupil of one eye, or two eyes.
Et pone sub oculo cotum imbibitum in albumine oui: et caput infirmi sit in sinu tuo.	And place under the eye a sponge soaked in albumin: and the head of the patient is in your lap.</start_of_turn>
Et pone digitum tuum indicem super medicinam, et preme ipsum parumper.	And place your finger on the sign of the physician, and press it lightly.</start_of_turn>
Et tu moueas ipsum quotiens sentit infirmus mordicationem medicinae: quoniam inuenit eius mordicatio sicut ignis.	And you will move it whenever the patient feels the bite of the medicine: for its bite is like fire.</start_of_turn>
Dum ergo perseuerat hoc quod ipse inuenit mordicatio, tunc dimitte medicinam, et moue ipsam cum digito tuo.	While you have done this and found the bite, then remove the medicine and move it with your finger.</start_of_turn
Cum ergo quiescit mordicatio, tunc remoue medicinam, et ablue oculum cum aqua.	When the bite has subsided, then remove the medicine and wash the eye with water.</start_of_turn
Et considera tunc, si uides palpebram eleuari, sicut eleuatur apud contractionem cum igne, aut cum incisione, est bene: et si non, tunc itera super ipsam ex medicina super locum, in quo non imprimit medicina, et non denigrat, donec aequetur operatio tua, et contrahatur oculus.	Consider then, if the pupil is raised, like that which is raised with contraction with fire, or with incision, it is well: and if not, then repeat the medicine over the place where the medicine does not stick, and does not cause harm, until your operation is complete and the eye is contracted.</start_of_turn>
Deinde pone super ipsum Cotum cum butyro, donec eradicetur cutis adustionis.	Then place upon it a sponge with butter, until the edge of the wound is eradicated.</start_of_turn
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguento diaphinicon, aut alio, donec sanetur.	Then care for it with ointment of diaphanicon, or something else, until it is healed.</start_of_turn>
Et necesse est tibi apud operationem, ut custodias ultima custodia, ne in oculum cadat aliquid ex medicina.	And it is necessary for you during the operation to take care that nothing of the medicine falls into the eye.</start_of_turn
Quod si mollificatur palpebra post dies, et pugnat ex capillis aliquid in oculo, tunc itera medicinam super illum locum, qui mollificatur ex palpebra proprie, sicut fecisti in primis.	For if the pupil becomes softened after a few days, and there is something of hair in the eye, then repeat the medicine over the place where the pupil is softened by the eye itself, as you did at the beginning.</start_of_turn
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then care for yourself until you are healed.
Et haec est forma folii myrti.	This is the manner of the myrtle leaf.
Et scias, quod oculi hominum diuersificantur in magnitudine, et paruitate.	Know that the eyes of men differ in size and shape
Ergo secundum illud sit consideratio tua: et non occultatur uia rectitudinis illi, cui est studium de hac arte.	Therefore consider this: and do not conceal the uprightness of this art which is the study of this craft
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Fistula lachrymali.	Concerning the cauterization of the fistula of the tear duct.
Caput XIX.	Chapter XIX
Quando curas Fistulam, cum eo quod diximus in diuisionibus aegritudinum, et non confert curatio tua: tunc, oportet ut cauterizes ipsam secundum hunc modum.	When you have treated the fistula, when it is not cured by your treatment: then it is necessary to cauterize it according to this method
Praecipe infirmo, ut ponat caput suum in sinu tuo, et teneat caput eius minister inter manus suas taliter, ut non moueatur, neque agitetur cum capite suo.	Command the patient to place his head in your lap and hold his head between your hands like this, so that it does not move or shake with his head
Deinde pone Cotum infusum in albugine oui, aut in mucilagine psilii super oculum eius: deinde igni Cauterium, cuius forma est haec.	Then place the soaked sponge in the white of the eye, or on the mucous membrane of the eyelashes above his eye: then ignite the Cauterium, which is in this shape.
Sit concauum, sicut forma cannae pennae uulturis ab extremitate una, cum qua fit Cauterium: et si uis sit penetrans usque ad extremitatem aliam, et si uis sit sursum sic tenta.	Hold it concave, like the shape of a feather quill at one end, as it is with the Cauterium: and if you wish it to penetrate until the other end, and if you wish it to be above, do so with the attempt.
Verumtamen hoc concauum est melius ad opus tuum.	It is better to hold it concave for your work
Deinde exprime fistulam, si est aperta, et extrahe ex ea saniem, et exicca ipsam: et si non est aperta, tunc aperi eam, et extrahe pus eius.	Then express the fistula, if it is open, and extract from it the pus, and dry it up: and if it is not open, then open it up, and extract the pus from it
Deinde pone tunc super eam Cauterium, quod fit ignitum ualde.	Then place over the fistula the Cauterium which is ignited lukewarmly
Et tene cum eo manum tuam parumper apud Cauterium ab oculo, ad partem nasi, ut non erret manus tua, aut inquietetur infirmus: et ponas Cauterium in adipe oculi, et corrumpas ipsum.	And hold your hand close to the Cauterium from the eye towards the nose, so that your hand does not move or shake: and place the Cauterium on the fat of the eye, and burn it through
Si ergo peruenis in principio Cauterii tui usque ad os, erit bene.	If therefore you proceed with the Cauterization from the beginning until the bone, it will be well.
Et si non: tunc itera Cauterium semel, aut bis, si indiges illo: et dimitte illud tribus diebus.	If not: then repeat the Cauterization once or twice, if you tolerate it: and discharge it in three days.
Deinde pone Cotum cum butyro, et cura ipsum cum unguento exiccatiuo, donec sanetur.	Then place a compress with butter, and care for it with an unguent dressing, until it heals.
Quod si praeterierint ei quadraginta dies, et non sanatur: tunc pone super ipsum medicinam acutam corrosiuam, donec detegatur os: et rade ipsum secundum quod uenit in capitulo suo.	If for forty days they do not heal: then place upon it a sharp corrosive medicine, until the bone is exposed: and then remove it according to what is written in its chapter
Et est modus alius Cauterii fistulae, quem quidam primi dixerunt.	And there is another method of Cauterization of fistulas, which some of the former have said.
Intende ad locum fistulae, et finde ipsum: deinde pone in ipsam fissuram camahan subtile, id est, Cannulam subtilem, cuius forma haec est.	Direct it to the place of the fistula, and find it: then place in the fistula a thin needle, that is, a needle with a fine point, of which the shape is this
Et funde in ipsum quantitatem drachmae ex plumbo liquefacto, et tene manum tuam cum Canna retentione bona, et non moueatur infirmus omnino, ut non currat, uel perueniat plumbum liquefactum ad oculum eius.	And mix in it the quantity of lead from a penny, and hold your hand with the needle firmly in place, and do not move the patient at all, so that it does not run, or that the liquefied lead should not reach his eye
Et oportet ut ponas super oculum infirmi cotum infusum in albumine oui, aut in aqua.	And it is necessary that you place upon the eye of the patient a compress soaked in albumin or in water.
Plumbum enim comburit locum fistulae, et sanat ipsam sanatione mirabili.	Lead therefore burns the place of the fistula, and heals it with a miraculous healing
Quod si sanatur fistula, cum eo quod diximus ex Cauterio, et curatione, est bonum.	When the fistula is healed, with what we have said of the Cauterization and the treatment, it is good
Et si non, tunc necesse est administrare foramen nasi, et reducere fistulam ad cursum nasi, secundum quod ueniet in loco suo sibi proprio.	And if not, then it is necessary to administer a nose-opening passage, and reduce the fistula to the course of the nose, according to what is written in its own place
¶ De modo cauterizandi in fissuris Labiorum.	¶ On the method of cauterizing of the lip-fissures.
Caput XX.	Chapter XX.
Multotiens accidunt in Labio fissurae, quae nominantur Pili, et praecipue in labiis puerorum.	Many wounds occur in the lip split, which are called Pili, and especially in the lips of children.
Cum ergo tu curas has fissuras, cum eo quod diximus in diuisione aegritudinum, et non confert curatio, tunc igni cauterium paruum cultellare, secundum hanc formam.	When you treat these splits, when you have done what we said in the instruction on ailments, and the cure has not been effected, then burn a small cautery with this shape
Et sit concauitas eius secundum subtilitatem cultelli.	And let the curvature of it be according to the thickness of the knife.
Deinde pone ipsum ignitum festinanter in ipsis fissuris, donec perueniat cauterium ad profundum fissurarum.	Then place the flame quickly in these splits, until the cautery reaches the depth of the split.
Deinde cura ipsum cum caeroto, donec sanetur.	Then care for it with the cautery until it is healed
¶ De modo cauterizandi in fistula Oris.	In the same way, cauterize in the fistula of the mouth.
Caput XXI.	Chapter XXI.
Quando accidit apostema in radice gingiuae, aut in palato, aut in radicibus dentium: deinde facit pus, et rumpitur: postea antiquatur, et currit pus, et fit fistula: deinde curas ipsam, et non confert in ea curatio, tunc oportet ut ignias cauterium secundum quantitatem, quod capiat in fistula.	When swelling occurs at the root of the tooth, or in the palate, or in the roots of the teeth: then pus forms, and it ruptures: afterwards it is treated, pus runs, and a fistula is formed: then one must burn the cautery in this quantity, as much as is taken up in the fistula
Deinde intromitte ipsum ignitum in foramine fistulae, et tene manum tuam, donec perueniat ferrum ignitum ad profundum eius, et ultimum eius: fac illud semel, aut duabus uicibus.	Then insert the flame into the cavity of the fistula, and hold your hand, until the iron is consumed by the depth of it, and its extremity: do this once, or twice at most.
Deinde cura ipsum post illud, cum eo quod diximus de curatione usquequo curetur.	Then care for it afterwards, as we said concerning the cure until it is healed.
Si ergo abscinditur sanies, et sanatur, erit bonum.	If it is cut away when healthy, and healed, it is good.
Et si non, tunc necesse est detegere locum, et auferre os corrupum secundum quod ueniet in capite suo.	And if not, then it is necessary to remove the corrupted bone according to what comes to pass in its head
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Gingiuis, et Dentibus mollificatis.	On the method of cauterizing in the Gingiues, and softening of the Dentibus.
Caput XXII.	Regarding the method of cauterizing in the Gingiues, and softening of the Dentibus.
Quando mollificatur gingiua propter humiditates, et mouentur dentes, et curas eam cum medicinis, et non confert: tunc pone caput infirmi in sinu tuo.	When softened by moisture, the Gingiues and teeth move, and the physician must take care with them as with colleagues, and must not cause injury: then place the patient's head in your lap
Deinde igni cauterium, cuius forma ueniet post haec, ita ut ponas Cannulam super dentem: et intromitte in ea Cauterium ignitum festinanter: et tene manum tuam parumper, donec sentiat infirmus calorem ignis iam peruenisse ad radicem dentis.	Then apply the cautery, whose form will appear afterwards, so that you place the Cautery over the tooth: and introduce the flame into it quickly: and hold your hand near the patient, until the patient feels the heat of the flame has reached the root of the tooth.
Et eleua manum tuam: deinde itera Cauterium aliquotiens, secundum quod uis.	And lift your hand away: then repeat the Cautery a few times, as you wish.
Deinde impleat infirmus os suum aqua salis, et teneat ipsam hora una: et exspuat ipsam.	Then let the patient rinse their mouth with salt water, and keep it for an hour: and then expel it.
Dens enim motus firmatur, et gingiua mollificata stringitur, et siccatur humiditas corrupta.	The tooth will then be firm, and the Gingiues softened, and the corrupt moisture will dry up
¶ De modo cauterizandi in dolore Dentium.	Regarding the method of cauterizing in toothache.
Caput XXIII.	When a toothache is severe, and the tooth is sensitive to cold, heat, or biting, and the pain persists, or is not relieved by other means, then take hold of the patient's head and open their mouth widely.
Quando dolor dentis est propter frigiditatem, aut in ipso est frigus, aut uermis, et non confert curatio cum medicinis: tunc Cauterium in ipso est secundum duos modos: aut Cauterium cum butyro: aut cauterium cum igne.	When the toothache is caused by cold, or by heat, or biting, and the pain does not subside with treatment by physicians: then apply the Cautery in two ways: either with butter or with fire
Cauterium autem eius cum butyro est, ut accipias butyrum uaccinum, et bullias ipsum in cochleari ferreo, aut in uenera.	The butter must be taken from cows which have eaten well, and the Cautery must be placed on the tooth in a pan or crucible made of iron or stone
Deinde accipe cotum, et inuolue ipsum super extremitatem tentae.	Then take hold of the tooth, and place the Cautery over the tip of the tooth
Deinde submerge ipsum in butyro bullito: et pone ipsum super dentem dolorosum festinanter, et tene ipsum donec infrigidet: deinde itera ipsum aliquotiens, donec perueniat uirtus ignis ad radicem dentis.	Then immerse the affected part in boiling butter: and place the part above the aching tooth quickly, and hold it there until it cools: then repeat the procedure several times until the heat of the fire reaches the root of the tooth.
Et si uis, submerge lanam, aut cotum in butyro frigido, et pone ipsum super dentem dolentem: et pone super ipsum ferrum ignitum, donec perueniat ignis ad profundum concauitatis dentis.	Or if desired, immerse wool or cotton in cold butter, and place it above the aching tooth: and place upon it a burning iron until the fire reaches the depth of the cavity of the tooth.
Cauterizatio autem eius cum igne est, ut intendas ad cannulam aeris, aut cannulam ferri.	The cauterization of it with fire is to be done, as in the case of a wound, so as to bring about the escape of air or iron.
Et sit in corpore eius quiddam grossitudinis, ut non perueniat acuitas ignis ad os infirmi.	And let there be some bulk in its body, so that the fire may not penetrate too deeply into the bone of the infirm person.
Deinde igni Cauterium, cuius forma ueniet: et pone ipsum super illum dentem: et tene manum tuam, donec infrigidetur Cauterium.	Then let the Cauterium take its natural shape: and place it above the tooth: and hold your hand until the Cauterium cools down.
Fac illud aliquotiens, nam dolor remouebitur, aut in illo eodem die, aut die alio.	Repeat this several times, for the pain will disappear, or on the same day, or on another day
Et oportet in impressione illius Cauterii, ut impleat infirmus os suum buyro bono, et teneat ipsum hora una: deinde exspuat ipsum.	And it is necessary to press down upon the Cauterium so that the infirm person may suck his own butter from his bone, and keep it for an hour: then remove it.
Et haec est forma Cauterii.	This is the form of the Cauterium.
Cauteriza cum quacumque extremitate uis secundum quod est possibile: et haec est forma Cannulae.	Cauterize with whatever extremity you wish, according to what is possible: and this is the form of the Canula.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Strophulis.	In this way the cauterization is to be done in the teeth.
Caput XXIIII.	Chapter XXIII.
Quando Strophulae sunt a phlegmate, et ab humiditatibus frigidis, et non sunt obedientes digestioni per mecicinas, et uis digestionem earum uelociter: tunc igni Cauterium concauum, cuius forma est haec.	When the teeth are affected by phlegmas and by cold humors, and do not obey digestion by medicines, and you wish to hasten their digestion: then cauterize the cavity, which is of this shape
Habens duas extremitates apertas, ut egrediatur fumus apud Cauterium ab extremitate altera: et pone ipsum ignitum super ipsum apostema semel, et secundo, si indiges illo, donec perueniat ad profundum apostematis.	Having two open extremities, like smoke emerging from Cauterium from the other limb: place the flame upon the latter and, if it does not suffice, continue until it reaches the depth of the cavity.
Quod si apostema est paruum: tunc pone Cauterium secundum quantitatem apostematis.	If the cavity is small: then place Cauterium according to the size of the cavity.</start_of_turn>
