Deinde dimitte ipsum tribus diebus, et pone super ipsum cotum infusum in butyro, donec remoueatur quod combussit ignis.	Then remove the flame after three days, and place upon it a pad soaked in butter, until the burn has subsided.</start_of_turn>
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguento dentis, donec sanetur forma cannulae.	Then care for it with tooth unguent until the burn is healed.</start_of_turn
¶ De modo cauterizandi in raucedine uocis, et constrictione anhelitus.	In the case of a wound of the rachis or constriction of the airway.</start_of_turn
Caput XXV.	Chapter XXV.</start_of_turn>
Quando uincunt humiditates super cannale pulmonis, et praecipue quando illud est cum frigiditate complexionis, tunc oportet ut euacuetur infirmus in primis cum medicinis solutiuis.	When the wind is moist upon the canal of the lungs, and especially when it is with the coldness of complexion, then it is necessary to expel the patient immediately with the physicians who are skilled in solution.</start_of_turn
Deinde cauteriza ipsum in nocrati apud radicem gutturis in loce depresso: et caue, ne peruenias cum Cauterio ad guttur, neque in cute, nisi quiddam eius.	Then burn in the night at the root of the guttur in a depressed place: and be careful, lest you should penetrate the gut with Cauterium, or in the skin, except for some of its substance.</start_of_turn
Deinde cauteriza ipsum cauterio alio apud iuncturam colli in ultimo spondili eius ultimando: et sit Cauterium clauile secundum modum, qui praecessit.	Then burn again with another Cauterium at the junction of the collar in the last rib: and let the Cauterium be closed according to the mode which went before.</start_of_turn
Deinde cura ipsum cum eo quod praecessit, donec sanetur.	Then care for it with what has gone before until it is healed.</start_of_turn
¶ De modo cauterizandi in aegritudinibus Pulmonis, et Tussi.	In the case of carbuncles of the Lung and Cough.</start_of_turn
Caput XXVI.	Chapter XXVI.</start_of_turn
Quando Tussis et aegritudo Pulmonis sunt ab humiditatibus frigidis, et infirmus non habet febrem, neque phthisim, et aegritudo antiqua: tunc cauteriza ipsum duobus cauteriis supra furculam in locis depressis, lenibus, uacuis.	When cough and pulmonary carbuncles are from cold humilities, and the patient has neither fever nor phthisis, and old cough: then burn with two Cauteriums above the nipple in depressed places, gentle, thick, and dark.</start_of_turn
Et cauterio alio in medio pectoris inter duas mammillas: et sit cauterium cannulae secundum formam quae praecessit.	And the cautery is done with another instrument in the middle of the chest between two nipples: and let the cautery be according to the shape which preceded.
Et si uis sit cauterizatio tua punctando cum cauterio, quod nominatur Punctum, cuius forma praecessit in punctatione doloris aurium: et sint puncta ex triginta punctis usque quasi ad alia.	And if you wish the cautery to be made by puncture with the cautery, which is called Punctum, whose shape preceded in the puncture of the ear: let there be punctures from thirty punctures up to almost as many
Deinde cura ipsum cum eo quod praecessit, donec sanetur.	Then take care of that which preceded, until it is healed.
Et iam sit cauterium habens tres ramos: secundum hanc formam.	And let the cautery be carried out with three branches: according to this shape
Quare alleuiatur cum eo cauterizatio, quando tu facis cum eo uice una tria Cauteria.	For the surrounding parts are relaxed when you do this with three Cauteria at once.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Titillico, in dislocatione Humeri.	Thus the cautery is done in Titillico, in dislocation of the Humerus.
Caput XXVII.	Chapter XXVII.</start_of_turn>
Quando dislocatur caput adiutorii caussa humiditatum, et nonfigitur in hora reditus sui a dislocatione sua, donec sit illud ei consuetudo reditionis, deinde dislocatur a paruo motu, qui accidit sicut nos iam testificauimus illud, tunc oportet ut reducas dislocationem in primis.	When the head of the adductor is dislocated by the cause of humidity, and does not return to its place in the hour following its dislocation, until it has become accustomed to the resumption of its place, then it must be displaced by a slight movement, which as we have testified above, then it is necessary to reduce the dislocation immediately.</start_of_turn>
Deinde resupinetur infirmus super dorsum suum, aut super latus sanum.	Then the patient is laid down on his back, or on the sound side.</start_of_turn>
Deinde eleua cutim, quae est in interiori Titillici ad superiora cum digitis manus tuae sinistrae: et si iunctura dislocatur ad interiora.	Then lift the skin which is inside the Titillicum towards the upper parts with your left hand: and if the dislocation has gone inwards.</start_of_turn
Deinde igni Cauterium habens duo uerua.	Then take two forceps.</start_of_turn
Cuius forma est haec.	Whose shape is this.</start_of_turn
Deinde cauteriza cutim, donec penetret eam usque ad latus aliud, et ueniet figura cauterizationis cum quatuor cauteriis.	Then cauterize the skin until it penetrates to the other side, and the figure of the cautery will appear with four cauteries.</start_of_turn
Et quandoque fit cauterizatio cum cauterio habente tria uerua, quare fit figura cauterizationis tunc sex cauteriorum: et sunt uerua secundum subtilitatem tentae.	When the cautery is performed with a cautery having three hairs, the figure of the cautery then consists of six cauteries: and the hairs are stretched according to their length.
Et haec est forma cauterii habentis tria uerua.	This is the figure of the cautery which has three hairs.
Et quandoque additur super hunc modum unum, quare sunt cauteria octo.	And when one more is added in this way, there are eight cauteries in all
Deinde pone super cauterium porros contritos cum sale.	Then place upon the cautery the hairs bound together with salt.
Deinde fac adhaerere infirmum tranquillitati, ut non moueatur membrum tempore aliquo, donec confortetur.	Then make the patient steady and calm, so that the limb does not move at any time until it is comfortable
Et si dislocatio est ad superiora, et raro fit illud, tunc cauteriza ipsum super humerum cauterio clauili, aut cauteriis multis punctando.	And if displacement has occurred to the upper parts, and this rarely happens, then cauterize it upon the shoulder with the cautery of the claw, or with many punctures.
Nam iunctura firmatur, et remouetur humiditas: et sanatur infirmus.	For the joining is firm, and the moisture is evacuated: and the patient is healed.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Stomachum.	On the method of cauterizing the stomach
Caput XXVIII.	Chapter XXVIII.
Quando accidunt in Stomacho frigus et humiditates multae, donec extrahant ipsum a complexione sua, et multiplicentur catarri ad ipsum, et assiduas modos curationis, et non confert: tunc oportet ut resupinetur infirmus super dorsum suum, et extendat crura sua, et manus suas.	When in the stomach there are cold and many humilities, until you have expelled it from its composition, and multiplied the catarrh towards it, and applied various methods of treatment, and you do not confer: then it is necessary that the patient lie down on his back, extend his limbs, and move his hands
Deinde cauteriza cum tribus cauteriis, cauterio sub cochleari pectoris quantitate digiti unius cum cauterio clauili, et duobus cauteriis inferius a duobus lateribus cauterii unius, donec ueniat figura cauteriorum triangulata.	Then cauterize with three cauteries, with a cautery under the collar of the breast of the size of a single digit with the claw cautery, and two cauteries below from two sides of the single cautery, until you obtain the triangular figure of the cauteries.
Et elonga inter utraque ut non coniungantur, quando facient pus.	And lengthen between each so that they do not join, when they make pus
Et sit profunditas cauterii quantitas duarum tertiarum grossitudinis cutis.	The depth of the burn should be equal to two-thirds of the thickness of the skin.
Et sit figura cauteriorum secundum hanc formam sine additione: et si uis cauteriza cauterio magno in medio stomachi secundum hanc formam: et sit cauterium quo fit hoc cauterium unum secundum figuram circuli secundum hanc formam.	The burn should be square in shape without adding any [irregularities]: if you wish to burn in the middle of the stomach according to this shape, then the burn should be as big as this burn alone according to the circular shape of this
Et cauterizatur stomachus punctando ei qui terretur ab hoc cauterio: et est, ut signes super stomachum punctum secundum quantitatem, quam uis cum encaustro: deinde cauteriza ipsum cum cauterio puncti: deinde cura ipsum cum curatione, quae praecessit donec sanetur.	The burn is cauterized by pricking the area around it which has been scorched by the burn: and it is that the signs on the stomach should be in number according to the quantity of the burn. Then cauterize the burn itself with the burn of the puncture. Then care for the burn with care until it heals.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Epar frigidum.	In the manner of cauterizing with cold:
Caput XXIX.	So it is necessary to know how to cauterize with cold in order to preserve life and limb.
Quando accidit in Epate dolor ex frigiditate et humiditate, aut ex uentositate grossa, donec egrediatur a complexione sua naturali egressione superflua, et curatur infirmus, cum eo quod diximus, et non proficit in illo: tunc oportet ut resupinetur infirmus super ceruicem suam, et signes cum encaustro tria cauteria secundum hanc figuram, et hanc quantitatem eandem super Epar inferius ab hypocundriis, ubi peruenit cubitus hominis: et sit spacium quod est inter omne cauterium secundum grossitudinem digiti: et sit cauterium secundum longitudinem corporis rectum: et non comprimas manum tuam cum cauterio multum.	When it happens in the case of pain due to cold and humidity, or from a large wound, until it comes out naturally from its natural configuration, and the sick person is cured, as we have said, and has not progressed in this: then it is necessary to cover the sick person with his own bed and to make three burns with the cautery, according to this shape and this quantity on the lower part of the Ep, where the elbow of a man lies: and let there be space between every burn according to the width of a finger. And let the burn be according to the length of the body from the rectum: and do not press your hand too much with the burn
Et sit quantitas eius quod aduritur ex spissitudine cutis, quantitas medietatis eius non additum: et sit infirmus stans super pedes suos.	And let the quantity of the burn be such as to burn out the thickness of the skin, without adding the middle quantity: and let the sick person stand on his own feet.
Si autem non est stans, tunc sit iacens, qui iam extendit crura sua, et eleuauit brachia sua.	If he is not able to stand, then let him lie down, who has extended his legs and raised his arms
Haec est forma cauterii.	This is the form of the cautery.
Et tibi quidem possibile est, ut cauterizes ista cauteria cum cauterio cultellari, quando tecum est subtilitas et prudentia in arte.	And indeed it is possible that these cauteries are performed with the cautery of a knife, when there is skill and prudence in the art.
Et custodi te, ut non ultime procedas in cauterizatione, et aduratur spissitudo cutis totius, quare aduratur corpus totum, et perueniat ad intestina: quoniam cutis illic est subtilis, scias ergo illud.	Beware lest you go too far with the cautery, and that you burn the whole body, because the body is thereby burned through to the intestines: for the skin there is thinness there, as you know well.</start_of_turn>
¶ De modo cauterizandi apostemata Epatis.	As regards the cautery of the after-effects of the liver.</start_of_turn>
Caput XXX.	Chapter XXX.</start_of_turn
Quando accidit exitura, et uis scire, si illud apostema est in carne Epatis, aut in tunica eius: tunc si est in carne Epatis, inuadit infirmum dolor, et grauitas absque acuitate: et si est in tunica Epatis, cum dolore est acuitas uehemens: et uides iam, quia fatigauit medicos eius curatio.	When this happens, and you wish to write, if that after-effect is in the flesh of the liver, or in its membrane: if it is in the flesh of the liver, it causes pain and great swelling without sharpness: and if it is in the membrane of the liver, with sharp pain which excites: and you must know that it fatigues the physicians of its care.</start_of_turn
Oportet ergo ut resupinet infirmus super ceruicem suam.	Therefore it is necessary that the patient lie on his belly over his cushion.</start_of_turn
Deinde figura locum apostematis cum encaustro: deinde ignias cauterium quod assimilatur radio.	Then the figure of the after-effect with the cautery: then you apply the cautery which is assimilated by the beam.</start_of_turn
Et haec est forma eius.	And this is its form.</start_of_turn
Et cauteriza cum eo cauterium unum, donec comburatur cutis tota, et perueniat ad siphac, donec egrediatur sanies tota: deinde cura ipsum curatione exiturarum, donec sanetur.	And cauterize with one cautery until the whole skin is burned through, and passes to the intestines, until the whole body is healed: then care for the after-effects of the cautery until they are healed.</start_of_turn
Et non oportet ut hac cauterii specie utatur, nisi cuius studium in arte medicinae prolongatur: et per cuius manus concurrunt aegritudines istae cum experimento aliquotiens: tunc enim audeat super huiusmodi operationem.	And it is not fitting that these cauteries should be repeated except by him who has studied the art of medicine for a long time: and by whom these ailments have been accompanied by experiments: for he who has heard of such an operation will be bold.</start_of_turn
At uero dimittere ipsam, apud me est melius.	Better for her to depart from me.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Pleuresi.	Better for her to depart from me.
Caput XXXI.	Better for her to depart from me.
Dixerunt antiqui, cauterium cum radicibus aristolochiae ad Pleuresim frigidam secundum hunc modum.	Better for her to depart from me
Et est, ut recipias ex radicibus aristolochiae siccae longae, radicem unam longiorem, quae ex ea inuenitur, et sit sicut grossitudo digiti.	Better for her to depart from me
Deinde submerge eam in oleo: et accende ipsam in igne.	Better for her to depart from me
Deinde cauteriza cauterio uno in eo quod est inter continuationem furculae cum collo, et duobus cauteriis paruis sub guidezi parum decliuibus ad partem, quae est sub barba.	Better for her to depart from me
Et duobus cauteriis etiam in eo, quod est inter costam quintam et sextam decliuibus ad posteriora parumper: et cauterio alio in medio pectoris, et alio supra stomachum.	Better for her to depart from me
Et tribus cauteriis a posterioribus: uno in eo quod est inter duas spatulas: et duobus cauteriis a duobus lateribus pectoris, inferius cauterio quod est inter duas spatulas.	Better for her to depart from me
Et non oportet ut comprimas manum tuam cum cauterio, imo sit in manifesto cutis odorando.	Better for her to depart from me
Et iam dixerunt quidam antiqui, quod ex hominibus sunt qui utuntur cauterio ex ferro simili radio: et igniunt, et intus mittunt ipsum in eo quod est inter costas, donec perueniatur cum eo ad ipsum apostema, et egrediatur sanies: sicut diximus in apostemate Epatis.	Better for her to depart from me
Sed in hac perforatione cum cauterio est ex timore, quod aut moritur infirmus statim, aut accidit in loco fistula, cui non est sanatio.	Better for her to depart from me
¶ De modo cauterizandi Splenem Caput XXXII.	Better for her to depart from me
Quando tu curas aegritudinem splenis, cum eo quod diximus ex curatione in diuisione aegritudinum, et non confert curatio tua, tunc cauterium in ea est secundum tres modos, qui omnes sunt recti.	Better for her to depart from me
Quorum unus est, ut facias tria cauteria, aut quatuor lineando secundum longitudinem splenis secundum figuram cauteriorum Epatis, quorum praecessit figura.	Better for her to depart from me
Et sit inter omne cauterium quantitas grossitudinis digiti, aut plus parum.	And let the quantity of the cautery be between that of the breadth of a finger, or less.
Et sit modus cauterii, quem diximus in cauterio epatis aequaliter.	And let the mode of the cautery be as we said concerning the cautery of the liver, equally.</start_of_turn>
Et non comprimas manum tuam cum cauterio: et sit infirmus resupinus super dorsum suum.	And do not press your hand with the cautery: and let the sickly man lie supine above his back.</start_of_turn
Et modus alius de cauterizatione est: ut ignias cauterium habens duo uerua, quod diximus in capitulo dislocationis humeri: et eleua cutem, quae est in directo splenis, ubi peruenit cubitus infirmi sinister: et sit eleuatio tua qua eleuas cutem secundum latitudinem corporis, ut cadant cauteria secundum longitudinem corporis.	And another mode of cautery is: as when you have two rings of cautery, as we said in the chapter on dislocation of the humerus: and elevate the skin which is over the spleen, where the left elbow of the sickly man lies: and elevate your hand as much as you elevate the skin according to the width of the body, so that the cautery drops according to the length of the body.</start_of_turn>
Deinde intromitte duo uerua ignita ualde, donec cum eis penetres cutem a parte altera: deinde extrahe cauterium: fiunt ergo cauteria quatuor.	Then introduce two rings of fire slowly, until when the fire has penetrated the skin from the other side: then withdraw the cautery: there will remain four cauteries.</start_of_turn
Et si uis cauteriza cum cauterio alio habente tria uerua.	And if you wish to cauterize with another cautery which has three rings.</start_of_turn
Deinde cura cauterium postquam dimittis ipsum emittere pus diebus multis: est enim magis conferens quamque reliqua quae praecesserunt ex curatione.	Then take care of the cautery after you have finished with it to emit pus for many days: for this is better than any other remedy which has preceded it.</start_of_turn
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Hydropisi.	And thus cauterize in Hydropisis.</start_of_turn
Caput XXXIII.	Chapter XXXIII.</start_of_turn>
Cauterium non cadit in Hydropisi, nisi ascliti proprie.	The cautery does not fall in Hydropisis, except as required.</start_of_turn
Quando tu curas Hydropicum cum modis curationis, quos diximus in diuisione, et non confert curatio, tunc oportet ut cauterizes ipsum quatuor cauteriis in circumitu umbilici, et cauterio uno super stomachum, et cauterio alio super epar, et cauterio super splenem, et cauteriis duobus post dorsum inter spondiles, et uno in directo pectoris, et alio in directo stomachi: et sit quantitas profunditatis cauterii propinqua spissitudini cutis.	When you are treating Hydropisis with the methods of treatment which we mentioned in the previous chapter, and the cure does not take hold, then you must cauterize the four corners of the belly, and one on the stomach, and one on the liver, and one between the ribs, and two below the shoulder-blades, and one in the chest, and one in the stomach: and let the quantity of the depth of the cautery be close to the thickness of the skin.</start_of_turn
Deinde dimitte cauterium apertum, ut emittat pus tempore longo.	Then discharge the open cautery, so that it emits pus over a long time.
Et non euacues infirmum a curatione post cauterium cum eo: quod oportet ut aggregentur ei duae intentiones: et festinabit ad ipsum sanatio cum auxilio Dei.	Then do not leave the patient without care after the cautery: for two intentions must be joined together, and it will speed up his healing with the help of God.
Forma uero cauterii cum quo cauterizatur uenter, sit clauilis: secundum quod praecessit forma eius: et illius cum quo cauterizatur dorsum, sit oliuaris secundum quod praecessit eius forma.	The form of the cautery which is used for the belly is like nails: according as it has gone before: and that which is used for the back is like olive-leaves according as it has gone before
¶ De modo cauterizandi Pedes, et Crura.	Regarding the cautery of feet and limbs:
Caput XXXIIII.	Chapter XXXIV.
Quando apostemantur in Hydropico, et replentur aqua citrina: oportet ut cauterizes super dorsum Pedis in nocrati, quae est inter auricularem et anularem: et eleua manum tuam cum cauterio, et non torqueas ipsum: deinde eleua manum tuam: et non iteres ipsum omnino.	When swelling appears in the Hydrope, and the limb is filled with citrine urine: it is necessary to cauterize over the back of the foot between the ankle and the heel: and raise your hand with the cautery, and do not twist it: then raise your hand again: and do not move it at all
Resudet enim aqua citrina, et sit cauterium secundum hanc formam.	The urine is citrine: and the cautery must be in this form.
Deinde fac super duo crura duo cauteria in omni crure, et fiat cauterium cum extremitate cultellari cauterii: et fiat cauterium secundum longitudinem cruris, unum sub genu, et alterum inferius eo, circiter medium cruris: et super omnem coxam cauteria duo: et dimitte cauterium apertum absque curatione tempore longo: ut resudet ex eo aliquod aquae: deinde cura ipsum cum reliquis quae diximus.	Then make on each limb two cauteries at the ankle: and do the cautery with the tip of the cautery: and do the cautery according to the length of the limb, one under the knee and the other below it at about the middle of the limb: and on every heel make two cauteries: and discharge the open cautery without care for a long time: so that some water may remain from it: then care for the limb as before
¶ De modo cauterizandi in solutione Ventris.	Regarding the cautery of the belly in solution
Caput XXXV.	Chapter V
Quando est solutio uentris ex frigore et humiditatibus, donec debilitet uirtutes retentiuam et digestiuam, quae sunt in stomacho et intestinis: et curatur illud cum modis curationis, et non sanatur: et uides infirmum tolerantem cauterium exuberantis uirtutis, tunc cauteriza ipsum cauterio magno super stomachum suum, secundum quod praecessit in cauterizatione stomachi cum cauterio circuli, et quatuor cauteriis in circumitu umbilici subtilibus, cum cauterio clauili subtili: et cauterio super alcatin supra alhosos magno, aut duobus cauteriis.	When the belly is in a state of heat and moisture from cold and dampness, until it has become weak in holding and digesting, which are in the stomach and intestines: and it is cured by the methods of treatment and not by nature: and you must give the patient the power to tolerate the excessive heat of the cautery: then cauterize it with a large cautery over the stomach, as it is done for the cautery of the stomach with the circular cautery, and four cauteries around the navel, with a nail cautery under the skin: and a cautery over the omentum above the intestines, or two cauteries.
Et si uides humiditates exuberantes, et infirmum tolerantem illud, tunc cauteriza ipsum cauterio super pectinem, et cauterio super omne ilium: et fortasse addes duo cauteria parua super stomachum prope magnum.	If the moisture has become excessive and the patient tolerates it, then burn the [affected area] with a cautery over the navel and over every ileum.  Perhaps two small cauteries may be added upon the stomach near the greater one.
Est enim curatio proficiens, cuius iuuamentum non errat.	It is a perfect cure whose method does not err
¶ De modo cauterizandi Hemorroidas.	Method of cautery for hemorrhoids.
Caput XXXVI.	Chapter 6
Quando in ano sunt Hemorroides antiquae multae, aut una, et sunt ex humoribus grossis, frigidis, aut humiditatibus corruptis, et curantur cum eo, quod diximus in diuisione, et non confert curatio: tunc cauteriza tribus cauteriis super inferiorem spondilem dorsi sub almeidati parumper triangulatim, et cauterio sub umbilico quasi duobus digitis.	When in the rectum are many old hemorrhoids, or one, and are from thick, cold, or moist humours, and are cured by that which we have said in the preceding discourse, and do not require cure: then burn three cauteries over the lower spin of the loin under the almond-shaped area triangularly, and a burn under the navel like two fingers.
Et si cogitas, quod stomachus eius infrigidatus sit, et cibus eius non digeratur, et faciem eius uides apostemari, tunc cauteriza eum super stomachum cauterio magno, secundum quod praecessit: et cauterio super Epar eius, et alio super Splenem ipsius, cum cauterio clauili: et dimitte cauterium apertum tempore aliquo: deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	And if you think that his stomach is hardened, and that his food does not digest, and that his face is pale from the moisture of the feces, then burn him over the stomach with a large cautery, as we have said before: and a burn over the liver and another over the spleen, with the cautery of the navel: and leave the cautery open for a while: then care for him until he is healed.
¶ De modo cauterizandi althelul post abscisionem eorum.	Method of cautery for the carbuncle after its excision
Caput XXXVII.	Chapter 7
Quando tu abscindis althelul, tunc ignias cauterium quod assimilatur radio.	When you excise the carbuncle, then burn a cautery which absorbs the heat.
Deinde intromittite ipsum ignitum in ipsum althelul abscisum: et ultima manum tuam, donec perueniat cauterium ad orificium uenae, ex qua currit sanguis: fac illud semel, aut bis.	Then introduce the burning cautery into the excised carbuncle: and move your hand until the cautery reaches the orifice of the vein from which blood flows: do this once or twice
Si ergo althelul fuerint multa, tunc cauteriza unumquodque cauterio secundum quod narrauimus.	If there are many carbuncles, then burn each one according to what we have said before.
Deinde cura ea, cum eo quod confert eis ex unguentis, donec sanentur.	Then care for it until it heals, when the moisture is removed from it.
Et si cauterizas eum cauterio magno super alcatin, est magis ultimum in iuuamento.	And if you cauterize it with a large cautery over the scales, this is the most perfect remedy.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Fistulam in ano.	Thus cauterize the fistula in the rectum.
Caput XXXVIII.	Chapter XXXVIII.</start_of_turn>
Quando non obedit infirmus sectioni et operi quod narrauimus in loco suo, et terretur ab illo, fortasse sanatur cum cauterio.	When the patient does not obey the section and the work that we have mentioned in its place, and returns from it, perhaps it will heal with cautery.</start_of_turn>
Cum ergo accidit alicui Fistula, et antiquatur, currit pus ex ea, et humiditates corruptae.	When this happens to any fistula, and it becomes old, pus runs from it, and moistens the corruptions.</start_of_turn
Dignius ergo quod oportet est, ut probes eam cum tenta subtili.	Therefore it is necessary to explore it with a fine hook.</start_of_turn
Deinde cognosce quantitatem profunditatis eius cum tenta.	Then learn the depth of its cavity with the hook.</start_of_turn
Deinde ignias cauterium, quod est simile radio.	Then burn the cautery, which is like a ray.</start_of_turn
Deinde intromit te ipsum ignitum in ipsam Fistulam et quantitatem in qua intrauit clauus.	Then introduce the burning cautery into the fistula itself and the quantity in which the gut has entered.</start_of_turn
Et itera super eam cauterium, donec comburantur illa omnia corpora corrupta, semel, aut bis, aut ter, secundum quantitatem necessitatis tuae.	And repeat the cautery over the gut until all the corrupt bodies are consumed, once, or twice, or three times, according to the necessity.</start_of_turn
Et custodi te ab adustione nerui, si est illic, aut uenae magnae: aut si Fistula uadit ad corpus uesicae, aut ad corpus intestini, tunc custodi te ab istis locis omnibus.	And take care that there is no scorching of nerves, if they are there, or large veins: or if the fistula comes close to the mesentery or to the intestines, then take care to avoid these places.</start_of_turn
Et non facias illud, nisi quando fistula est in loco carnoso: et cogitas, quia non est penetrans.	Do not do this except when the fistula is in a fleshy place: and think, for it is not penetrating.</start_of_turn
Deinde cura locum usquequo sanetur.	Then care for the place until it heals.</start_of_turn
Si autem sigillatur locus, et abscinduntur ab eo materiae, et remanet sic tempore longo: tunc scias, quia iam sanatus est integre.	If, however, the mark be sealed and the matter be severed from it, and it remains thus for a long time: then you know that it is already healed throughout.
Et si non abscindunt ab eo materiae, tunc scias quia est penetrans, aut in profundo eius est os corruptum, aut quasi illud ex illis: quorum rememoratio ueniet in loco suo.	If it is not severed from the matter, then you know that it is penetrating, or that there is a broken bone beneath the surface, or something like that: of which the memory will arise in its place.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Renes.	In this way, concerning the cautering of the reins.
Caput XXXIX.	Chapter XXXIX.
Quando accidit in Renibus dolor ex frigore, aut ex uentositate grossa, et minuitur propter illud coius infirmi, tunc oportet ut cauterizes ipsum super almethenem super ipsos renes, cauterio super omnem renem cum cauterio clauili, cuius praecessit rememoratio.	When it happens in the reins that there is pain from cold or from great swelling, and it is diminished through this from that which makes the patient infirm, then it is necessary to cauterize it above the marrow above the kidneys, with cautery over every kidney along with the cautery of the claw, of which there is memory.
Et fortasse cauterizamus ipsum secundo in ipso almeidatu.	And perhaps we cauterize it again in the same cavity.
Quare uenient tria lineata.	Because there will arise three lines.
Ergo erunt magis ultima in iuuamento.	Therefore there will be two last things in the treatment.
¶ De modo cauteritzandi Vesicam.	Concerning the cautering of the bladder.
Caput XL.	Chapter XL
Quando accidunt in Vesica debilitas, et mollificatio a frigo re et humiditatibus, donec non retineat infirmus urinam, tunc cauteriza ipsum in inferiori parte suminis super Vesicam, ubi incipiunt pili pectinis, et cauterio a dextra suminis, et alio a sinistra illius: et sit longitudo illius cauterizationis lateris secundum quantitatem nodi pollicis: et cauteriza ipsum cauterio inferiori dorsi, aut duobus cauteriis, si indiges illo: et sit secundum quod praecessit cauterium clauile.	When there is weakness in the bladder, and softening from gravel and moisture until the patient does not retain urine, then cauterize it in the lower part of the belly above the bladder, where the hair of the testicles begins, and cauterize from the right side of the belly and from the left side of it: and let the length of that cautery be as much as the breadth of the thumb: and cauterize the lower back, or with two cauteries, if you like: and let that be according to what precedes the cautery of the claw
¶ De modo cauterizandi Matricem.	Concerning the cautering of the matrix
Caput XLI.	Chapter 41.
Quando accidunt in Matrice frigus et humiditates, et prohibetur per illud ab impregnatione, et corrumpuntur menstrua eius, et tardatur prouocatio eorum, et accidit ei apud aduentum eorum dolor, tunc oportet ut cauterizetur tribus cauteriis in circumitu umbilici, sicut diximus in cauterizatione uesicae, et cauterio super alcatim inferius dorso, aut duobus cauteriis: et sit cauterium clauile.	When cold and moisture abound in the matrix and impede its impregnation, and its menstrual blood is corrupted, its period is delayed, and there is pain in its companion, then it is necessary to cauterize three times around the navel, as we mentioned in the cauterization of the uterus, and to cauterize over the lower part of the navel, or to make two cauterizations: and let the cauterization be blunt.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Ancham in dislocatione.	In the dislocation of the Ancham, cauterize three times around the navel, and over the lower part of the navel, or make two cauterizations: and let the cauterization be blunt.
Caput XLII.	Chapter 42.
Quando effunduntur humiditates mucosae ad pixidem Anchae, et fiunt caussa exitus eius a loco suo: et signum illius est, quod prolongatur crus super alterum, quando comparantur adinuicem: et inuenitur locus dislocationis in eo uacuus.	When moisture of the mucous membrane flows down to the heel of the Ancham, and becomes the cause of its displacement from its place: and its sign is that the heel rests upon the instep, when they are compared together: and the place of dislocation is found in that hollow space.
Oportet ergo ut cauterizes infirmum super pixidem Anchae ipsius cauterio simili circulo: postquam tu signas cum encaustro in circumitu pixidis, sicut reuoluitur: et ut cadat ipsa pixis in medio circuli.	It is therefore necessary to cauterize the diseased heel of the Ancham with a cautery similar to a circle: after having drawn a circle around the heel with the cautery, as it is returned: and let the heel fall into the middle of the circle.
Et sit cauterium cuius forma praecessit in cauterizatione stomachi.	And let the cautery be of the form which we mentioned in the cauterization of the stomach.
Quod si tibi non est praesens hoc cauterium, tunc cauteriza ipsum tribus cauteriis, cum cauterio oliuari magno: et fiat cauterio profunditas secundum quantitatem spissitudinis cutis totius.	If this cautery is not present, then make three cauterizations with a large olive cautery: and let the depth of the cautery be according to the quantity of the thickness of the skin of the whole
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then take care of it until it is healed.</start_of_turn>
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Sciatica.	(The text continues with instructions on how to cauterize the Sciatica.)
Caput XLIII.	Chapter 43
Quando accidit dolor in pixide anchae, et sunt caussa illius frigus et humiditates: et curatur infirmus cum eo, quod diximus in diuisione, et non confert curatio, et antiquatur illud: tunc oportet ut soluas infirmum ab humoribus grossis cum pillulis foetidis, aut cum pillulis artificialibus, et similibus.	When pain occurs in the testicles, and the cause is cold and moisture: the physician should treat the patient with something which we have mentioned previously, and not leave the treatment uncompleted; for it will become old. Then it is necessary to remove the patient from the thick humours with foul pills, or with artificial pills, and the like.
Deinde cauteriza eum.	Then cauterize him.
Et modus cauterii in ea est secundum duos modos: aut cauterium cum medicinis adurentibus, aut cauterium cum igne.	And the manner of cauterization in these two ways: either with cautery with burning medicines, or with cautery with fire.
Cauterium cum igne, est secundum multos modos.	Cautery with fire is in many ways
Quorum unus est, ut cauterizes super pixidem anchae ipsius tribus cauteriis triangulatis, secundum hanc formam.	One of them is that you cauterize over the testicles three times with triangular cautery, according to this form.
Et fac eis profunditatem bonam, uel malam.	And make the depth good, or bad
Et sit spacium quod est inter omne cauterium quantitatis grossitudinis digiti: sitque cauterium oliuare.	And there should be space between each cautery equal to the thickness of a finger: and let the cautery be oily
Quandoque autem fit cauterium in medio super caput anchae ipsius.	When, however, the cautery is done in the middle over the head of the testicles.
Quare sunt quatuor cauteria.	Then there are four cauteries
Et si uis cauteriza cum circulo, cuius praecessit forma in cauterizatione dislocationis anchae, uno: ut sit circulus continens ancham totam.	And if you cauterize in a circle, whose form precedes the cautery of dislocation of the testicles, one: so that it surrounds the whole testicles
Et combure spissitudinem cutis totius.	And burn the hairiness of the whole skin
Iste est modus cauterii in Sciatica, quando dolor est adhaerens anchae ipsi, et non extenditur usque ad coxam et crus.	This is the manner of cautery in Sciatica, when the pain adheres to the testicles and does not extend until the cox and the thigh
Si autem extenditur usque ad coxam et crus, tunc cauteriza ipsum duobus cauteriis super coxam, super locum ad quem innuit illic infirmus, in quo est dolor, et cauterio tuo super cauillam quatuor digitis ad partem syluestrem parumper: et sit cauterium cultellare.	If it extends until the cox and the thigh, then cauterize it with two cauteries over the cox, over the place where the patient feels pain there, and cauterize with your hand four fingers to the side of the base: and let the cautery be in a straight line
Et sit profunditas cauterii secundum profunditatem spissitudinis cutis.	The depth of the burn should be in accordance with the depth of the thickness of the skin.
Quod si infirmus innuit quod dolor extenditur usque prope digitos pedis, tunc cauteriza ipsum illic ubi innuit cum cauterio puncti, tribus, aut quatuor, aut pluribus, si indiget illo.	If the patient complains that the pain extends up to the toes, then burn there where the pain originates, with a burn of three, four, or more points as needed.</start_of_turn>
Et si innuit dolorem esse sub genu uersus crus, tunc cauteriza ipsum illic cauterio uno cultellari.	If the pain is below the knee, burn only with a single burn.</start_of_turn
Et caue tibi in omni cauterizatione tua, ut non ultimes cum cauterio ad hoc ut comburas neruum, aut arteriam magnam, et attrahas per illud super infirmum nocumentum malum, aut contractionem.	In all your burnings, take care not to reach the nerves or great arteries, nor to cause pain or contraction.</start_of_turn>
Et ego quidem iam uidi unum et alium, ex eis qui cauterizauerunt supra cauillam, et ultimauerunt in cauterizatione, et inflatum est crus, donec tumor consecutus est pedem, et perforatus est totus, et corruptus est totus pes: deinde accidit solutio uentris, et mors post illud.	I also know of one who burnt a patient on the thigh, and the burn did not take hold, and the limb became swollen, until the foot was completely blown up, and the whole limb was perforated and corrupted: afterwards, the belly was resolved, and the wound was healed.</start_of_turn>
Quod si dolor est in duabus partibus simul, cauteriza utramque secundum hunc modum.	If there is pain in two parts together, burn both according to this manner.</start_of_turn
Et sapientes quidam dixerunt in cauterizatione anchae, cuius cauterii iste est modus.	And some wise men say concerning the burn of an ache, that this is the way to burn it.</start_of_turn>
Fac simile samio ex ferro, cuius diametrus sit medietas palmi: et sit apud orificium suum secundum grossitudinem nuclei dactyli, aut minus parumper: et intra illud samium sit samium tertium.	Make a mark like that of iron, whose diameter is half the palm: and let it be at a distance from its opening equal to the thickness of the knuckle of the finger, or less.</start_of_turn
Et sit spacium quod est inter omne samium per quantitatem nodi pollicis: et sint samia aperta a duabus partibus: et sit altitudo eorum quasi nodus, aut duo nodi: et fac eis manubrium ex ferro decenter aptatum in samiis.	And there should be a space between every mark equal to the length of the thumb node: and let the marks be open from two sides: and let their height be like a knot, or two knots: and make a handle of iron well adapted to the marks.</start_of_turn
Et haec est forma eius.	This is its form.</start_of_turn
Deinde igniatur in igne, donec rubeat, et proiiciat scintillas: deinde ponatur super pixidem anchae infirmo accubitato super latus sanum.	Then it is ignited in fire until it turns red, and it throws sparks: then it is placed upon the bandage covering the sick person on the side of the healthy person.
Cauteriza ergo eum tribus cauteriis rotundis in uice una.	It is cauterized three times with round cautery irons in one vessel
Deinde dimitte ipsum tribus diebus.	Then leave it for three days.
Postea emplastra cum butyro: et dimitte uulnus apertum diebus multis.	Then plaster with butter: and leave the wound open for many days.
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguento, donec sanetur.	Then care for it with ointment until it heals.
Inquit Albucasis, hac specie cauterii o filii, parum usi sumus, propter terrorem aspectus eius: et propterea, quod paucos inuenimus qui expectent super ipsum.	Albucasis says: We rarely use this kind of cautery because of its harsh appearance: and because few people endure it
Verumtamen est ex bonis cauteriis ei qui suffert, et inuenit cum eo locum eius.	But in truth, from the good cautery instruments it is useful to those who can endure it, and it is found to be useful in its place.</start_of_turn>
Cauterium autem cum medicinis adurentibus est, ut tu facias duo samia habentia perforatam armillam, in quam descendit cardo portae eius ex aere, aut ferro, longitudo parietis: quorum in altitudinem eorum sint duo nodi, aut quasi ipsi.	The cautery is useful with physicians who are accustomed to surgery, as when you make two incisions in the arm, in which the radial artery comes out of the bone, or with iron, the length of the edge is two nodes, or as if by itself.</start_of_turn>
Et sit spacium quod est inter utraque quantitas grossitudinis digiti, et sint aperta inferius et superius: et sit quod contineant se adinuicem, secundum hanc formam.	And there should be space between the two incisions equal to the thickness of a finger, and there should be an opening above and below: and that they should enclose the nerve, following this shape.</start_of_turn
Deinde depone eam super pixidem anchae, infirmo iacente super latus sanum.	Then place it upon the bandage covering the sick person on the side of the healthy person.</start_of_turn
Et comprime manum tuam super pixidem anchae multum.	And press your hand heavily upon the bandage.</start_of_turn
Deinde funde inter duos circulos ex aqua calida, quae sit calefacta cum igne parumper, et tene eam quantitate horae temporalis: et toleret infirmus mordicationem eius, et ipsius adustionem, nam ipse inuenit mordicationem sicut ignis, donec quiescat mordicatio.	Then pour between two circles of lukewarm water, which is warmed with fire slightly, and keep it for the quantity of an hour: and the patient will tolerate the pain of the cautery, and even the pain of the instrument, for he finds the pain of the cautery to be like that of fire until the pain subsides.</start_of_turn
Deinde eleua manum tuam cum instrumento, et absterge aquam calidam ab ancha tota cum aqua dulci: deinde dimitte illud tribus diebus.	Then raise your hand with the instrument and bathe the entire area with warm water and sweet water: then leave it for three days.
Et pone super illud butyrum, donec remoueatur nigredo adustionis: et dimitte illud diebus aliquot, et curret ex eo pus.	And place butter over it, until the black spot of the wound has vanished: then leave it for a few days, and pus will run out of it
Est enim ultimum in iuuamento.	This is the last remedy.
Deinde cura illud cum unguentis, donec sanetur.	Then care for it with unguents until it is healed.
Quod si extendatur dolor usque ad coxam, aut crus: fac ei statuam in eo quod continet aquam, secundum quod fecisti in ancha aequaliter.	If the pain extends up to the hip or the thigh: make for it a basin containing water, as you did in the area
Et iste est modus aquae calidae: et ego iam scripsi eam in tractatu rectificationis medicinarum.	This is the manner of warm water: and I have written about it in the treatise on the rectification of medicine.
Sume alcali, et calcis non extinctae amborum ana partem unam: tere utraque, et pone ea in ollam nouam, cuius inferior pars sit perforata foramine uno paruo, secundum quantitatem quod ingrediatur ipsum radius: et pone sub fundo ollae ollam aliam uitreatam: et proiice super alcali et calcem ex aqua dulci, quod submergat utraque per digitum: post quam tu comprimas ea manu tua compressione bona: et dimite ollam, donec descendat aqua acuta inferiori parte ollae uitreatae.	Take alkali, and unburnt lime of both, and take a portion of each and put them into a new vessel, of which the lower part is perforated with a small hole, according to the quantity of the radius: and put under the bottom of the vessel another vessel filled with water: and throw over alkali and lime from sweet water, which submerges both through a finger: and when you have pressed them with your hand with a good compression: and leave the vessel until the acute water has descended from the bottom of the treated vessel.
Deinde aggrega illam aquam totam, et proiice eam super aliam calcem: et cola, donec renouetur.	Then gather up the whole water, and throw over it another lime: and leave it, until it recovers
Ipsa enim erit tunc fortis acuitatis ualde, quae administratur in multis operationibus medicinae, et in cauterizatione reliquorum membrorum.	These are indeed strong and acute things which are administered in many medical operations, and in the cauterization of the remainder of the limbs.
Quoniam efficit operationem ignis ipsius.	Because it does the work of the fire itself
Et ex medicinis sunt, cum quibus cauterizantur ancha, etiam sicut tesisie, et mel anacardi, et calx cum sapone, ita quod utraque sint permixta. ¶	And from the physicians, who cauterize the area, even like testicles, and mastic resin, and chalk with soap, thus that both are mixed together.
Et Galenus quidem narrando retulit, cuiusdam uiri ex antiquis curationem, qua curatus est dolor anchae et uenae sciaticae: et magnificauit esse eius ualde.	Galenus also reports that a certain man from ancient times received treatment for pain in his groin and sciatica: and he praised his modesty.
Et dixit, quia non indiguit alia curatione, et quia sanatus est ex uice una, donec retulit, quia ipse fortasse intrauit balneum delatus, et exiuit ex eo iam sanus.	He also says that he did not deem it necessary for any other treatment, and that he was healed with one bath alone, because he himself perhaps suffered from a painful bath and emerged from it healed.</start_of_turn>
Et est, ut accipiatur ex seitaragi uiridi: et si non inuenitur uiride, sumatur siccum, recens: et teratur multum cum aliquanto adipe, et ponatur super ancham, ubi est dolor, aut crus, aut in coxa: et ligetur, et dimittatur quantitate trium horarum, aut per quantitatem quod sentiat infirmus sedationem adustionis.	It is like taking from the proverb of the green man: if it is not to be found green, take the dry, recommend: and do it often with some fat, and put it on the groin, or the thigh, or the hip: and bind it, and leave it for the space of three hours, or for as long as the patient feels the pain diminishing.</start_of_turn>
Deinde intromitte eum in balneum.	Then put it into the bath.</start_of_turn>
Cum ergo roridum fit corpus eius, intromitte ipsum in solium.	When the body is softened by the heat of the bath, put it into the bath.</start_of_turn
Nam dolor recedit, et sanatur.	For the pain will subside and he will be healed.</start_of_turn
Et scias, quia non oportet ut utatur aliquis cauterio cum istis medicinis, nisi post euacuationem corporis.	And you know that it is not proper to use any cautery with these remedies except after the evacuation of the body.</start_of_turn
Et Dioscorides qui dem dixit, quod stercus caprarum, quando cum eo cauterizatur uena sciatica, confert ei: et fit cauterium secundum hunc modum.	And Dioscorides says that when the buttocks of a goat are cauterized with regard to the sciatic bone, it brings about a cautery of the second kind.</start_of_turn
Sumatur lana, et imbibatur oleo antiquo, et ponatur super locum profundum, qui est inter pollicem pedis, et inter focile, et est propinquior focili.	Take wool, soak it in old oil, and put it on the deep place which is between the thumb of the foot and the heel, and is nearer to the heel.</start_of_turn
Deinde accipe stercus caprarum siccum, et inflamma ipsum in igne, donec fiat carbo.	Then take the dry buttocks of a goat, burn them in the fire, until they are charcoal.</start_of_turn
Deinde pone ipsum super lanam, et dimitte ipsum, donec extinguatur.	Then put it on the wool and leave it until it is extinguished.</start_of_turn
Deinde itera illud.	Then do it again.
Non cesses ergo facere illud, usquequo perueniat sensus super mediatione usque ad ancham, et quiescat dolor.	Then do it again until the sensation returns above the middle, and the pain rests.
Et iste modus cauterii nominatur cauterium Vaccinum.	This is the method of cauterization called 'cauterium Vaccinum'.
¶ De cauterizatione doloris Dorsi.	Concerning the cauterization of back pain.</start_of_turn>
Caput XLIIII.	Chapter 44.</start_of_turn>
Quandoque accidit dolor in Dorso ex caussis multis, aut a casu, aut a percussione, aut euacuatione superflua, et illis similibus, ex infusione materiei frigidae, et humidae: et cauterium quidem non cadit, nisi in hac specie sola, quae fit ex infusione materiei frigidae.	When there is pain in the back from many causes, such as from a wound, or from a blow, or from excessive evacuation, or in similar cases, from the infusion of cold and moist material: and cauterization is not useless, except for one kind only, which is done by the infusion of cold material.</start_of_turn
Oportet ergo post euacuationem infirmi cum pillulis foetidis, et eis similibus, ut fiant super Dorsum, ubi est dolor, tres lineae secundum latitudinem almeidati ipsius, postquam signas cum encaustro in omni linea quinque cauteria, aut plura secundum quantitatem quae uenit ex tolerantia infirmi uirtute eius: et fiat cauterizatio cum cauteriopuncti.	It is necessary therefore after evacuation of the patient with foetid pills, and things of a similar kind, to make three lines on the back where the pain is, according to the width of the patient's palm, after having marked with the cautery every five cauteries, or as many as the patient's tolerance allows of its kind: and then make the cauterization with the pointed cautery.</start_of_turn
Et si uis, cauteriza tribus cauteriis, aut quatuor, cum cauterio clauili mediali, secundum hanc formam.	And if you wish, cauterize three or four times with the middle cautery, according to this form.</start_of_turn
¶ De modo cauterizandi in incaeptine Gibbositatis.	Concerning the method of cauterization in the armpit.</start_of_turn
Caput XLV.	Chapter 45.</start_of_turn
Multotiens accidit haec aegritudo infantibus paruis.	This pain often occurs in young children.</start_of_turn
Et signum incaeptionis eius in pueris est: quod accidit super eum strictura in anhelitu apud eleuationem, et motum: et inuenis in ultima spondilium Dorsi et nodorum eius, quod iam incaepit eminere super reliquos spondiles.	Its sign in children is: when there is a stricture in the armpit during elevation and movement, and swelling: and you will find it in the last vertebra of the back and the nodes of the back, which begin to swell above the others.</start_of_turn
Cum ergo uides illud, et uis facere illud, tunc cauteriza ipsum cum cauterio quod sit circulus secundum hanc formam.	When you have done that, and when you wish to do that, then cauterize it with the cautery that is in the shape of a circle according to this form.
Et capiat cauterium super omnem partem spondilis aequaliter: et si uis cauteriza in circumitu spondilis cum cauterio puncti duas lineas, aut tres: et sint puncta propinqua adinuicem.	Take the cautery and grasp it over the entire area of the sponge equally: and if you wish to cauterize the circumference of the sponge with the cautery, make two lines or three, and let the points be close to each other.
Deinde cura locum, donec sanetur cum eo quod diximus.	Then take care of the place, until it is healed as we have said.
Et caue, ne administres cauterium in gibbositate, quae fit in spasmo nerui.	And be cautious, lest you administer the cautery to a prominence, which causes spasm of the nerve.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Podagra, et doloribus iuncturarum.	As for cauterizing in Podagra and for joined pains.
Caput XLVI.	Chapter XLVI.
Quando dolores iuncturarum sunt ab humiditatibus frigidis, quae effunduntur ad cuiuslibet membra corporis, tunc quando accidunt dolores in pedibus, de consuetudine medicorum est, ut nominent illud Podagram proprie.	When the pains of the joints are from cold humors which flow upon every limb of the body, then when these pains happen in the feet, it is customary among doctors to call that Podagra
Cum ergo curatur Podagra frigidae caussae cum modis curationis, et non remouentur dolores, tune cauterium remouet eos.	When it is cured by cold causes of Podagra with methods of treatment, and the pains are not removed, then the cautery removes them
Et est, ut cauterizes eum post euacuationem in circumitu iuncturae pedum, cauteriis multis: et sit cauterium Oliuare.	And it is necessary to cauterize around the joints of the feet after the evacuation of many cauteries: and let the cautery be of Olive Oil
Cuius haec est forma.	Whose is this shape?
Et si indiges ut punctes super faciem pedis, tunc fac cum cauterio puncti.	And if you do not wish to puncture the sole of the foot, then make it with the cautery of a point.
Quod si ascendunt dolores usque ad genua, aut reliquas iuncturas, et multotiens accidit illud, tunc cauteriza ipsum super omne genu tribus cauteriis, aut quatuor ab omni parte, cum hoc eodem cauterio Clauili.	When the pains rise up to the knees, or reach the other joints, and many such things happen, then cauterize over every knee with three cauteries, or from every side with four, with this same cautery of Clauili
Si autem necessaria sunt tibi plura hoc cauterio, tunc cauteriza ipsum.	If, however, several of these are necessary, then cauterize them.
Et non submergas manum tuam cum cauterio, imo sit circiter spissitudinem cutis tantum.	Do not immerse your hand with the cautery, but rather keep the thickness of the skin at a distance.
Si autem ascendunt dolores ad genua, et dorsum: tunc administra quod diximus ex cauterio in capitulo suo.	If, however, pain arises to the knee and back: then apply what we have said of the cautery in its chapter
Quod si dolores sunt in manibus tantum, tunc puncta in circumitu focilium, sicut reuoluuntur duae lineae.	If the pain is only in the hands: then prick around the edges of the wound, as two lines are twisted together
Si autem remanet ex doloribus in digitis, tunc puncta eos, super omnem nodum punctum, et super pectinem manus.	If, however, the pain remains in the fingers: then prick throughout, over every nodule and over the palm of the hand
Si autem ascendunt dolores post dies ad cubitos, aut ad humeros, tunc cauteriza utrosque ab omni parte.	If, however, pain arises after a few days to the cubits or arms: then cauterize both from every side
Et non euacues infirmum ex regimine bono, ex recaeptione medicinarum.	And do not weaken the patient by excessive use of the cautery, but by the recovery of medicines.
Nam si bonum fiat regimen, et euacuetur phlegma, sanabitur auxilio Dei cum isto cauterio.	For if good treatment is done and phlegm is evacuated, healing will come with the help of God through this cautery.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Rupturis.	In the event of a rupture...
Caput XLVII.	Chapter XLVII.</start_of_turn>
Quando accidit Ruptura in inguinibus, et descendit intestinum, aut zirbum ad testiculum, et est illud incipiens propinquum: tunc oportet ut praecipias infirmo dimittere comestionem in die suo.	When a rupture occurs in the groin, and the intestine or bladder has descended close to the testicles: then it is necessary to discharge the contents of the bowels on that day
Et utatur ex lenientibus, quo descendat stercus a uentre suo.	And let him be cleansed with soft things, so that the stool may descend from its belly
Deinde sedeat inter manus tuas super dorsum suum: et praecipe ei, ut teneat anhelitum suum, donec egrediatur, uel appareat zirbum, aut intestinum.	Then let him sit between your hands on his back: and command him to hold his breath until the bladder or intestine comes out, or until it is seen
Deinde reduc ipsum digitis tuis, et signa cum encaustro sub Ruptura super os pectinis, cum signo cuius extremitas sit similis medietati circuli ad superiora corporis.	Then draw it out with your fingers, and sign with the cautery under the rupture over the bone of the hip, with a sign like that which has its extremity similar to the middle of the circle towards the upper parts of the body
Deinde igni cauterium, cuius haec est forma, donec ueniat album, et proiiciat seintillas.	Then the cautery is ignited, its form being like this until it turns white, and it throws sparks.
Deinde reduc intestinum, aut zirbum ad concauitatem suam.	Then the intestine is reduced, or the liver to its own concavity.
Deinde ponat minister manum suam super locum, ut non exeat intestinum: et tu iam aperuisti inter crura infirmi, et posuisti sub eo puluinar, et seruiens alius super crura eius, et alius super pectus eius qui tenet manus.	Then the minister places his hand over the place [of the wound], so that the intestine does not escape: and you have opened between the crura of the patient, and put under it powder, and another servant over the crura, and another over the belly which holds the hand.
Deinde depone cauterium super ipsum signum, manu tua cum cauterio stante recta.	Then the cautery is placed over the very sign, your hand with the cautery being held straight up
Et tene ipsum, donec cum eo consequaris os: aut itera cum eo uice alia, si non consecutus fueris cum eo in prima usque ad os.	And hold it there until you reach the bone: or repeat it again with the same, if you have not reached the bone in the first place until the bone itself
Et prudenter obserua ab exitu intestini in hora cauterizationis tuae, ne comburas ipsum, et eueniat per illud super infirmum aut mors, aut malicia magna.	And observe cautiously the exit of the intestine in the hour of your cautery, lest you burn it, and it escapes through that over the patient or the wound, or maliciousness great
Et scias, quod quando tu non consequeris cum cauterio os, non confert operatio tua.	And you know that when you do not reach the bone with the cautery, your operation will be in vain.
Et oportet ut sit cauterium infantium subtile, secundum mensuram eorum.	And it is necessary that the cautery be fine for infants, according to their measure
Deinde cura cum reliquis unguentis, donec sanetur.	Then take care of the rest of the unguents, until they are healed.
Et sit infirmus iacens super dorsum suum quadraginta diebus, donec sigilletur uulnus.	And let the patient lie on his back for forty days, until the wound is healed.
Et oportet, ut ponas nutrimentum eius longitudine temporis curationis eius, quod leniat uentrem eius: ut non exeat intestinum apud conamen et egestionem.	And it is necessary that you give the patient food during the time of his cure, which will soften his belly: that the intestine does not escape from the wound and be evacuated
Deinde quando uult surgere post quadraginta dies, tunc administra ligamentum decenter factum, et teneat ipsum quadraginta diebus aliis.	Then when you wish to remove the cautery after forty days, then administer the ligature of the center made, and keep it for another forty days.
Et minoretur a labore, et repletione cibi et potus, et uocibus uehementibus.	They do not return from toil, neither do they replenish food and drink, nor do they endure harsh words.
Nam quando utitur hoc regimine, ita sanatur sanatione integra.	When one adheres to this regimen, complete healing is achieved.
Et ego dicam curationem Rupturarum cum incisione in capitulo suo.	And I shall speak of the treatment of ruptures with an incision in their chapter.
Quando autem Rupturae accidunt in reliquo uentre, et sunt incipientes, et uis ut non addantur, tunc cauteriza Rupturam eius cauterio rotundo secundum quantitatem eius: et sit illud quod aduritur ex tunc sicut tertia eius.	When, however, ruptures happen in the remainder of the belly, and are just beginning, and you wish them not to grow, then cauterize the rupture with a round cautery according to its quantity: and let it be so that what is burned away from that moment be like a third of it
Deinde cura ipsum, cum eo quod diximus: et non addetur.	Then care for the rest, as we have said: and do not add to it
Et iam dixerunt quidam primi: ut cauterizetur Ruptura cum cauterio triangulato, secundum hanc formam.	And some people say: cauterize the rupture with a triangular cautery, according to this form
Postquam signatur cum encaustro, et ponitur linea quae est per latitudinem in latere superiori Rupturae, et linea altera ad inferius.	When it is signed with a burn, and a line is drawn which passes through the width at the upper side of the rupture, and a second line is drawn downwards.
Et depone manum tuam in medio cum cauterio clauili.	And place your hand in the middle with the cautery claw
Sed cauterium primum est facilius et melius.	But the first cautery is easier and better
¶ De modo cauterizandi in doloribus propter casum, aut percussionem.	In the case of pains caused by a fall, or a blow.
Caput XLVIII.	Chapter XLVIII.
Quando accidit in quibusdam membris a casu, aut percussione dolor: et perseuerat ille dolor tempore longo, et non confert in eo curatio cum medicinis: tunc oportet ut cauterizetur cum cauterio Puncti.	When something happens in some limb by a fall, or a blow, and the pain persists for a long time, and does not yield to treatment with doctors: then it is necessary to cauterize with a Puncti cautery
Et sit cauterium omnis membri cauterium secundum magnitudinem eius, et ipsius paruitatem, et debilitatem eius, et ipsius uirtutem, et locationem torsionis, et doloris ex eo.	And the cautery of every limb must be done according to the size of it, and its proportion, and its flexibility, and its toughness, and the position of torsion, and the pain from it
Si ergo sanatur ex cauterio primo, est bene.	If, therefore, the patient is healed by the first cautery, it is well.
Si non: tunc itera super ipsum cauterium.	If not: then repeat the process with a second cautery.</start_of_turn>
Quoniam de consuetudine horum dolorum est, ut permutentur ex membro ad illud quod appropinquat ei.	For in the habit of these pains, it is necessary to change from one part to another that approaches them.</start_of_turn>
Quare oportet ut consequaris eos cum cauterio, donec sanetur infirmus.	Therefore it is necessary to follow the cautery with other things until the patient is healed.</start_of_turn
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Lepra.	(The text continues with instructions on treating leprosy using cautery.)</start_of_turn>
Caput XLIX.	Chapter XLVIX.</start_of_turn>
Leprosi autem quandoque iuuantur cauterio iuuamento maximo.	Leprosy, however, is sometimes treated with the greatest cautery.</start_of_turn
Et praecipue species Leprae, quae fit propter putrefactionem phlegmatis et melancholiae: cum ergo uis cauterizare ipsam considera.	And especially those species of leprosy which arise from the putrefaction of phlegm and melancholy: in such cases the physician must carefully consider the cautery itself.</start_of_turn
Si ergo Lepra est ineipiciens, et curasti eam cum eo, quod diximus in diuisione, et non descendit, neque stat: et times super infirmum, quod comprehendat corruptio super totam complexionem eius: tunc cauteriza eum super caput quinque cauteriis: uno in medio capitis noto, et secundo inferius eo uersus frontem apud finem capillorum, et duobus super duo cornua, et uno posterius super nucea ceruicis.	If, however, leprosy is not readily eliminated by the first cautery, and if it persists, and does not yield: and the disease spreads over the whole face: then repeat the cautery five times over: one in the middle of the head, and one below at the front near the hair's end, and two over the two horns, and one behind the nape of the neck.</start_of_turn
Et ultima manum tuam cum cauterio parumper, donec imprimat in os impressionem paruam, et dislocentur ex eo cortices: ut alleuietur expiratio uaporum grossorum ex eo, et cauteriza cauterio etiam super ipsum splenem, secundum quod praecessit.	And finally hold your hand with the cautery close by, until you make an imprint in the bone; thus the cortex will be loosened and the thick vapor will be driven out. And burn the spleen also with the cautery, as before.</start_of_turn
Sin autem Lepra iam sparsa est super infirmum, et apparet manifeste: tunc oportet ut cauterizes cum istis cauteriis, quae diximus in capite, et cauterio super extremitatem nasi, et duobus cauteriis super duas maxillas, et duobus cauteriis super spondiles colli, et sex super spondiles dorsi, et uno magno super alhahosos apud gran caudae et uno supra ipsum, in ipso almeidati: et duobus super anchas: scilicet super omnem ancham uno, et duobus super genua: uno super omne genu, et duobus super humeros, et duobus super cubitos, et duobus super teneritudines pectoris sui: et cauteriza ipsum super omnem iuncturam, ex iuncturis digitorum manuum suarum, et pedum suorum: et cauteriza super omnem calcaneum pedum suorum, et focilia manuum suarum.	If, however, leprosy has become sparse over the patient, and is clearly visible: then it is necessary to burn with these cauteries which we mentioned in the head, and with a cautery on the tip of the nose, and with two cauteries on the two cheeks, and two on the thyroid cartilage, and six on the spinal column, and one large one on the hairless parts of the buttock and one above the testicles: and two on the shoulders: that is, one on each shoulder, and two on the knees: one on each knee, and two on the upper arms, and two on the forearms, and two on the chest. Burn the whole of the joints of the hands and feet, and the soles of the feet.</start_of_turn
Et caue tibi a neruis qui sunt super postremum calcanei, ut non comburas eos.	And take care of the nerves that are above the heel, so that you do not burn them.
Et quandoque cauterizatur cauterio super os pectinis, et alio super os stomachi, et alio super epar.	When you burn with the cautery above the bones of the heel, and also above the bones of the stomach, and also above the spleen.
Et scias, quod quanto plus addis cauterium, est magis iuuamentum, et magis conferens.	And you know that the more you add the cautery, the more damage you cause, and the more suffering you produce.
Et scias, quod infirmus non inuenit in cauterio dolorem, sicut inueniunt ipsum sani: propterea, quod corpus eius iam stupefactum est.	And you know that the sick man does not feel pain in the cautery, just as he does not feel it in his health: because his body is already stupefied.
Et oportet ut sint cauteria ex magnitudine, et paruitate secundum membra et iuncturas: secundum quod praecessit ex speciebus ferramentorum.	And it is necessary that the cautery should be of a suitable size, and of a degree of fineness corresponding to the parts and the connections: according to what preceded from the kinds of instruments
Deinde cura cauterium ex farina herbi cum melle, et reliqua curatione, donec sanetur.	Then take care of the cautery from the flour of herbs with honey, and the rest of the treatment, until he is healed
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Stupore.	In this way, burn in the wound.
Caput L.	The head of L.
Quando stupet aliquod membrum, et curatur cum medicinis, et oleis, et emplastris, et non sanatur, tunc cauteriza ipsum membrum stupefactum cauteriis, secundum quod meretur magnitudo membri, aut paruitas eius.	When some part is swollen and is being treated with doctors, and oils, and plasters, and does not heal, then burn that part which is swollen with the cautery, according to the measure of the size of the part, or its degree of fineness
Et sit cauterium tuum intrans in spissitudinem cutis parumper.	And let your cautery not penetrate too deeply into the thickness of the skin
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguento, donec sanetur.	Then take care of it with ointment, until he is healed
Et quandoque cauterizatur ad quiddam stuporis, qui accidit manui, et pedi, in spondilibus dorsi apud exitum neruorum, qui mouent illud membrum: et remouetur stupor.	And when you burn something of a swelling, which happens to the hand and the foot, on the bones of the back near the exit of the nerves which move that limb: and you will remove the swelling.
Verum non praesumat super illud, nisi qui est sapiens in anatomia membrorum, et egressione neruorum mouentium corpus.	But do not be proud of this, except for one who is learned in the anatomy of the limbs, and the coming out of the nerves which move the body
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Albaras.	How to cauterize in Albaras.
Caput LI.	How to cauterize in Albaras.
Quando antiquatur Albaras, et non confert in eo aliquid ex ingeniis medicinae: tunc cauteriza super ipsam cauterio profundo parumper, secundum quantitatem spissitudinis cutis, donec remoueatur albedo, et mutetur color eius.	When Albaras becomes hardened and no longer yields to medical treatment: then cauterize over the area with a deep burn, according to the amount of thickness of the skin, until the white is removed and its color is changed.
Deinde cura ipsum cum farina herbi, et lentis cum oleo rosa, et foliis arnoglossae, et sanguine columbae, et sanguine hyrundinis: de unoquoque sit pars una: misceantur haec omnia, et liniantur super pannum, et adhaereant loco, donec sanetur.	Then care for it with barley meal and lentils with oil of rose, and rue leaves, and columbine blood and hyacinth blood: a little of each: mix these together and smear over the wound, and bind firmly in place until healed
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Cancro.	How to cauterize in Cancer
Caput LII.	How to cauterize in Cancer
Quando Cancer est incipiens, et uis ipsum sistere: tunc cauteriza ipsum cum cauterio circuli in circuitu eius, sicuti reuoluitur.	When Cancer is beginning and you wish to stop it: then cauterize it with a circular burn around its circumference as it shrinks.
Sapientes autem dixerunt, ut cauterizetur cauterio ultimo in medio.	Wise men however say, that the last should be burned in the middle
Mihi autem non uidetur illud: quoniam timeo quod ulceretur: et ego iam uidi illud aliquotiens.	I do not see that: for I fear that it will ulcerate: and I have seen this happen many times.
Et rectius est, ut cauterizetur in circumitu eius cum circulo, sicut diximus: aut cauteriis multis.	It is better to burn around it with a circle, as we said: or with multiple burns.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Adubelati.	How to cauterize in Adubelati
Caput LIII.	How to cauterize in Adubelati
Quando aliquis habet Adubelati, et tardatur in maturatione, aut propter superfluitatem facientem eam, aut propter aetatem infirmi, quando est decrepitus pauci sanguinis, aut propter tempus, et uis festinare in maturatione Adubelati, tunc cauteriza in circumitu eius cum cauteriis paruis multis punctando.	When anyone has Adubelati and they are delayed in maturity, or because of excess flesh, or because of age's infirmity, when he is weak from lack of blood, or from time, and wishes to hasten the maturity of the Adubelati: then cauterize around its circumference with many small burns puncturing
Deinde dimitte eam.	Then discharge him.
Nam ipsa festinabit cum maturatione.	For indeed he will recover with the passage of time.
Si autem uis perforationem eius cum cauterio, tunc igni cauterium, cuius haec est forma.	If, however, you wish to perforate it with the cautery, then apply the cautery, for this is its form.
Et depone ipsum in medio Adubelati, donec penetret cutem: et sit cauterium ab eo quod sequitur infirmus, ut alleuietur cursus puris.	And place it in the middle of the Adubelat, until it pierces the skin: and let the cautery follow the diseased part, so that it may alleviate the flow of pus
Deinde cura ipsum donec sanetur.	Then care for it until it is healed
¶ De modo cauterizandi in malo corrodente.	Thus cauterize in a soft swelling
Caput LIIII.	Chapter 14.
Corrodens non est nisi corruptio in membro ambulans, et corrodit ipsum: sicut ignis comedit ligna sicca.	A swelling is not without corruption in a movable limb, and corrupts it: thus as fire consumes dry wood.
Si ergo uides corrodentem in loco qui toleret cauterium cum igne, tunc igni cauteria multa, clauilia parua et magna, secundum quod conueniet illi loco in quo est corrodens.	If therefore you wish to cauterize a swelling which tolerates it with fire, then apply the cautery many times, with small and large claws, according as it will be convenient in the place where the swelling is located
Deinde cauteriza ipsum ab omni parte donec eradices corruptionem totam, et non remaneat ex ea aliquid penitus.	Then cauterize it from all sides until you have eradicated the whole corruption, and let nothing remain of it except the healthy tissue
Deinde dimitte ipsum tribus diebus, et pone super loca cauterizata sulphur tritum cum oleo, donec eradicentur escharae omnes, et omnis corruptio.	Then discharge him in three days, and place over the cauterized place powdered sulphur with oil, until all the eschar has disappeared and all the corruption is gone.
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguentis generantibus carnem.	Then care for it with nourishing unguents of flesh.
Si ergo uides, quod post tres dies caro nascitur natiuitate sana, in qua non est corruptio, est bonum.	If therefore after three days the flesh has recovered its natural health, without corruption, this is good
Et si non: tunc itera cauterium super illud quod remansit ex locis corruptis.	And if not: then repeat the cautery over that which remains of the corrupted parts
Et corrodens medicatur quandoque cum medicina acuta.	The swelling is treated when it is acute with acute medicine.
Ipsa namque surgit loco cauterii.	The fire itself arises at the place of the cautery.
Verumtamen cauterium cum igne est uelocioris iuuamenti: et ego quidem iam dixi cauterizationem eius cum medicina acuta in diuisione: accipe ergo eam illic quando ea indiges.	The fire itself arises at the place of the cautery.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Clauis, et Verucis.	The fire itself arises at the place of the cautery.
Caput LV.	The fire itself arises at the place of the cautery.
Multotiens accidit in inferioribus partibus pedum haec aegritudo: et est res grossa, filtrata, quae laedit pedem.	The fire itself arises at the place of the cautery
Et cauterium quidem in eis est secundum duos modos: cauterium cum igne, et cauterium cum aqua calida.	The fire itself arises at the place of the cautery
Quantum autem cum igne est, ut ignias cauterium concauum simile pennae uulturis: quod fiat ex ferro, secundum quantitatem quod contineat clauum ab omni parte: et sit subtilium marginum.	The fire itself arises at the place of the cautery
Deinde depone ipsum ignitum super clauum.	The fire itself arises at the place of the cautery
Deinde reuolue manum cum cauterio in circumitu claui, donec perueniat cauterium ad profunditatem claui: et dimitte ipsum tribus diebus, donec incipiat emittere pus.	The fire itself arises at the place of the cautery
Deinde emplastra ipsum cum maluis syluestribus, contritis cum sale: et dimitte emplastrum super ipsum in nocte.	The fire itself arises at the place of the cautery
Ipse enim eradicabitur ex radicibus suis.	The fire itself arises at the place of the cautery
Deinde cura locum unguento generatiuo carnis, donec sanetur.	The fire itself arises at the place of the cautery
Quod si sunt non conuersi, et multotiens accidunt in superficie corporis, praecipue in manibus et pedibus: tunc administres in eis cauterium cum aqua calida: et est, ut accipias cannulam ex aere, aut ferro, aut ex penna uulturis: et depone eam super clauum, aut althelul.	The fire itself arises at the place of the cautery
Deinde proiice in cannulam ex aqua calida quantitatem paucam: retine manum tuam, et tu reuolue eam cum compressione manus tuae parumper, ut imprimatur margo cannulae in radice claui, et inueniat aqua calida uiam ad profundum, ad radicem claui: et expectet infirmus parumper super mordicationem aquae calidae hora una.	The fire itself arises at the place of the cautery
Deinde dimitte ipsum, nam clauus eradicatur cum radicibus suis.	Then let go of it, for the abscess will vanish with its roots.
Ita fac cum eis uno post unum, donec uenias super omnes qui ex eis sunt in corpore.	Do so with one hand after the other, until you have gone over all that is in the body from the hand that is lower
Deinde cura eos postquam eradicantur, cum eo quod generat carnem ex unguentis.	Then take care of the wound after it has vanished, when that which has been produced by the abscess from the roots is gone.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Tremore.	In this way, cauterize in Tremore.
Caput LVI.	Chapter 66.</start_of_turn>
Quando accidit alicui Tremor ex frigore in neruo, aut ex febre quartana, aut alio: tunc oportet ut cauterizes ipsum quatuor cauteriis, aut quinque super spondiles dorsi, et inter omnem spondilem cauterio, et in pectore eius cauterio, et super stomachum eius cauterio.	When it happens to anyone to have a tremor from cold in a nerve, or from a quartan fever, or from something else: then it is necessary to cauterize it four times with the cautery, or five over the vertebrae of the back, and between every vertebra cauterize, and in its belly cauterize, and over its stomach cauterize.</start_of_turn>
Tremor enim quiescit cum cauterio oliuari, et festinat sanitas aegritudinis frigidae.	The tremor will cease with the cautery of oil, and the health of the cold will be restored.</start_of_turn>
¶ De modo cauterizandi Albathir.	In this way, cauterize Albathir.</start_of_turn
Caput LVII.	Chapter 67.</start_of_turn
Quandoque expelluntur in corpore Albathir foedae, id est, pustulae, quae fiunt a materiis grossis corruptis.	When there are expelled from the body in the body of Albathir pus, that is, bubbles, which are caused by corrupted thick materials.</start_of_turn
Oportet ergo in primis cum apparent, ut cauterizentur super omne caput pustulae cauterio subtili cum ligno myrti, cuius extremitas accensa est cum igne.	It is necessary therefore at first when they appear to cauterize over every head of the bubbles with fine cautery with a twig of myrtles, whose extremity is inflamed with fire.</start_of_turn
Aut cum radice aristolochiae longae.	Or with the root of long aristolochia.</start_of_turn
Aut cum cauterio lenticulari.	Or with lenticular cautery.</start_of_turn
Et quandoque cauterizantur ademenul, in principio expulsionis suae secundum hunc modum: et non augentur: et disrumpitur superfluitas faciens eos, et sanatur ex eis.	And when they have been cauterized enough, at the beginning of their expulsion in this way: and they do not increase: and the superfluous is ruptured making it go away, and it is healed from the remnants.</start_of_turn
Verumtamen oportet ut fiat illud post euacuationem cum phlebotomia.	It is proper to perform this after evacuation with a phlebotomy.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in fluxu sanguins ex arteria in uulnere.	In the flow of blood from the artery to the wound.
Caput LVIII.	Chapter 58.</start_of_turn>
Multotiens accidit fluxus sanguinis ex arteria, quae incisa est apud uulnus, quod accidit extrinsecus, aut apud incisionem apostematis, aut cauterium membri, et similia eis: et fit difficile abscindere eum.	Many things happen with the flow of blood from the artery, which has been cut at the wound, which happens outside, or at the incision of the after-pulse, or by cautery of the limb, and the like: and this makes it difficult to close it off.</start_of_turn>
