And both kinds do not begin except from the greater tear-duct, until it has gradually become softened, until it covers the useful part, and excludes light and the movement of the eye
Et modus operandi in incisione eius est: ut ponat infirmus caput suum in sinu tuo.	And the manner of working in its incision is: as you place your diseased head in your lap.
Deinde aperi oculos eius, et eleua palpebram manu tua.	Then open its eyes, and elevate its eyelid with your hand
Deinde collige ungulam cum uncino paucae duplationis, et extende eam ad superiora.	Then collect the nail with a hook of few turns, and extend it upwards.
Deinde accipe acum, et intromitte in eam pilum ex pilis equi, et bouis, aut uaccae: et sit filum forte, et duplica extremitatem acus parumper, et fige eam in medio ungulae: et penetra eam cum acu, et liga cum filo ungulam, et extende eam ad superiora: et excoria cum pilo latus ungulae quod sequitur pupillam, ac si tu serres eam cum pilo usque ad postreimnum eius.	Then take a needle, and penetrate it through the hair from the hair of the horse, and sow, or ligate: and let the thread be strong, and double the end of the needle slightly, and fix it in the middle of the nail: and penetrate it with the needle, and ligate the nail with the thread, and extend it upwards: and remove the surrounding hair with the nail that follows the pupil, as if you were grooming the nail until its extremity.
Deinde incide residuum in radice lachrymalis cum spatumili subtili, aut cum forficibus paruis: et dimitte carnem lachrymalis naturalem, ut non accidat ex incisione eius cursus lachrymarum assiduus.	Then cut the remaining part at the root of the tear-duct with fine scissors, or with small forceps: and let go of the natural meat of the tear-duct, so that it does not suffer from the incision of its course of tears
Et quandoque extenditur ungula cum uncino solo: aut cum filo, sicut diximus.	When an ungulay is extended with a single thread: or with a piece of wire, as we have said.
Deinde excoriatur cum spatumili leni, cuius haec est forma.	Then it is to be pared with a blunt spatula of fine texture, whose form is as follows.
Et caue, ne tangat spatumile tunicam corneam, et accidat in ea ruptura, et perforetur pupilla.	Beware lest you tear the delicate membrane of the cornea, and cause a perforation of the pupil.
Deinde post incisionem, proice in oculum aliquid salis contriti, aut ex sief facto ex ziniar, et dimitte ipsum usque ad diem alium.	Then, after the incision, pour some powdered salt, or mix it from barley flour, and leave it in the eye until tomorrow.
Deinde cura ipsum cum eo quod oportet, usquequo sanetur.	And care for the eye until it has healed.
Quod si ungula est non neruosa, et non potes intromittere in eam acum, neque figitur in ea uncinus, tunc multotiens curatur haec species ungulae cum medicinis, et sanatur sicut narraui in diuisione.	If the nail is neither nerve nor bone, and does not secrete pus into the wound, then it must be treated in many ways with the help of physicians, and will heal as I have mentioned before
Quod si uis incidere eam, tunc aperi oculum infirmi, et accipe spatumile subtile, lene, debilis acuitatis, secundum hanc formam.	If you wish to make an incision in the eye, then open the eye of the patient, and grasp the membrane under a fine, soft spatula, of slight degree of sharpness, according to this form
Et rade ungulam desuper rasione cum subtilitate.	And remove the nail from above with care and precision
Quod si uides quod ipsa rarificatur et confringitur, et imprimit in eam rasio, tunc distilla ex hora tua in oculum ex sief facto ex ziniar, aut ex sief rubeo, aut sale trito: et opila oculum usque ad diem alium.	If you see that it is becoming soft and broken, and that it has burst in the ratio, then do not instill anything into the eye from this hour until tomorrow. Mix together barley flour, or red ochre, or salt, and instill in the eye
Deinde itera super ipsam operationem, donec remoueatur totum eius.	Then repeat the operation until it is completely finished
Nisi contrarium sit tibi in oculo apostema calidum: tunc enim dimitte ipsam, et cura apostema, donec sanetur.	Except that in the eye there be a thick yellow pus: then indeed do remove it, and care for the pus until it has healed
Deinde itera operationem super ipsam cum rasione, donec sanetur.	Then repeat the operation with care until it has healed
Eminentia autem carnis lachrymalis, si nocet in oculo nocumento magno, suspendatur cum uncino, et incide ex ea partem eius: et non ultimes incisionem, ut non accidat cursus lachrymarum.	The swelling of the caruncular membrane of the lacrimal gland, if it hinders the eye at night, is to be suspended with a single thread, and to cut away a part of it: and do not make the incision at the end, lest you cause the discharge of the tears to be delayed
Deinde stilla in lachrymale sief rubeum, aut factum ex ziniari, donec sanetur.	Then stay still in the tear of the red [eye], or make it from the iris, until it heals.
¶ De incisione Alguardenic, et carne nata in oculo.	Regarding the incision of the pupil, and the native tissue of the eye.
Caput XVII.	Chapter XVII.</start_of_turn>
Nascitur quandoque in quibusdam oculis hominum caro rubea composita, uel superposita, donec cooperit pupillam, aut appropinquat, aut stringit super palpebras, et fortasse conuertit palpebras ad exteriora: et assimilatur rosae balaustinae.	Sometimes in the eyes of men there is a red piece of flesh composed or superposed, which covers the pupil, approaches or tightens over the eyelashes, and perhaps turns the eyelashes outwards: and it is assimilated like the dust of roses.</start_of_turn
Et operatio in ea etiam est, ut ponat infirmus caput suum in sinu tuo.	And also in this case there is an operation, as you put your hand in my belly.</start_of_turn
Deinde aperi oculos eius, et collige illam carnem totam cum uncinis conuenientibus ad illud: et tene illud cum forcipe uno, aut gesti.	Then open his eyes, and collect all that flesh with hooks which are convenient for this: and hold that with a force one, or grasp it.</start_of_turn
Deinde incide carnem in primis, donec finiatur totum eius cum incisorio.	Then cut the flesh at first, until it is finished with the knife.</start_of_turn
Et caue ab oculo, ut non laedas ipsum apud operationem: et sit incisio tua qua ipsam incidis, aut cum spatumili, quod narrauimus in incisione ungulae: aut cum forficibus paruis, cum quibus colligitur asebel, secundum quod ueniet forma eius post hoc capitulum.	And burn from the eye, so that you do not damage it in the operation: and let your incision be like that which we mentioned in the incision of the nail: or with small forceps, with which you collect fat, according as will come after this chapter.</start_of_turn
Cum ergo completur incisio tua, et remouetur tota alguardenici, tunc imple oculum ex sale contrito: aut distilla in eum puluerem rubeum, et similia illi ex medicinis corrosiuis: et pone super oculum deforis cottum cum albugine oui: ut securetur ab apostemate calido.	When your incision is finished, and you have moved all the pupil, then put the eye out of salt mixed with flour: or distill into it red powder, and like this from physicians who concoct medicines: and put over the eye a bandage of white wool or linen: to protect from the heat.</start_of_turn>
Quod si remanet ex alguardenici aliquid, et dominatur tibi sanguis calidus, et times apostema calidum: tunc dimitte oculum, et cura ipsum cum eo quod sedat apostema.	And if anything remains of the pupil, and you dominate the hot blood, and wait for the heat of the swelling: then remove the eye, and care for it as it settles the swelling.</start_of_turn
Deinde itera super ipsum cum operatione, donec sanetur.	Then proceed further over the said with the operation until it is healed.
Et similiter fac cum carne addita quae accidit in oculo ex hac specie.	Proceed in like manner with the flesh added which has happened in the eye of this kind.
Verumtamen oportet, ut alienes curationem omnis oculi debilis ex uia naturali, aut ex uia accidentali, operando cum ferro: et non intromittas manum tuam in aliqua harum operationum, donec uideas, quod illud membrum est tolerans illam operationem.	It is necessary to know, that other cures of the eye must be excluded both natural and accidental, operating with iron: and do not insert your hand into any of these operations, until you know that the limb can tolerate that operation.
¶ De collectione Sebel ex oculo.	Of collection of the fat from the eye.</start_of_turn>
Caput XVIII.	Chapter 18.</start_of_turn>
Sebel sunt uenae rubeae quae texuntur super oculum, et prohibent uisui operationem suam: et debilitant oculum cum longitudine dierum.	Fat is a red wax which covers the eye, and hinders the operation of the water: and weakens the eye with the length of days.</start_of_turn
Necesse est ergo tibi in primis, ut consideres, si oculus in quo est Sebel, est fortis, et non est in eo aegritudo aliqua, praeter Sebel: tunc collige Sebel eius.	It is necessary therefore that you should first consider, if the eye in which the fat is, is strong, and is not suffering from any other ailment except for the fat: then collect the fat from it.</start_of_turn
Et est, ut praecipias infirmo, ut ponat caput suum in sinu tuo.	And it is necessary to prevent the patient from looking downwards.</start_of_turn
Deinde suspende illas uenas cum uncino uno, aut duobus secundum prudentiam tuam: et sit uncinus subtilis duplationis, secundum hanc formam, aut sint duo uncini gradat in corpore uno, secundum hanc formam.	Then suspend those waxes with one or two fingers, according to your prudence: and let the needle be thin as half the diameter, or two fingers together in one body, according to this form.</start_of_turn
Deinde collige cum forficibus subtilibus illas uenas cum subtilitate, et absterge sanguinem hora post horam, donec uideas illas uenas remoueri ex oculo, et resoluuntur: et caue ne laedas oculum cum extremitatibus spatumilis.	Then collect with fine forceps those waxes with attention, and wash away the blood an hour after an hour, until you know that those waxes have been removed from the eye, and have dissolved: and beware lest you damage the eye with the extremities of the forceps.</start_of_turn
Et sit operatio tua in meridie coram sole, et sis firmus in operatione tua ualde: ut non incidas nisi illas uenas.	And let your operation be in the middle of the day before the sun, and be firm in your operation, so that you do not cause any unnecessary damage.</start_of_turn
Et cum tu expleueris, tunc distilla in oculum sief uiride, aut rubeum: ut sua acuitate corrodat quod remansit ex sebel.	When you have finished, then distill into the eye a yellowish or reddish [substance]: so that its sharpness may eat away what remains of the swelling.
Si autem non est tibi possibile colligere illud totum in illa hora, tunc emplastra oculum cum eo, quod sedat dolorem oculi: et dimitte ipsum diebus aliquot, donec sedetur dolor eius: et securetur ab apostemate calido: deinde itera super ipsum secundum modum eundem, donec sanetur.	When if it is not possible to collect all of it in that hour, then plaster the eye with this, which will soothe the eye pain: and leave it for a few days until the pain subsides: and keep it away from heat: and repeat over it in the same way until it is healed.
Et haec est forma forficis.	This is the form of the forceps.
¶ De reductione Arissati ad nasum.	On the reduction of the swelling of the nose.
Caput XIX.	Chapter XIX.</start_of_turn>
Nominant medici Arissati Fistulam, quam curas cum cauterio, aut cum medicina acuta comburente, secundum quod praecessit eius narratio.	Physicians call the swelling of the nose a Fistula, which they treat with cautery or with acute medicine burning, according to what is appropriate for its nature.</start_of_turn>
Et si non sanatur, tunc non est ingenium in ea: nisi ut findas super apostema apud natiuitatem eius, et extrahas totam humiditatem quae est in eo et pus, donec detegatur os.	If it does not heal, then there is no wisdom in that: except that you find pus at the opening of its cavity, and you remove all the moisture which is in it and pus, until the bone is exposed.</start_of_turn
Cum ergo detegitur os, et uides in eo corruptionem, aut nigredinem, tunc rade ipsum cum instrumento, cuius forma est haec.	When the bone is thus exposed, and the wound is corrupted, or blackened, then smear it with an instrument which has this form.</start_of_turn
Et nominatur Asperi capitis.	This is called the Aspiration of the head.</start_of_turn
Fiat ex ferro indo, et sit caput eius rotundum sicut azir, quod sit punctatum punctatione limae, aut punctatione aliskilferi punctatione subtili: et pone ipsum super locum corruptum ossis.	Make it from iron, and let its head be rounded like an egg, which is pierced with the point of a lime, or with an awl, or with a fine puncture: and place it over the corrupted part of the bone.</start_of_turn
Deinde reuolue ipsum inter digitos tuos, et tu preme manum tuam parumper, donec scias quod illa corruptio iam rasa est: et fac illud aliquotiens.	Then draw it out between your fingers, and your hand close to you, until you know that that corruption is gone: and do this several times.</start_of_turn
Deinde restaura locum cum medicinis exiccatiuis stipticis.	Then restore the place with physicians skilled in stiptic substances.
Si ergo consolidatur locus, et nascitur in eo caro, et abscinditur cursus saniei: et remanet quadraginta diebus, et non renouatur, et non apostematur, et non accidit in eo accidens: tunc scias quia iam sanatus est.	If, however, the place is consolidated and a swelling arises in it, and the flow of the healthy substance is cut off: and it remains for forty days, and does not return, and does not break down, and does not happen in it any chance: then you know that it is healed.</start_of_turn>
Et si non, tunc non est in eo ingenium, nisi reducere fistulam ad foramen nasi, secundum hanc formam.	And if not, then it is not in it the faculty, except to reduce the fistula to the opening of the nose, according to this fashion.</start_of_turn>
Et est, ut detegas ab osse secundo cum ferro, aut cum medicina acuta: et cum detectum est os, tunc accipe terebrum secundum hanc formam, sit extremitas ferrea, triangulata: et lignum eius sit pyramis extenuata usque ad extremitatem, sicut uides.	And it is necessary to grasp the second bone with iron, or with acute medicine: and when it is grasped, then take hold of the prominence according to this fashion, so that the iron be at its extremity, triangular: and the wood of it be extended until the extremity, like water.</start_of_turn
Deinde pone illud super os ipsum: et sit illud prope lachrymale: et elonga manum tuam ab oculo parum.	Then place that upon the bone itself: and let it be close to the tear duct: and extend your hand from the eye a little.</start_of_turn
Deinde reuolue manum tuam cum terebro, donec penetret os, et sentiat illud infirmus: per hoc quod inuenit uentum exire ex eo, quando tenet manum suam super nasum suum.	Then withdraw your hand with the prominence, until it pierces the bone, and you feel it is inflamed: by this you will know that the flux has escaped from it, when you hold your hand over your nose.</start_of_turn
Ergo tunc restaura locum cum medicinis stipticis exiccantibus, sicut docui te.	Therefore, then restore the place with physicians skilled in stiptic substances, as I have taught you.</start_of_turn>
Cum ergo nascitur caro, et induratur locus: tunc materia quae effundebatur ad exteriora, redit ad nasum: est ergo leuius illud super infirmum.	When, however, a swelling arises in the carpus and the place is hardened: then the substance which flowed outwards returns to the nose: thus it is easier for it to lie over the inflamed.</start_of_turn
¶ De reductione eminentiae Oculi.	¶ On the reduction of the prominence of the eye.</start_of_turn>
Caput XX.	Chapter XX.</start_of_turn
Quando eminet Oculus cum totalitate sua, et non accidit in uisu nocumentum, neque diminutio: tunc oportet ut soluas infirmum: deinde phlebotomes eum: postea ponas uentosas in ceruice absque scarificatione, sed cum suctione.	When the eye is swollen with its entirety, and does not happen in any degree of swelling or diminution: then it is necessary to dissolve the inflammation: then perform phlebotomy on it: afterwards apply moist compresses to the eye without causing a scar, but with suction.</start_of_turn
Deinde pone super Oculum linimentum quod fit ex acacia, et aloe, et olibano, et sarcocolla.	Then apply over the eye a liniment made from acacia, aloe, olive oil, and ochre.
Deinde stringe Oculum desuper super emplastrum cum puluillis multis.	Then bind over the eye a patch with many little seeds
Et modus puluillorum est: ut accipias pannos lenes, multos, et duplicetur omnis pannus ex eis super quatuor: fac ex eis multos: deinde pone eos unum super alium, secundum quantitatem qua indiget Oculus: deinde stringe super ipsos cum panno duro strictura forti.	And as for the seeds, take fine wool, many, and double every thread over four: make many of them: then put one upon another, according to the quantity required for the eye: then bind over them with a strong piece of cloth.
Et itera uentosas cum suctione sine scarificatione.	And do this repeatedly with gentle suction without cutting
Deinde aufer uentosas, et dimitte oculum strictum die et nocte.	Then remove the swelling and keep the eye closed tightly day and night.
Si autem ligamentum iterum mollificatur, tunc oportet ut stringatur multum: deinde aufer ligamentum post diem et noctem, sicut diximus.	If, however, the ligament is again softened, then it must be tightly bound: then remove the ligament after a day and a night, as we have said
Si ergo uides oculum iam redisse uuae tunicae, est bonum: et si non, tunc itera emplastrum, et puluillos, et stricturam, et uentosas, donec sanetur.	If thus you see the eye again red, then it is good: and if not, then repeat the patch, the seeds, and the binding, and the swelling, until it is healed
¶ De incisionie Vuae tunicae.	Of incision of the edge of the eye
Caput XXI.	Chapter 21.
Quando accidit disruptio in tunica Vuea, deinde eminet et procedit extra palpebras sicut granum Vuae, et foedatur forma hominis propter illud, et uis incidere illud: tunc operatio in eo est, secundum quod narro: et est, ut intromittas acum in radice Vuae ab inferiori ad superiorem partem.	When disruption occurs in the membrane of the eye, then it will protrude and proceed outside the eyelids like a grain of sand, and will be deformed like a man because of that, and you must cut it out: then the operation in this is as we have said, and it is that you introduce the needle into the root of the eye from the lower part to the upper part
Deinde intromitte acum aliam in qua sit filum duplum a parte lachrymalis, et fac eam penetrare: et dimitte acum primam secundum dispositionem suam.	And introduce another needle into which there is a double thread from the lachrymal part, and make it penetrate: and withdraw the first needle according to its position.
Deinde incide locum fili dupli, et liga cum eo partem Vuae in circumitu acus: et stringe eam multum.	Then pierce the place of the double thread, and bind with it the edge of the eye around the needle: and bind it tightly
Deinde extrahe acum, et pone super oculum lanam infusam in albugine oui: et dimitte eum, donec cadat filum cum Vua.	Then extract the thorn, and place above the eye a wool plug soaked in alum: and let it go, until the thread comes out with you.
Deinde cura oculum cum eo, quod confortat ipsum, donec sanetur uulnus.	Then care for the eye with this, which soothes it, until the wound is healed.</start_of_turn>
Et quandoque stringitur Vua ab omni parte cum circulo ex panno, donec addat oculus eminentiam magnam.	And when the thread is drawn out from all around with a circle of cloth, until the eye regains its great prominence.</start_of_turn>
Deinde perforetur cum spatumili subtili, quod perueniat ad profundum oculi, et currat humiditas albuginea, et descendat oculus, et ingrediatur statim: deinde stringe eum, donec sanetur.	Then perforate with a fine needle which will reach the depth of the eye, and smear moist albumin, and let the eye go down, and immediately insert: then draw it out, until it is healed.</start_of_turn>
¶ De curatione Alcomnati.	And for the care of the eye.</start_of_turn>
Caput XXII.	Chapter XXII.</start_of_turn
Haec Aegritudo quae nominatur Alcomnati, non, est nisi sanies, quae aggregatur in oculo, similis aquae descendenti, et non est ipsa.	This ailment which is called Alcomnati, is not other than health which collects in the eye, like water which descends, and is not itself.</start_of_turn
Et modus operandi in ea est, ut facias sedere infirmum super sedem praeparatum, uel directum.	And the way of dealing with it is that you make the patient sit on a prepared seat, or directly.</start_of_turn
Deinde accipe caput eius manibus tuis a partibus duabus, et moue ipsum, donec uideas saniem peruenire ad inferiora oculis tuis.	Then grasp his head with your hands from both sides, and move it, until you see health go up to the lower parts of your eyes.</start_of_turn
Deinde figatur, et non descendat, et absoluatur lumen: et uideat infirmus res sicut uidebat: et si non descendit inferius, scias quia est aqua.	Then stabilize it, and do not let it go down, and open your eyes: and he will see as he saw before: and if it does not go down below, you know that it is water.</start_of_turn
Si autem non praeparatur descensus saniei cum eo quod diximus, tunc fac sedere infirmum inter manus tuas.	If however you do not prepare the descent of health with that which we have said, then make the patient sit between your hands.</start_of_turn
Deinde accipe spatumile subtile, et finde cum eo supra panniculum corneum parumper apud continuationem coniunctiuae cum tunica cornea in corona, donec egrediatur sanies.	Then grasp a fine needle, and find with it above the cornical membrane a part of the conjunctiva which is close to the cornea in a circle, until health comes out.</start_of_turn
Cum ergo egreditur, tunc distilla in oculum aquam calidam in qua miscuisti mel: aut aquam in qua iam bullisti foenumgraecum et mel: deinde curetur cum reliqua curatione, donec sanetur.	When the patient departs, then let warm water be distilled into the eye which has been mixed with honey: or water in which barley chaff has been boiled with honey. Then let it be treated with the remaining treatment until the patient is healed.
¶ De cura aquae, quae descendit in oculo, uel cataracta.	Concerning the treatment of water which descends into the eye, or for a cataract.
Caput XXIII.	This section is missing from the provided text.
Iam Diximus species aquae in diuisione, et quae conuenit ad perforandum sermone declarante et exponente, tunc accipe illud idem secundum sanitatem.	We have said concerning the species of water in the making of an eye-wash, and which is suitable for the perforation which is declared and shown, then take that which is appropriate according to the health.
Tunc ergo oportet ut facias sedere infirmum inter manus tuas quadratum, oppositum lumini, prope solem: et liga oculum eius sanum, et stringe eum ualde: deinde palpebram oculi eius manu tua dextra, si oculus in quo est aqua, est oculus sinister: aut manu tua sinistra, si oculus est dexter.	Then let the patient sit with his hands square between yours, opposite the light, near the cheek: and bind his healthy eye, and draw it tightly: then take the outer corner of his eye with your right hand, if the eye which has the water in it is the left: or take the outer corner of his eye with your left hand, if the eye which has the water in it is the right
Deinde accipe manu tua dextra almagda, si oculus est sinister: aut manu tua sinistra, si oculus est dexter.	Then take your right hand with the almond, if the eye is left: or your left hand with the almond, if the eye is right
Deinde pone extremitatem almagda prope coronam per grossitudinem radii in ipsa albedine oculi apparente lachrymalis minoris: deinde impelle almagda cum uirtute: et tu reuoluis cum eo manum tuam, donec penetret in albuginem oculi: et sentias, quod almagda iam peruenit ad rem uacuam.	Then place the edge of the almond close to the edge of the pupil along the apparent white of the eye: then push the almond with force: and you will know that the almond has reached the bottom of the eye when you feel that the almond has gone past the edge of the pupil
Et oportet, ut sit mensura itineris almagda ad profundum, mensura spacii quod est a pupilla usque ad finem nigredinis: et est corona oculi.	And it is necessary that the measure of the journey of the almond be to the depth, the measure of the space from the pupil to the end of the black: and this is the rim of the eye
Uidebis enim ea in ipsa pupilla uisione oculi, propter claritatem tunicae corneae.	You will see this in the pupil of the eye by the clarity of the cornea.
Deinde pone almagda usque ad locum in quo est aqua.	Then place the almond until it reaches the place where the water is
Deinde preme ipsum inferius uice una post aliam.	Then immediately the lower part after the upper part.
Si ergo descendit aqua statim, tunc infirmus uidet illud super quod aperit uisum suum statim, et almagda in oculo suo.	If water therefore descends immediately, then the sick person will immediately suffer over that which he has opened up, and the swelling will be in his eye.
Deinde quiescas paululum.	Then rest a little while.
Si ergo descendat aqua, tunc depone eam secundo, praeter quod egrediatur almagda.	If water therefore descends, then draw out the second part except for what is coming out with the swelling.
Quando ergo figitur, et non ascendit: tunc extrahe almagda cum facilitate: et tu reuoluis manum tuam paulatim.	When it has become firm, and does not ascend: then draw out the swelling easily: and you will gradually turn your hand back
Deinde dissolue in aqua aliquid ex sale claro gemmae: et ablue cum eo oculum deintus.	Then dissolve on water some of the clear salt of the gem: and wash with it when the eye is closed
Deinde pone extra oculum totum stuppam, aut lanam infusam oleo rosato, et albugine oui: et liga cum eo oculum sanum.	Then put on the whole eye a cushion, or wool infused with rose oil, and alum: and bind with it the healthy eye.
Nos autem, et illi qui sunt nostri temporis, ponimus super eum ciminum tritum cum albumine oui.	But we, and those who are with us at this time, put on over it a rough cloth with alum and egg white.
Quod si non obedit tibi almagda ad introitum in oculum propter duriciem suam, quoniam ex hominibus est, cuius oculus est durus ualde: tunc oportet ut accipias spatumile, quod nominatur Alberid, cuius haec est forma.	And if the swelling does not obey you to enter the eye because of its hardness, because it is from a man whose eye is hard and cold: then it is necessary that you take a sponge, which is called Alberid, which has this form
Pefora ergo cum eo ipsam coniunctiuam tantum, et non ultimes manum tuam in foramine: et non est nisi ut facias uiam ad almagda locum subtilem.	Wash therefore with it the eye itself joined together, and do not move your hand to the bottom: and do not do anything except make the swelling lie in a low place
Deinde intromitte almagda, secundum quod diximus.	Then introduce the swelling, as we have said before
Et apud complementum operis tui, praeparetur infirmo dormitorium decenter factum, in quo dormiat super dorsum suum in domo tenebrosa: et prohibeatur ab omnibus motibus, et a tussi: et pone cibum eius illud quo lenitur natura eius: et non moueat caput suum dextra, neque sinistra omnino.	And in order to complete your work, prepare the sick person a resting place made in the center, in which he will sleep on his back in a dark room: and prevent him from all movements, and from coughing: and give him food for his nourishment: and do not move his head to the right or to the left at all.
Et sit ligamentum secundum dispositionem suam usque ad diem tertium.	The ligament should remain in its usual position until the third day.
Deinde solue illud in illa domo tenebrosa, et experire uisum eius: et fac eum uidere res.	Then loosen it in the dark chamber and try its action: and make it useful for something.
Deinde reduc ligamentum usque ad diem septimum.	Then reduce the ligament until the seventh day.
Et non oportet ut faciat illud in hora curationis, aut post incisionem statim: imo oportet, ut alienes illud: propterea quod aqua ascendit uelociter per aspectum uehementem.	It should not be forced at the time of care, nor immediately after incision: indeed it should be delayed, because water ascends quickly through the open wound
Si autem accidit apostema calidum: tunc oportet ut soluas oculum ante septimum: et rectifica illud cum eo quod sedat apostema, donec sedatur: tunc absolue ipsius uisum, et pone super faciem eius orale quo regatur uisus eius sub eo diebus aliquot, ipso existente in illa domo tenebrosa.	If however a black swelling occurs: then it is necessary to loosen the eye before the seventh day: and correct it when the swelling has subsided: then the action of the medicine will remain, and put over its face a quantity of the medicine which was previously placed in the dark chamber
Deinde egrediatur a domo gradatim, et conuersetur in casis suis.	Then depart from the dark chamber gradually, and return to your home.
Et scias, quod in zaltea non excusatur discipulus a uisione aliquotiens: tunc enim audeat super operationem.	You know that in the hospital a disciple is not excused from seeing the doctor several times: then indeed he will learn about the operation.
Et iam quidem peruenit ad nos quidam ex illis qui sunt de Alayrach, qui dixit, quod factum fuit in Alayrach magdan perforatum, quo sugitur aqua.	And indeed it came to pass that some of those from Alayrach reported that in Alayrach there was a perforation of the bladder, through which water was flowing out
Verum ergo non uidi aliquem in terra uostra, qui fecerit illud: neque legi illud in aliquo ex libris antiquorum: et est possibile, ut sit illud nouum.	Truly no one in our land has ever done this: neither have I read of it in any of the ancient books: and it is possible that it is a new thing.
Et istae sunt formae specierum ex magda, ut stet super ea qui ea ignorat.	These are the forms of the spirits from the madhouse, as they linger over those who ignore them
Fiant ex aere proprie: et sint extremitates eorum cum hac eadem subtilitate triangulatae, et extremitas acuta.	Let them be of air of their own: and their extremities with the same triangular shape, and acute extremities
Formae magda.	The shapes of madmen.
¶ De cura Carnis natae in naso.	On the care of the newly born in the nose
Caput XXIIII.	Chapter XXVIIV.
Quandoque nascuntur in naso Carnes diuersae additae, ex quibus est aliquid quod assimilatur scorpioni multorum pedum: et ex ea est caro cancerosa, lapidea, fusci coloris: et ex ea est quae est caro lenis, non fusci coloris.	When various meats are added to the nose of a Carnes, from which there is something that is absorbed by many scorpions' feet: from this there is a cancerous tumor, a stone, and a fleshy color: from this there is what is a soft tumor, not fleshy colored.
In ea ergo quae ex istis carnibus est lenis, non fraudulenta, neque cancerosa, oportet ut facias sedere infirmum inter manus tuas oppositum soli, et aperi nares eius, et proiice uncinum in illas carnes: deinde trahe eas ad exteriora, et incide quod comprehendisti ex eis cum spatumili subtili acuto a parte una, donec scias quod caro tota iam ablata est.	In this, therefore, which is soft, not fraudulent, neither cancerous, should be made to sit between your hands opposite the solid part, and open its nose, and expel the tongue into those meats: then draw them outwards, and cut away what you have seen with a fine and sharp knife from one side, until you know that the whole flesh has been removed
Quod si remaneret aliquid ex ea cuius abscisio non est possibilis: tunc rade illud cum uno instrumentorum subtilium cum facilitate, donec non remaneat ex eo aliquid.	What if anything remains of that from whose excision is impossible: then cut that away with a fine instrument with ease, until nothing remains of it
Si autem sanguis tibi dominatur, aut accidat apostema calidum: tunc oppone ei per id quod oportet: aut est ex apostematibus malignis, tunc propera cauterizando eum, donec abscindatur sanguis, et auferantur omnes carnes.	If, however, blood dominates you, or a thick clot adheres: then oppose it with that which is suitable: or with malignant clots, then cauterize it until the blood is separated, and remove all the meats.
Deinde proiiciatur in nasum post incisionem acetum, et aqua, aut uinum.	Then spit into the nose after the incision of the flesh, and water, or liquid.
Si autem aperitur nasus, et procedat ex eo humiditas usque ad palatum, tunc scias quia iam sanus est.	If, however, the nose opens, and there proceeds from it moisture up to the palate, then you know that it is already healed.
Si uero non penetrat humiditas, secundum quod oportet, tunc scias quod intra ipsum est caro nata in superioribus ossibus naris, ad quae non peruenit cum incisione instrumentum.	If, however, moisture does not penetrate, according to what is suitable, then you know that the flesh has been born inside the upper bones of the nose, which does not come out with the incision of the instrument.
Tunc ergo oportet, ut intromittas filum lini cui sit quaedam grossitudo, et noda in eo nodos multos: et pone inter omnem nodum quantitatem digiti, aut minus: et ingeniet infirmus, ut mittat extremitatem unam fili in nasum cum radio, aut cum quo possibile est ei postquam fecerit ipsum simile azer: et trahat odoratum suum, donec perueniat usque ad caassum, et egrediatur super guttur suum.	Then, therefore, you must introduce a thread with some thickness into which there are many knots: and put between every knot as much as a digit, or less: and the infirm person will grasp, so that he may send one end of the thread into the nose with a hook, or in whatever way is possible for him to do so after he has made it similar to an ass: and he will draw out the foul matter until it reaches the caulking, and it will go out through the mouth.
Et multotiens quidem faciunt simile huic Attomi pueri in scholis: et est res facilis ei, qui uult.	Many, indeed, do like him in schools, this Attomi boy: it is an easy matter for him who wishes.
Deinde pone duas extremitates fili, extremitatem unam quae egreditur super nasum, et alteram quae remansit in naso.	Then place two extremities of the boy, one which projects beyond the nose, and the other which remains in the nose
Deinde ac ministra serraturam carnis cum nodis qui sunt in filo.	Then grasp the flesh with the minister and close the wound with knots that are in the limb.
Fac illud donec scias quod carnes iam sunt cum nodis fili.	Do this until you know that the flesh is again with the knots of the limb.
Deinde extrahe filum: et pone in nasum post abstersionem sanguinis licinium quod imbibisti in unguento aegyptio: fac illud tribus diebus, aut plus, donec unguentum corrodat totum quod remansit ex carnibus.	Then draw out the thread: and put it in the nose after you have washed away the blood with vinegar which you have drunk in Egyptian unguent: do this for three days, or more, until the unguent has eaten away all that remains of the flesh.
Deinde pone in fine rei in nasum cannulam de plumbo, diebus aliquot, donec sanetur.	Then put at the end of the thing in the nose a lead cannula for a few days, until it heals.
Si autem indiget curatione quae exiccet, utere illa.	If, however, you think that further treatment is required, do so by all means
Ad caputpurgium faciendum, cum quo distillantur olea, et aliae medicinae in nasum, fac illud ex argento, aut aere: quod sit simile lampadi paruae, apertum sicut conchula: et meatus eius similiter.	For the head of the wound must be made with that with which the oils are distilled, and other medicines in the nose, do this of silver, or of brass: and make its passage like that of the horn of a snail, opened like a conch: and the opening of it like that of a lentil
Et si uis fac cannulam clausam, sicut canna.	And if you wish to make a closed cannula, like a tube
Et conchula instrumenti ad caputpurgium faciendum, sit plena, detecta: cui sit manubrium in postremo eius, cum quo teneas ipsam, quando calefacis in ea oleum, aut quod uis ex succis, et rebus fluxibilibus.	And the cannula for the instrument for making the head of the wound must be full, detected: which has a handle at its back, with which you grasp it, when you heat it in oil, or which you wish to take from succus, and from fluid blood
Et haec est forma instrumenti.	This is the form of the instrument.
¶ De cura Thelul nasi.	Concerning the care of the eye of the nose
Caput XXV.	Chapter XXV.
Multotiens nascitur in extremitate nasi Thelul, et magnificatur, et augmentatur cum diebus, donec foedus fit aspectus eius.	Many are born at the extremity of the nose Thelul, and grow large, and increase with the days until the wound becomes like its aspect.
Et propter illud oportet, ut in cidas illud in principio apparitionis eius, et eradices totum eius.	Therefore it is necessary to cauterise it at the beginning of its appearance, and to drain all of it.</start_of_turn>
Deinde pone super locum, aut cauterium, aut medicinam comburentem quae stat loco eius.	Then place above it either a cautery or a burning medicine which is at its place.</start_of_turn>
Si ergo tardatur incisio eius, donec magnificetur, tunc considera, si est lapideum, durum, fusci coloris, pauci sensus: tunc non tangas ipsum cum ferro: quoniam apostema est cancerosum.	If, however, its incision is slow to take effect while it grows large, then consider whether it is a stone, hard, of the colour of pitch, with little sensation: then do not touch it with iron: for it is cancerous.</start_of_turn>
Multotiens enim uidi, qui incidit hmoni apostema, et accidit ex eo malicia magna super illum qui ipsum habebat.	Many are born from the blood which flows from the wound, and from it comes great malice over the light which it had.</start_of_turn>
Et si apostema est lenis tactus, non fusci coloris, et uides quod incisio possibilis est in toto eius, tunc euacua infirmum, et incide ipsum sine timore, absque pauore: et cura locum cum eo quod exiccat et constringit, donec sanetur.	If indeed the wound is soft to the touch, not of the colour of pitch, and the blood which flows from it is possible to make an incision throughout, then evacuate the sick person and make the incision without fear, without pain: and care for the place with that which covers and binds it until it heals.</start_of_turn>
¶ De sutura nasi, et labii, et auris.	Of the suture of the nose, and the lip, and the ear.</start_of_turn
Caput XXVI.	Chapter XXVI.</start_of_turn>
Scias Quia quando accidit solutio continuitatis in una harum cartilaginum, parum confert in ea operatio, nisi in quibusdam hominibus.	You know that when a solution of continuity is made in one of these cartilages, it is little useful in this operation, except in some people.</start_of_turn
Oportet ergo quando accidit alicui aliquid ex illo, ut consideres, si est uulnus recens cum sanguine suo: et tunc aggrega duolabia uulneris cum sutura: deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	It is necessary therefore when anything is done to it, that you consider whether there is a wound which runs with its blood: and then join together the edges of the wound with a suture: then care for it until it heals.</start_of_turn
Et si solutionis continuitatis labia iam separata sunt, et facta est unaquaeque pars sana: tunc oportet ut excories omnem partem a cute sua apparente, donec sanguinetur.	And if the solution of continuity of the lip has been separated and is made whole once more: then it is necessary to scour every part from its outer surface until it bleeds.</start_of_turn
Deinde aggrega duo labia cum sutura, et stringe ea, et pulueriza super ipsum sanguinem draconis, et olibanum trita: et pone supra pulueres frustum emplastri diafinicon, et alicuius alterius ex emplastris consolidatiuis: et dimitte ipsum ligatum duobus diebus, aut tribus.	Then join two lips together with a suture, draw them tight, and sprinkle above them the blood of a dragon, and olibanum that has been triturated: and place above the sprinkles a fragment of diafinicon plaster, and some other solid plaster: and leave the ligation for two days, or three.
Deinde solue ipsum, et permuta medicinam: et dimitte ipsum, donec abscindantur fila per se.	Then remove it, and change the medicine: and leave it until the stitches dissolve by themselves.
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguento, donec sanetur.	Then care for it with unguents, until it heals.
Modus autem suturae est, ut aggreges solutionem continuitatis, aut cum acubus, sicut narrauimus in sutura uentris: aut aggrega solutionem cum filo, sicut feci te scire.	The way of stitching is that you join together the solution of continuity, or with a lump, as we have narrated in the gut suture: or join the solution with the thread, as you have been told.
¶ De extractione nodorum labiorum.	Regarding the extraction of lip nodes.
Caput XXVII.	Chapter XXVII.</start_of_turn>
Multis Quidem hominibus accidunt plaerumque in interioribus labiorum suorum apostemata dura similia granis herbi: et quaedam eorum minora, et maiora.	Many people have these things happen to them in the insides of their lips, behind their teeth, things that are like hard grains of herbs: and some of them are small, and some are large.</start_of_turn>
Ergo oportet ut conuertas labium, et findas super omnem nodum eius, et suspendas ipsum cum uncino, et incidas ipsum ab omni parte.	Therefore it is necessary to cover the lips, and find on every node of them, and suspend it with a hook, and cut it away from all sides.</start_of_turn
Deinde impleas locum post incisionem zegi trito, donec abscindatur sanguis.	Then put on the place of the incision a piece of burnt alum, until the blood has clotted.</start_of_turn
Deinde colluatur cum aceto, et curetur locus cum eo, in quo est stipticitas, usquequo sanentur uulnera.	Then bandage it with vinegar, and care for the place with it, in which there is styptic action, until the wound has healed.</start_of_turn>
¶ De incisione carnis natae super gingiuam.	Regarding the incision of the natural flesh over the gums.</start_of_turn>
Caput XXVIII.	Chapter XXVIII.</start_of_turn
Multotiens nascitur super gingiuam caro addiat, quam antiqui nominant abuluss.	Many things are born on the gums, flesh that the ancients call abuluss.</start_of_turn
Oportet ergo ut suspendas eam cum uncino: aut teneas eam cum forcipibus, et incidas eam apud radicem suam, et dimittas saniem currere, aut sanguinem.	It is necessary therefore that you suspend the bowels with a single hook: either grasp them with forceps, and cut them at their root, and let the bowels go, or let the blood flow out.
Deinde pone super locum zegi tritum, aut alios pulueres stipticos, exiccatiuos.	Then place over the place of injury a piece of charcoal or other absorbent powder, and dry it out.
Quod si redit illa caro post curationem, nam multotiens redit, tunc incide eam secundo, et cauteriza ipsam: ipsa namque non redit post cauterium.	If the flesh returns after the treatment, for it does not often return, then cut through it again, and burn it: for it will not return after being burned.</start_of_turn>
¶ De rasione Dentium cum ferro.	Regarding the wisdom of using a tooth with a iron.</start_of_turn>
Caput XXIX.	Chapter XXIX.</start_of_turn>
Quandoque aggregantur in superficiebus Dentium ab interiori et extetiori parte, et inter gingiuas cortices asperi, turpes, et quandoque denigrantur, et citrini fiunt, et uirides, donec peruenit ex illo corruptio ad gingiuam, et foedi fiunt dentes per illud.	When these things gather on the surfaces of the teeth from the inside and outside, and between the gums, the enamel becomes rough, black, and sometimes decays, and cavities appear, and the teeth become yellow until the corruption reaches the gum, and cavities form in the teeth from this.</start_of_turn
Oportet ergo ut facias sedere infirmum inter manus tuas, et caput eius in sinu tuo, et rade molam et dentem, in quo apparent tibi cortices, et res similis arenae: donec non remaneat ex eis aliquid, et similiter fac de nigredine, et uiriditate, et citrinitate, et aliis donec mundentur.	It is necessary therefore that you make the infirm man sit between your hands, and hold his head in your lap, and move the tongue and the tooth, in which you see the enamel, and things like sand: until something remains from that, and do the same with black material, and yellowing, and cavities, and other things until the matter is cleansed.</start_of_turn
Si ergo auferatur quod in eis est a principio rasionis, bonum est: et si non, tunc itera super eos rasionem die alio, secundo, et tertio, donec ad ultimum perueniat studium in eo quod uis.	If therefore that which is in the matter from the beginning of the wisdom is taken away, it is good: and if not, then repeat the wisdom day by day, second, and third, until the study is finally completed in that which you wish.</start_of_turn
Et scias, quod dens indiget rasoriis diuersarum formarum, multarum figurarum: secundum quod praeparatur operationi tuae: proptera, quod rasorium quo raditur dens ab inferiori parte, est aliud a rasorio quo raditur inter dentes, secundum formas alias.	And you know that teeth need various razors of different forms, many figures: according to the way you prepare the operation.</start_of_turn
Et istae formae rasoriorum sint apud te praeparatae, quas uides.	These forms of razors are at your disposal.
¶ De extractione doloris Dentium.	These forms of razors are ready at your disposal.
Caput XXX.	Chapter XXX
Oportet ut cures Dentem a dolore suo cum omni ingenio, et tardes in eradicatione eius.	It is necessary to extract the tooth from its pain with every skill, and to follow this up by eradicating it
Non est enim quod uicem eius suppleat quando eradicatur: quoniam est substantia sublimis: donec quando non est excusatio de eradicatione eius, tunc oportet quando cogitur infirmus eradicare ipsum, ut firmetur, et certificetur apud te dens dolens.	There is nothing that can replace its extraction when it is eradicated: for it is a sublime substance: except when there is no excuse for its eradication, then it is necessary to order the sick man to eradicate it himself, so that it is confirmed, and certified to you that the toothache has ceased
Multotiens enim decipit infirmum dolor, et putat quia est in dente saha et eradicat ipsum: deinde non recedit dolor, donec eradicetur dens infirmus.	Many times the sick man feels the pain and thinks that it is in the tooth and eradicates it: but the pain does not cease until the diseased tooth is eradicated itself
Nos enim iam uidimus illud ex operatione phlebotomatorum.	We do not go about this from the performance of phlebotomies
Cum ergo certificatur apud te dens dolens ipsemet, tunc oportet ut scarifices in circumitu dentis cum spatumili, in quo sit quiddam uirtutis, donec soluatur gingiua ab omni parte: deinde moue ipsum digitis tuis, aut cum forcipibus subtilibus in primis paulatim, donec concutias ipsum.	When it has been certified to you that the toothache itself is present, then it is necessary to make incisions around the tooth with sponges, in which there is some art, until the gums are separated from every part: then move the tooth with your fingers, or with fine forceps at first slowly, until you have severed it
Deinde loca tunc in eo forcipes magnos locatione bona, et caput infirmi inter genua tua: quod iam bene tenuisti, ita quod non moueatur: deinde trahe dentem secundum rectitudinem, ut non frangas ipsum.	Then place the forceps in a good location and grasp the head of the patient between your knees: which you have held firmly, so that it does not move: then draw out the tooth according to its direction, so that you do not break it
Si ergo non egreditur, tunc accipe aliquod illorum instrumentorum, et intromitte ipsum sub eo ab omni parte cum facilitate, et conare motionem eius, sicut fecisti in primis.	If it does not come out, then take some of those instruments and introduce them under it from every part with ease, and make an attempt to move it, as you did at first
Si autem dens est perforatus, aut corrosus: tunc oportet ut impleas illud foramen panno: et stringas ipsum cum extremitate radii subtilis, ut non frangatur in hora constrictionis tuae super ipsum cum forcipibus.	If the tooth is perforated or corroded: then it is necessary to fill the hole with gauze: and tie it with a fine thread, so that it does not break in the hour of your constriction with the forceps
Et oportet, ut exquisite agas cum scarificatione in circumitu gingiuae ab omni parte multum.	It is necessary that the skilled surgeon go round about the circumference of the wound many times with the scalpel.
Et custodi fortitudinem tuam, ut non frangas ipsum, et remaneat pars eius, et redeat super infirmum ex ea malicia quae sit maior dolore eius primo.	Beware lest you break the thing, and leave some of it, and return above the diseased part from the greatest pain which is in it at first
Et caue, ne facias illud quod ignorantes faciunt phlebotomatores in festinatione sua, et audacia ipsorum super eradicationem eius, praeter quod administrent illud quod narrauimus.	Take heed, lest you do that which the unskilled do, like phlebotomists in their pride, and overconfidence concerning its extermination, beyond what we have said.
Multotiens enim faciunt euenire super homines infirmitates magnas, quarum difficiliores sunt ut frangantur, et remaneant radices eius omnes, aut quaedam earum: aut ut extrahant ipsum cum quibusdam ossibus mandibulae: sicut testificati sumus multotiens illud.	Many indeed do this with great men in their sickness, of whom some are difficult to break, and remain with all their roots, or that they extract the whole with some of the jaw-bones: as we have heard from many people
Deinde colluatur post eradicationem eius cum uino, aut cum aceto et sale.	Then it is to be joined after its extermination with wine, or with vinegar and salt
Quod si accidat fluxus sanguinis ex locis (multotiens enim accidit) tunc tere aliquid ex zegi, et imple cum eo locum: et si non, cauteriza ipsum si non confert tibi zegi.	If blood flows from the place (for many indeed do so), then there is something from the vessel there, and put a pledget there: and if not, cauterize it if it does not suffice to clot the blood
Formae forcipum subtilium quibus mouetur dens in primis, sint longarum extremitatum, breuis manubrii, grossi, ut non duplicentur quando cum eis premitur super dentem: sint sicut uides grossorum manubriorum, donec quando stringis cum eis, non dent seipsas, neque duplicentur: breuium extremitatum, et sint ex ferro indo, aut ex faled decenter facti, directarum extremitatum: et in eorum extremitatibus sint dentes, quorum quidam ingrediantur in quosdam, et stringant constrictione decenti, forti.	The forceps which are used to grasp the tooth in the first place are of subtle form, their handles are long, their thumbs are short, their bodies are thick, so that they do not double up when pressure is put on them when they are pressed against the tooth: they are like the claws of large men, until when they are bound to the tooth, they do not bite themselves, neither do they double up: their thumb is short, and they are made of iron or of lead that has been hollowed out in the middle, their handles are straight, and in their extremities are teeth, some of which are contained in others, and they bind the constriction loosely, firmly
Et quandoque fiunt extremitates sicut forma oris auis quae nominatur ciconia, et sunt fortis constrictionis.	And when the extremities are like the beak of a bird called a ciconia, and are strong constrictions.
¶ De eradicatione Dentium, et extractione ossium mandibularum fractorum.	On the eradication of wisdom teeth, and the extraction of fractured bones of the mandible.
Caput XXXI.	On the eradication of wisdom teeth, and the extraction of fractured bones of the mandible.
Quando remanet apud eradicationem Dentis qui frangitur aliquid, tunc oportet ut ponas super locum cotum cum butyro die uno, aut duobus diebus, donec mollificetur locus: deinde intromitte ad ipsum algasti, aut forcipes: quorum extremitates assimilantur ori auis quae nominatur ciconia.	When remains remain after the eradication of a tooth which has fractured something, then it is necessary to place butter on the place of the fracture for one or two days, until the place is softened: then introduce into the wound, or forceps: the extremities of which absorb the origin of the pain which is called ciconia.
Forma autem haec est forcipum.	The form of these forceps is as follows.
Sint extremitates eorum factae sicut lima deintus: aut sicut aliskilfegi.	The extremities of these forceps are made like a file, or like an awl
Si ergo non obedit tibi ad exitum cum istis forcipibus, tunc oportet, ut caues super radicem, et detegas carnem totam, et intromittas instrumentum quod nominatur Palanca parua, cuius forma est haec.	If therefore these forceps do not suffice for the extraction with these teeth, then it is necessary to place the forceps above the root, and to remove the whole flesh, and to introduce the small hook, which is called Palanca, whose form is as follows
Sit breuis extremitatis, grossae parumper: et non sit imbibitum, ut non frangatur.	Its short handle and large head: and it is not bent, so that it does not break
Si ergo egreditur radix per illud, est bonum: et si non, iuuare oportet cum istis instrumentis aliis quorum formae sunt istae.	If therefore the root comes out through that, it is good: and if not, it is necessary to pull with other instruments whose form is like these
Forma primi triangulatae extremitatis, in qua est quaedam grossitudo.	The first triangular-shaped extremity, in which there is some thickness
Forma triangulatae extremitatis subtilis.	The second triangular-shaped extremity is thin
Etiam iuuatur cum hoc instrumento habente duos ramos, cuius haec est forma.	It is also used with this instrument which has two branches, whose form is as follows
Et cum aliis instrumentis et ferramentis quae praecesserunt in rasione dentium.	And with other instruments and materials which are necessary in the case of teeth.
Etiam sit iuuamentum cum hoc instrumento quod assimilatur uncino magno, huius formae, triangulatae extremitatis tortae, in qua est quiddam grossitudinis, ut non frangatur: et sit non imbibitum.	It is also necessary to grasp with this instrument which absorbs a large stone, of this form, triangular-shaped extremity twisted, in which there is some thickness, so that it does not break: and it is not bent
Et scias, quod instrumenta dentium sunt multa: et similiter reliqua instrumenta non computantur, et artifex prudens, subtilis in arte sua inuenit per se ipsum instrumentum, secundum quod significant ei operatio et aegritudines ipsae.	And know this, that the instruments for teeth are many: and like all other instruments, they do not work alike. And a skilled artificer, experienced in his art, discovers for himself the appropriate instrument for each operation and each ailment.
Quoniam ex agritudinibus sunt ad quas non dixerunt antiqui instrumentum, propter diuersitatem specierum earum.	For indeed, from the ailments for which the ancients did not speak of an instrument, because of the variety of their kinds.
Si autem frangatur os ex mandibula, aut ex aliis ossibus oris, aut putrefit: tunc perscrutare super ipsum in loco suo cum eo quod conuenit ei ex instrumentis et forcipibus quae dixi in extractione radicum, et iuuare cum gesti, cuius forma est haec.	If, however, the jawbone be fractured from the mandible, or from any other bone of the mouth, or putrefy: then he must consider concerning himself with the thing itself in its place with that which is suitable for it among the instruments and forceps which I mentioned in the extraction of roots, and to handle it with his hands, whose form is like this
Sit in eo quiddam grossitudinis paulatim, ut stringatur, uel teneatur cum eo os, et non fugiat et uadat, donec egrediatur os: et restaura locum cum medicinis conuenientibus ad illud.	So be it of some measure that it may be stretched out, or held with it against the bone, and not flee and wander, until the bone is extracted: and restore the place with the physicians who are accustomed to this.
Si autem in osse est putredo parua, tunc rade ipsum a putredine sua, et cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	If, however, there is a little pus in the bone, then remove the pus from it, and care for it, until it is healed.
De serratura Dentium eminentium super alios.	Concerning the closure of teeth which are prominent over others.
Caput XXXII.	Chapter 2.
Quando Dentes eminent non secundum cursum suum naturalem, foeda fit per illud forma: et praecipue quando accidit illud in mulieribus, et puellis, scilicet uenalibus.	When teeth protrude not according to their natural course, an ulcer forms by that shape: and especially when it happens in women and girls, since it is in their gums
Oportet ergo ut consideres.	Therefore he must consider concerning himself with it
Nam si dens est natus post dentem alium, et non locatur, uel est possibilis eius serratura, neque limatura ipsius: tunc eradica ipsum: et si est annexus cum dente alio, tunc incide ipsum cum isto instrumento, cuius haec est forma.	Because if a tooth has been born after another tooth, and is not placed, or if it is possible to suture it, or to file it down: then extract it: and if it is joined to another tooth, then cut it with this instrument, whose form is like this
Est simile rostro paruo, et fit ex ferro indo, acutae extremitatis ualde.	It is like a small face, made of iron, with a sharp edge at the end
Et sit incisio tua qua ipsum incidis in diebus multis, et propter duriciem dentis, et ut non commoueatur alius ex dentibus.	And let your incision be such as that which you make on many days, because of the hardness of the tooth, and that it does not damage any other tooth.
Si autem est eminens expositus limaturae suae: tunc lima ipsum cum lima ex indo, cuius forma est haec.	If however the exposed edge of the lamina be imminent: then file that with a file of the same shape as that
Sit totum ex indo, et manubrium eius minutorum punctorum ualdae, sicut lima cum qua fiunt acus: cum quo limetur dens paulatim in diebus multis cum facilitate, ut non commoueatur dens, et cadat: deinde leni ipsum, in fine rade ipsum cum quibusdam rasoriis.	And let the whole of the handle of the file be minor than the points of the nails, in such manner as a file is to an awl: so that the tooth may be ground away gradually in many days with ease, without damaging the tooth, and falling out: then afterwards smooth it, at the end sharpen it with some rasps.
Quod si est dens, ex quo frangatur pars, et laedit linguam: tunc oportet ut limes eum etiam, donec auferatur asperitas illius fractionis, et aequetur: et applanetur, et non laedat linguam, neque corrumpat sermonem.	And if there be a tooth from which a part has broken off, and which is causing pain of the tongue: then it is necessary to file it also until the asperity of that fracture has been removed, and it has been made even: and it must be flattened, and does not cause pain, neither does it corrupt speech
¶ De retatione Dentium cum filis auri.	Of the reposition of a tooth with files.
Caput XXXIII.	Chapter 33.
Quando accidit Dentibus anterioribus concussio et commotio a percussione, aut casu: et non potest infirmus stringere super illud quod comedit ut non cadat: et curasti eos cum medicinis stipticis, et non ualuit curatio: tunc ingenium in eis est, ut stringantur cum filo auri: quoniam argentum fit uiride, et putrefit post dies: sed aurum nunquam mutatur.	When it happens that the front teeth are fractured and displaced by percussion, or in a case: and it is not possible to hold them together because of their discomfort: then it is necessary to support them with gold wire: for silver is too soft, and it putrefies after a few days: but gold never changes.
Et sit filum medium in subtilitate et grossicie secundum quantitatem quod capiat inter Dentes.	And let the wire be of medium thickness and breadth according to the quantity that it can grasp between the teeth.
Et forma quidem retationis est, ut accipias filum, et intromittas duplum eius inter duos dentes sanos: deinde texeas cum duabus extremitatibus fili inter dentes motos, siue unus sit, aut plures, donec peruenias cum tela usque ad dentem sanum alterius partis.	And the form of the reposition is that you take hold of the wire, and pass its double between two healthy teeth: then you shall weave it with two extremities of the wire between the moving teeth, whether one or more, until you have reached the healthy tooth of the other side
Deinde itera texturam usque ad partem a qua incaepisti: et stringe manum tuam cum subtilitate et sapientia, donec non remoueatur prorsus: et sit constrictio tua qua stringis filum, apud radices dentium, ut non euadat.	Then again, repeat the manipulation until you reach the part from which you commenced: and bind your hand with skill and wisdom until it ceases to move forward: and let your constriction be such as that it binds the thread at the roots of the teeth, so that it does not slip away.
Deinde incide extremitates fili superfluentes cum forficibus: et aggrega utrumque, et conuerte eas cum gesti: et occulta ipsas inter dentem sanum et dentem motum, ut non laedat linguam: deinde dimittatur ita strictum dum remanet.	Then again, cut away the excess thread with scissors: and gather up both together, and bind them together with the thumb: and hide them between the sound tooth and the moved tooth, so that it does not irritate the tongue: then let go of the tension when it remains.
Si autem soluitur, aut inciditur, stringe eos cum filo alio, et stabit cum eo taliter tempore toto.	If, however, it dissolves or breaks, bind it with another thread, and hold it in such a way as to keep it firm throughout the whole time
Et haec est forma Dentium, et figura retationis duorum dentium sanorum, et duorum dentium motorum, sicut uides.	This is the form of teeth, and the figure of the rotation of two sound teeth and two moved teeth, like those of water
Et quandoque fit, ut redeat dens unus, aut duo post casum urriusque in locis suis, et retentur sicut narrauimus, et remaneant: et non facit illud nisi artifex, prudens, et expertus.	And when it happens that one tooth, or two after a fall and swelling in their places, returns as we have said, and remains: this does not happen except by a skillful, wise, and experienced artist.
Et quandoque aptatur aliquod ex ossibus uaccinis: et fit ex eo sicut forma dentis, et ponitur in loco, ex quo munitur dens et stringitur, sicut diximus: et remanet, et seruitur cum eo tempore longo.	And when some piece of bone or flesh has become loose: and it becomes like a tooth in shape, and is placed in its place, from which the tooth has been loosened and bound: it remains, and serves for a long time
¶ De incisione ligamenti quod accidit sub lingua, et prohibet loquelam.	Of the incision of the ligament which happens under the tongue, and which hinders speech
Caput XXXIIII.	Chapter XXXIV.
Quandoque ligamentum hoc quod accidit sub lingua, est aut naturale, cum quo nascitur homo, aut accidentale, a uulnere quod iam consolidatum est.	When this ligament which happens under the tongue is severed, it is either natural, as it is in the birth of a man, or accidental, from an injury which has hardened.
Et operatio in eo est, ut aperias os infirmi in capite eius in sinu tuo, et eleua linguam eius: deinde incide illud ligamentum neruosum per latitudinem, donec soluatur lingua a retentione sua.	And the operation in this is that you open the jaw of the patient in your hand, and lift up his tongue: then cut through that nerve of the ligament throughout its breadth, until the tongue is freed from its retention.
Quod si in eo fuerit quiddam duriciei et nodationis, et fuerit illud ex consolidatione uulneris: tunc proiice in illud uncinum, et finde illud per latitudinem, donec incidas ligamentum, et soluatur nodatio.	If there be in that any hardness and swelling, and if that be from consolidation of the wound: then thrust into that the hook, and find that by its breadth, until you cut the ligament, and it shall be dissolved.
Et caue, ne sit fissura in profundo carnis, et incidas arteriam illic, et accidat fluxus sanguinis.	Take heed, that there be no deep wound, and cut the artery there, and blood flow shall be restored.
Deinde colluatur in uestigio incisionis cum aqua rosata, aut cum aceto, aut aqua frigida.	Then it shall be bound up in the vicinity of the incision with rosewater, or vinegar, or cold water.
Deinde pone sub lingua licinium ex lino, quod teneat infirmus in omni nocte: ut non consolidetur secundo.	Then place under the tongue a piece of linen, which shall hold the patient at night: that he may not consolidate the second time
Si autem accidat fluxus sanguinis, tunc pone super locum zegi tritum.	But if blood flow be restored, then place over the place a piece of torn sponge.
Si uero uincit te sanguis, tunc cauteriza locum cum cauterio lentiginoso, quod conuenit ad illud: deinde cura ipsum cum reliqua curatione, donec sanetur.	If blood spurts, then burn the place with a sponge cautery, which is suitable for that: then care for the place with the rest of the treatment, until it be healed
¶ De extractione Ranulae quae fit sub lingua.	On the extraction of a ranula which is under the tongue.
Caput XXXV.	Chapter 5.
Quandoque accidit sub lingua apostema quod assimilatur Ranae paruae, prohibens linguam ab operatione sua naturali: et fortasse magnificatur adeo, donec implet os.	When there occurs under the tongue a swelling which assimilates the small ranula, preventing the tongue from its natural operation: and perhaps it increases so much, that it fills the mouth.
Et operatio in eo est, ut aperias os infirmi coram sole: et considera apostema.	The operation in this is, that you open the mouth of the patient before the sun: and consider the swelling.
Si ergo uides ipsum fusci coloris, aut nigri, durum, cui non inuenit infirmus sensum: tunc non tangas ipsum, quoniam est cancer.	If therefore you see that it is of a yellow or black color, hard, which does not cause the patient any pain: then do not touch it, because it is cancer
Et si est decliue ad albedinem, in quo est humiditas, tunc proiice in ipsum uncinum, et incide ipsum cum spatumili subtili, et libera ipsum ab omni parte.	And if it inclines towards whiteness, in which there is moisture: then thrust into it the hook, and cut it with a fine knife, and free it from all parts
Quod si uincit te sanguis in hora tuae operationis, tunc pone super ipsum zegi tritum, donec abscindatur sanguis: deinde redi ad operationem tuam, donec extrahas ipsum cum complemento eius.	If blood flows upon thee in the hour of thy operation, then place upon it a dry sponge, until the blood is separated: afterwards return to thy operation, until thou hast extracted it with its complement.
Deinde colluatur cum aceto et sale: et cura ipsum reliqua curatione conueniente ad illud, donec sanetur.	Then apply vinegar and salt: and care for the rest with such treatment as is convenient for that, until he is healed.
¶ De curatione apostematis duarum Amigdalarum.	Concerning the treatment of the two wounds of the amygdalae.
Caput XXXVI.	Chapter 6.
Quandoque accidunt inter guttur godad, id est, glandulae, quae similantur algodad, quae accidunt deforis: et nominantur duae Amigdalae: quas quando curas cum eo quod diximus in diuisione, et non sanantur, tunc considera.	When wounds happen between the gullet and the gods, that is, the glands which are like almonds, which happen outside: and which are called two amygdalae: when you cure them with what we said in the explanation, and they do not heal, then consider them
Si ergo est apostema durum, fusci coloris, pauci sensus: tunc non tangas ipsum cum ferro.	If there is a hard wound, of a brown color, with little sensation: then do not touch it with iron
Et si est rubei coloris, et radix eius est grossa: tunc non tangas ipsum etiam cum ferro, timens fluxum sanguinis, imo dimitte ipsum, donec maturetur.	And if it is red and its root is large: then do not touch it even with iron, fearing the flow of blood, rather leave it alone, until it is healed
Et tunc aut perforabis ipsum: aut rumpetur per se.	And then either perforate it or rupture it by itself.
Et si est albi coloris, rotundum, et est radix eius subtilis: tunc oportet ipsum incidi.	And if it is white in color, round, and its root is slight: then you must cut it open.
Et operatio in ipso est, ut consideres ante operationem suam, si quieuit apostema eius calidum quiete completum, aut imminuitur quadam diminutione: tunc ergo fac sedere infirmum coram sole, et caput eius sit in sinu tuo: et aperi os eius, et accipiat seruiens inter manus suas, et premat linguam eius inferius cum instrumento, cuius haec est forma.	And the operation in this is as you consider before your operation, if the wound has cooled completely and is complete, or if it is threatening some reduction: then do this make the patient sit facing the sun, and place his head in your lap: and open his mouth, and take out the saliva between your hands, and pull down his tongue with an instrument, which has this shape.
Fiat ex argento, aut aere, quod sit subtile sicut cultellus.	Do this with silver, or with air, which is subtle like a knife
Cum ergo premis cum eo linguam, et ostenditur tibi apostema, et cadit super ipsum uisus tuus: tunc accipe uncinum, et fige ipsum in amigdalam, et extrahe eam ad exteriora quantum potes, praeter quod trahas cum ea aliquid ex tunicis.	When the language is spoken and the limb is exposed, and it falls upon the object of your care: then grasp the hook and fix it to the bone, and draw it out to the exterior as much as possible, without tearing anything from the skin.
Deinde incide eam cum instrumento, cuius haec est forma quae sequitur.	Then incision is made with the instrument whose form follows this.
Assimilatur forficibus: uerumtamen extremitates eius sint curuatae, ita quod orificium cuiusque earum est in directo alterius acute: unde cura ut sit ex ferro indo, aut alfuled imbibitum.	Like scissors: truly the extremities of these are curved, so that the opening of each is directly opposite the other at an angle: care must be taken that it be firm, or blood-soaked.
Si autem non est praesens hoc instrumentum, tunc incide ipsum cum spatumili, cuius haec est forma.	If this instrument is not present, incision is made with a sponge, whose form is like this
Sit acutum a parte una, non acutum a parte altera.	Acute from one side, not from the other side.</start_of_turn>
Et postquam incidis amigdalam unam, incide alteram secundum hanc eandem speciem incisionis.	And after you have incisions on one side, make the other side according to this same kind of incision.</start_of_turn>
Deinde post incisionem gargarizet infirmus cum aqua frigida, aut cum aceto et aqua.	Then after the incision the patient will be gargled with cold water, or with vinegar and water.</start_of_turn
Si autem accidat ei fluxus sanguinis, gargarizet cum aqua in qua bulliti sunt cortices granatorum: aut folia myrti, et similia illis ex stipticis, donec abscindatur fluxus sanguinis: deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	If however blood flows from it, gargle with water in which coriander seeds are boiled: or leaves of myrtle, and things like these from sponges: until the bleeding stops: then care for it until it heals.</start_of_turn>
Et quandoque nascuntur in gutture apostemata alia, praeter amigdalas duas.	And when there appear in the throat other abscesses, besides the two tonsils.</start_of_turn
Incide ergo ea secundum quod dixi in incisione duarum amigdalarum aequaliter.	Incision is made for these like that which I said concerning the incision of the two tonsils equally.</start_of_turn
Et ego quidem iam medicatus fui mulierem ex apostemate, quod natum erat inter guttur eius, quod trahebat ad fuscedinem, pauci sensus, quod iam fere clauserat guttur: et mulier respirabat a meatu stricto, et iam prohibuerat ei comestionem, et potum aquae: et iam peruenerat ad mortem, si remansisset uno die, aut duobus diebus.	And I myself was a physician for a woman who had an abscess in her throat, which was born between her ribs, which was dragging down, little sense, because she was almost suffocating: and the woman was breathing from a narrow passage, and I forbade her from eating and drinking: and she died within one or two days.</start_of_turn>
Et apostema tantum ascenderat, quod emiserat duos ramos, donec exierant super duo foramina nasi.	The swelling will thus ascend as far as it emitted two branches, until it passes beyond the two nostrils.
Properaui ergo festinanter, et fixi in unum eorum uncinum.	The swelling will thus ascend as far as it emitted two branches, until it passes beyond the two nostrils.
Deinde traxi ipsum, et tracta ex eo est portio magna.	Then draw out the rest, and from that part is the greater portion
Deinde abscidi eam, ubi comprehendi ex foramine nasi.	Then cut away that which is within the nostrils
Deinde feci illud ei quod processit ex foramine nasi altero.	Then do the like with the other nostril
Deinde aperui os eius, et pressi linguam eius: et postea fixi uncinum in ipsum apostema: deinde abscidi ex eo partem eius, et non cucurrit ex eo nisi sanguis paucus: absolutum est ergo guttur mulieris, et incepit statim bibere aquam, deinde accepit ex cibo.	Then open its mouth, and press down its tongue: and afterwards fix the tissue to that swelling: then cut away from that part a portion of it, and no blood will issue from that. Absolutely, therefore, is the woman's throat, and she immediately drinks water, and then takes food.
Non ergo cessaui incidere ex illo apostemate multotiens tempore longo: et apostema succedebat loco eius quod incidebam, donec prolongatum est nimis et cum ea illud.	It is not necessary to cut away from that swelling many times for a long time: and the swelling will come back to the place from which it was cut, until it is prolonged and with it.
Ingeniaui ergo, et cauterizaui apostema inter guttur.	I devised therefore, and cauterized the swelling between the throat.
Stetit ergo ab additione: deinde ambulaui a parte, et non sciui quid fecit Deus cum ea post me.	It stood still from the addition: then I went away from that part, and I do not know what God did with her after me
¶ De incisione apostematis uuulae.	Of the incision of the swelling of the nose.
Caput XXXVII.	Chapter 7.
Quando descendit catarrus ad uuulam, et apostematur, et est long: tunc ipsa nominatur perpendicularis: et si est in inferiori parte grossa, rotunda, tunc ipsa nominatur uua.	When the catarrus descends to the nose, and swells, and is long: then it is called perpendicular: and if it is in the lower part large, round, then it is called double
Quando curatur cum eo quod diximus in diuisione, et non confert curatio: et uides quod apostema calidum quieuit ab ea, et est subtilis: tunc oportet ut incidas eam.	When it is cured with that which we said in the enumeration, and the cure does not suffice: and you see that the swelling is softened from it, and is slight: then it is necessary to cut away from it
Et quae ex ea est aggregata rotunda, et non est ei longitudo, et est sanguinea, aut fusci coloris, aut nigri, et non est ei sensus: tunc oportet ut deuites incisionem eius.	And whatever is aggregated in a round shape, which has no length, is either blood, or of a tawny or black colour, and has no sensation: in such a case it is necessary to make an incision in it.
In ea enim est timor super infirmum.	And there is fear of the disease on account of the sick person.
Oportet ergo quando uides eam secundum modum quem dixi ex albedine, et longitudine sua, ut facias sedere infirmum coram sole: et premas linguam eius cum instrumento, cuius praecessit narratio: deinde fige uncinum in uuam, et trahe eam inferius: et incide eam cum uno duorum instrumentorum quae dixi in incisione duarum amigdalarum.	It is necessary therefore when you are treating the patient as I have said from the white and the black, and of its length, so that you make the patient sit with his face towards the sun: and you take hold of his tongue with an instrument of which I have spoken before: then you fix the flesh in one place, and draw out the bowels: and you cut through the bowels with one of the two instruments which I have mentioned in the incision of two armpits.
Et oportet ut non incidas ex ea, nisi illud quod additur super naturalem terminum sine additione.	And it is necessary that you do not cut through from that except that which is added beyond the natural limit without addition
Nam si tu incidis ex ea plus, laedes uocem et sermonem.	For if you cut through from that more, you will wound the bowels and the speech.
Deinde post incisionem utere eo quod narrauimus in incisione duarum amigdalarum: et cura eam, donec sanetur.	Then after the incision make use of what we have spoken of in the incision of two armpits: and take care of the bowels until they are healed.
Si autem terretur infirmus ab incisione: tunc oportet ut utaris ingenio in cauterizatione eius absque timore et pauore.	If however the patient returns from the incision: then it is necessary that you use your skill in cauterizing it without fear and without hesitation.
Et modus cauterii in ea non est, nisi cum aqua acuta: et est, ut ponas caput infirmi in sinu tuo.	And the method of cauterizing in these is not except with acute water: and it is that you place the head of the patient in your lap.
Deinde preme linguam eius cum instrumento quod diximus.	Then take hold of his tongue with the instrument which we have mentioned.
Deinde accipe ex aqua quam dixi tibi in capitulo cauterizandi, et confice cum ea calcem non extinctam, et pone eam non spissam, neque subtilem, et imple ex ea concauitatem huius instrumenti, cuius haec est forma.	Then take from the water which I have mentioned above and mix it with charcoal not burnt out, and put it not thick nor thin, and bring from that the cavity of this instrument which has this shape
Sit extremitati eius in qua ponitur medicina concauitas, sicut concauitas cochlearis radii.	The extremities of it on which the medicine is placed are like the concavity of the cochlea of a radius
Et pone instrumentum cum medicina super uuulam ipsam: et infirmus sit iacens super latus suum, ut currat saliua ex ore eius ex intrinseca medicina, ut non descendat ex ea ad guttur ipsius aliquid, et laedat ipsum.	Place the instrument with the medicine above the limb itself: and let the patient lie upon his side, so that the moisture from his mouth may flow outwards from the medicine inwards, and not descend downwards into his gut, and thereby cause him pain.
Deinde tene manum tuam cum medicina.	Hold your hand with the medicine.
Et tu ex primas eam super uuulam quantitate medietatis horae, donec uideas eam iam denigratam, et sedatam mordicationem medicinae.	And you from the first touch over the limb for the quantity of half an hour, until you see it is softened, and seat the biting of the medicine.
