Et si uis ut accipias cotum, et inuoluas ipsum super extremitatem radii, et infundas cotum cum medicina, et intromittas radium cum coto in cannulam desuper, donec adhaereat cotum super uuulam.	And if you wish to grasp the limb, and cover it with the medicine at its extremity, and inflate the limb with the medicine, and insert the finger with the coat into the canal above, until the coat adheres to the limb itself
Fac illud multotiens, donec consequaris quod uis de cauterizatione uuae.	Do this often, until you achieve what you desire of the cauterization of the limb
Deinde dimitte eam: ipsa namque arescit et cadit post tres dies, aut quatuor.	And then remove the medicine: for it itself will dry up and fall off in three days, or four.
Quod si indiges ut iteres medicinam, itera ipsam: et post cauterizationem absterge in circumitu uuae cum coto imbibito in butyro, et mundifica cum eo quod est in circumitu eius ex medicina: et colluatur cum aqua frigida.	If you find that the medicine has not taken hold, repeat it: and after the cauterization, remove the surrounding parts of the limb with the coat, and moisten with butter, and anoint with oil what is around it from the medicine: and cool it with cold water
Et curetur extrinsecus cum embrocis, et deintus cum gargarismis, donec sanetur.	And care for the outside with bandages, and for the inside with gargling, until it is healed
Haec ergo species curationis est salubrior incisione et longinquior a timore.	Thus this kind of treatment is more beneficial than incision and is longer lasting in respect of fear
Et quandoque curatur uuula etiam cum eo quod est subtilius quam cauterium et incisio: curatur enim cum suffumigatione, secundum hunc modum.	And when the limb is healed even with this, which is more subtle than cauterization and incision: it is healed by fumigation, in this manner.
Sume calamentum, et hyssopum, et origanum, et rutam, et sseah, et chamomillam, et abrotanum, et similia eis ex herbis: et aggrega ea omnia, aut quaedam eorum in olla, et submergantur cum aceto, et bulliant: et olla sit lutata cum luto decenter: et sit in medio ollae foramen, super quod componatur instrumentum concauum secundum hunc modum.	Take calamine, and hyssop, and origanum, and rue, and sage, and chamomile, and chamomile flower, and such like herbs: and mix them all together, or some of them in a pot, and immerse them in vinegar, and boil: and put a hole in the middle of the pot, over which is placed a concave instrument according to this manner.
Fiat ex argento, aut aere: et intromittatur extremitas, in qua est granatum, in os infirmi, donec ascendat uapor ad uuulam super cannulam, donec obscuretur uuula multum.	Let air or metal go: and introduce the extremity, in which is the pomegranate, into the bone of the patient, until the vapor rises up to the upper cannula, until the upper part is obscured much.
Deinde itera super ipsam multotiens, donec arescat.	Then repeat over the latter several times, until it heals.</start_of_turn>
Et caue, ne facias hanc curationem in principio aduentus apostematis.	And be careful, do not perform this treatment at the beginning of an abscess.</start_of_turn>
Plaerumque enim addit in apostemate: et non oportet ut facias illud nisi apud declinationem apostematis eius calidi.	It is useful indeed to add in the abscess: and it is not necessary that you do this except when the abscess is cold.</start_of_turn>
Si autem non est praesens tibi hoc instrumentum, tunc accipe cannam, et compone in extremitate eius corticem oui: ut non comburatur os infirmi: quoniam cortex oui prohibet uaporem comburere os: et haec est ex bona curatione cum salute.	If however this instrument is not present with you, then take a needle and fashion in its extremity a piece of cork or resin: so that it does not burn the bone of the patient: because the cork or resin hinders the vapor from burning the bone: and this is from a good treatment with safety.</start_of_turn>
¶ De extractione spinarum, et ossium de gula.	About the extraction of thorns, and bones from the jaw.</start_of_turn
Caput XXXVIII.	Chapter XXXVIII.</start_of_turn>
Multotiens adhaeret in gutture os, aut spina piscis, aut aliud.	Many things adhere to the gut of the bone, or a fish spine, or something else.</start_of_turn
Oportet ergo ut extrahas quod ex eis est apparens super quod cadit uisus, postquam premis linguam cum instrumento apud solem, et declaratur tibi quod est in gutture.	It is necessary therefore that you extract what appears from the gut when the tongue is pressed with the instrument at the edge, and that you declare that it is in the gut.</start_of_turn
Et quod non apparet tibi et occultatur in gutture, oportet ut facias uomere infirmum antequam digeratur cibus in stomacho.	And what is not apparent to you and is hidden in the gut, you must make the patient vomit before the food is digested in the stomach.</start_of_turn
Fortasse enim egredietur res annexa per uomitum.	Perhaps therefore the attached thing will go out by vomiting.</start_of_turn
Aut deglutiat infirmus frustum napi, aut radicem lactucae, aut deglutiat buccellam panis sicci: aut accipiat frustum spongiae marinae siccae lenis: et liga ipsum in filo, deinde deglutiat ipsum.	Or the patient may swallow down a piece of barley chaff, or a radix of lettuce, or swallow down a dry piece of bread, or take up a piece of dry sea sponge: and bind it up in a thread, then swallow it down.</start_of_turn
Cum ergo peruenit ad locum ubi sunt spinae, aut os, et extrahitur, tunc egreditur.	When the limb approaches the place where bones or spines are found, and is drawn out, it then emerges.
Si ergo non egreditur cum eo quod diximus: tunc utere instrumento ex plumbo secundum hanc formam.	If it does not emerge with it as we have said: then use an instrument of lead according to this shape.
Sit grossius quam Radius parumper, et in extremitate eius sit curuitas, quam intromittat in guttur suum cum facilitate: et ipse habeat caput suum eleuatum sursum.	Let it be thicker than a radius and smaller than a barleycorn, and have a curve at its extremity which projects into its guttur with ease: and let it have its head elevated above.
Et caueat a tactu suae epiglotis, ut non accidat ei tussis, et impellat cum eo os, aut spinam, aut intromittat ipsum medicus manu sua.	And beware of its touch on the epiglottis, that it does not cause it to swell, and drive out with it bone, spine, or bring the physician's hand forward
Verum quod infirmus intromittat, hoc est melius: propter scientiam suam de loco rei annexae: et impellat inferius, aut trahat manum suam cum instrumento sursum, totum illud secundum quantitatem quae praeparatur ei, donec egrediatur.	But that the sick person brings it forward, this is better: because of his knowledge of the place of the annexed thing: and drives downwards, or draws his hand upwards with the instrument above, all this according to the quantity which is prepared for him, until it emerges
¶ De extractione Sanguisugae.	Of the extraction of the blood-sucker.</start_of_turn>
Caput XXXIX.	Chapter XXXIX.</start_of_turn>
Quando medicatur sanguisuga cum eo quod dixi in diuisione ex curatione cum medicinis, et non confert, tunc considera in gutture infirmi coram sole, siue apud solem postquam premis linguam eius cum instrumento quod narraui tibi.	When the physician treats the blood-sucker with that which I mentioned in the treatise on treatment with the physicians, and it does not yield, then consider in the guttur of the patient in front of the sun, or behind the tongue after having drawn out its tongue with the instrument which I mentioned.</start_of_turn>
Si ergo cadit uisus tuus super sanguisugam, extrahe eam cum uncino paruo, aut cum gesti subtilibus decenter.	If therefore your hand slips over the blood-sucker, draw it out with a small hook, or with fine fingers detached from each other.</start_of_turn
Quod si non est possibile cum eis: tunc accipe cannulam concauam, et intromitte eam in guttur infirmi usque prope guttur: deinde intromitte in concauitatem cannulae ferrum ignitum cum igne.	If this is not possible with these means: then take a curved needle, and insert it into the guttur of the patient almost to the guttur: then insert the burning iron into the curve of the needle.</start_of_turn
Fac illud multotiens: et abstineat infirmus ab aqua tota die.	Do this often: and let the patient abstain from all water throughout the day.
Deinde accipiat uitreatam plenam aqua frigida, et aperiat os eius in ea: et colluat os suum cum ea, et non deglutiat ex ea aliquid: et moueat aquam una hora post aliam cum manu sua.	Then he shall take a full treatment of cold water, and open his mouth with it: and he shall gather his teeth with it, and let him not swallow anything from it: and he shall drink water once an hour after each meal with his hand
Sanguisuga enim ilico cum sentit aquam cadit.	When he feels that blood is coming from his mouth with the water.
Si autem non egreditur cum eo quod narrauimus, tunc suffumiga infirmum cum cimicibus, aut cum asa cum instrumento quod narraui in suffumigatione uuulae.	But if it does not go away when we have told you, then fumigate the patient with vinegar, or with alum as an instrument of fumigation for the wound
Fac illud multotiens, quoniam ipsa cadet.	Do this often, for it will go away by itself.
Et modus operationis in suffumigatione est, ut accipias ollam, in qua sint prunae uiuae cum igne: et olla sit cooperta cum coopertorio, in cuius medio sit foramen: et componatur in illo foramine extremitas instrumenti.	And the mode of operation in fumigation is that you take a vessel in which are dates with fire: and the vessel be covered with a cover, in the middle of which is a hole: and make in that hole the extremity of the instrument.</start_of_turn>
Deinde proiice suffumigationem, et ponat infirmus os suum in extremitate cannulae, et claudat os suum, ut non egrediatur suffumigatio, donec scias quod suffumigatio iam peruenit ad sanguisugam.	Then throw the fumigation and put the patient's mouth in the extremity of the tube, and close the mouth, so that it does not escape the fumigation, until you know that the fumigation has passed to the bleeding.</start_of_turn>
Nam sanguisuga statim cadet.	For bleeding stops immediately.</start_of_turn>
Quod si non cadit, tunc itera suffumigationem multotiens.	If it does not go away, do the fumigation often.</start_of_turn
Et toleret infirmus sitim, et comedat salsa, et allia, et non bibat aquam.	And the patient can tolerate sitting, and eat garlic and onions, and does not drink water.</start_of_turn
Necesse est ergo ut egrediatur cum hoc regimine.	It is necessary therefore that he should go out with this regimen.</start_of_turn
Et haec est forma instrumenti cum quo extrahitur sanguisuga ex gutture, quando cadit super ipsam uisus.	And this is the form of the instrument with which blood is extracted from the gut when it falls upon the vomit.</start_of_turn
Est simile forcipibus, sicut uides: nisi quia est ei haee curuitas quae intromittitur ad guttur.	It is like pincers, thus also liquids: except that it has a curvature which enters the gut.
Et extremitas eius similis ori auis quae nominatur ciconia, in quo est asperitas limae: quando comprehendit aliquid, non dimittit ipsum omnino.	Its extremities are like the beak of a heron which is called ciconia, in which there is a roughness of lime: when it grasps something, it does not relinquish it entirely.
¶ De apertione Apostematum, et eorum sectione, et cura in genere.	About the opening of the rectum, and its section, and care in general.
Caput XL.	Chapter 40.</start_of_turn>
Apostematum species sunt multae, multorum modorum, secundum quod uenit rememoratio eorum, scilicet unius, et unius in hoc libro: et sunt diuersae in perforatione eorum, et sectione ipsorum ex duobus modis.	There are many kinds of rectum, of various methods, according as the nature of the case reminds us: and they are diverse in their perforation and their section into two methods.
Quorum unus est ex specie apostematis in seipso, et eo quod comprehendit ex humiditatibus.	One of them is the kind of rectum which comprehends humours.</start_of_turn>
Et modus secundus est propter loca, in quibus accidit ex corpore.	The other is on account of the place where it happens to the body.</start_of_turn
Quoniam apostema accidens in capite, est aliud ab apostemate accidente in ano: et apostema accidens in loco carnoso, est aliud ab apostemate accidente in iuncturis: et unicuique eorum est iudicium suum ex operatione.	Because the rectum happens at the head is different from the rectum which happens in the belly: and the rectum which happens in a fleshy place is different from the rectum which happens at the joints: and each one of them has its own judgement according to the operation.</start_of_turn
Et ex apostematibus sunt quae non oportet ut perforentur, nisi post maturationem saniei in eis, et complementum eius: et ex eis sunt, quae oportet ut perforentur, dum sunt cruda, et non maturantur secundum complementum.	There are those which do not require perforation of the rectum except after the completion of health in youth, and its complement: and there are those which require perforation while they are raw and have not matured according to the complement.</start_of_turn
Sicut apostemata quae sunt propinqua iuncturis.	Like the rectum which is close to the joints.</start_of_turn
Quoniam apostema quando accidit prope iuncturam, et prolongatur esse eius, donec putrefit quod est in circumitu eius fortasse corrumpuntur ligamenta, aut nerui illius iuncturae: quare est caussa propior contractionis illius membri.	For the rectum when it happens near the joint, and extends itself, until it putrefies which is in its circumference perhaps the ligaments or the nerves of that joint are ruptured: which is the cause of the closer contraction of that limb.</start_of_turn
Aut est apostema apud membrum principale: quoniam si tu tardas perforationem eius, donec maturetur, nocebit uel illi, uel per illud membro principali.	The abscess is near the main limb: for if you delay its perforation until it matures, it will cause either a swelling or an infection in that main limb.
Aut est prope anum, perfora ergo ipsum immaturum: et non oportet, ut perfores, apostema crudum, non completae digestionis, nisi quod est prope anum, ut non putrefiat profundum, et longetur ad interiora ani, et fiat fistula, aut fiat in termino eius quod non sanatur.	The abscess is close to the limb: for if you perforate it while it is immature, it must not be left without completing its digestion, except when it is close to the limb, lest it should putrefy deeply, and reach the interior of the limb, and form a fistula, or remain unhealed at its end
Oportet ut scias horam perforationis apostematis, quod maturatum est secundum complementum: et est apud sedationem doloris, recessionem febris, et diminutionem rubedinis, et pulsationis, et acuitatem capitis apostematis: et reliqua signa.	You must know the time of perforation of the abscess, for it is matured according to the completion of its digestion: and it is with the cessation of pain, lowering of fever, and diminishing of redness, and pulse, and the sharpness of the head of the abscess: and the rest of the signs.
Et oportet, ut facias eandem perforationem in inferiori loco apostematis, et uehementioris eminentiae: et sit perforatio uadens in longitudine corporis, si apostemata sunt in partibus manuum et pedum, et locis lacertorum, et chordarum, et neruorum, et arteriarum, et ad ultimum in omnibus locis aequalibus, quibus non est reflexio.	You must make the perforation in a lower place of the abscess, and more cautiously: and let the perforation be wide in length of the body, if the abscesses are in the parts of the hands and feet, and the places of lacerations, and strings, and nerves, and arteries, and finally in all the places which have no reflection
In illis autem quae reflectuntur, uade cum perforatione secundum illud membrum.	But in those which reflect, be cautious with the perforation according to that limb.
Quando uero apostema est in locis carnosis: tunc melius est ut dimittas perforationem eius, donec confirmetur eius digestio, sicut diximus secundum complementum.	When indeed the abscess is in a place of hardness: then it is better to omit the perforation of it until its digestion is confirmed, as we have said according to completion
Quoniam si tu perforas ipsum ante illud, prolongatur cursus uirus ex eo, et est multae sordis et sordiciei, et fortasse indurantur labia eius, et profunditas eius.	For if you perforate it before that, you prolong the course of the infection from that, and there is much pus and discharge, and perhaps swelling of its lip, and depth of it.
Et quaedam apostemata perforantur secundum latitudinem corporis apud necessitatem: aut secundum illud quo indiget membrum.	And some abscesses are perforated according to the width of the body for necessity: or according to that which the limb requires.
Et oportet, ut administres in apostematibus paruis perforationem paruam, et in apostematibus magnis perforationem amplam: aut sectiones multas per similitudinem magnitudinis apostematis.	And you must manage in small abscesses a moderate perforation, and in large abscesses a wide perforation: or many sections like the magnitude of the abscesses.
Et sunt ex apostematibus, in quibus oportet ut concauetur cutis: et incidatur quando iam facta est sicut pannus, et facta est in termino, quod iam mortua est: sicut illud quod accidit in multis, ut dubelet, et bubonibus.	And there are from the apostemata, in which it is necessary that the skin should be concaved: and it occurs when it has been made like a piece of cloth, and has been made at the end, when it is dead: as it happens with many things, as with worms and boils.
Et ex eis sunt quae secantur sectione habente tres angulos.	And there are those which are cut through with a section having three angles.
Et ex eis est, ex quo inciditur sicut figura folii myrti.	And there are those which occur like the shape of a myrtle leaf
Sicut apostema inguinum.	Like the apostema of the groin
Et ex eis sunt in quibus administratur sectio rotunda, et sectio lunaris: et similes eis ex sectionibus.	And there are those in which a round section and a crescent section are administered: and similar things from sections
Illud uero cui non est caput, sicut sunt apostemata lenia superficialia, oportet ut perfores ipsum perforatione superficiali, uel plana tantum.	That which has no head, like the superficial leninous apostemata, must be pierced through with a superficial perforation, or flattened only
Et oportet, quando apostema est grossum, et iam collegit saniem multam, et perforas ipsum, ut non properes et extrahas pus totum in illa hora: imo extrahe ex ipso partem eius.	And it is necessary, when the apostema is thick and has collected much blood, to perforate it so that it does not swell and extract all the pus in an hour: indeed extract from it a part of itself
Deinde opila apostema usque ad diem alium.	Then anoint the apostema until the next day.
Deinde extrahe quiddam ex pus iterum.	Then draw out some of the pus again.
Fac illud multotiens secundum gradationem, donec egrediatur: praecipue si infirmus est debilis uirtutis, aut mulier praegnans, aut puer paruus, aur senex decrepitus: spiritus enim animalis ab animali multotiens resoluitur cum egressione saniei: et fortasse moritur infirmus, et tu non percipis.	Do this many times according to the degree, until the patient is discharged: especially if the patient is weak in virtue, or a pregnant woman, or a young child, or an old man decrepitus: for the spirit of the animal is dissolved with the discharge of the pus: and perhaps the patient will die, and you will not perceive it
Caue ergo hoc capitulum cautela magna.	Beware therefore of this chapter, for it contains great caution
Et post perforationem tuam, qua ista perforas apostemata, oportet ut abstergas uulnus: et considera.	And after you have perforated the apostema, which you have perforated, you must remove the clot: and consider carefully
Si ergo est uulnus apostematis paruum, aut est sectio plana, tunc administra licinia ex lino, aut coto antiquo.	If there is a small abscess of the apostematis, either perform a plane section or administer ointment from an old bottle.
Et si est apostema magnum, et fissurae perforationis multae sunt, oportet tunc ut intromittas in omnem fissuram licinium, donec perueniant adinuicem.	If there is a large abscess and many puncture wounds exist, it is necessary to instill ointment into every wound until they reach the innermost part.</start_of_turn>
Et si in apostemate abscidisti partem cutis, aut in circumitu concauasti eam: tunc oportet ut impleas eam coto ueteri, aut sicut quando texitur pannus, aut raditur lanugine lini absque humiditate: et stringe ipsum usque ad tertium diem.	If you have excised a piece of skin from the abscess, or if you have cauterized the circumference: then you must apply an old bottle of ointment, or as when a cloth is taken away, or cover it with wool without moisture: and keep it bound until the third day.</start_of_turn>
Deinde proiice ipsum, et cura illud cum eo quod oportet ex unguento, donec sanetur.	Then remove it and care for it with ointment until it heals.</start_of_turn
Si autem accidat fluxus sanguinis in hora tuae operationis, tunc administra aquam frigidam, et acetum, postquam imbibitur in eis pannus: et ponis ipsum super locum fluxus sanguinis multotiens.	If, however, blood flow occurs during your operation in this hour, then administer cold water and vinegar, after they have been swallowed in a cloth: and place it over the site of the bleeding many times.</start_of_turn>
Si autem perseuerat fluxus sanguinis, tunc oportet ut administres regimen, et curationem, et pulueres, quae narraui in locis multis huius nostri libri, et ex diuisione.	If the bleeding persists, then you must administer treatment, care, and powders, which I have mentioned in many places of this book, and from experience.</start_of_turn>
Si autem est in tempore hyemis, et locus apostematis est multorum neruorum: tunc oportet ut infundas puluillos cum uino, et oleo calidis: et ponas eos super loca.	If it is in winter and the abscess is in a place with many nerves: then you must infuse sponges with wine and oil of warmth: and place them over the area.</start_of_turn
Et si fuerit in aestate, et loca sunt carnosa: tunc oportet ut ponas puluillos imbibitos in aqua, et oleo, aut eum uino et oleo, et totum illud frigidum.	And if it is in summer and the place is fatty: then you must place sponges soaked in water, and oil, or both with wine and oil, and keep it cold.</start_of_turn>
Donec quando erit dies tertius, sicut diximus, tunc oportet ut soluas apostema, et abstergas ipsum, et administres in curatione eius quod ei conuenit, donec sanetur.	Until then, as we have said, on the third day you must drain the abscess, remove it, and administer treatment which is suitable for it until it heals.</start_of_turn
Hoc est ergo quod necessarium est ex cognitione curationis apostematum uniuersaliter.	This is therefore necessary from the knowledge of the treatment of all apostemata.
Secundum semitam uero distinctionis, iam dixi de omni apostemate, qualiter est uia ad curationem eius capitulatim singulariter.	According to the manner of distinguishing things, as I have said concerning every apostematum, how it is that the way to its cure is set out singly
¶ De sectione apostematum quae accidunt in cute capitis.	Concerning the section of apostemata which happen in the head.
Caput XLI.	Chapter 41.
Accidunt in cute capitis apostemata parua, et sunt ex speciebus Nodorum, quos continent tunicae, quae sunt eis sacci: quasi ipsa sint hausolati gallinae.	There happen in the head small apostemata which are of the kind of knots, which contain tunicae, which are like sacks: as if they were themselves like the gall-cocks' houses
Et ipsorum species sunt multae.	And their kind is many
Ex eis sunt pingues: et ex eis sunt quae continent humiditatem similem limo: et ex eis quae continent humiditatem similem frisatis et pultibus: et eis similibus, et ex eis sunt, quae sunt lapidea dura.	Some are fat: and some contain moisture like slime: and some contain moisture like blood clots: and some are like these, and some are hard stones
Et in sectione omnium, et ipsorum extractione non est timor, dum apud ipsorum sectionem non facit contrarietatem arteria.	And in the section of all of them, and their extraction is not to be feared, as long as during their section there is no contradiction of the arteries.
Et operatio in sectione eorum est, ut experiaris ea cum instrumento, cuius forma uenit post haec, quod nominatur Intromissum, donec scias quid contineat.	And the operation in their section is to learn them with the instrument which form comes after this, which is called the Intromissum, until you know what it contains
Nam si est illud quod continet humiditas, tunc seca ipsum sectione secundum longitudinem sectione superficiali: secundum hanc formam.	For if it contains moisture, then dry it out by the superficial section: by this form.
Et incipe cum sectione ex linea b. ad lineam, g. Cum ergo euacuatur humiditas, tunc excoria kistin quae continet illam humiditatem, et non dimittas ex ea aliquid penitus.	And begin with the section from line b to line g. When as much moisture has been evacuated as possible, then remove the knot which contains it, and do not leave anything behind
Multotiens enim redit, si remanet ex ea aliquid.	Many are returned if anything is left behind
Deinde submerge cotum in unguento aegyptio, si est praesens: et si non, in aqua et sale: et imple cum eo uulnus, et dimitte ipsum usque ad diem alium.	Then immerse the head in Egyptian unguent if it is present: and if not, in water and salt: and anoint with oil and draw out on another day
Ipsum enim corrodet quod remansit ex kisti.	The wound eats up that which remains from the cyst.
Deinde itera super ipsum cotum cum aegyptio secundo, et tertio, et si indiges illo, donec confidas quia non remanserit ex kisti aliquid, tunc enim cura uulnus cum unguento, donec sanetur.	Repeat over the wound with Egyptian resin first, second, and third time, and if it does not digest it, until you are confident that nothing remains of the cyst, then indeed cure with oil until it is healed
Quod si apostema continet nodum pinguem: tunc seca ipsum secundum hanc formam, sectione habente formam crucis: et proiice uncinos inter duolabia sectionis, et excoria ipsum ab omni parte: et conare uirtutem tuam in extractione tunicae quae continet ipsum.	If there is a swelling with a pimple, then dry it with this form, by section having the shape of a cross: and project the threads between the two lobes of the section, and remove it from all sides: and try your skill in the extraction of the membrane which contains it.
Si autem contrarietatem facit tibi arteria, tunc fac illud quod narrabo tibi post.	If, however, it makes resistance, it is an artery, then do as I shall tell you afterwards.
Et similiter fac in apostemate, si est lapideum, ex sectione, et curatione eadem, secundum quod diximus.	And in a stone abscess, if it is stony, do the same, by section, and the same cure, as we said before
Et sectio super apostema lapideum est facilior: quoniam est pauci sanguinis et humiditatis.	And the section of a stone abscess is easier: because there is little blood and moisture.
Et quandoque sunt quaedam horum apostematum quae sunt in capite in quibusdam hominibus, cum quibus penitus non est humiditas.	And sometimes there are some head abscesses in certain people, in which there is no moisture at all
Quod est: quia ego secui super apostema in capite mulieris uetulae, et inueni apostema sicut lapis solidus et durus, asper, albus, qui non poterat frangi: et si percuteretur cum eo aliquis proiiciendo, uulnerat ipsum.	Which is: because I have seen over a head abscess in a maidservant, and I found an abscess like a solid and hard stone, rough, white, which could not be broken: and if I pierced it with anything, it burst open
In aliis uero apostematibus accidentibus in capite, praeter haec scilicet apostemata quae accidunt in capitibus puerorum, et apud radices aurium, sectio eorum omnium sit sectio superficialis.	In other abscesses which happen in the head, besides these indeed there are head abscesses which happen in children, and near the roots of the ears, the section of these is to be superficial
Vel pone perforationem eorum semper ab inferiori parte eorum, ut alleuietur cursus saniei ad inferiora.	Or make the perforation always from the lower part downwards, so as to preserve the progress of the healing downwards
Deinde cura ea cum eo quod conuenit eis ex curatione.	Then care for it as seems good to you from this point forward.
¶ De sectione Strophularum in collo.	On the section of the Stropharia in the neck.
Caput XLII.	On the section of the Stropharia in the neck.
Multotiens acccidunt ista apostemata in collo, et sub assellis, et inguinibus: et quandoque accidunt in reliquo corpore.	Many times these [lymph nodes] are found swollen in the neck, under the armpits, and in the groin: and sometimes also in the rest of the body.
Et super illa quae ex eis accidunt in collo, sunt unum, et multa: et generantur ab inuicem: et omnis Strophula ex eis est intra tunicam propriam ei, sicut est in nodis et apostematibus capitis, sicut narrauimus.	And concerning those which are in the neck, there is one and many of them: and they are generated from each side: and every Strophary is within its own sheath, as in the nodes and the swellings of the head, as we have mentioned
Et species harum Strophularum sunt multae.	There are many kinds of these lymph nodes
Et ex eis enim sunt lapideae: et ex eis sunt quae continent humiditates: et ex eis sunt malignae, quae non obediunt curationi.	These are fatty [lymph nodes], and those which contain moisture, and malignant ones which do not yield to treatment
In illa ergo quam ex eis uides bonae dispositionis in tactu, cuius manifestum est propinquum colori cutis, et mouetur ad omnem partem, et non est annexa cum neruis colli, neque cum guidegi, neque cum arteria, neque est profunda: oportet ut seces eam sectione superficiali a superiori parte ad inferiorem partem corporis ex linea, b. ad lineam, g. et excoria eam ab omni parte: et extende duo labia cutis cum uncino, aut cum uncinis multis, si indiges illo, sicut diximus in apostematibus capitis, et extrahe eam paulatim.	Wherein, if there is a good flow of blood in the touch [i.e. the colour of the lymph node is similar to that of the surrounding skin], and it moves towards all parts, and is not connected with the nerves of the neck, or with the jugular veins, or arteries, or is not deep: it should be cut with a superficial incision from the upper part to the lower part of the body along a line, b. along a line, g. and the skin should be stripped away from all sides: and two lips of skin should be held together with a single layer, or with many layers if necessary, as is done with the swellings of the head, and the lymph should be extracted gradually
Et est super cautelam, ut non incidatur uena, aut neruus.	It is important to be cautious not to cut any blood vessel or nerve
Et sit spatumile non acutum ualde: ut non addat tibi manum tuam cum incisione, aut inquietet infirmum, et incidas quod non est necesse.	The wound should not be too sharp and wide: so as not to make your hand slip with the incision, or to frighten the patient, and you should cut only what is necessary
Si autem incidis uenam, aut arteriam, aut prohibet te ab operatione, tunc pone in uulnus zegi tritum, aut quosdam pulueres qui abscindunt sanguinem, et stringe uulnus, et dimitte ipsum, donec quiescat acuitas apostematis, et mollificetur uulnus: uel incipit et uult putrefieri.	If, however, you cut a vein or an artery, or are hindered by the operation, then put in the wound a piece of sponge which absorbs blood, or any powder which absorbs blood, and press the wound firmly, and leave it alone until the swelling subsides, and the wound is softened: or begin again and desist from the operation
Nam sanguis abscinditur tuncia Redi ergo ad operationem tuam, donec compleas.	Blood is severed by the clamp, Redi, until you complete the operation.
Deinde inquire digito tuo indice, si remansit aliquid ex Strophulis aliis paruis: ergo incide eas, et munda eas.	Then inquire with your index finger whether anything remains from the other small trophues: if so, cut them away, and wash them clean.
Quod si est in radice Strophulae uena magna: tunc oportet ut non incidas illam Strophulam ex radice sua: imo oportet ut liges eam cum filo duplato forti, et dimittas eam donec cadat per se absque nocumento.	If there is anything in the root of the large trophue: then it is necessary that you do not cut that trophue from its root: rather it is necessary that you bind it with a strong doubled thread, and let it go until it falls off by itself without any strangulation
Deinde imple uulnus coto ueteri, quod iam submersisti in unguento aegyptio.	Then place the outer coat of the sponge which you have submerged in Egyptian unguent under the edge of the wound
Deinde cura ipsum.	Then take care of yourself.
Si inciditur Strophula tota, tunc oportet ut aggreges labia duo uulneris: et suas ipsum statim, postquam uides quia prorsus non remansit superfluitas.	If the whole trophue is cut through, then it is necessary that you gather the two lips of the wound: and hold them together immediately, after which you should wash because there is no surplus left.
Si autem uides quod remansit superfluitas propter magnitudinem Strophulae, tunc oportet ut intendas ad incidendam radicem eius, et extrahendam eam: et administra suturam quam diximus.	If, however, you wash and find that there is still surplus because of the size of the trophue, then it is necessary that you insert your finger to the root of it and extract it: and perform the suture as we have said.
Et quae ex Strophulis continet humiditates, perfora illam perforatione superficiali: ut appareat tibi locus maturitatis eius: et pone perforationem ab eo quod sequitur inferius corporis, sicut diximus.	And as for the remainder of the trophues which contains moisture, perforate it with a superficial perforation: so that you may see the place of its maturity: and place the perforation below that which follows from the lower part of the body, as we have said
Deinde administra post perforationem licinia cum unguento, et similia eis, ut corrodat quod remansit ex corruptione, donec quando uides uulnus iam mundatum esse: tunc cura ipsum cum unguento generatiuo carnis, donec sanetur.	Then administer after the perforation lint with unguent, and like that, so that it consumes what remains from the corruption, until when you wash the wound you find that it is clean: then take care of yourself with the generated carnation of flesh until it is healed
¶ De sectione Epiglotis ab apostemate intra guttur accidente.	In the cutting of the epiglottis from the apostemate inwards of the gut, by chance
Caput XLIII.	Chapter XLIII.
Dixerunt antiqui hanc sectionem in Epigloti, et non uidi aliquem in terra nostra, qui eam fecerit: et haec est scriptura sermonis eorum.	They say that the ancients made this incision in the epiglottis, and no one in our land has ever done it: this is the writing of their words.
In habentibus autem synanchiam, oportet ut deuitetur sectio Epiglotis: cum non fiat iuuamentum per illud: propterea, quod omnes uenae et pulmo sunt infirmi.	But in our times, when the synanchiam has become swollen, it is necessary to make an incision in the epiglottis: for if this is not done, the veins and the lungs will be weakened.
In illis uero qui habent apostema calidum in ore, aut gutture, aut duabus amigdalis, quando non est aegritudo in cannali, oportet uti sectione Epiglotis, ad fugiendum ex perditione quae fit ex praefocatione.	In those who have a callous swelling in the mouth, or the gullet, or two abscesses in the tonsils, when there is no inflammation in the channel, it is necessary to make an incision in the epiglottis, in order to escape the destruction which results from the protrusion
Oportet ergo quando uolumus illud, ut secemus Epiglotim sub tribus circulis Epiglotis, aut quatuor, sectione parua per latitudinem, in eo quod est inter duos circulos per quantitatem, quod sit sectio in sifac, non in cartilagine: et iste quidem locus est conueniens sectioni, quoniam est priuatus carne, et uasa sanguinis ab eo sunt longinqua.	It is necessary therefore, when we wish to do this, to cut the epiglottis under three or four circles of the epiglottis, with a small incision across the width of the tissue between two circles, as it is in the cartilage, not in the flesh: and this is the most convenient place to make the incision, because it is devoid of flesh, and the blood vessels from it are long
Quod si medicator est timidus, tunc oportet ut extendat cutem gutturis cum uncino.	If the physician is timid, then it is necessary for him to extend the skin of the gullet with one finger.
Deinde findat cutem, donec quando peruenit ad cannalem: deuitet uas sanguinis, si uidet ex eis aliquid.	Then he will find the skin, until he reaches the channel: he will see blood vessels there, if anything has leaked out from them.
Deinde secet sifac quod narrauimus: et significatur super sectionem cannalis ex phlegmate quod egreditur ex ea, cum eo quod disrumpitur, et abscisione uocis.	Then he will cut the cartilage which we mentioned: and it is signified above the incision of the channel by the phlegm which comes out of it, with that which is broken, and with the cutting of the vein.
Et dimitte uulnus apertum tempore aliquo.	And let the wound be closed at a suitable time.
Cum ergo remouetur hora in qua timetur praefocatio, aggrega duo labia uulneris cutis, et sue ipsam solam absque cartilagine.	When the hour has passed in which the protrusion is complete, gather together two lips of the wound and stitch them only with the skin, without the cartilage
Deinde administra medicinas quae faciunt nasci carnem, usquequo sanetur.	Then give medicines which cause the flesh to grow until it is healed.
Inquit Albucasis.	Then give medicines which cause the flesh to grow until it is healed.
Summa huius sermonis quem narrauimus, expositio non est, nisi quando uident, quod aliquod horum apostematum iam opilauit guttur infirmi: et sublimatus est infirmus super mortem, et uult intersecari anhelitus eius: uadunt ad secandum Epiglotim, ut respiret infirmus super locum uulneris quadam respiratione, et saluetur a morte: et propter hoc praeceperunt dimittere uulnus apertum, donec consumatur malicia aegritudinis, et est malicia eius tribus diebus, et quasi ipsa: tunc ergo praecaeperunt suere uulnus, et curare ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then give medicines which cause the flesh to grow until it is healed.
Et illud quod uidi per me ipsum est, quod una ancilla accaepit cultellum, et misit cum in guttur suum, et incidit cum eo partem cannalis pulmonis.	Then give medicines which cause the flesh to grow until it is healed.
Et uocatus sum ad curationem eius, et inueni eam mugire, sicut est mugitus mortui.	Then give medicines which cause the flesh to grow until it is healed

Confisus ergo sum, quod ipsa non absciderat uenam, neque guidegi: et uentus egrediebatur ex uulnere.	Then give medicines which cause the flesh to grow until it is healed

Hinc ergo dico: quod in sectione Epiglotis non est timor.	Then give medicines which cause the flesh to grow until it is healed
¶ De sectione Herniae gutturis.	Then give medicines which cause the flesh to grow until it is healed
Caput XLIIII.	Then give medicines which cause the flesh to grow until it is healed
Hoc Apostema nominatum Hernia gutturis, est apostema magnum, secundum colorem corporis: et est in mulieribus multum.	Then give medicines which cause the flesh to grow until it is healed
Et est secundum duos modos: aut enim est naturale: aut est accidentale.	Then give medicines which cause the flesh to grow until it is healed
In naturali certe non est ingenium.	Then give medicines which cause the flesh to grow until it is healed
Accidentale uero est secundum duos modos: quorum unus est similis nodis pinguibus.	The accidental wound is of two kinds: one is like a pimple.
Et modus alter, est similis apostemati quod fit ex nodatione arteriae.	The other kind is like an abscess which arises from a knot in a blood vessel.
Et in ipso est timor, et non oportet ut praesumptio fiat ad ipsum cum ferro, nisi in eo quod est paruum: et tu proba ipsum, et inuestiga ipsum cum Intromisso.	There is fear in this, and it must not be presumed that it is small: and you must try it out and examine it with an instrument.
Si ergo inuenis ipsum simile nodo pingui, et non est suspensum cum aliqua uenarum: tunc seca ipsum, sicut secantur nodi: et extrahe ipsum cum eo quod continet ex kisti, si est in kisti: et si non, tunc perscrutare totum eius.	If you find it to be like a pimple and not associated with any other swelling: then dry it out, as you would dry out a pimple; and extract it with the instrument which contains the pus, if there is pus in it: or if not, then examine the whole of it thoroughly
Deinde cura locum cum eo quod oportet ex curatione, donec sanetur.	Then care for the place with it until it is healed
¶ De sectione super species Nodorum.	Regarding the excision of something bigger than a pimple.</start_of_turn>
Caput XLV.	(The text continues with the next section of the book.)</start_of_turn>
Nodorum multae sunt species, et ego iam dixi omnes species eorum in diuisione: et oportet ut narrem hic differentiam inter Nodum, et Exituram: cum sit dubitationem faciens.	There are many kinds of knots, and I have already mentioned all their kinds in their order: and it is necessary to know the difference between a knot and an extrusion, when there is doubt.</start_of_turn>
Dico ergo, quod cum Exitura est caliditas, et febris, et dolores uehementes, donec sedatur ebullitio superfluitatis, et completur putrefactio: tunc enim quiescunt febris et calor.	I say, therefore, that when an extrusion has become cold, and has lost its heat, and the pain has subsided: then the swelling has subsided, and the corruption has ceased. And then the fever and heat will cease.</start_of_turn
Cum Nodo uero non est caliditas, neque febris, neque dolores, et continet eos kistis sifachin, qui est eis saccus proprius, et est secundum colorem corporis: et est incaeptio eorum sicut cicer, et fit sicut batecha, et maior et minor.	When, on the other hand, there is a knot which has no heat, neither fever, nor pain, and which contains pus in its own sac, which is its natural container, and which is similar in color to the body: and which has the character of cicer, being soft and having the size of a bean, or bigger or smaller.</start_of_turn
Et sunt secundum duas species: aut pingues: aut continent humiditatem.	And there are two kinds: either soft or containing moisture.</start_of_turn
Et colores humiditatis sunt multi, secundum quod dixi in diuisione.	And the colours of moisture are many, as I have said in the previous discourse.
Oportet ergo, quando peruenis ad curationem Nodi, ut experiaris eum, et inquiras ipsum in primis cum instrumento quod nominatur Intromissum, secundum quod ueniet forma eius in capitulo quod est post hoc.	It is necessary therefore, when you reach the treatment of the Node, to experiment with it and inquire about it first with the instrument which is called the Intromissum, as its form will be explained in the following chapter.
Et modus inquisitionis apostematum, et Nodorum omnium est, ut accipias hoc instrumentum, et intromittas ipsum in humidiorem locum, quem inuenis in apostemate: et tu reuolue digitos tuos cum eo paulatim, donec scias quod instrumentum iam penetrauit cutem.	The method of inquiry after the swelling of the Node and of all Nodes is as follows: you take this instrument and introduce it into the moist place which you find in the swelling: and you gradually withdraw your fingers until you know that the instrument has penetrated the skin
Deinde ultima manum tuam secundum mensuram magnitudinis apostematis.	Then lastly you move your hand according to the measure of the swelling
Deinde extrahe Intromissum, et considera illud quod egrediur in uestigio eius.	Then withdraw the Intromissum and consider what comes out of its wound
Si ergo egreditur humiditas currens, quicunque color sit: tunc seca ipsum sectione superficiali, secundum quod dixi in reliquis apostematibus.	If therefore liquid moisture comes out, whatever its colour be: then dry it with a superficial section, as I have said in the other swellings.
Et si non egreditur humiditas in uestigio Intromissi, tunc scias quia est pinguis: seca ergo super ipsum sectione habente formam crucis, secundum formam hanc, sicut docui te: et suspende ipsum cum uncinis, et excoria cutem ab omni parte cum facilitate: et custodi kistin si potes super illud, ut extrahas ipsam sanam cum Nodo.	And if no moisture comes out of the wound of the Intromissum, then you know that it is hard: dry it therefore with a section having the shape of a cross, as it has been shown: and suspend it with sutures, and strip away the skin from all sides with ease: and keep the fat if there is any above that, until you have extracted the Node whole.
Si autem disrumpitur kistis apud operationem, et non est possibile extrahere ipsam sanam, multotiens enim accidit illud, tunc extrahe ipsam frustatim, donec non remaneat ex ea aliquid.	If indeed the bladder is burst during the operation and it is not possible to extract it whole, as often happens in this case, then extract it fragment by fragment, until nothing remains of it
Nam si remanet ex ea aliquid parum, aut multum, redit Nodus secundum plurimum.	For if there remains anything of it, little or much, the Node returns most of the time.
Quod si uincit te, et remanet ex eo parum: tunc imple uulnus apud completionem tuam, quibusdam pulueribus corrosiuis acutis: et stringe uulnus, et pone supra ipsum quod sedet apostema calidum, et cura ipsum cum reliqua curatione, donec sanetur.	If you are stung by it, and there remains a little: then make a wound at the completion of your work, with some corrosive powders for acute wounds: and string the wound, and place above it the softened swelling, and care for it with the rest of the treatment, until it heals.</start_of_turn>
Si ergo est Nodus magnus, tunc sue duo labia eius, et cura ipsum cum eo quod incarnat.	If there is a large knot, then two of its lips must be sutured, and care for it as though it were a living thing.
Si autem est tibi contraria uena pulsatilis, aut non pulsatilis: tunc propera, et imple locum zegi trito, et dimitte ipsum strictum duobus diebus, aut tribus, donec putrefiat uulnus, et quiescat ebullitio sanguinis: deinde redi ad incidendum illud quod remansit ex Nodo.	If, however, the opposite side be swollen or not swollen: then prepare it, and make a place for the excision of the tumor, and keep it bound for two or three days, until the tumor has decayed, and the blood-clotting has ceased: then return to the incision which remains of the knot.
¶ De foris instrumentorum pro sectione et perforatione.	As to instruments for the cutting and perforating of the knot.
Caput XLVI.	Chapter 46.
EX Eis sunt formae Intromissorum, et sunt trium specierum.	From the veins there are three forms of inward protrusions, and there are three kinds of them.
Ex eis enim est magnum, et ex eis est medium, et ex eis est paruum.	From these veins there is a large one, and a medium one, and a small one
Fiant ex ferro alfulud quadratarum extremitatum decenter, ut festinent introitum in apostemate.	Let them be of iron, blunt at the extremities and pointed in the middle, so that they may hasten the entrance into the abscess
Et istae sunt formae Experientium, et no, id est, perforantia: et unum eorum nominatur beris, idest, peforans: et sunt trium specierum.	These are the forms of the experienced ones, and no, that is, perforators: and one of them is called a beris, that is, a perforator, and there are three kinds of them
Ex eis enim est magnum, et medium, et paruum.	From these veins there is a large one, and a medium one, and a small one
Conueniunt, ut inuestigentur per ea apostemata, et exiturae, et fistulae, et bubones ab eo quod inter ea est ex ossibus.	They converge, so that they may investigate through these abscesses, and exits, and fistulas, and bubbles from that which is between the bones
Et aliis fiunt rotunda, tersa, lenia, sicut acus magnae quibus subsellia suuntur, ex citrino scilicet, aut ex aere, aut ferro, aut argento.	And others are round, third, and smooth, like a large needle which sews under silk, from citrine or from air, or iron, or silver.
Et meliora eorum sunt quae fiunt ex citrino.	And the best of these are those which are made from citrine.
Et fiunt Experientia etiam de plumbo nigro, quae conueniunt ut per ea experiantur fistulae, quarum concauitate sunt reflexiones, ut reflectantur cum lenitate sua cum illis reflexionibus.	And there are also experiences to be made from black lead, which converge so that they may pass through these fistulas, the reflections of whose concavity will be reflected back with their smoothness against those reflections
Et sunt iterum trium specierum.	There are three kinds again.
Quoniam ex eis sunt longa, ex eis media, et ex eis breuia, secundum quantitatem amplitudinis fistulae et stricturae eius.	For according to the quantity of the breadth of the fistula and the extent of its narrowing, there are three kinds: long, medium, and short.
Forma Vncinorum, et sunt multarum specierum.	The shapes of the fistulas are various, and there are many kinds
Quoniam ex eis sunt simplices, scilicet quibus est curuitas una: et sunt trium specierum sicut uides, Magni, Medii, et Parui.	For according to the quantity of the breadth of the fistula and the extent of its narrowing, there are three kinds: simple, that is to say having only one curvature: and there are three kinds like fluids, great, medium, and small
Et ex eis sunt Vncini caeci: et sunt trium specierum.	The fistulas are blind at one end, and there are three kinds of them.
Et ex eis sunt uncini habentes duas curuaturas, et sunt trium specierum: et ex eis sunt uncini habentes tres curuaturas, et sunt trium specierum: et omnes isti sunt necessarii in loco suo.	There are three kinds which have two curvatures at one end, and three kinds which have three curvatures at one end; all of these are necessary in their place
Et istae sunt formae Scalpellorum, quibus secantur et excoriantur Nodi, et apostemata: et sunt trium specierum: quoniam ex eis est magnum, medium, et paruum.	These are the forms of scalpels which cut and scrape knots and abscesses: and there are three kinds of them, for according to the quantity of the breadth of the fistula and the extent of its narrowing there are three kinds: large, medium, and small
Eorum extremitates quibus fit sectio sunt acutae, extremitates aliae sunt non acutae: et non ponuntur taliter, nisi ut cum eis fiat iuuamentum in excoriatione Nodorum apud timorem incisionis uenae, aut nerui: et ut sanetur per ea infirmus, et inueniat tranquillitatem parumper ex adustione quam inuenit apud excoriationem apostematis.	The extremities which are cut are acute, but the others are not acute: and they are not placed like this, except when there is an operation on the excision of knots near the fear of the division of the vein, or nerve: and in order that the patient may recover more easily from the surgery than from the excision of an abscess
Istae sunt Magda, et sunt specierum trium.	These are great, and there are three kinds of them
Fiunt ex aere, et sunt similia Radio, cum quo fit alcohol: et in extremitate lata est puncta Spatumilis occultata: et in ea currit ad interiora, et ad exteriora quando uis, sicut uides.	They are made of air, and are similar to a radio, with which alcohol is made: and at the wide end there is a hidden Spatumilis point: and in this there runs inwards and outwards when needed, like liquids
Forma Spatumilium quae absconduntur inter digitos apud perforationem apostematum: et non percipiunt ea infirmi: et sunt trium specierum, magnum, medium, et paruum.	The form of the Spatumili which are driven between the fingers at the perforation of the abscess: and the patient does not perceive them: and there are three kinds, large, medium, and small
Fomae Ventosarum cum quibus abscinditur fluxus sanguinis: et sunt trium specierum, magnae, mediae, et paruae.	Wind-formed foam when severed breaks blood flow: there are three kinds, great, medium, and small.
Fiant ex aere, aut citrino, rotundae, ad longitudinem parumper, sicut uides: et sint ad subtilitatem.	Foam arises from air or citrine [substance], rotund in shape, to a moderate length, like tears: and they are slight in weight
Et oportet ut sint istae species Ventosarum apud te magnae, et paruae: ut abscindas per eas sanguinem cum uelocitate apud necessitatem, et tunc quando non est tibi praesens medicina.	It is necessary that these kinds of wind-foam should be great and small in your case: so that you can sever blood flow quickly when necessary, and when there is no physician present.
Verumtamen non utaris eis in abscisione sanguinis in omni loco corporis, et non utaris nisi in locis carnosis: sicut lacertis cruris, et coxae, et lacertis brachiorum, et mammillarum, et uentris, et inguinum, et similibus eis, ex lacertis carnosis, humidis.	Indeed, do not employ these in the severance of blood in every part of the body, and do not use them except in places where there is carnation: such as for fractures of the limb, the hip, fractures of the forearm and breast, of the belly, groin, and similar places, from fractures of carnation, humors.
Et quandoque fiunt ex eis instrumenta parua alia similia corticibus fisticorum, secundum suam formam: quibus abscinditur sanguis quando fluit ex loco phlebotomiae, aut apud incisionem uenae, aut arteriae: et quandoque fiunt ex eis rotundae secundum hanc formam.	And sometimes these are other small instruments like fragments of sponges, according to their form: with which blood is severed when it flows from the site of phlebotomy, or at the incision of the vein, or artery: and sometimes they are rounded in this fashion
¶ De cura Mammillarum hominum quae mammillis mulierum assimilantur.	Concerning the care of the breasts of women who suckle the breasts of women.
Caput XLVII.	Chapter XLVII.
Quandoque inflantur Mammillae quorundam hominum apud complementum somni (id est, cum incipiunt pollui in somno) donec similantur mammillis mulierum: et remanent apostemosae foede.	When the breasts of some men swell somewhat during the night (that is, when they begin to become soiled in sleep) until they resemble the breasts of women: and they remain soft after they have become soiled.
Qui ergo abhorret illud, oportet ut secet super mammillas sectione lunari, secundum hanc formam ex linea, b. ad lineam, g. Deinde excoria pinguedinem totam.	Whoever dislikes that, it is necessary to cut across the breast with a lunar section, according to this form from the line A to line B, and then from line B to the edge.
Postea imple uulnus ex medicamine incarnatiuo.	Then apply a little ointment from the medicaments of incision.
Deinde aggrega duo labia uulneris cum sutura, et cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then join the two lips of the incision with sutures, and care for it until it heals.
Si autem declinat mammilla ad inferiora, et mollificatur propter magnitudinem suam, sicut accidit mulieribus: tunc oportet ut findatur in duobus lateribus suis superioribus duabus sectionibus similibus figurae lunari, quarum unaquaeque continetur cum altera apud fines utriusque, donec sit linea maior continens minorem, secundum hanc formam ex linea, b. ad lineam, g. Postea excoria cutem quae est inter duo labia, et aufer pinguedinem, et administra quod diximus de sutura et pulueribus, quod est necessarium ex curatione, donec sanetur.	If, however, the breast droops downwards and is softened by its size, as often happens with women: then it is necessary to find two sutures on the two upper sides of the breast, similar in shape to a crescent moon. Each one should be continued with the other at the end of each, until the line which contains the greater part contains the smaller, following this shape from the line b. to the line g. Then scrape the skin between the two lips and remove the fat, and administer what we have said concerning suture and powder, which is necessary for the cure, until the wound is healed.
Si autem non comples incisionem eius quod oportet te incidere, propter inquietudinem infirmi, aut propter fluxum sanguinis: tunc oportet ut impleas uulnus coto submerso unguento corrosiuo, et dimitte ipsum, donec corrodat illud quod remansit ex pinguedine.	If, however, you do not wish to make an incision, because of the patient's anxiety or because of the flow of blood: then you must place a sponge soaked in corrosive unguent under the wound and let it go, until that which remains of the fat has corroded.
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then care for the wound until it is healed.</start_of_turn>
¶ De perforatione apostematis, quod accidit sub Titillico.	In the perforation of the nipple, which happens under the nipple of Titillicus.</start_of_turn>
Caput XLVIII.	Chapter XLVIII.</start_of_turn
Ista apostemata quae accidunt sub Titillico, sunt ex speciebus Strophularum dura, quae continet kistis, et ex eis sunt quae continent humiditates.	These nipples which happen under the nipple of Titillicus are of the kind of hard stropheae which contain vesicles, and from these are those which contain humours.</start_of_turn

Which are from the humours which contain moisture, must be sectioned with a lunar shape, following this shape from the line b. to the line g. when all that is in the nipple is evacuated from the blood, then place a sponge under the old one and let it go until the next day.</start_of_turn
Deinde auferatur cotum, et curetur cum unguento conueniente ad illud, donec sanetur.	Then remove the sponge and care for it with a suitable unguent until it is healed.</start_of_turn
Quod si apostema fuerit ex specie nodorum Strophularum, tunc scinde super ipsum, sicut diximus in sectione super Strophulas aequaliter.	If the nipple should be of the kind of knots of stropheae, then split it above it, as we said concerning the stropheae which are equal.</start_of_turn

¶ De sectione apostematis quod accidit propter Arteriam et Venam.	In the event that the swelling results from an artery or vein.</start_of_turn>
Caput XLIX.	Chapter 49.</start_of_turn>
Quando disrumpitur Arteria, et consolidatur cutis quae est supra eam, tuno multotiens accidit inde apostema: et similiter accidit Venae etiam, ut accidat in ea apostema et inflatio.	When an artery is ruptured, and the skin above it is consolidated, a great swelling often arises from the wound: in the same way, swelling may also arise in a vein, as it does in the case of the wound and the swelling.</start_of_turn
Et signa quibus cognoscitur, quod apostema et inflatio sint propter Arteriam et Venam, sunt: quoniam, quando apostema est propter arteriam, est longum, aggregatum in profundo corporis: et quando impellis apostema digits tuis, sentis quasi sit ei stridor.	The signs by which it is known that the swelling and swelling are caused by an artery or a vein are these: for when the swelling is caused by an artery, it is long and aggregated in the depth of the body: and when you press on the swelling with your finger, you feel as though there is a constriction.</start_of_turn
Et illud quod est propter Venam, est rotundum in manifesto corporis.	And that which is caused by a vein is round in its manifestation on the surface of the body.</start_of_turn
Et sectio super hoc apostema est error, et praecipue quod est sub ascellis, et inguinibus, et collo, et in locis multis corporis: et est magnum ualde.	The section of such a swelling is dangerous, especially if it is under the armpits, and in the groin, and the throat, and in many parts of the body: and it is very dangerous.</start_of_turn
Oportet ergo ut deuitetur eius cura cum ferro, et quod ex eis etiam est in extremitatibus, aut in capite, oportet ut deuitetur.	It is therefore necessary to take care of such a swelling with fire, and that which is also in the extremities, or in the head, it is necessary to take care of it.</start_of_turn
Super illud ergo quod ex eis est ex inflatione orificii Arteriae, finde in cute sectione in longitudine.	Furthermore, from the inflation of the opening of the artery, find in the cut in the length.</start_of_turn
Deinde aperi sectionem cum uncinis, postea Arteriam: et libera eam ex tunicis, donec detegatur.	Then open the cut with hooks, afterwards the artery: and free the wound from the tunics, until it is detached.</start_of_turn
Deinde intromitte sub ea acum, et fac eam penetrare usque ad latus aliud, et stringe Arteriam cum filo duplo in duobus locis, secundum quod docui te in extractione duarum Arteriarum quae sunt in timporibus.	Then introduce under these the point of the needle, and make the wound penetrate right through to the other side, and ligate the artery with two threads in two places, as we taught you in the extraction of two arteries which are in the course of time.</start_of_turn
Deinde punge locum, qui est inter duo ligamenta cum spatumili, donec egrediatur sanguis qui est in eo totus, et soluatur apostema.	Then plunge the location which is between two ligaments with the sponge, until blood which is in it altogether has gone out, and the swelling is dissolved.
Deinde administra curationem quae generat pus, donec cadant ligamenta: postea cura illud cum unguentis conuenientibus ad illud, donec sanetur.	Then perform the treatment which generates pus, until the ligaments are severed: afterwards care for it with suitable unguents until it is healed.
Quod si fuerit apostema propter sectionem Venae, tunc oportet ut teneas manu tua quod tibi possibile est ex apostemate cum cute.	If there is swelling because of the cutting of a vein, then it is necessary to remove the clots from the swelling with the hand as much as possible from the swelling with the skin
Deinde intromitte acum sub loco quem tenuisti manu tua, et fac eam penetrare: et sit in ea filum duplum, donec extrahas ipsum ex latere altero.	Then introduce the needle under the place where you have held your hand, and make it penetrate: and be in it two strings, until you have pulled it out from the other side.
Deinde liga cum ipso apostema ligamento bono: secundum quod dixi tibi in ligamento uuae, a duabus partibus cum duabus extremitatibus fili.	Then bind with the swelling the ligament with a good ligature: according to what I have said to you concerning the ligature of the veins, from two parts with two extremities of the thread.
Si autem times quod extrahatur filum, tunc intromitte acum aliam cum filo alio sub apostemate toto apud incisionem acus: preme, et stringe fila tua in quatuor locis.	If you are afraid that the thread will be pulled out, then introduce another needle with another thread under the whole swelling at the incision of the needle: beforehand, and tighten your thread in four places
Deinde seca apostema in medio sui, donec quando egreditur quod in eo est: tunc incide superfluitatem cutis, et dimitte quod ligatum est ex ea.	Then dry the swelling in its middle, until when it has gone out what is in it: then cut the excess of the skin, and remove what is bound from it
Deinde pone super ipsum puluillum quem submersisti in uino, et oleo.	Then put over it a little ball which you have submerged in wine, and oil.
Deinde administra curationem, quae fit cum liciniis et unguentis, donec sanetur.	Then perform the treatment which is made with liniments and unguents, until it is healed
¶ De apostemate quod accidit ex torsione Neruorum.	As for the swelling which arises from the twisting of nerves.
Caput L.	Chapter L.
Sicut accidit apostema in Arteria et Vena, similiter accidit apostema in Neruis: quod accidit in eis percussio, aut accidit a labore superfluo, et similibus: et fit plurimum illis in locis adiutoriorum, aut calcanei, et in omni loco in quo mouentur iuncturae: et est apostema graue.	Like that which happens with swelling in the Artery and the Vein, in the same way it happens with the nerves: which happens in the percussion of them, or from excessive work, and in a similar way: and it happens most of all in the armpits, or the calves, and in every place where there is a joint movement: and it is a serious swelling
Similatur color eius reliquo corpori, et est in pluribus dispositionibus absque dolore: et quando stringitur cum uehementia, sentit in eo infirmus simile stupori.	Its colour is similar to that of the rest of the body, and is in various positions without causing pain: and when it is stretched with force, it feels in it like drunkenness.
Et non est apostema aggregatum in profundo corporis, imo est sub cute, et ipsum mouetur ad omnem partem, et non uadit ad anteriora, uel ante, neque retro ad posteriora.	It is not a swelling which has gathered in the depth of the body, but is under the skin, and it moves to every part, and does not go forward or backward or downwards
Quod ergo ex eis est in iuncturis, non oportet ut inuadatur cum ferro.	That which is in the joints is like nails, it does not cause them to be struck with iron.
Fortasse enim accidet contractio.	Perhaps there will be a contraction.
In illo autem quod ex eis est in capite, aut in fronte, finde cutem cum spatumili.	But as for that which is in the head, or in the face, find the skin with a spatula.
Si ergo est apostema paruum, tunc tene ipsum cum forficibus, et abscinde ipsum a radice.	If it is a small swelling, then hold it with forceps, and cut it off from its root.
Et si est magnum, tunc suspende ipsum eum uncino, et excoria ipsum: deinde aufer ipsum, et aggrega uulnus cum sutura: et cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	And if it is large, then suspend it with a thread, and scrape it off: then take it away, and mix it with wax: and sew it up, and care for it until it heals.
¶ De sectione apostematis, quod accidit in uentre.	About the cutting of a swelling which happens inside.
Caput LI.	Chapter LI.</start_of_turn>
Accidunt quibusdam hominibus multotiens in uentribus eorum, et in reliquis corporibus ipsorum, thelil, quae nominantur Fungalia, per similitudinem ipsorum cum fungis.	These things happen to many people in the belly and in the rest of their bodies, these things which are called Fungalia, because of their resemblance to fungi.</start_of_turn>
Quorum radix est subtilis, et ipsorum caput est grossum, et conuersa sunt labia eorum.	Their root is soft, and their head is large, and their edges are rounded off.</start_of_turn
Et est ex eis paruum: et est ex eis quod magnificatur ualde.	And it is like a small nail: and it grows large with heat.</start_of_turn
Et ego quidem iam uidi uirum, et in uentre eius erant duo thelil, quae erant magis quam rebus aliis similia fungis: non erat differentia inter ea, alba, minutae radicis, et inuersabantur labia eorum, et findebantur, et humiditas currebat ex eis semper.	And I also saw a man who had two of these things in his belly, which were larger than any others: there was no difference between them, white or black, small or large, and their edges were flexible, and there was moisture coming from them always.</start_of_turn
Incidi ergo ea, et inueni in pondere unius quasi X et VIII uncia et in altero quasi VI uncia Et operatio in incisione eorum est, ut consideres tunc, si infirmus est humidus, et color thelil est albus, humidum, subtilis radicis: tunc incide ipsum cum spatumili lato, et sint in praesentia tua cauteria in igne.	The wound did yield somewhat, and I found in its weight about X and eight uncia in one and about six uncia in the other. And the operation in its incision is such that you must consider immediately if the patient is humidus, and the colour of the thelil is white, humidum, subtilis radicis: then you must make the incision with a broad spatula, and there will be in your presence cauteria in igne.
Multotiens enim expellitur apud sectionem eius sanguis multus: propera ergo si te uincit sanguis, tunc cauteriza ipsum.	A great quantity of blood is expelled at the section of the wound: take care therefore if blood is inciting you, then cauterize it immediately.
Quod si uides infirmum pauidum et timidum ab incisione cum ferro, tunc accipe filum ex plumbo decenter factum, et stringe cum eo athelul: cuius modus est quem diximus, et dimitte ipsum duobus diebus.	If you see the patient weak and timid from the incision with the knife, then take a leaden weight with a hole in the middle, and string it with thread: in whose manner it is which we have said, and let it go in two days
Deinde adde in strictura plumbi.	Then add lead to the stricture.
Non ergo cesses stringere plumbum, quotiens imprimit in thelil, donec abscindatur, et cadat per se absque labore.	Do not cease to string the lead until it is excreted, and it will go out by itself without toil
Si autem thelil grossae fuerit radicis, tunc in incisione eius est quiddam timoris et pauoris: praecipue quod est in uentre.	If the thelil is large of root, then in its incision there is something fearful and weak: especially what is in the belly.
Verumtamen possibile est, ut incidas medietatem eius.	It is indeed possible that you may cut through the middle of it.
Deinde cauteriza ipsum, ut non redeat.	Then cauterize it, so that it does not return
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur uulnus.	Then care for it, until the wound is healed
Et caue ne praesumas incidere thelil quod est fusci coloris, pauci sensus, foedi aspectus: ipsum enim est apostema cancerosum: et ego ueniam cum rememoratione Cancri post hoc.	And take heed that you do not presume to cut the thelil which is of a dusky colour, little sense, foul aspect: for it is a cancerous tumour: and I shall remind you of cancer after this
¶ De cura eminentiae Vmbilici.	About the care of the umbilical cord.
Caput LII.	Section 52.
Fit eminentia Vmbilici ex caussis multis.	The swelling of the Umbilical region is from many ulcers.
Aut ex fissuris sifac, quod super uentrem est: et exit ex eo althub, aut intestinum, secundum quod accidit in reliquis rupturis.	Or from rents in the bowels which are above the belly: and come out from this through the navel, or the intestines, according as is the case with the rest of the ruptures.
Aut ex sanguine qui fluit ex Vena, aut ex Arteria, secundum quod praemissum est.	Or from blood which flows from the vein, or from the artery, according as has been said before.
Aut ex uentositate coartata in eo.	Or from a clotted mass in that area.
Si autem est propter fissuram sifac, et exitum thirbi: tunc est color apostematis similis colori corporis: et est lene, absque dolore: et apparet diuersi situs.	If however it is from a rent in the bowels, and the evacuation of the black bile: then is the colour like that of the body: and is soft, without pain: and appears in various places.
Et si est propter egressionem intestini, tunc est situs eius, cum eo quod narrauimus, uehementioris diuersitatis.	And if it is from the discharge of the intestines, then is its place with that which we have narrated, of greater diversity.
Cum ergo tu premis ipsum digitis tuis, occultatur: deinde redit, et fortasse est cum eo sonitus: et magnificatur multum apud introitum balnei, et laborem uehaementum.	When you place your finger on it, it is hidden: then it returns, and perhaps with a sound: and swells greatly at the entrance of the bath, and painful sweat
Si uero est propter humiditatem, est lene, tunc non occultatur quando premis ipsum manu tua, neque constringium, neque additur.	If however it is from humidity, it is soft: then it is not hidden when you place your hand on it, neither is it constricted, neither does it increase
Quod si est propter sanguinem, tunc cum istis signis apparet apostema ad nigredinem de cliue.	Which if from blood, then appears with these signs a black bile.
Si autem est propter carnem natam: tunc est apostema graue, grossum, durum, et figitur secundum quantitatem unam.	If however it is from dead flesh: then is the bile dark, thick, hard, and appears according to the quantity of one.
Si uero est propter uentositatem, tunc tactus eius est lenis.	If however it is from inflammation, then its touch is soft
Et operatio in illo est, ut consideres tunc, si eminentia umbilici est propter sanguinem Arteriae, aut Venae, aut uentositatem: tunc oportet ut prohibearis a curatione eius.	And the operation in that is as you consider, if the swelling of the navel is from blood of the artery, or the vein, or inflammation: then it is necessary to abstain from its treatment.</start_of_turn>
Nam in illo est timor et pauor, sicut docui te in capitulo, in quo dixi apostemata propter arteriam et uenam.	Fear and timidity are common in such matters, as I have already taught you in the previous chapter, concerning the evacuation of stool due to an artery and vein.
Quod si eminentia umbilici est propter intestinum, aut zirbum: tunc oportet ut praecipias infirmo, quatenus teneat anhelitum suum, et stet stans extensus.	If the swelling of the belly is caused by the intestines or the spleen: then it is necessary to urge the patient to evacuate his flatulence, as much as he is able, and to remain standing extended
Deinde signa cum encaustro in circumitu umbilici totius.	Then signs are with retention of the faeces all around the belly.
Postea praecipe ei, ut resupinetur inter manus tuas super dorsum suum.	Then command him to lie down between your hands on his back
Deinde circunda cum spatumili lato in circumitu umbilici super locum quem signasti cum encaustro.	Then surround with a sponge broad in the circumference of the belly on the place which you indicated with retention of the faeces
Postea extende medium apostematis ad superiora, cum uncino magno.	Then extend the middle of the evacuation towards the upper parts, with a large sponge.
Deinde liga eum in circumitu forti cum filo, aut cum chorda de serico ligamento firmo: et sit nodus ligamenti alenxotati.	Then bind him firmly in the circumference with thread, or with a strong silk cord: and make a knot which is fixed.
Deinde aperi medium apostematis extensum supra ligamentum.	Then open the middle of the evacuation which is extended above the ligature.
Si ergo inueneris ipsum iam captum a ligamento: tunc extrahe alenxotati, et intromitte in ipsum digitum indicem, et impelle intestinum ad interiora uentris: et si inueneris zirbum, tunc accipe ipsum cum uncino, et incide superfluitatem eius.	If you find that the bowels are caught by the ligature: then draw out the fixed parts and introduce the index finger into it, and push the intestine inwards: and if you find the spleen, then grasp it with the thumb and cut off its excess
Si autem contraria est tibi arteria, aut uena: tunc circunda ipsum multum.	But if the artery or vein is contrary: then surround it muchly
Deinde redi ad operationem tuam.	Then return to your operation.
Et accipe duas acus, et intromitte in eis duo fila fortia: et intromitte duas acus in circumitu quem fecisti circa apostema in modum crucis, quas facis penetrare.	And take two needles, and introduce them into the two strong threads: and introduce two needles in the circumference which you made around the stool in the manner of a cross, which you make penetrate
Deinde stringe apostema in quatuor locis super acus: et si uis, aufer acus, et dimitte locum, donec putrefiat caro extensa: et cadat per se: aut incide ipsam quando subtiliatur et putrefit.	Then string the stool in four places on the needles: and if you wish, remove the needles and leave the place, until the extended flesh has putrefied: and it will fall away by itself: or cut it off when it has become thin and putrefied
Deinde cura ipsum cum eo quod oportet ex unguentis, donec sanetur.	Then care for yourself with what is necessary from unguents until you are healed.
Quod si eminentia umbilici est ex carne nara in eo, aut ex humiditate: tunc oportet ut concaues apostema, sicut diximus.	If swelling of the belly is from carrion in it, or from moisture: then it is necessary to make incisions of the carbuncles, as we have said
Et extrahas sanguinem, aut humiditatem, quam inuenis in eo.	And draw out the blood, or moisture, which you find in it
Deinde cura ipsum cum eo quod solidat locum.	Then care for yourself with what is necessary from unguents until you are healed.
¶ De cura CANCRI.	About the care of cancer
Caput LIII.	Chapter 53
Iam diximus in diuisione species Cancri, et qualiter est uia ad curationem eius cum medicinis: et cauendum ab eo cum curatione eius cum ferro, ut non ulceretur: et diximus Cancrum generatum in matrice, et cautelam a curatione eius.	We have already said in the discourse concerning the kinds of cancer, and how it is to be treated by physicians: and we must be careful with it so that it does not ulcerate: and we have said that cancer is generated in the womb, and we must be cautious of its treatment.
Et dixerunt antiqui, quod quandoque Cancer est in loco, ubi possibilis est eius eradicatio: sicut Cancer qui est in mammillis, aut in coxa, et eis similibus, ex membris locatis ad extrahendum totum eius: praecipue quando est incipiens paruus.	And the ancients have said that when cancer is in a place where it is possible to eradicate it: such as cancer that is in the breast, or in the hip, and the like, from members that can be excised whole: especially when it is beginning small.
Quando uero antiquatur, et est magnus, non oportet ut appropinques ei.	When it is old, and is great, it is not proper to approach it.
Ego enim non potui sanare ex eo aliquem: neque uidi alium ante me qui peruenerit ad illud.	I cannot cure anyone from it: neither do I know anyone who has been able to do so before me
Et operatio in eo, quando est locatus sicut diximus, est, ut praecedas, et soluas infirmum ex cholera nigra aliquotiens.	And the operation in it, when it is located as we have said, is to precede it, and to solve the disease with black bile several times over
Deinde phlebotoma ipsum si inuenis cum repletione manifesta.	Then perform a phlebotomy if you find it with a swelling that manifests itself
Deinde praepara infirmum praeparatione, in qua locetur cum operatione.	Then prepare the patient for the preparation in which he is placed with the operation
Deinde proiice in Cancrum uncinos qui conueniunt ei.	Then remove from cancer the nails that agree with it
Postea concaua ipsum ab omni parte cum cute, secundum perscrutationem, donec non remaneat aliquid ex radicibus eius: et dimitte sanguinem currere, et non abscindas ipsum uelociter, imo exprime loca, et absterge sanguinem grossum totum manu tua, aut cum quo possibile est ibi ex instrumentis.	Afterwards, concave out the cavity entirely with the knife, following the directions, until nothing remains of the roots: then let blood flow freely, and do not quickly cut through it, but rather press down firmly, and evacuate all the thick blood from your hand, or with whatever instruments are available.
Si autem contrarietatem facit tibi fluxus sanguinis grossi ex incisione arteriae, aut uenae: tunc cauteriza uenam, donec abscindatur sanguis.	If, however, it causes the thick blood to flow from the incision of an artery or vein: then cauterize the vein, until the bleeding stops.
