Then strip the intestines, and those which are under the skin of the testicles, until the white intestine is detected, hard from all parts: then insert your finger into the index of that which follows the testicle, in that which is between the white intestine and the testicle, which is under the skin, and between the intestines according to quantity, and absolutely with that which is adhered to the posterior part of the testicle.
Deinde moue cum manu dextra ad interiora cutem testiculorum: et cum hoc extende sifach album ad sursum, cum manu sinistra: et eleua ouum cum sifach ad partem sectionis: et praecipe ministro, ut extendat ouum ad sursum: et tu solue adhaerentiam, quae est retro solutione completa.	Then move with your right hand to the inside of the skin of the testicles: and with this extend the white intestine upwards with your left hand: and elevate the gut with the intestine to the part of the section: and command the minister to extend the gut upwards: and you resolve the adhesion which is behind the complete solution
Et quaere digitis tuis, ut non sit aliquid illic ex intestino inuoluto in sifach albo duro.	And seek with your fingers that there be nothing there in the white intestine which is hard.
Si autem inuenis ex eo aliquid: tunc impelle ipsum ad uentrem inferius.	If indeed you find something there: then push it downwards towards the lower part
Deinde accipe acum, in qua sit filum grossum, factum licinium ex decem filis: et intromitte ipsam apud postremum sifach, id est, tunicae, quod est sub cute testiculorum quae sequitur sectionem: deinde incide extremitates quae eminent ex filo, donec sint quatuor fila.	Then grasp a needle, in which is a thick thread, made of twelve threads: and insert it into the back of the white intestine, which is under the skin of the testicles which follow the section: then cut off the extremities which protrude from the thread, until there remain four threads.
Deinde compone quaedam eorum super quaedam cum figura quae sit in modo crucis: et liga cum eis alsifach, de quo diximus, quia est sub cute testiculorum ligamento uehementi, donec non possit aliquod ex uasis, quae nutriunt eos mittere ad eos aliquid: ut non accidat inde apostema calidum.	Then make a loop with some of them above some with the shape of a cross: and tie with silk thread, of which we have spoken, because it is under the skin of the testicles a strong ligament which cannot be undone, until it does not have any of the things which nourish them send them to them: that it does not happen that there should be a cold abscess.
Et pone iterum ligamentum secundum extra ligamentum primum, longinquum ab eo minus duobus digitis.	And place again the ligament next to the first ligament, distant from it by the space of two fingers.
Et post ista duo ligamenta dimitte ex sifach, quod est sub cute testiculorum, quantitatem magnitudinis digiti: et incide reliquum totum secundum rotunditatem, et aufer ex eo ouum.	And remove from the sheath two ligaments, which are under the testicles, in the quantity of the magnitude of a finger: and incline the rest entirely according to the roundness, and remove from it all.</start_of_turn>
Deinde seca in inferiori parte cutis testiculorum sectione, ex qua currit sanguis, et sanies: sicut narrauimus in eo quod praemissum est.	And dry in the lower part of the skin of the testicles a section from which blood runs, and heal: as we have said before.</start_of_turn>
Deinde administra lanam submersam in oleo, et pone in uulnus: et administra ligamentum quod narrauimus.	And administer wool soaked in oil under the bandage, and put in a wound: and administer the ligament which we have mentioned.</start_of_turn>
Et quandoque cauterizatur sifach album quod diximus, post incisionem eius timendo de fluxu sanguinis.	And when the white sheath which we mentioned has been cauterized, after its incision fearing the flow of blood.</start_of_turn
Multotiens enim accidit illud.	Much of this has happened.</start_of_turn
Et dimitte ligamentum, donec cadat per se.	And remove the ligament, until it falls by itself.</start_of_turn
Si autem tardatur casus eius, tunc embrocetur cum aqua calida: et pone super ipsum illud quod diximus, donec cadat.	If however its case is delayed, then it will be embroidered with warm water: and put over that which we mentioned, until it falls.</start_of_turn
Deinde cura uulnus cum reliqua curatione uulnerum, donec curetur.	And then care for the wound with the rest of the care of wounds, until it heals.</start_of_turn
¶ De Ramice uentosa.	Of a wound filled with blood.</start_of_turn>
Caput LXVI.	Chapter LXVI.</start_of_turn>
IN Hac Ramice non uidi aliquem qui ausus fuerit super curationem eius cum ferro.	In such a wound no one should be allowed to remain above its care with a knife.</start_of_turn
Et primi quidem dixerunt, quod fit sicut narrauimus in Ramice quae est cum Vite.	And the first said that it is done as we have narrated in the wound which is with the Bit.</start_of_turn
Quod est, ut liges uasa post sectionem super ea cum facilitate inferius: deinde seca in medio, et cura postremo cum eo quod aperit ipsum, donec cadant uasa: et cura uulnus, secundum quod diximus, donec sanetur.	That is, as soon as it has been sectioned above that with ease: then dry in the middle, and care afterwards with that which opens it up, until the nails fall out: and care for the wound, as we have said, until it is healed.</start_of_turn
¶ De disruptione quae fit in inguinibus.	On the disruption which happens in the groin.
Caput LXVII.	On the disruption which happens in the groin.
Quando accidit Ruptura in inguinibus, sicut diximus, et eminet locus, et non descendit ad testiculos aliquid ex intestinis: et si descendit, est illud parum, et redit in omnibus horis: uerum si prolongatur cum ea tempus, additur fissura in sifach, donec descendunt intestina in sifach.	When a rupture occurs in the groin, as we have said, and the place protrudes, and does not descend to the testicles anything from the intestines: and if it descends, it is little, and returns in all hours; but if it is prolonged with that time, a fissure is added in the groin, until the intestines descend into the groin.
Et accidit illud ex extensione sifach, quod est in inguinibus, sicut diximus.	And this happens from the extension of the groin, which is in the groin, as we have said
Quod est, quia extenditur sifach: deinde mollificatur, et apostematur locus, et eminet.	Because the groin is extended: then it becomes softened, and the place protrudes, and the place protrudes
Et cura eius est cum cauterio, sicut praecessit eius narratio.	And its treatment is with cautery, as it has been mentioned before.
Et quandoque curatur cum ferro, secundum hunc modum: et est, ut iaceat infirmus super dorsum suum inter manus tuas.	And sometimes it is treated with iron, in this way: and the patient lies on his back between your hands
Deinde seca locum Rupturae apostematum et eminentem, sectione per latitudinem, secundum quantitatem trium digitorum.	Then dry the place of the rupture after it has protruded and emerged, by cutting across its width, according to the quantity of three fingers.
Deinde stringe alsifak et, quae sunt sub cute, donec quando detegitur sifach album, quod est sub cute quae sequitur ipsum.	Then bind the intestines and those which are under the skin, until the groin is white, which is under the skin that follows it
Tunc accipe radium, et pone ipsum super locum eminentem ex sifach, et preme ipsum ad profundum uentris.	Then take a sponge and place it over the place where the groin has protruded, and press it deep into the belly
Deinde sue duo loca eminentia super extremitatem radii ex sifach, et annecte cum sutura unum eorum cum altero: deinde extrahe extremitatem radii.	And then two places where the groin has protruded at the extremities of the sponge, and connect them with a suture one with the other: and then draw out the extremity of the sponge.
Et non incidas alsifach omnino, neque tendas ouum, neque aliud, sicut feci te scire in curatione ramicis intestinalis.	And do not cut the intestines at all, neither stretch them out or do anything else, as I have told you in the treatment of intestinal branches.
Deinde cura illud curatione uulnerum.	Then care for the wound.
Cum ergo incidis fila, mundifica illud, et restaura uulnus, donec consolidetur.	When you have finished cutting the thread, moisten it, and close the wound, until it is healed.</start_of_turn>
Sisach enim contrahitur, et non additur eminentia Rupturae.	Do not let the edges of the wound be drawn together, and do not add prominence of the rupture.</start_of_turn>
Et cauterium est melius in hoc loco: quoniam est propinquius ad salutem.	And the cautery is better in this place: because it is closer to the tissue.</start_of_turn
¶ De mollificatione cutis testiculorum.	About the softening of the skin of the testicles.</start_of_turn
Caput LXVIII.	Chapter LXVIII.</start_of_turn>
Multotiens mollificatur cutis testiculorum in quibusdam hominibus, propter quod mollificantur carnes quae sunt inter ea, et foedatur aspectus eius.	Many people soften the skin of their testicles for some reason, because of which the surrounding flesh is softened and its appearance is spoiled.</start_of_turn
Ergo necesse est ei qui rogatur in curatione eius, ut faciat iacere infirmum super dorsum suum, et incidat totam cutem quae mollificata est super cutem naturalem.	Therefore it is necessary for the one who is asked to care for it, to make the sick man lie down on his back, and to cut away all the softened skin over the natural skin.</start_of_turn
Deinde aggreget duo labia cum sutura: et si uis, sue in primis superfluitatem cutis mollificatae tribus suturis, aut quatuor, et firma suturam.	Then gather together two lips with a suture: and if you wish, put in the beginning a little of the softened skin with three or four stitches, and make a firm suture.</start_of_turn
Deinde incide inter sututuras.	Then cut between the sutures.</start_of_turn
Deinde cura curatione reliquorum uulnerum, usquequo sanetur, et cadant fila.	Then care for the care of the remaining wounds, until they are healed, and the threads are cast off.</start_of_turn
¶ De Castratione.	About castration.</start_of_turn
Caput LXIX.	Chapter LXIX.</start_of_turn
Scias, quod Castratio in lege nostra excommunicata est: et propter illud liceret mihi, ut non rememorarer eius in libro meo isto: et non est necessaria rememoratio eius, nisi propter duos modos.	You know that castration is forbidden in our law: and for that reason I will not mention it in this book: and it is not necessary to mention it, except for two cases.</start_of_turn
Quorum unus est, ut sit illud in scientia medici quando interrogatur de ea: et ut sciat curationem eius cui accidit.	Whoever is present is sufficient to know the science of medicine when he is questioned about it: and to know the treatment for that which has befallen him.
Et modus alter est, quod nos multotiens indigemus castratione quorundam animalium, propter iuuamenta nostra per illud, sicut arietum, hyrcorum, et gattorum, et similium ex animalibus.	The other method is that we often do not require castration of many animals for our purposes, because of the remedies which we have for them, such as oxen, horses, and goats, and the like among animals.
Dico ergo, quod Castratio fit secundum duos modos.	I say therefore, that castration is done in two ways.
Aut per attritionem.	Or by attrition.</start_of_turn>
Aut per fissuram, et sectionem.	Or by incision, and section.</start_of_turn>
In illa autem quae fit per attritionem, uia operationis est: quod nos faciamus sedere animal in aqua calida, donec mollificentur testiculi eius, et leniantur, et pendeant: deinde attere eos manu tua, donec resoluantur et non appareant sub tactu.	In the former method, however, the operation is: we make the animal sit in warm water, until the testicles soften and relax, and hang down; then we shall cut off the testicles, until they are resolved and do not appear to the touch.</start_of_turn
In castratione autem per fissuram et sectionem, oportet ut teneas animal, et premas cutem testiculorum eius cum manu sinistra.	In castration by incision and section, it is necessary to hold the animal, and grasp the skin of the testicles with the left hand.</start_of_turn
Deinde liga suspensorium, et seca super omne ouum sectione una, donec quando procedunt duo oua: tunc incide ea postquam excoriaueris utrumque, et non dimittas super ea ex sifaket aliquid praeter sifac subtile, quod est super uasa.	Then tighten the suspension, and cut through the whole with one incision, until two holes have appeared: then when these have appeared, close them up after you have scraped away everything except for a small piece of fat, which is above the veins.</start_of_turn
Et iste modus castrationis est melior eo qui fit per attritonem: quoniam attritio fortasse relinquit aliquid ex testiculis, quare desiderat animal coitum.	And this method of castration is better than the one by attrition: because attrition may leave something behind in the testicles, which the animal desires for coitus.</start_of_turn>
Deinde cura uulnus, donec sanetur.	Then care for the wound, until it is healed.</start_of_turn>
¶ De cura Hermafroditae duorum modorum.	Regarding the care of hermaphrodites, there are two methods.</start_of_turn
Caput LXX.	Chapter 70.</start_of_turn>
Hermafrodita ex uiris est secundum duos modos.	Hermaphrodites are of two kinds according to the two sexes.
Vnus eorum est, quia apparet in eo quod sequitur spacium, aut in cute testiculorum, in eo quod est inter duos testiculos, figura quasi uulua mulieris, in qua sunt pili: et quandoque currit urina ex eo quod est in cute testiculorum.	Hermaphrodites are of two kinds according to the two sexes. One kind appears with the scrotum either in the space following the scrotum or between the testicles, in which there is a figure like a female vulva, which has hair, and sometimes urine runs from the scrotum.
In mulieribus autem est species una, et est uulua mulieris super pectinem sicut testiculi uiri parui omnino, eminentes ad exteriora: quorum unus est sicut priapus uiri, et duo sicut duo testiculi.	Hermaphrodites are of two kinds according to the two sexes. One kind appears like a female vulva sitting on the pubic bone just like the testicles of a small man, standing outside: one is like the penis of a man, and two are like two testicles
Et curatio trium specierum, duarum ex uiris, et speciei unius ex mulieribus, est: quia oportet ut incidas carnes additas, donec effugiat impressio earum.	And the care of these three kinds, two of which are hermaphrodites and one of which is female, is: because it is necessary to cut away the fat added, until the impression of them is gone.
Deinde cura eas curatione reliquorum uulnerum.	And then care for the rest of the wounds.
In specie autem secunda uirorum, ex qua egreditur urina, quae est in cute testiculorum, non est operatio, neque est eius curatio omnino.	As for the second kind of male, from which urine comes out, which is in the scrotum, there is no operation, nor any care for it
¶ De incisione Tentiginis, et carnis eminentis in uuluis mulierum.	About the incision of the tentorium and the fat eminating in the women's bodies.
Caput LXXI.	Section 71.
Tentigo fortasse additur super rem naturalem, donec foedatur et turpis fit aspectus eius: et quandoque magnificatur in quibusdam mulieribus adeo, donec expanditur sicut in uiris, et peruenit usque ad coitum.	The tentorium may perhaps be added above the natural thing, until it is bruised and makes its aspect unsightly: and when it is increased in some women so much, until it expands like in the males, and persists until the coitum.
Oportet ergo ut teneas superfluitatem Tentiginis manu, aut cum uncino, et incidas: et non ultimes in incisione, praecipue in profundo radicis: ut non accidat fluxus sanguinis.	It is necessary therefore to cut away the superfluous tentorium, either alone or with one incision, and cut: and do not be excessive in the incision, especially in the depth of the root, so that there does not result the flowing of blood.
Deinde cura ipsam curatione uulnerum, donec sanetur.	Then care for the wound itself until it heals
Caro autem orta, est caro quae nascitur in orificio matricis, donec impleat ipsum: et fortasse egreditur ad exteriora secundum similitudinem caudae: et propter illud quidam primi nominant aegritudinem caudatam.	The belly which is born from the matrix orifice until it fills itself up, and sometimes it goes out to the outside like the tail, because of this some call the disease of the tail.
Oportet ergo ut incidamus eam sicut incidimus Tentiginem, et curemus eam, donec sanetur.	It is necessary therefore that we proceed thus as we proceed with the Tentigine, and we must care for it until it is healed.</start_of_turn>
¶ De cura Alratica, quae est uulua mulieris non perforata.	Concerning the care of the female ulcer which is an unperforated wound of a woman.</start_of_turn>
Caput LXXII.	Chapter LXXII.</start_of_turn
Alratica est, ut sit uulua mulieris non perforata, aut sit foramen paruum.	The female ulcer is, as it were, an unperforated wound of a woman, or a small hole.</start_of_turn
Et est aut naturalis, aut accidentalis.	It is either natural or accidental.</start_of_turn
Accidentalis est ex aegritudine quae praecessit: et ipsa quidem fit aut ex carne nata addita, aut sifach subtili, aut spisso: et fit aut in profundo matricis, aut in lateribus eius, aut in superiore ipsius, aut inferiori eius: et prohibet a coitu et impregnatione, et partu, et fortasse prohibet menstrua.	The accidental one is that which arises from an existing ailment: and this may be either from the natural formation of the flesh added to itself, or from the fine sand or from a hair: and it may be either in the depth of the matrix, or in the flanks, or in the upper part of it, or in the lower part of it: and it hinders coitus and conception, and delivery, and perhaps also the menstruation.</start_of_turn
Et cognitio illius fit per aspectum obstetricis, si opilatio est apparens propinqua.	And the knowledge of it is by the aspect of the obstetrician, if the visible prolapse is close.</start_of_turn
Si autem non est apparens, tunc quaere eam digitis tuis, aut cum radio.	If however it is not visible, then inquire with your fingers, or with the radio.</start_of_turn
Si autem opilatio est ex sifach subtili, et est propinqua duobus labiis: tunc propera, et disrumpe ipsam.	If however the prolapse is from fine sand, and is close to two teeth: then cleanse it, and break it.</start_of_turn
Et est, ut ponas super duo labia puluillos.	And it is necessary to place over two lips two cushions.</start_of_turn
Deinde pone indices tuos duarum manuum simul, et mulier sit super dorsum suum expansis cruribus suis.	Then put your two fingers of both hands together, and the woman should sit with her back expanded and her legs spread wide.</start_of_turn
Deinde extende duo labia cum fortitudine, donec disrumpatur sifach subtile, et aperiatur opilatio.	Then extend two lips with force, until the hidden vein is ruptured, and the opening is made.
Deinde accipe lanam, et imbibe eam in oleo, et pone ipsam super locum: et coeat mulier omni die, ut non consolidetur locus uice alia.	Then grasp the lip and absorb its blood into the sponge, and place it over the place: and let the woman do everything every day, so that it does not solidify in another place.
Si autem sifach est grossum, spissum: tunc oportet ut seces ipsum cum spatumili lato simili folio myrti.	But if the vein is great, thick: then it is necessary to cut it with a broad scalpel like the leaf of myrrh
Si autem opilatio est ex carne nata, tunc suspende eam cum uncinis, et incide eam: et sint tecum medicinae quae fluxum sedant sanguinis absque mordicatione, sicut acacia, et sanguis draconis, et thus aggregatum cum albugine oui.	But if the opening is from natural flesh, then suspend the blood with hooks, and cut it: and be with physicians who will stop the flow of blood without damage, such as acacia, and dragon's blood, and thus aggregated with alum.
Deinde administra cannulam ex plumbo amplam, ut non consolidetur uulnus uelociter, teneat eam diebus aliquot: et administra licinium ex lino sicco, deinde curetur reliqua curatione, donec sanetur.	Then give a broad leaden catheter, so that the wound does not solidify too quickly, keep it for a few days: and give vinegar from dry linen, then care for the rest of the treatment, until it is healed
Et quandoque nasciur in matrice natiuitas carnium aliarum: oportet ergo ut incidantur secundum hunc modum: dum non est apostema cancerosum apostemati enim canceroso quod est in matrice, non fiat contrarietas cum ferro omnino.	And when there is birth in the matrix of other flesh: it is necessary therefore to cut them in this way: while there is no cancerous ulcer in the matrix, no contradiction is made with iron in any way
¶ De cura hemorroidarum, Athehelil, et Bothor rubeae in uuluis mulierum.	Concerning the care of hemorrhoids, Athehelil, and Bothor of the red ones in women's veins.
Caput LXXIII.	Chapter 73.
Hemorroides quidem sunt apertio orificiorum uenarum, donec currit ex eis sanguis multus assidue.	Hemorrhoids are indeed a bursting of the veins through the opening of the veins, until there is a great discharge of blood from them
Cum ergo antiquantur hemorroides, fiunt thelil: et iam dixi in diuisione species earum, et signa ipsarum: et dicam hic quae ex eis recipiunt curationem, et quae non.	When they are thus diminished, the hemorrhoids become thelil: and I have already said in the discussion of their species and signs: and here I will say what is to be received for their treatment, and what is not
Dico ergo, quod hemorroides quae sunt in orificio matricis, et non apparent sensui: tunc non est ei curatio cum ferro.	I say therefore, that hemorrhoids which are in the matrix opening, and which are not apparent to the sense: then there is no treatment with iron for them
Quae autem ex eis sunt in orificio matricis super quas cadit sensus, sunt quae curantur.	Whatever exists in the cavity of the uterus above which sensation has fallen is cured.
Oportet ergo ut intromittas mulierem in domum frigidam.	It is necessary therefore that you introduce the woman into a cold house.
Deinde extende athehelil cum forficibus, aut cum panno aspero, et incide eas ex radicibus suis.	Then stretch out the belly with forceps, or with a rough cloth, and cut away the hair from its roots
Deinde pulueriza super eas apud fluxum sanguinis ex uno puluerum incisiuorum absque mordificatione: sicut acacia, et sanguis draconis, et thus, et similia eis.	Then powder over the wound with one of the powders mentioned above without causing any injury: like acacia, dragon's blood, and thus, and similar things.
Deinde impellat pedes eius ad parietem hora una.	Then press her feet against the wall for an hour.
Postea depone eam in aquam frigidam.	Then place her in cold water
Quod si perseuerat fluxus sanguinis: tunc fac eam sedere in decoctione sumach, et corticum granatorum, et gallarum, et similium.	If the bleeding persists: then make her sit in a decoction of sumach, and caraway seeds, and gallnuts, and similar things.
Deinde accipe farinam hordei, et confice eam cum melle et aceto, et fac emplastrum cum eo super dorsum eius.	Then take barley flour, and mix it with honey and vinegar, and make a plaster with it on her back
Si ergo abscinditur sanguis cum eo, bonum est: et si non, fac adhaerere dorso uentosas, et mammillis, absque scarificatione.	If blood therefore dries up with this, that is good: and if not, make it adhere to the tender parts, and blood clots, without making a scar
Deinde accipe lanam, et submerge in succo tarathit, aut succo arnoglossae, aut succo ramorum alaulat, id est, aglanter, uino pontico, et fac adhaerere loeo.	Then take wool, and soak it in the juice of tarth, or the juice of arnica, or the juice of chamomile blossoms, that is, gentian, pontic wine, and make it adhere to the blood clot
Cum ergo quiescit apostema, tunc cura locum cum unguentis, donec sanetur.	When the wound has calmed down, then take care of the place with unguents, until it has healed
Albarth uero rubeum est simile capitibus alhaasse, et est asperi aspectus.	Although it is red like the heads of almonds, and has a rough appearance
Oportet ergo ut incidas quod apparet ex eo, secundum quod dixi in thelil aequaliter: et cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	It is necessary therefore that you cut away what appears from it, according to what I have said above: and take care of it, until it has healed
¶ De perforatione Exiturae quae accidit in matrice.	On the perforation of the Exitura which occurs in the matrix.
Caput LXXIIII.	On the perforation of the Exitura which occurs in the matrix.
Accidunt in matrice species multae apostematum, sicut cancer, et apostema lapideum, et ulcera, et adubelati, et alekilati, id est, herpes, aestiomemus, et fistulae, et hemorroides, et ragadiae, et thelil, et apostema calidum.	Various kinds of extrusions occur in the matrix, such as cancer, stone abscesses, ulcers, foreign bodies, and swellings, such as herpes, swelling, fistula, haemorrhoids, carbuncles, and abscesses.
Et ego quidem iam dixi omnes has aegritudines et species earum, et signa ipsarum, et earum curationes in diuisione: necesse est ut dicam in hoc tractatu apostema calidum quod accidit in matrice, quando est ex apostematibus quae colligunt saniem, et uis scire qualiter fit eius apertio cum ferro.	And I will also mention concerning all these ailments and their kinds, their signs and their treatments in general: it is necessary for me to speak in this treatise of the perforated abscess which occurs in the matrix, when it is extruded from other abscesses which connect the health, and to tell how it is opened with an iron
Oportet ergo ut consideres.	It is necessary for you to consider this.
Tunc si dolor apostematis in incaeptione sua est acutus cum percussione sua, et flamma, et febre: et uides ipsum rubere: si cadit super ipsum sensus, tunc non properes cum perforatione eius: et cura ipsum cum eo eo quod iuuat super maturationem, donec quando quiescat acuitas accidentium.	If the pain of the abscess becomes acute with percussion, inflammation, and fever: and you see it turning red: if it goes beyond your senses, do not attempt to perforate it: cure it with that which will promote healing, until the acute pain subsides
Tunc oportet ut facias sedere mulierem super sedem quae labeat duo sedilia, et reclinetur, uel appodietur super dorsum suum, et aggreget pedes suos ad partem inferiorem uentris: et sint coxae eius expansae, et ponat brachia sua sub genibus suis, et liget utraque ligamento conueniente ad illud.	Then you must make her sit on a cushion which supports two cushions, and recline, or lie down on her back, and rest her feet on the lower part of the belly: and let her knees be spread wide, and put her arms under her armpits, and bind each ligament conveniently to that.
Deinde sedeat obstetrix a latere dextro, et administra instrumentum quo aperitur orificium matricis.	Then let the obstetrician sit at the right side, and administer the instrument with which the opening of the maternal orifice is made.
Cuius forma uenit in eis quae sunt post.	Which form it has comes to light in those things which follow.
Et oportet quando uis administrare hoc instrumentum, ut figas cum Radio profundum matricis mulieris: ut non sit illud quod ingreditur ex instrumento plus, quam profundum matricis, et laedat infirmam.	And you must take care when you administer this instrument that the ribs do not touch the radio of the deep matrix of the woman: that it does not go deeper into the matrix than necessary, and does not damage the lower part
Si autem fuerit instrumentum magis quam profundum, tunc oportet ut ponas puluillos super tecturam profundi matricis: ut prohibeatur introitus instrumenti totius in profundum matricis: et oportet ut ponat uertiginem, quae currit in instrumento, ex latere superiore: et ut teneat instrumentum, et ut reuoluat minister uertiginem, donec aperiatur profundum matricis.	If the instrument be deeper than profound, it is necessary to place sponges over the covering of the profound matrix: in order to prevent the entrance of the entire instrument into the profound matrix. And it is necessary to pour out the moisture which runs in the instrument from the upper side: and to keep the instrument firm, and to draw back the minister of moisture until the profound matrix is opened.
Cum ergo apparet Exitura, et tangitur manu, et est lenis et mollis: tunc oportet ut seces ipsam apud caput suum cum spatumili lato.	When it appears that the orifice has been reached, and the hand touches it, and it is soft and yielding: then it is necessary to dissect it at its head with a broad spatula.</start_of_turn>
Cum ergo euacuatur sanies, tunc oportet ut ponas in uulnus licinium submersum in oleo rosaceo: aut oleo uiridi, in quo sit quaedam stipticitas: et pone licinium, et extrahe sectionem in profundo matricis.	When the pus has been evacuated, then it is necessary to place in the wound a swab dipped in rose oil or green oil, in which there is some astringency: and place the swab, and draw out the section from the profound matrix.</start_of_turn
Et pone exterius super matricem, et super pectinem lanam mundam submersam in aqua, in qua bullitae sunt maluae.	And place externally over the matrix, and over the wound a wool pad soaked in water, in which there are air bubbles.</start_of_turn
Deinde curetur post duos dies cum unguento quod conuenit ad illud, donec sanetur.	And then care for it for two days with an ointment which is suitable for it, until it is healed.</start_of_turn>
Et quandoque abluitur matrix et uulnus, ita quod clisterizatur cum aqua et melle: deinde cum aqua in qua bullita est radix lilii, aut aristolochia longa: deinde redeat ad unguentum.	And when the matrix and the wound are washed, it should be cleansed with water and honey: then with water in which there is a radix of lily or long aristolochia: then return to the ointment.</start_of_turn>
Quod si uulnus absconditum fuerit interius in matrice, tunc oportet ut prohibearis ex curatione eius cum ferro, imo cura ipsum cum eo quod diximus in diuisione.	If the wound is hidden inside the matrix, then it is necessary to forbid its care with iron, and care for it in the way which we mentioned in the instructions.</start_of_turn
¶ Doctrinae Obstetricum, qualiter medicentur embriones uiui, secundum figuram non naturalem egressi.	The doctrine of obstetrics concerning the way in which the physician should treat the fetuses of women, according to the unnatural form of their egress.</start_of_turn
Caput Lxxu.	Page 72.</start_of_turn>
Necesse est Obstetrici, ut cognoscat in primis figuram partus naturalis.	It is necessary for the Obstetrician to first become acquainted with the natural form of the partus.
Ex signis ergo eius est, quod quando uides mulierem comprimi ad inferiora, et desiderat odorare aerem, et alleuiatur super eam quod super ipsam est de partu, et festinat exitus embrionis: tunc scias quod iste partus est secundum figuram naturalem, et est exitus eius super caput suum, et secundina cum eo: aut suspensa, uel pendens ex umbilico.	It is necessary for the Obstetrician to first become acquainted with the natural form of delivery
Cum ergo uides haec signa, tunc oportet ut comprimatur uenter eius, ut descendat embrio uelociter.	When therefore you see a woman in labor, who desires to smell the air and who lets go of what is above her belly in connection with the delivery, and when the embryo comes out quickly: then you know that this delivery is natural, and that its issue is above its head and following.
Nam quando descendit super caput suum, descendit secundina cum eo, et mundatur ex illis superfluitatibus mundificatione bona.	For in such a case, when it descends above the head and follows after, it comes down along with the second part, and goes out with the greatest ease.
Qui autem est praeter hunc partum, est innaturalis, illaudabilis.	Whoever is outside of this delivery is unnatural and perilous.
Quoniam quandoque egreditur foetus super pedes suos, et egreditur corpus eius ante caput ipsius, et pedes eius, et manus eius una, aut pes eius unus: aut egreditur caput eius et manus eius: aut egreditur uentrinus: et fortasse conuertitur super collum suum, et similia ex figuris illaudabilibus.	For when the fetus comes out upon his feet, and his body goes before his head, and his feet and hands together, or one foot alone, or his head and hands, or his belly: or perhaps it bursts through the collar of his garment. And similar things happen in unnatural deliveries.
Necesse est ergo Obstetrici, ut sit prudens, subtilis in istis rebus omnibus, et caueat sibi ab errore et decaeptione: et ego sum ostendens omnem figuram ex eis, et qualiter est ingenium in ea, et significetur per illud, et stetur super ipsum.	It is necessary for the Obstetrician to be prudent and cautious in all these matters, and to avoid error and extravagance: and I shall show you all the figures and how they are established by this, and what is signified thereby, and I shall stand by myself.
Quando egreditur foetus super caput suum egressione sua naturali, et uehemens fit illud super mulierem, et difficilis fit ei partus, et uides uirtutem eius iam debilitatam: tunc fac eam sedere super sedem, aut mulieres teneant eam: et uapora uuluam eius cum foenugraeco decocto, et cum oleis humidis.	When the fetus comes out above his head in his natural delivery, and when he feels that he is above the woman, and that the delivery is difficult for her: then let her sit down, or let the women hold her up: and let her breathe with a wet cloth over her face, and with warm oils.
Deinde intromittat Obstetrix inter digitos suos Spatumile paruum, et findat cum eo secundinam, et secet eam ungue suo, donec currat quod est in ea ex humiditate: et preme uentrem mulieris, donec descendat foetus.	Then the Obstetrix inserts his thumb between the fingers of the Spatumile, and finds its second digit, and severs it with his nail until it is free from the moisture: and he first grasps the woman's womb, until the fetus descends.
Si autem non descendit, tunc oportet ut clisterizetur mulier ex mucillagine foenugraeci, cum oleo sisamino.	If however it does not descend, then it is necessary to instill the woman with a douche of foehnus mucus.
Deinde praecipe ei post clistere, ut comprimatur: et fac eam sternutare cum condisi, et tene os eius et nasum ipsius hora una.	Then command her to sit down after the clistering: and make her clench and relax her abdomen for an hour together.
Foetus enim egredietur statim.	The fetus will immediately come out.
Quod si egrediantur duae manus foetus in primis, iunc oportet ut reducas eas cum facilitate paulatim.	If two hands of the fetus come out at once, it is necessary to reduce them gradually
Si autem non obedit in introitu, tunc pone mulierem super sedem, et eleua pedes eius sursum: deinde concute sedem super terram: et mulier teneatur, ut non cadat apud concussionem.	If however it does not obey in its introversion, then place the woman on her seat, and lift her feet above the head: then press her seat against the ground: and the woman must keep still, lest she fall from the concussion
Si ergo non egrediuntur manus, et moritur foetus: tunc incide eas, et extrahe residuum foetus: et liga manum eius cum panno, et extrahe ipsum cum aequalitate: nam ipse egredietur.	If therefore they do not come out, and the fetus dies: then cut through the palms of the hands, and extract the remaining fetus: and bind up the hand with a cloth, and extract it with equality: for it itself will come out.
¶ Exitus embrionis super pedes suo.	The exit of the embryo through the feet.
Quando egreditur foetus super pedes suos, tunc oportet ut impellat eos sursum: deinde conuertat foetum paulatim: postea aequet ipsum.	When the fetus comes out through the feet, then it is necessary to push it upwards: then gradually turn the fetus: afterwards equalize it
Deinde accipiat unum pedum eius, et extendat eum paulatim.	Then grasp one foot of it, and extend it gradually
Cum ergo egrediuntur usque ad coxas, tunc praecipe ei, ut comprimatur, et fac eam sternutare cum condisi: egredietur enim, si Deus uoluerit.	When they come out as far as the hips, then command her to clench and relax, and make her clench her abdomen: the fetus will come out if God wills it.
Et si non egreditur cum eo quod narrauimus, tunc reduc foetum paulatim, donec ponas eum secundum figuram naturalem.	If it does not go out with it as we have said, then gradually reduce the limb, until you have set it according to its natural form.
Nam ipse egredietur tunc egressu facili.	The limb itself will then come out with the evacuation
Quod si prohibeatur cum eo toto quod narrauimus: tunc accipe ex mucillagine alteae, et oleo sisamino, et gummi soluto: et percute totum in mortario percussione bona: deinde line cum eo uuluam mulieris, et inferius uentris eius.	If it is opposed by all that we have said: then take from the high slime, and the fat, and gum dissolved in vinegar: and pierce all through in a good percussion: then line with the hair of a woman, and below with the belly of her
Deinde fac eam sedere in aqua tepida, donec consequatur hypocundria.	Then make it sit in warm water, until the discharge follows naturally.
Cum ergo uides quod iam calefacta sunt inferiora eius, tunc fac ei sief de myrrha: et suppone ipsum.	When the lower parts are thus warmed, then make for it a sieve of myrrh: and support it.
Quando ergo tenet sief hora una, tunc fac eam sedere super sedem.	When it has held the sieve for an hour, then make it sit upon a seat.
Deinde fac eam sternutare: et stringe ipsius os et nasum: et preme inferiorem partem uentris compressione facili.	Then make it cough: and bind its bone and nose: and press the lower part of the belly with ease
Nam foeus egredietur statim.	For the pus will come out immediately.
¶ Exitus foetus super genua et manus.	The fetus comes out over the knee and hand
Quando egreditur secundum hanc formam, tunc ingeniet in intromittendo manus suas paulatim.	When it comes out according to this form, then it will enter inwards gradually withdrawing its hand.
Deinde resupinetur mulier super collum suum, et pendeant pedes eius ad inferiora: et ipsa sit iacens super lectum, et complicet manus suas.	Then the woman lies over her neck, and hangs her feet downwards: and she lies recumbent on the bed, and tightens her hands
Deinde preme supra uentrem eius paulatim.	Then press upon her belly gradually
Deinde extrahe quod est sub pedibus eius ex puluinaribus, donec sit praeparata in inferiori parte.	Then draw out what is under her feet from the nails, until it is prepared in the lower part.
Quod si non egreditur foetus, tunc accipe pedes eius, et moue eos motu uehementi.	If the fetus does not come out, then grasp her feet, and move them with force
Deinde preme quod est supra hypocundria paulatim, donec ascendat foetus ad superiora.	Then first of all that is above the navel gradually, until the fetus ascends to the upper parts.
Deinde intromittat manus suas, et aequet foetum paulatim: et praecipe mulieri, ut comprimatur, donec egrediatur foetus.	Then withdraw your hand gradually, and equalize the fetus gradually: and command the woman to press, until the fetus comes out.
¶ Exitus foetus latitudinaliter pendens ex manibus.	The fetus is delivered with a lateral slant from the hands.
Ingenietur in reductione manus eius.	There is an inclination towards reducing the hand in this way.
Si autem non potest reducere eam, tunc eleua mulierem, et fac eam ambulare.	If, however, it is not possible to reduce the hand, then elevate the woman, and make her walk about
Si uero ambulare non potest, tunc fac eam iacere super lectum: et concute crura eius concussione uehementi.	If she is unable to walk, then make her lie upon a bed: and strike her legs with a striking of concussion
Deinde administra linimentum quod praeparasti ex mucillaginibus.	Then apply the unguents which you have prepared from mucilages
Quod si accipit eam partus, tunc fac eam sedere super sedem.	If she contracts during the delivery, then make her sit down upon a seat
Deinde stude in reductione manus, et aequa foetum secundum figuram naturalem: et fac sternutare mulierem, et praecipe ei, ut comprimat se, donec egrediatur.	Then study in the reduction of the hand, and equalize the fetus according to the natural figure: and command the woman to strain, and tell her to press herself, until she comes out.
¶ Exitus foetus super collum suum, expansis manibus, et est facies eius ad dorsum matris suae.	The fetus comes out over his collar, with his hands spread out, and his face is towards the mother's back
Oportet ut teneat Obstetrix manum foetus, deinde reuoluat eum paulatim, et aequet eum cum facilitate.	The Obstetrician must hold the hand of the fetus, then gradually turn him around, and equalize him with ease
Cum ergo aequatur, tunc pone super uuluam eius quod narrauimus ex oleo et mucillaginibus.	When he is equalized, then place upon his wound that which we mentioned from wax and mucilages
Deinde praecipe ei, ut moueatur paulatim.	Then tell her to move gradually
Cum ergo feceris illud, tunc fac eam sedere super sedem, et praecipe ei ut inclinetur ad latus dextrum.	When you have done this, then make her sit down upon a seat, and tell her to lean towards the right side
Deinde praecipe ei, ut comprimatur: et fac eam sternutare cum condisi.	Then command him to lie down: and make him raise his chest with his chest muscles.
¶ Exitus foetus praeparati super latus.	Then command him to lie down: and make him raise his chest with his chest muscles.
Quando descendit ad orificium matricis secundum hunc modum cum secundina, tunc scinde secundinam cum ungue tuo, donec euacuetur ex humiditate.	When he has descended to the orifice of the matrix in this manner with this movement, then split the second [layer] with your finger until it is evacuated from the moisture.
Si ergo suspenditur super faciem foetus, et collum eius, tunc incide eam ex umbilico: ut non retineatur, et moriatur.	If, therefore, it hangs suspended over the face of the fetus, and his neck, then cut him from the navel: so that it does not remain, and he may die
Deinde impelle foetum ad interiora, donec ponas eam secundum quod oportet: et praecipe mulieri, ut comprimat se aliquotiens: ipse enim egredietur exitu leui.	Then drive the fetus inwards, until you place your hand according to what is necessary: and command the woman to compress herself slightly: he himself will depart through the easy exit
¶ Exitus Geminorum, aut foetuum multorum.	The exit of twins, or many fetuses.
Scias, quod Gemini multotiens nascuntur: et quandoque nascuntur tres, et quatuor.	You know that twins are often born together: and sometimes three, or even four are born together.
Verumtamen illud extraneum est, et raro contingit.	Indeed that is extraordinary, and rarely happens.
Quinque uero est res extra naturam, et non uiuunt penitus: et continet eos, quamuis multiplicentur, secundina una: et separantur per sifach, distinguens inter eos ligatum in umbilico cuiusque eorum.	Five indeed are things beyond nature, and do not entirely endure: and contain these [fetuses], although they multiply, in one: and they are separated by the navel, distinguishing between the ligament of each one.
Et quandoque egrediuntur sicut egreditur foetus unus exitu naturali, facili: et egrediuntur exitu illaudabili, sicut narrauimus.	And sometimes they depart as does a single fetus through a natural exit, easily: and they depart through an unnatural exit, as we have narrated.
Quod si difficiles fuerint quidam eorum apud partum, et perueniunt ad illud quod diximus ex figuris innaturalibus, tunc cura eos sicut narrauimus: et sit ob stetrix subtilis, et faciat quod facit cum facilitate et tarditate, et ingenietur secundum omnem figuram cum eo quod praeparatur ei ex ingenio ducente ad salutem.	If, however, there are some things which are difficult at the birth, and are prolonged to this which we have mentioned from unnatural figures, then take care of them as we have narrated: and let the midwife be gentle, and do what she does with ease and delay, and adapt to every figure which is prepared for her from the ingenuity leading to health
¶ Rememoratio eius quod formatur in matrice ex embrionibus, et abortiuntur.	Remember that it is formed in the matrix from seeds and is aborted.
Quandoque formatur in matrice unus, et duo, et tres, et quatuor, et quinque, et sex, et septem, et plures decem: et iam uerificatum est apud me, quod mulier abortiendo emisit septem, et alia quindecim, omnes formatos.	When one, two, three, four, five, six, seven, or more seeds are formed in the matrix, and they are aborted: then it is verified that the woman has aborted seven in one instance and fifteen in another.
Quod factum est mensuratione gloriosi sapientis.	Which is confirmed by the measurement of a wise man.
Hoc ergo totum oportet ut sit in scientia Obstetricis.	Therefore all this is necessary to be learned in the science of Obstetrics.
Fortasse enim perueniet ad eam simile illius: opponat ergo ei cum illo quod oportet	Perhaps indeed it will be like this: let us compare it with that which is necessary
¶ De extractione foetus mortui.	Of the extraction of the dead fetus.
Caput LXXVI.	Chapter LXXVI
Quando curas foetum mortuum cum eo quod dixi in diuisione ex medicatione, et non egreditur, et cogeris uti operatione cum manu, tunc oportet ut consideres.	When you cure the dead fetus with the medicine which I mentioned in the treatise on medication, and it does not go out, and you must use an operation with the hands, then you must consider it
Si ergo mulier est sanae uirtutis, et non est cum aliquo ex accidentibus, ex quibus timetur super eam perditio: tunc oportet ut resupinetur mulier super lectum, super dorsum suum, et sit caput eius inclinatum inferius, et crura eius eleuata: et ministra teneat eam a duabus partibus, aut ligetur ad lectum, ut non extrahatur corpus eius apud extractionem foetus.	If, therefore, the woman is of sound virtue and is not with any of the things from which one might fear a loss of life during the process: then it must be arranged that the woman lies over the couch, over her back, with her head inclined downwards and her legs raised up: and the minister should hold the patient's body from two parts, or it should be bound to the couch, so that the body is not pulled out during the extraction of the fetus
Deinde humecta os matricis ex oleis humidis cum mucillagine alteae, et foenugraeci, et seminis lini.	Then moisten the os matricis with oily substances with high mucilage, with aloes and fennel seeds, and linseed seeds.
Deinde inungat Obstetrix manum suam cum istis oleis et mucillaginibus: deinde intromittat eam in matricem cum facilitate.	Then the Obstetrician should smear his hand with these oils and mucilages: then he should introduce the hand into the matrix with ease
Deinde quaerat cum ea locum in quo figat uncinos ex foetu, et loca conuenientia ad illud.	Then he seeks the place where the nails of the fetus are fixed, and the convenient place for this
Considera ergo tunc, si foetus est praeparatus ut descendat super caput suum: tunc fige uncinos in oculos eius, aut in collo eius, aut in ore eius, aut in palato ipsius, aut sub barba eius, aut in furcula ipsius, aut in locis propinquis costis, et sub hypocundriis.	Consider therefore at all times, if the fetus is prepared to descend over its head: then fix the hooks in its eyes, or in its neck, or in its mouth, or in its palate, or under its beard, or in its armpits, or in the neighboring parts of the ribs, and under the hyoid bone.
Si autem descensus est super pedes eius, tunc in pectine, et costis eius mediis.	If it descends upon its feet, then in the groin, and the middle ribs.
Et oportet, ut teneat uncinum cum manu dextra: et ponat curuitatem eius in eo quod est inter digitos sinistrae manus: et intromittat cum manu cum facilitate, et figat uncinum in aliquo illorum locorum quae diximus, donec perueniat ad rem uacuam.	And it is necessary to hold the hook with the right hand: and place the suture in that which is between the left thumb and index finger: and introduce it with the thumb with ease, and fix the hook in one of those places which we have mentioned, until it reaches the desired thing.</start_of_turn>
Deinde figat in oppositione eius uncinum alium, aut tertium, si indiges: ut sit contractio aequalis, et non declinet ad partem.	And fix the other hook, or the third, if necessary: so that there is an equal tension, and it does not incline towards the part.</start_of_turn>
Deinde extendatur extensione aequali, et non sit extensio secundum rectitudinem tantum, imo moueatur ad omnem partem, ut alleuietur exitus eius: sicut fit cum dente apud eradicationem eius.	And extend with an equal extension, and it should not be extended only in a straight line, but should be moved towards all parts, so as to alleviate the exit of it: just as it is done with a tooth when extracting it.</start_of_turn>
Et oportet in eo quod est inter illud, ut mollificetur extensio.	And it is necessary in that which is between them, to soften the extension.</start_of_turn
Quod si retineatur ex eo pars, tunc oportet ut inungat Obstetrix quosdam digitos cum oleo, et intromittat eos ex parte, ut reuoluat cum eis quod retinetur.	Because if it is retained from that part, then it is necessary for the obstetrician to grasp any two fingers with the thumb and index finger, and introduce them from the side, so that it may recoil with what is retained.</start_of_turn
Si ergo egreditur pars foetus, tunc permutentur uncini ad locum alium qui sit altior: fac hoc donec egrediatur foetus totus.	If therefore the part of the fetus comes out, then exchange the sutures to another place which is higher: do this until the fetus comes out entirely.</start_of_turn
Si ergo egreditur manus ante alia, et non est possibile reducere eam, propter coartationem eius: tunc oportet, ut inuoluatur super eam pannus.	If therefore the hand comes out before the other, and it is not possible to reduce it because of its adhesion: then it is necessary to cover over the hand with the palm.</start_of_turn
Deinde extrahe eam donec quando egreditur tota, incide eam aut in iunctura plantae, aut in cubito: et ita oportet ut facias in manu altera, et in duobus pedibus.	Then extract the bone until it comes out whole, or break it at the junction of the plant, or in the cubit: and so it must be done in the other hand, and in both feet.
Si autem caput foetus est magnum, aut accidit ei coartatio in exitu, aut est in capite eius aqua aggregata: tunc oportet ut intromittat inter digitos Spatumile spinosum, et findat cum eo caput, et extrahat aquam: aut disrumpat ipsum cum instrumento quod nominatur Almisdac: cuius forma uenit cum formis reliquorum instrumentorum in capitulo quod est post hoc.	If the fetus's head is large, or if there is a coarsening of the delivery, or if there is water in the head: then it must be introduced between the fingers of the Spatumile spinosum, and find the head with it, and extract the water: or break it with the instrument called Almisdac, which has a form like that of the other instruments in this chapter.
Similiter faciat si foetus est magni capitis natura, tunc oportet ut seces algengematu: aut extrahas ipsum cum misdach, sicut diximus.	Proceed in the same way if the fetus has a large head, then it must be severed from the membrane: or extract it with the forceps, as we have said
Deinde attrahas ossa cum forcipibus.	Then grasp the bone with forceps.
Quod si egrediatur caput, et coartetur apud furculam: tunc findatur, donec effundatur humiditas quae est in pectore.	When the head comes out, and is close to the rib cage: find it until the moisture that is in the chest has drained out.
Si autem non complicatur, neque obedit ad exitum: tunc incide caput frustatim, secundum quod possibile est tibi.	If it does not become complicated, and does not yield to delivery: then break the head coarsely, as much as is possible to you
Quod si inferius uentris est apostematum, aut est in eo hydropisis: tunc oportet ut perfores ipsum, donec currat humiditas ex eo.	If the lower belly is swollen, or if there is swelling in it: then it must be pierced, until the moisture from it comes out
Si uero foetus est super pedes suos, tunc attractio eius est facilis, et directio eius ad os matricis est leuis.	If the fetus is above his feet: the traction of it is easy, and the direction of it towards the maternal bone is smooth.
Si autem coartatur apud uentrem, aut pectus: tunc oportet ut extrahas ipsum cum panno quem inuoluisti super manum tuam: et findat uentrem, aut pectus, donec currat quod est in eis.	If it is obstructed at the belly, or the chest: then it must be extracted with the cloth which you have put over your hand: and find the belly, or the chest, until the moisture has drained out of it
Si autem auferuntur reliqua membra, et redit caput: tunc intromittat Obstetrix manum sinistram.	If the rest of the limb has been delivered, and the head returns: then the Obstetrix will introduce his left hand.
Si ergo os matricis est apertum, tunc intromittat manum in profundum matricis, et quaerat cum ea caput, et attrahat ipsum cum digitis usque ad os matricis: deinde intromittat in eo uncinum unum, aut uncinos duos, et attrahat ipsum cum eo.	If the os of the matrix is open, then insert the hand into the depth of the matrix and grasp with the head, and draw it out with the fingers until it reaches the os of the matrix: then insert into it one hook or two hooks and draw it out with it.
Quod si os matricis coartatur, propter apostema calidum quod accidit ei: tunc non oportet ut laboretur super ipsum, imo oportet tunc administrare effusionem rerum humidarum, pinguium: et administra emplastra: et sedeat in aquis quae mollificant et humectant.	If the os of the matrix is closed, because of a thick clot that has happened to it: then it is not necessary to labour above it, but it is necessary to administer effusion of humours, fat: and administer plasters: and sit in waters which soften and moisten
Quod si foetus est super latus suum, tunc possibile est ut aequetur: tunc administretur quod diximus in foetu uiuo.	If the foetus is above its side, then it is possible to equalise it: then is administered what we said in the foetus above.
Quod si non est possibile illud, tunc incidatur frustatim, et extrahatur.	If it is not possible to do this, then it is cut off, and it is extracted.
Et oportet ut non dimittas aliquid ex secundina intus omnino.	And it is necessary that you do not let anything out of the second [part] entirely.
Cum ergo compleueris operationem tuam, tunc administra quod diximus in apostematibus calidis quae accidunt in matricibus.	When you have completed your operation, then administer what we said in the cold clots which happen in the matrixes.
Quod si accidat fluxus sanguinis, tunc descendat in aquis stipticis, et administra reliquam curationem.	If there happens to be a flow of blood, then descend in styptic waters, and administer the rest of the cure.
Et ego quidem iam uidi mulierem, in cuius uentre mortuus erat foetus: deinde impregnata est super ipsum uice alia, postea mortuus est foetus alius etiam.	And I myself saw a woman in whose womb there was a dead foetus: then it was impregnated over it again with oil, and afterwards the other foetus also died.
Accidit ergo ei post tempus longum apostema in umbilico suo, et inflatum est, donec apertum est: et coepit emittere pus.	It happened to her at length a clot in her navel, and it became inflated, until it was opened: and it began to emit pus.
Vocatus sum ergo ad curationem eius, et medicatus sum ei tempore longo: et non consolidatum est uulnus.	I was called to care for her, and I treated her for a long time: and it was not solidified.
Posui ergo super ipsum ex quibusdam emplastris fortis attractionis: et exiuit ex loco os.	I put upon her from some strong plaster of adhesion: and it came out of the place of the bone.
Deinde praeterierunt ei dies aliquot, et exiuit os aliud.	Then some days passed by, and another bone escaped.
Miratus sum ergo inde, cum in uentre non sit os.	Then I was astonished, for in the midst there was no bone left.
Cogitaui ergo, quia erant ex ossibus foetus mortui.	I thought, therefore, that the bones of the fetus had perished
Inquisiui ergo uulnus, et extraxi ossa multa, muliere existente in melioribus dispositionibus suis: et iam uixit taliter tempore longo, et mittit ex loco pus parum.	I inquired of the woman, and I extracted many bones, the woman being in better condition than before.  And it passed in this way for a long time, and a little pus came out from the place.
Et ego non firmaui hic hoc extraneum, nisi quoniam in eo est scientia, et adiutorium ad illud, quod administrat medicus artifex cum manu ex curatione.	I did not trust this external thing, except that it had science, and an assistant who worked with the physician in surgery.
¶ De formis Instrumentorum necessariorum in extractione foetus.	Concerning the forms of the necessary instruments for the extraction of the fetus.
Caput LXXVII.	Chapter 77.
Hic inferius est forma Strictorii, quo aequantur libri, cui aequaliter sunt duae uertigines in duabus extremitatibus duorum lignorum.	Here below is the form of the Strictor, with which books are equaled, to which are equal two rings at the ends of two sticks.
Verumtamen haec Vertigo oportet ut sit subtilior strictorio: et ut fiat, aut ex ebano, aut ex ligno bussi.	It must be known that this Vertigo must be smaller than the Strictor: and that it may be made either of ebony or of seasoned wood
Et sit latitudo omnis ligni quasi duo digiti: et margo cuiusque amborum est quasi digitus unus, et longitudo cuiusque eorum est palmus et medietas: et in medio duorum lignorum sunt duo additamenta ex genere eiusdem ligni, quae iam firmata sunt in utrisque, quorum longitudo est medietas palmi et plus parum: et latitudo utriusque est quasi duo digiti, aut plus parum.	The width of every stick is like two fingers; and the margin of each of the two is like a single finger, and the length of each of them is a palm and a middle: and in the middle of the two sticks are two additions of the same kind of wood, which are fixed in both, of whose length is half a palm and less, and the width of each is like two fingers, or less
Et ista duo additamenta intromittuntur in os matricis, ut aperiatur cum eis quando tu reuoluis duas Vertigines.	And these two additions are introduced into the maternal bone, so that it opens when two Vertigines are rotated together
Forma Vertiginis qua aperitur matrix.	The form of the Vertige which opens the matrix
Forma alia ad simile illius, subtilior, et leuior.	Another form similar to this, smaller and smoother
Fiat ex ligno ebani, aut bussi, secundum similitudinem forcipum.	Let wood be cut from the rib, or from the buttock, according to the shape of the forceps.
Verumtamen in extremitate eius sint duo additamenta, sicut uides hic supra: et longitudo omnis additamenti ex eis est quasi palmus: et latitudo utriusque est, duo digiti.	Two additional pieces should be made at the extremity of it, as above: and the length of each additional piece is like a palm, and the width of each is two fingers wide.
Cum ergo uis aperire matricem cum eo, tunc fac sedere mulierem super lectum, pendentibus pedibus eius, aperto quod est inter crura eius.	When you wish to open the matrix with this, then make her sit over the lectum, with her feet dangling over the edge, and open what is between her thighs
Deinde intromitte ista duo additamenta coniuncta in matricem: et tu es tenens extremitatem instrumenti inferius inter coxas eius.	Then insert these two additional pieces together into the matrix: and you hold the lower extremity of the instrument between her thighs.
Deinde aperi manum tuam cum instrumento, sicut facis cum forficibus, aequaliter secundum quantitatem quam uis ex apertione oris matricis, donec faciat Obstetrix quod uult.	Then open your hand with the instrument, like making a pair of forceps, equally according to the quantity of the opening of the matrix, until the Obstetrix does what she wishes.
Forma Vertiginis alterius quam dixerunt antiqui Forma Impellentis quo impellitur foetus.	The shape of the other Vertex which they have mentioned is like the shape of the Impelling Force by which the fetus is driven forward.
Forma Almisdac, qua conteritur caput magnum: et assimilatur forcipi, cui sunt dentes in extremitate, sicut uides.	The shape of the Almond, which opposes the large head: and it is assimilated to the forceps, which have teeth at the extremity, like the above
Et quandoque fit oblungum, sicut forcipes secundum hanc formam, sicut uides, cui sunt dentes sicut dentes serrae, quo inciditur et conteritur.	And when it is flattened, like the forceps following this shape, like the above, which have teeth like saw teeth, that will break and counteract
Forma Almisdac quo conteritur caput paruum.	The shape of the Almond which opposes the small head.
Forma Vncini habentis spinam unam.	The shape of the Neighbor having a single spine
Forma Vncini habentis spinas duas.	The shape of the Neighbor having two spines
Forma forcipis cui sunt dentes serrae, cum quo conteritur caput foetus.	The shape of the forceps which have saw teeth, with which the fetus's head is countered
Forma Spatumilis habentis duas extremitates ad abscindendum caput.	The shape of the Sponge having two extremities to cut off the head.
Forma duorum Spatumilium etiam latorum.	The shape of two spatulas also of the hands.
Ista instrumenta omnia exercentur, et quanto plus multiplicantur species eorum, et praeparata sunt apud artificem, est uelocior ad operationem suam, et altior apud homines, propter quantitatem suam.	All these instruments are exercised, and the more numerous their kinds, and the better they are prepared in the artificer's shop, the more rapid is the operation and the greater the benefit to men, because of their quantity.
Non ergo despicies ex eis instrumentum, quin sit apud te praeparatum.	Observe not the mean of the instruments, but their preparation which is with you
Inexcusabilis est enim necessitas eorum.	For their necessity is undeniable
¶ De extractione Secundinae.	About the extraction of the second [tooth].
Caput LXXVIII.	Chapter 78.
Quando retinetur Secundina apud partum, tunc oportet ut praecipias infirmae, ut retineat anhelitum suum.	When the second [tooth] remains at the root, then it is necessary to remove the inferior ones in order to retain the breath.
Deinde fac eam sternutare cum condisi: et stringe manum tuam super os eius, et nares ipsius.	Then make a depression with the thumb, and grasp the hand over the bone and the breath of the patient.
Si ergo egreditur per hoc, bonum est.	If it comes out through this, it is good
Si non: tunc accipe ollam, et perfora in coopertorio foramen: et pone in ea herbas aperientes os matricis, sicut calamentum, rutam, et anetum, et camomillam, et sseham, et cassiam ligneam, et centauream: accipe omnes istas herbas, aut quasdam earum, et submerge eas cum aqua, et pone eas super ignem.	If not: then take hold of the pulp, and pierce through the bone in the socket: and place in it herbs which open the bone like calamine, rue, alum, chamomile, henbane, and poppy seed, and cedar wood: take all these herbs, or some of them, and soak them in water, and put them over fire
Deinde pone embulam arundinis super foramen coopertorii ollae, et extremitatem aliam in os matricis: et teneat eam donec perueniat uapor ad concauitatem matricis.	Then put a piece of Arundinum over the socket of the bone, and the other extremity in the bone: and hold it until the vapor has gone up to the cavity of the bone.
Deinde fac eam sternutare, sicut diximus.	Then make a depression once more, as we have said
Secundina enim egredietur cum facilitate.	The second [tooth] will come out easily
Si autem remaneat post hanc curationem, et non egrediatur: tunc praecipe Obstetrici, ut submergat manum suam in oleo sisamino, aut mucillagine alteae.	If however it remains after this treatment, and does not come out: then command the Obstetrician to soak the hand in boiling lime or high mucilage
Deinde intromittat in uuluam, et quaerat cum ea Secundinam.	Then he inserts his hand into the belly and searches with her second hand.
Cum ergo inuenerit eam, tunc accipiat eam, et extendat ipsam paulatim.	When he has found it, then he grasps it and slowly extends it outwards.</start_of_turn>
Si autem fuerit annexa in profundo matricis, tunc intromittat manum, secundum quod narrauimus, donec quando inuenerit Secundinam, et extrahat eam paulatim secundum rectitudinem, ut non cadat matrix apud attractionem uehementem: imo oportet, ut permutetur cum facilitate ad latera dextra et sinistra: deinde addatur in quantitatem attractionis.	If, however, it is an appendix that lies deep in the belly, then he inserts his hand, as we have said, until he has found the second hand, and he gradually pulls it outwards along the straight line, so that the belly does not tear due to the stretching force: indeed it is necessary to turn it with ease to the right and left sides: then it should be added in the amount of the stretching force.</start_of_turn>
Ipsa enim obedit tunc, et seruatur, et euadit ab adhaerentia.	It itself obeys him then, and is served, and departs from the adhesion.</start_of_turn
Quod si os matricis est coartatum, sicut nos iam narrauimus: cura eam cum sternutatione, et ex medicatione ollae cum herbis.	Which if the belly is hard, as we have already said: take care of the belly with straining, and from an ointment of oil with herbs.</start_of_turn>
Si autem non egreditur cum omnibus quae narrauimus, tunc caue ne fatigeris super eam in iteratione extractionis.	If, however, it does not come out with all that we have said, then take care not to strain too much in the process of extracting it.</start_of_turn
Verum oportet, ut quod egreditur ad os matricis ex ea, liges ad coxam mulieris.	Indeed it is necessary that what comes out through the belly to the woman's hip should be bound to the woman's hip.</start_of_turn
Deinde clisteriza eam cum unguento tetrapharmacon.	Then he closes the belly with four unguents.</start_of_turn
Ipsum enim putrefaciet eam post dies, et dissoluetur, et egredietur.	This itself will putrefy the belly after a few days, and will be dissolved, and will go out.</start_of_turn>
Verumtamen quando putrefit, eleuatur ex ea odor malus ad stomachum et caput, et laedit illud infirmam.	Indeed when it has putrefied, there will be a bad smell emanating from it to the stomach and head, and it will cause pain which will render the patient weak.</start_of_turn
Oportet ergo ut administrentur suffumigationes conuenientes ad illud.	It is necessary therefore that suitable fumigations be administered for this.</start_of_turn>
Quidam autem antiquorum iam experti sunt suffumigationem nasturtii, et ficuum siccarum.	Some of the ancient ones are experts in fumigation with rue and dried figs.</start_of_turn
Forma instrumenti quo suffumigatur mulier apud retentionem Secundinae et menstruorum.	Instrument formation for the fumigation of a woman during the second retention and menstruation.
Fiat ex uitro simile alcama, aut ex zere: et ponatur extremitas ampla super ignem: et suffumigatio sit posita super prunas: teneat eam, donec consumatur illa suffumigatio: et itera aliam.	Let an instrument be made like an upturned bowl, or from horn: and its wide end be placed over the flame: and the fumigation be placed over the berries: and hold it until the fumigation has consumed itself: and do it again for another.
¶ De curatione Ani non perforati.	About the care of an unpierced beast.
Caput LXXIX.	Chapter 79.
Nascuntur multi puerorum, et Ani eorum sunt non perforati, quos iam opilauit sifac subtile.	Many boys are born, and of them some are unpierced, whom I have oiled with subtle saffron.
Oportet ergo, ut obstetrix perforet illud sifac digito suo: et si non, perforet ipsum cum Spatumili acuto: et caueat lacertum, ne tangat eum.	It is necessary therefore, that the midwife pierce that saffron with her finger: and if she does not wish to, she shall pierce it with a sharp spatula: and let tears flow, lest it touch him
Deinde pone super ipsum lanam infusam in uino et oleo.	Then place upon it wool soaked in wine and oil
Deinde cura ipsum cum ungentis, donec sanetur.	And care for him with nails, until he is healed
Si autem times quod opiletur, tunc pone in foramine cannulam de plumbo diebus multis, et auferatur quando puer uult egerere.	If however it is necessary to oil him, then put in the wound a lead cannula for several days, and take it out when the boy wishes to urinate
Et iam accidit opilatio Ani etiam ex consolidatione uulneris, aut apostematis.	And sometimes the oiling of an Ani is from the consolidation of a wound, or from a swelling.
Oportet ergo ut secetur illa consolidatio, deinde curetur cum eo quod diximus ex curatione et plumbo.	It is necessary therefore to dry up that consolidation, and then care for him as we said before concerning the care and lead
¶ De curatione Fistularum quae accidunt in inferiori parte.	About the care of fistulas which occur in the lower part
Caput LXXX.	Chapter 80
Fistulae quae accidunt in inferiori, sunt Nodatio, et Grossitudo quae accidunt prope anum deforis: aut in spacio unius partium: et est Fistula una, aut plures.	Fistulas which occur in the lower part are Nodulation and Swelling which occur near any bone of the limb: or in the space of one part: and there is one fistula, or more
Cum ergo antiquatur illa Nodatio, aperitur, et currit ex ea humiditas aquosa alba, aut pus subtile.	When the old knot has become loose, it opens and a white watery moisture or subtle pus flows from it.
Et quandoque sunt ex istis Fistulis penetrantes.	And sometimes these penetrating fistulas arise from it.
Ergo penetrantes cognoscuntur per illud quod egreditur ex egestione, et uentositate, quando utitur infirmus egestione: et fortasse egreditur ex eis uermis.	Therefore, the penetrating ones are recognized by that which proceeds from its discharge and its swelling, when the patient egests with pain: and perhaps it proceeds from worms.
Et sunt ex eis Fistulae quando sunt in spacio penetrantes usque ad uesicam, et usque ad meatum uirgae.	And these are fistulas when they are penetrating from the space until the belly and until the marrow of the bone
Et sunt ex eis penetrantes usque ad iuncturam coxae, et usque ad nodum caudae.	And they are penetrating until the joint of the hip and until the knot of the buttocks
Ex eo autem quo cognoscitur Fistula penetrans usque ad anum, etiam a non penetrante, est, ut intromittas digitum tuum indicem in anum: et intromittas tentam subtilem in Fistulam ex aere, aut ferro: quando non est tortuositas.	From this, however, it is recognized that a penetrating fistula until the groin, even if it is not penetrating, is as it were, as when you insert your finger into the groin: and you insert a subtle piece of lead or iron into the fistula from the air, or from the iron: when there is no swelling
Quod si in ea est tortuositas, tunc intromitte in eam tentam ex plumbo subtilem, aut pilum ex pilis equarum, donec sentias tentam, aut pilum in digito tuo.	When there is swelling there, then insert into the wound a subtle piece of lead or a hair from a horse's tail until you feel the tension, or until you see the hair in your finger.
Quod si non sentis ipsam penitus, neque procedit ex foramine aliquid ex egestione, neque uentositas, neque uermis sicut dixi: tunc scias, quia est non penetrans: propera ergo ad curationem.	If you do not feel the tension, neither is anything coming out from the discharge, neither swelling, nor worms as I have said: then you know that it is not penetrating: remedy therefore for the treatment.
Et quando Fistula est penetrans usque ad uesicam, aut ad meatum urinae: tunc significatio eius est exitus urinae ex ea, et prohibitio eius ab hoc ut consolidetur locus cum medicinis.	And when the fistula is penetrating until the belly or until the bladder: then the significance of that is the discharge of urine from it, and the prohibition of this until it is consolidated with the physicians.
Si uero est penetrans usque ad iuncturam coxae, aut ad os coxae: tunc signum eius est, quod perueniat tenta usque illuc, si non est in ea tortuositas usque ad os: et inuentio doloris in circumitu partis, et quod egreditur pus ex ea semper: et quod non ualeat in ea medicatio, neque consolidatur cum unguento.	If indeed it is penetrating until the hip joint or the hip bone: then the sign of that is that the tension persists until there, if there is no swelling until the bone: and there is pain around the part and pus always comes from it: and it does not improve with medication, neither is it consolidated with ointment
Et in istis Fistulis omnibus penetrantibus non est curatio omnino: et curatio earum est labor et uanitas ei, ex stultis medicis, super quem formatur.	And in all these penetrating fistulas there is no complete cure: the cure for them is toil and humility before the stupid doctors who formed them.
In illa autem quae non est penetrans, et non antiqua, speratur sanatio cum serro: secundum quod ego narro tibi, et ego iam probaui: et est, ut iaceat infirmus inter manus tuas super dorsum suum: et eleua crura eius usque supra coxas ipsius, et coxae eius sint inclinatae ad uentrem ipsius.	And in those which are neither penetrating nor ancient, hope for recovery is expected with an incision: as I have said before, and as I have proven: let the sick man lie between your hands on his back; elevate his limbs up to above his hips, and let his knees be bent towards his belly.
Deinde intromittetentam plumbi, aut aeris, si est in Fistula tortuositas, donec scias ubi peruenit tenta.	Then introduce lead or air into the fistula, until you know where its outlet is.
Si autem sentit eam infirmus circa anum, tunc oportet ut intromittas digitum tuum indicem in anum.	If the sick man feels around his belly, then it is necessary to insert your finger into the belly
Si ergo sentis in digito tuo tentam iam penetrasse per seipsam detectam, praeter quod sentias inter digitum tuum, et inter ipsum sifac, aut carnem: tunc ergo scias certe, quia est penetrans: non ergo labores in ea, quoniam non est eius sanatio, sicut diximus.	If you feel in your finger an attempt to penetrate itself which you detect, besides that which you feel between your finger and the abdomen, or meat: then you know certainly that it is penetrating: for there is no cure for that, as we have said
Dixerunt tamen, quia sanatur in quibusdam hominibus caro, et ex medicatione qua ei speratur iuuamentum, est, ut ignias cauterium subtile secundum amplitudinem Fistulae, sicut praecessit, et intromittas ipsum ignitum in Fistulam, donec perueniat circa anum.	They say that in some men the carrion itself heals, and from the medicine which is expected to be applied: it is necessary to apply gentle cautery according to the size of the fistula, as has been said before, and to introduce the flame into the fistula until it comes around the belly
Deinde itera illud bis, aut ter, donec scias, quia iam adustae sunt omnes illae carnes additae filtratae, quae sunt similes cannulae pennae auis.	Then do that again two or three times, until you know that all the added fatty tissue which is like the quill of a bird has been consumed.
Deinde cura illud cum liciniis inuolutis in butyro, donec egrediantur illae carnes, quae adustae sunt: deinde cura illud cum unguentis generantibus carnem et consolidantibus.	Then care for it with cloths softened with butter, until those fatty tissues have gone out: then care for it with nourishing unguents which generate flesh and consolidate.
Si ergo sanatur, bonum est.	If it heals well, that is good.
Et si non, tunc non sanatur cum alia curatione unquam.	If not, then it does not recover with any other treatment at all.
Et si egreditur tenta, et non peruenerit usque ad digitum tuum, qui est in ano, et est inter ipsum et tentam uelamen spissum ex carne, aut sifac: et uides Fistulam in eo quod sequitur superficiem cutis, tunc seca cutem ab initio Fistulae, et tu uadis secando cum tenta quod est in fistula, donec perueniat secatio ubi peruenit tentae extremitas, et liberatur tenta et cadit.	If not, then it does not recover even if you take away the hand which is in the armpit and which is between the thumb and the fleshy swelling of the flesh, or if you lance it: and if you pour oil into the fistula following the surface of the skin, then dry the skin from the beginning of the fistula, and you dry with the hand which is in the fistula until the cutting has passed beyond the extremity of the thumb, and the thumb is freed and falls off.
Deinde mundifica illas carnes filtratas, quae assimilantur cannulae pennae auis, ut non remaneat ex eis aliquid.	Then soften the flesh which has been cut through, which has absorbed the bristles of a feather pen, so that nothing remains of it from the flesh
Si autem uincit te sanguis, et soluit inter te et inter operationem tuam ut seces illas carnes: tunc melius quod fit, et uelocioris iuuamenti, cauterizare eam cum igne, aut cum medicina acuta.	If however blood flows and separates between you and the operation, then it is better to cauterize with fire or with acute medicine than to cut the flesh: for it is more rapid in healing and more secure.
Quoniam cauterium cum igne aggregat habitudines bonas, adustionem illarum carnium additarum, et abscisionem sanguinis, et exiccationem humiditatum.	For fire-cautery unites the good qualities, adds the adhesion of the tissues, and brings about the separation of blood and drying of moisture
Deinde cura illud cum liciniis inuolutis in butyro, aut caulibus tritis, donec locus emittat pus, et egrediantur illae carnes adustae in pus.	Then care for it with cloths soaked in butter, or with bruised twigs, until the place emits pus, and the flesh is drawn out in pus
Deinde cura tunc uulnus cum unguentis consolidatiuis, generantibus carnem duram: et sunt medicinae in quibus sunt stipticitas et exiccatio.	Then care for it with strong stitches of solidified wax, generating tough flesh: and these are the medicines which have stypticity and drying qualities.
Nam quando restaurantur, tunc iam sanatur: et non times iterationem.	For when they are restored, then it is healed: and it does not take long time.
Si autem Fistula iam peruenit usque ad profundum ani, et elongatur a superfluitate corporis: tunc intromitte digitum tuum in anum, et inquire cum eo.	If however the fistula persists to the depth of the anus, and extends from the excess of the body: then introduce your finger into the anus and inquire concerning it.
Si ergo sentis tentam, et inter te, et inter eam est uelamen ex sifac, aut carne, et est propinqua penetrationi: tunc non est operatio in illo, nisi secundum uiam fiduciae et spei.	If you feel the thumb and there is between you and the fistulous matter a swelling of fat or flesh, and is close to penetration: then there is no operation in that case, except according to the degree of confidence and hope
Quod est, quia administratur in eo unus trium modorum: aut ut cauterizes ipsam, sicut diximus: aut seces eam, donec consequaris concauitatem eius, ut sit possibile tibi intromittere licinia, et curationem ex proximo.
