If one mode be sufficient, it is either to cauterize the part itself, as we have said before, or to dissect it, until you have reached its concavity, so that you may afterwards introduce instruments and perform the cure.
Et non procedas multum cum sectione, ut non incidas lacertum continentem anum, et accidat super infirmum exitus egestionis absque uoluntate.	Proceed not too far with the dissection, lest you pierce the membrane containing the marrow, and cause an unfavourable outcome of the evacuation without your desire.
Deinde cura illud cum eo quod diximus.	Then cure it as we have said before.
Fortasse enim sanabitur: aut elonges ipsum uelamen, et mundes ipsum postquam secas ipsum usque prope anum, sicut diximus, aut cum tenta, aut cum instrumento alio acutae extremitatis.	Perhaps it will be healed: or you may stretch out the membrane itself, and dry it after you have scraped it close to the bone, as we have said, or with hooks, or with another acute instrument.
Deinde mundifica illas carnes filtratas quae sunt in sectione, usque ubi potes cum perscrutatione.	Then drain the bloody parts which are left after the dissection, until the bone is firm with the mark of the incision
Deinde conare restaurationem uulneris totius cum sectione, et orificio superiore ubi consolidatur: et remanet Fistula aperta in interiore parte anus, et erit leuius super infirmum.	Then attempt to restore the entire wound with the incision, and the upper orifice where it is consolidated: and there remains an open fistula in the inner part of the anus, and it is better to leave it open
Et quandoque suitur Fistula secundum hunc modum: et est, quando intromittis tentam in Fistulam: et est in latere ani circa superficiem corporis cum cute et margine ani: tunc accipe tentam perforatae extremitatis, quae est sicut acus aleskef, id est, praeparantium coria, secundum hanc formam.	And when the fistula is to be sutured in this way: when you introduce the hook into the fistula: and it is on the side of the anus around the surface of the body with skin and the margin of the anus: then grasp the hook pierced through the end, which is like a needle with a head, that is, preparing the skin, according to this form
Et intromitte in eam filum inuolutum ex quinque filis, et circiter ea.	And introduce into it a thread wound from five threads, and pass it around these.
Deinde intromitte tentam cum filo in Fistulam, donec consequatur concauitatem eius.	And introduce the hook with the thread into the fistula, until you have reached its concavity
Si ergo est penetrans in margine ani interius prope, tunc extrahe filum ex illo foramine: ita ut intromittas digitum tuum in anum, et extrahas extremitatem fili, et aggreges duas extremitates simul: et stringe utramque, et dimitte illud die uno, aut duobus diebus: et quanto plus incidit filum in carne, stringe ipsum bene, donec incidantur illae carnes quae sunt inter duas extremitates fili, et cadant: deinde cura uulnus, donec consolidetur, et sanetur.	If there is a puncture in the inner margin of the anus close to the bone, then draw out the thread from that hole: so that you can introduce your finger into the anus, and draw out the end of the thread, and join the two ends together: and bind them as much as necessary: until those parts which are between the two ends of the thread have become soft and fallen away: then cure the wound, until it is consolidated and healed
Si autem orificium Fistulae non est penetrans: tunc fac ipsum penetrare quocunque modo praeparatur tibi, nisi sit in profundo multum.	If the opening of the fistula is not penetrable: then make it so by whatever means are prepared, except if it is in great depth.
Non enim inest tibi, ut facias illud propter lacertum, ut non incidas ipsum.	Except that you do not make it wide open by means of a laceration, lest you destroy it.
Deinde fac cum ea sicut diximus, donec sanetur.	Do so then as we have said, until it is healed.
Forma Spatumilis spinosi quo finditur Fistula, cuius curuitas est acuta ualde, et pars altera est non acuta, ut non incidat illud quod non est necesse, sicut uides.	Shape the sponge-rubber as it is found, concerning the fistula, whose curve is acute above and blunt below, and the other part is not acute, so that you do not damage that which is not necessary, like water
¶ De sutura Hemorroidarum, ex quibus currit sanguis ex incisione earum: et cura fissurarum.	Concerning the stitching of hemorrhoids from which blood runs from the incision of them: and the care of the incisions.
Caput LXXXI.	Chapter 81.
Sunt Hemorroides secundum duos modos.	There are hemorrhoids in two ways.
Aut enim sunt intra anum, similes uesicis carbonum, uel prunarum: aut quasi ipsae sint grana uuae.	They are either inside the rectum, like little stones of the intestines or dates: or they are like little seeds of wheat
Et ex eis sunt paruae, et magnae: et sanguis currit ex eis semper, et est una, et sunt multae.	And they are small and great: and blood runs from them always, and there is one of them, and there are many of them.
Et sunt extra anum, et in extremitatibus eius.	And they are outside the rectum, and at their extremities
Verumtamen istae quae sunt extra anum, sunt secundum plurimum paucae humiditatis, ex quibus currit aqua citrina, aut parum sanguinis cursu assiduo: et sunt secundum colorem corporis.	However, those which are outside the rectum are mostly small and moist, from which runs clear urine, or a little blood slowly: and they are of different colors of the body
Et curatio eius quae est intra anum, est, ut praecipias infirmo ut assellet: et exprimatur, donec egrediatur anus, et appareant athelil tibi.	And the care of those which are inside the rectum is that you urge the patient to bear down: and evacuate, until the anus appears, and the little one comes out.
Propterea ergo et suspende cum uncinis: aut tene eos cum ungue tuo.	Therefore, do this also with stitches: or hold it with your finger
Deinde incide eos apud radices suas.	Then cut through at the roots of them
Si autem non retinentur in eis uncini, propter humiditatem eorum et ipsorum mollificationem: tunc cape eos cum panno aspero, aut cum coto ex diploide lanea, et extrahe eos cum digitis tuis.	If they do not remain in the wound due to the humidity of the air and their softness: then cover them with rough linen cloth, or with a coat of lanolin from a sheep's wool, and extract them with your fingers.
Deinde incide eos, et pulueriza super eos post incisionem quosdam pulueres calidos, ut stent eis loco cauterii.	Then pierce the wound, and sprinkle over it after incision any fine, warm powder, so that they remain in the place of the cautery.
Aut cauteriza eos secundum quod praecessit in capitulo cauterizandi.	Or cauterize them according to what was mentioned in the chapter on cautery.
Deinde cura eos cum reliqua curatione, donec sanentur.	Then care for the wound with the remaining treatment until it heals.
Quod si non obedit anus egressioni, tunc clisteriza infirmum clisteri in quo sit mordicatio parua, ut lauetur cum eo quod est in ano, et obediat egressioni uelociter, quando exprimit se infirmus.	If it does not obey the opening of the anus, then give the patient a suppository in the rectum where there is a small bite, so that it will be evacuated with the feces, and the patient will soon evacuate it when it is expelled naturally.
Si autem athelil sunt extrinseci ab ano, tunc res eorum est leuis, facilis: et est ut capias eos cum ungue tuo, aut capias eos cum uncino, et incidas eos.	If they are nevertheless extruded from the anus, then it is a light matter, easy: grasp them with your finger or grasp them with a forceps, and cut them off.</start_of_turn>
Deinde cura eos cum eo quod diximus, donec sanentur.	Then care for the wound as we have said until it heals
Et qui abhorret incisionem cum ferro, tunc oportet ut administres suturam eorum secundum hunc modum.	And whoever dislikes an incision with a knife, then he must administer a suture of them in this way.
Accipe filum inuolutum, et intromitte ipsum in acum.	Take a thread that has been twisted, and introduce it into the substance.
Deinde extrahe athelil ad superiora, et fac ipsum penetrare cum acu in radice eius ex parte altera: et inuolue duas extremitates fili, in inferiori parte acus, et sint latitudinaliter: et stringe athelil strictura forti.	Then extract the foreign bodies upwards, and make it penetrate with the needle at its root from the opposite side: and loop two extremities of the thread, in the lower part of the needle, and let them be parallel: and tighten the foreign bodies with a strong suture.</start_of_turn>
Deinde noda filum, et extrahe acum.	Then knot the thread, and extract the needle.</start_of_turn>
Fac illud cum omnibus athelil, et dimitte ex eis unum: nec suas ipsum, ut currat ex eo superfluitas sanguinis.	Do this with all the foreign bodies, and discharge from the wound one at a time: neither leaving them, lest there be excessive bleeding.</start_of_turn>
Deinde pone super anum pannum infusum in oleo rosato, aut caeroto, et pone ipsum super anum: et praecipe infirmo, ut quiescat.	Then place upon the wound an infused cloth in rose-water, or vinegar, and place the latter upon the wound: and command the patient to rest.
Deinde dimitte ipsum, donec cadat.	Then leave it until it falls off naturally.</start_of_turn>
Cum ergo cadunt athelil, cura eos cum unguentis, et reliqua curatione, donec sanentur.	When it falls off by itself, care for it with unguents, and remain attentive until healed.</start_of_turn>
¶ De cura Fissurarum.	(The text continues with instructions for treating wounds.)</start_of_turn>
Multotiens enim accidunt ex exiccatione stercoris, et constrictione naturae.	Many are caused by the evacuation of feces, and the constriction of nature.</start_of_turn
Cum ergo antiquantur, et non ualet in eis medicina: tunc oportet ut radas cum puncta Spatumilis, aut cum ungue tuo, donec fiant humidae, et auferatur ab eis cortex superior qui prohibet eas a consolidatione.	When these things have been evacuated, and do not avail in medicine: then it is necessary to apply a sponge with Spatumilian seeds, or with your finger, until they become moist, and the outer layer is scraped away which hinders adhesion.</start_of_turn
Deinde cura eas, donec consolidentur secundum quod oportet.	Then care for the wound, until it is consolidated as it should be.</start_of_turn
Si autem non consolidantur: tunc itera eas cum rasione uehementiori quam prima, donec sanguinentur multum, et excorientur deinde cura eas, donec sanentur.	If, however, they do not consolidate: then repeat the wound with greater reason than before, until much blood flows, and then care for the wound until it heals.</start_of_turn
¶ De curatione Almirmar inuersorum, et non inuersorum: et Athelil siccorum, et Formicae.	(The text continues with instructions for treating various ailments.)</start_of_turn
Caput LXXXII.	(The book continues with further medical instructions.)</start_of_turn>
Scias quod Almirmar non est nisi nodus rotundus secundum colorem corporis, similis capiti claui: et fit in toto corpore, praecipue in inferioribus partibus pedum, et digitis: et accidit ex eis dolor apud ambulationem.	You know that Almirmar is not except a round knot according to the color of the body, similar to a claw head: and it occurs throughout the body, especially in the lower parts of the legs and fingers: and it happens from pain in walking.</start_of_turn
Oportet ergo ut secetur quod est in circumitu claui, et teneatur cum forficibus, aut cum uncino, et eradicetur ex radice sua.	It is necessary therefore to cut around the claw and hold it with forceps, or with a needle, and eradicate it from its root.</start_of_turn
Deinde cura illud: et si uis cauteriza illud secundum quod praecessit in capitulo suo.	Then care for that: and if you wish to cauterize that, do so according to what precedes in its chapter.
Ex athelil autem siccis unus est eminentia parua, aspera, filtrata, rotunda supra superficiem corporis.	However, from the heel thus a small, rough, filtered, rounded elevation appears on the surface of the body.
Et multotiens accidunt in manibus puerorum.	And they often happen in the hands of children.
Et curatio eius est, ut extendas athelil, et incidas ipsum: aut stringas ipsum cum filo de serico: aut cum pilo, donec cadat.	And its care is that you extend the heel and cut it through: or you bind it with a silken thread: or with hair, until it falls off
Et si uis, cauteriza ipsum secundum quod praemissum est cum igne, aut cum medicina acuta: et iam eradicantur athelil inuersi, et non inuersi cum instrumento quod ego dicam.	And if you wish, cauterize it according to what is prescribed with fire, or with acute medicine: and thus the heel will be eradicated both inwards and outwards, not inwards alone with the instrument that I speak of
Formica autem est etiam eminentia parua filtrata, grossa, super superficiem corporis, uadens in profundum ualde: et quando inuenit eam frigus, sentitur in ea simile mordicationi formicae, et fit in corpore toto: et plurimum eius fit in manibus.	A worm is also a small, filtered elevation, large, on the surface of the body, which extends inwards to the depth of the ulcer: and when it comes into contact with cold, it feels like the bite of a worm in it, and it causes pain throughout the body, and most of all in the hands
Et curatio eius est, ut accipias cannulam ex penna anseris, aut penna uulturis forti: et pone illam cannulam super Formicam, donec contineat circulus cannulae ex partibus eius.	And its care is that you take a needle from the beak of an ostrich, or a strong quill, and put it over the worm, until it is surrounded by the circumference of the needle around its parts
Deinde reuolue manum tuam cum cannula, donec seces quod est in circumitu Formicae: et ponas eam in profundo carnis, et eradices Formicam ex radice eius.	Then withdraw your hand with the needle, until you have severed what is around the worm: and you put it into the depth of the flesh, and extract the worm from its root.
Et si uis, fac illud cum cannula aeris, aut ferri, secundum hanc formam.	And if you wish, do it with an air needle, or a needle of iron, according to this form
Sit superius cannulae ad sublimitatem trahens surdum inuolutum, ut alleuietur super digitum apprehensio eius et ipsius reuolutio.	Let the upper part of the needle reach the thickness of the surrounding skin, so that it may alleviate the tension on the thumb and its retraction
Et si uis cauteriza Formicam secundum quod praemissum est in cauterizatione Athelil in capitulo de cauterio.	And if you wish, cauterize the worm according to what is prescribed in the chapter on cauterization of the heel.
¶ De formis Instrumentorum quae administrantur ad Clisteria in aegritudinibus Ani, et solutionis uentris, et colicae.	Concerning the forms of instruments which are administered to patients in ailments of the belly and intestines, and the solution of the belly and the intestines.
Caput LXXXIII.	Concerning the forms of instruments which are administered to patients in ailments of the belly and intestines, and the solution of the belly and intestines.
Quandoque Clistere fit ex argento, aut ex aurichalco, aut ex aere fuso, aut malleato.	When the intestines are made of silver, or gold, or blown glass, or hammered out.
Et quandoque fit ex istis Instrumentis paruum, et magnum, secundum illos in quibus administrantur.	And when these instruments are made of small and large sizes, according to those which are administered
Illud ergo quod administratur in curatione puerorum paruorum, sit paruum: et quorum ani sunt debiles, aut dolorosi, sic et clisteria eorum.	This is what is administered in the treatment of young children with loose bowels, be they weak or painful, so also with clisteria
Clistere magnum.	Large intestines
Cistere paruum.	Small intestines
Canna eius, id est, caput superius in quo ligatur uter, sit amplum secundum hunc modum: et sit ei distinctio ut ligetur uter sicut uides, et extremitas eius inferior quae intromittitur in anum, sit surda, id est, non aperta, lenis, ualde, trahens ad subtilitatem: et in uno laterum eius sint duo foramina, et in latere altero foramen unum.	The upper part of the head which is bound up by the uterus, be it wide according to this manner: and that it has a distinction so that the uterus is bound up like water, and the lower part of it which enters the belly be closed, hard, blunt, stretching to thinness: and on one side of it are two holes, and on the other side one hole
Et sit amplitudo foraminis secundum grossitudinem radiorum, et grossius parum, et sit uter in quo ponuntur medicinae ex uesica animalis: aut ex charta ouis, quae sit secundum formam asofrati paruae: cuius radix sit palmus unus.	And the breadth of the hole according to the length of the ribs, and more widely a little, and the uterus in which the medicines are placed from the belly of the beast: or from paper wool, which is like the shape of the small asphodel: whose root is one palm
Et perforetur foraminibus multis sicut reuoluitur, et sit spacium quod est inter omne foramen grossitudo digiti.	And it is perforated with many holes as it is turned, and there is space between every hole the size of a finger
Deinde intromitte in illa foramina filum forte ex filo crudo, quod sit ex decem filis, aut circiter ea, et aggrega cum eo utrem sicut asofrati.	Then insert into these holes a strong thread from a strong thread, which is from ten threads, or thereabouts, and gather with it like asphodel.
Cum ergo ponitur in eo uter, stringatur in capite clisteris inter duo distinguentia constrictione forti.	When it is thus placed in this uterus, it is bound up in the head of the clister between two distinguishing constrictions strong
Deinde clisteriza cum eo.	Then anoint the cavity with oil.
Et haec est forma circuli utris hic depicta, et foraminum.	This is the form of the circle here depicted, and of holes.
Qualitas autem clisterizandi cum eo, est: ut impleas utrem, aut uesicam ex medicina, quae sit calefacta secundum quantitatem tolerantiae infirmi: et caue ne sit calida ualde, aut frigida ualde.	The quality of the anointing with oil is this: that you apply as much of the belly, or from the medicine, as is appropriate for the tolerance of the patient: and take care that it is neither too hot nor too cold, neither too warm nor too cold.
Deinde resupinetur infirmus super dorsum suum, et eleuet crura sua ad superiora: et pone sub eo inthaan, id est, corium super quod iacent homines, aut linteamen.	Then the patient lies on his back, and raises his legs towards the head: and put under it fat, that is, skin which men lie upon, or lint
Deinde inunge extremitatem Clisteris cum oleo, aut cum albugine oui, aut cum mucillagine foenugraeci, aut similium.	Then anoint the area with oil, or with alum, or with barley mucilage, or similar things.
Deinde intromitte ipsum in anum cum facilitate.	Then introduce the instrument into the cavity with ease.
Deinde accipiat minister utrem cum duabus manibus suis simul, et exprimat ipsum cum uehementia, donec euacuet totum quod est in Clisteri in intestinum.	Then take hold of the belly with two hands simultaneously, and press it out with force, until it has evacuated everything that is in the cavity of the Clister into the intestines
Deinde extrahe Clistere, et eleuet infirmus crura sua ad parietem.	Then remove the Clister, and raise the patient's legs to the side
Quod si medicina cogit eum ad exitum, tunc teneat quantum potest.	And if the medicine compels you to remove it, then hold for as long as you can.
Et si dormit cum ea nocte tota, est magis ultimum in iuuamento.	And if he sleeps through the whole night, it is the greatest remedy.
Si autem clisterizas eum in aegritudinibus solutionis uentris, et festinat exitus eius: tunc itera clistere, donec sanetur.	If however you anoint him in the ailments of the bowels of the belly, and he has a speedy recovery: then repeat the Clister until he is healed.
Quod si in ano sunt hemorroides, aut apostemata laedentia, tunc sit clistere subtile ualde, lene, ex clisteribus quibus clisterizantur pueri.	If there are hemorrhoids or abscesses of pain: then let the Clister be gentle and cold, soft, from the Clisters which are used to anoint children
Et haec sit forma clisteris subtilis super quod sit stricta cutis.	And this is the form of the gentle Clister which is over the strictness of the skin.
¶ De curatione Vulnerum capitis sine fractura ossis.	On the treatment of wounds of the head without fracture of the bone.
Caput LXXXIIII.	Head wound without bone fracture.
Iam dixi in diuisione de curatione uulnerum quod conueniebat libro, et ego dicam hic curationem eorum cum manu, et cum medicinis secundum complementum.	I have said in the discussion of wound treatment that it agrees with the book, and I will now speak of their treatment with the hand and with the help of physicians as a supplement.
Dico ergo, quod uulnera diuersificantur secundum illud quo fiunt uulnera, et secundum locum super quem cadit uulnus.	I say, therefore, that wounds are varied according to the nature of the wound and the place where the wound falls
Res ergo quibus fiunt uulnera multotiens, sunt sicut iactus lapidis: aut incisio ensis, aut cultelli: aut percussio cum lancea, aut ligno, aut sagitta: et similibus illis ex rebus multis.	The nature of wounds is diverse, as are the impacts of a stone: either an incision with a sword or knife, or a blow with a lance, stick, or arrow, and the like
Vulnera autem quae fiunt secundum loca corporis sunt, sicut uulnus quod cadit super caput, aut collum, aut pectus, aut uentrem, aut epar: et similia ex eis membris.	Wounds, however, which are caused by the place of the body, are like those which fall on the head, or the neck, or the chest, or the stomach, or the limbs: and the like from various parts of the body.
Et ego sum narrans curationes quorundam uulnerum, ut ponam eam ratiocinationem et regulam super reliqua uulnera.	And I shall speak of the treatment of some wounds, in order to set out the ratiocination and rule regarding the rest of the wounds.
Et ego incipiam a uulneribus capitis simplicibus: quoniam rememoratio compositorum ueniet in principio capituli tertii.	I will begin with simple head wounds: because the memory of composite matters will come at the beginning of the third chapter of the head.
Dico ergo.	I say.
Quando accidit in capite uulnus simplex, et non est fractura ossis: considera tunc, si est ex iactu lapidis, aut ei similibus, et iam fregit cutem tantum: et est uulnus magnum, et times super infirmum euentum apostematis calidi: tunc propera, et phlebotoma cephalicam statim: et non tardes illud: et extrahe ei ex sanguine secundum quantitatem uirtutis eius: si non fuerit prohibens aliquid a phlebotomia, praecipue si fuerit sanguis qui egreditur ex uulnere paucus.	When in the head there is a simple wound and there is no fracture of the bone: consider then, if it is from the impact of a stone, or like it, and if the skin is only bruised: and it is a great wound and the time is great for an inflamed swelling of the head: then act immediately, and perform a cephalic phlebotomy: and do not delay: and extract from him blood according to the quantity of his virtue: if there is nothing to prevent phlebotomy, especially if there is little blood coming from the wound.
Et sit phlebotomia ex contrario partis uulneratae.	And let the phlebotomy be from the opposite side of the wounded part.
Et caueat infirmus sibi a repletione, et uino, et cibis grossis.	And let the patient abstain from repletion, from wine, and from coarse food
Si autem minutionem prohibet aliquid, tunc minoretur ex cibo, et non appropinquet carnibus, neque uinis.	But if anything hinders the reduction, then one should abstain from food, and not approach meat, nor drink wine.
Et pone super uulnus si accidit ei apostema calidum, cotum infusum in oleo rosato solo, aut cum uino in quo est stipticitas.	And let there be placed upon the wound if it happens to have a thick clot, a soft cushion filled with fat, or with wine in which there is stickiness
Si autem securus fueris ab apostemate calido, tunc pone super uulnus, si est recens cum sanguine suo, et non mutauit ipsum aer, puluerem quem ego narrabo post paululum: et si iam mutauit ipsum aer, tunc pone super ipsum quaedam unguenta, donec sanetur.	And if you are certain that the clot is thick, then place upon the wound, if it exists with its own blood, and has not changed the air, the powder which I will tell you about later: and if it has changed the air, then place upon it some unguents until it is healed
Si autem uulnus est magnum, aut est ex incisione ensis, et similium: et non aggregantur labia eius per puluillos, tunc aggrega ipsa cum sutura, secundum quod ego narrabo in uulneribus uentris de sutura eorum.	And if the wound is large, or has been made by a sword, and is similar: and the edges of it are not to be held together by threads, then gather them together with sutures, as I shall tell you concerning the sutures of wounds within in the same way
Si autem uulnus iam detectum est ab osse, et pendet, et non est retentio eius, nisi in suspensorio paruo: tunc incide ipsum.	And if the wound has been detected from a bone, and hangs, and its retention is not necessary except for a small suspension: then cut it through
Deinde cura uulnus cum medicinis, et restaura in eo carnem duram loco cutis, et praecipe infirmo, ut alatur cibis in quibus est grossitudo, sicut sunt capita, et triticum coctum, donec sit ut puls: et eis similia.	Then care for the wound with the physicians, and restore in it solid flesh in the place of the skin, and command the patient, let him eat foods in which there is greatness, such as heads, and barley cooked, until the pulse is like this: and the like
Quod si inuenis in cute putrefactionem, et non adhaeret ossi: tunc incide putrefactum totum, et proiice ipsum: deinde cura illud.	When you find in the flesh putrefaction, and it does not adhere to the bone: then cut through the whole putrefaction, and throw it away: then care for that
Si autem in his uulneribus est arteria, aut uena ex qua fluit sanguis: et non abscinditur per medicinas, tunc inquire super arteriam.	And if in his wounds there is an artery, or a vein from which blood flows: and it is not to be clipped by the physicians, then inquire about the artery.
Si ergo inuenis eam non sectam, tunc seca eam cum Spatumili, aut liga eam.	If the wound is not closed, then dry it with Spatumili, or ligate it.
Quod si necessitas prouocat quando non confert illud quod diximus, tunc cauteriza eam, donec abscindatur sanguis.	If necessity compels when it does not agree with what has been said, then cauterize the wound until the blood is separated
Si autem uulnera ista sunt parua, simplicia, tunc res eorum est facilis, leuis: ita ut puluerizes super ea hunc puluerem: quoniam consolidat ea antequam mutet ea aer.	If the wound is small and simple, then it is sufficient to sprinkle it with powder: because it strengthens them before they change from air.
¶ Modus Pulueris incarnatiui.	Method of applying powdered charcoal.
Recipe olibani partem unam, et sanguinis draconis partes duas, et calcis non extinctae partes tres: teratur totum multum, et cribelletur: et impleatur ex eo uulnus, et constringatur constrictione bona, donec adhaereat super ipsum bene, et coaguletur cum sanguine.	Recipe for olive oil, dragon's blood, and burnt lime. Mix one part of each together, and grind them to a fine powder. Apply this powder to the wound and bind it securely, until it adheres well and coaguates with the blood
Deinde stringe ipsum desuper cum puluillis, et dimitte ipsum, neque soluas ipsum dum permanet, ita quod non apostemetur.	Then string the wound over sponges, and let it go, without loosening it until it remains, so that it does not stick to the wound
Nam non eradicatur ab eo medicina, donec sanatur.	For it is not eradicated by medicine until it heals
Et quandoque facit illud calx sola, quando non sunt tibi in praesenti olibanum, et sanguis draconis etiam facit eandem operationem in multis ex uulneribus magnis, quando conuenit ut ponatur super ea et stringantur, et sunt uulnera recentia cum sanguine suo, quae non alterauit aer.	And when it does this with lime alone, when it is not joined with olive oil and dragon's blood, it does the same operation in many large wounds, when it is necessary to put it on and string them, and when the wound is fresh with its own blood, which has not changed from air
Quod si iam alterauit ea aer quadam alteratione, praecipue quando est in tempore aestatis, tunc non est in positione huius pulueris intentio: cura ergo ipsum cum eo quod diximus, ita ut ponas super ea quaedam unguenta digestiua: aut ponas super ea pultes ex farina hordei, factas cum aqua et melle, donec emittant pus.	When it has changed from air by any alteration, especially in the summer season, then it is not appropriate to apply this powder: rather care for the wound as we have said, by putting on over it some unguents of digestion: or put on over it balls of barley flour, made with water and honey, until pus comes out
Deinde cura ea reliqua curatione, donec sanentur.	Then care for the rest of the treatment until it heals
Si uero accidat cum uulnere fractura in osse, et est parua, tunc extrahe illud cum Gesti: et ego iam dicam curationem fracturarum capitis in eo quod futurum est.	If indeed it happens that a fracture occurs with a wound in a bone and is small, then extract that with Gesti: and I will tell you the treatment of fractures of the head in that which the future is.
¶ De uulneribus Colli.	Of head wounds.
Caput LXXXV.	Head wound section.
SI Autem uulnus accidat in Collo, tunc non est inter ipsum differentia in medicatione, et inter uulnus capitis quando est simplex.	If indeed it happens that a wound occurs in the head, then there is no difference in treatment between it and a simple head wound
Si autem iam incisus est neruus Colli, aut arteria: tunc si est neruus, non est in eo ingenium, nisi ut deuitetur curatio eius cum eo quod facit stipticitatem uehementem, sicut ziniar, et zegi, et eis similia.	If, however, the nerve or an artery is cut: then if it is the nerve, it is not in vain, unless its cure be sought with that which makes hemostasis immediate, as for example, sponges and sponges of silk and things of that kind
Quoniam nocent neruis, et contrahunt eos.	For the nerves are not known, and they are contraacted by them.
Et non ponas super uulnus aliquid frigidum omnino: quoniam substantia neruorum est frigida, et continuatio eius est cum cerebro, quod est sublimius membrorum: et sit illud quo curatur ex medicinis lene, sicut calx lota cum aqua dulci aliquotiens infusa cum oleo, aut cum oleo rosato, et tuthia, quando abluitur etiam cum aqua dulci: et reliqui lapides minerales, secundum hunc modum, et unguenta humida.	You must not put anything cold upon the wound at all: for the substance of nerves is cold, and its continuation is with the brain, which is the soul of the limbs: and let that be which is cured by the physicians gently, as for example, lime with sweet water occasionally infused with oil, or with rose oil, and alum, when it is washed away even with sweet water: and the rest of the mineral stones, according to this method, and moist unguents.
Si autem uulnus est magnum, tunc administra suturam: aut coarta labia eius cum puluillis.	If however the wound is great, then administer a suture: or close its lips with pieces of wool.
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then take care of it until it is healed
Si uero uulneri est profunditas, aut accidit in eo sinus in inferiori parte eius, in quo iam aggregatur pus, tunc perfora ipsum in magis depresso loco in eo.	If indeed the wound is depth, or has occurred in that sinus in the lower part of it, in which pus is gathered, then perforate it in the lowest place in that.
Quod si iam incisa est in uulnere arteria, et consecutus est sanguinem eius fluxus: tunc separa, uel seca eam, et liga ipsam: aut cauteriza eam, si prouocat necessitas ad illud.	If indeed a blood vessel has been cut, and its blood flow has followed: then separate it, or dry it up, and ligate it: or cauterize it, if need be for that
Si autem iam incidit spondiles gutturis, aut totum, et saluatae sunt alhaudegi: tunc aggrega labia cutis cum sutura super cannam gutturis, et non tangas guttur, imo aequa ipsum, et reduc ipsum super figuram naturalem.	If, however, the cheekbones of the gullet have been fractured, either entirely or partially, and the soft parts are protruded: then join the lips of the skin with a suture above the canthus of the gullet, and do not touch the gullet, but rather equalize it with itself, and reduce it above its natural position.
Deinde stringe ipsum strictura decenti, et dimitte ipsum diebus aliquot.	Then bind it with a loose dressing, and discharge it in a few days.
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguentis in quibus est stipticitas et exiccatio, donec sanetur.	Then care for it with poultices in which there is styptic and drying action, until it has healed.
Si autem uulnus iam fecit impressionem in osse, tunc perquire ipsum: tunc si in ipso sunt fragmenta ossis, extrahe ea omnia, aut quae potes ex eis: et quod non praeparatur, dimitte illud, donec putrescat uulnus, et separetur et alleuietur egressio eius.	If, however, a nail has made an impression in the bone, then investigate it: then if there are fragments of bone in the same, remove them all, or whatever can be extracted from it: and whatever cannot be prepared, discharge it, until the nail has rotted away, and the swelling has subsided.
Quod si uulnus fuerit recens, tunc pulueriza super ipsum puluerem quem narraui.	And if the nail should be broken, then grind over it the powder which I have mentioned before.
Si autem uidetur in uulnere os, et fit Fistula: tunc cura ipsam cum eo cuius rememoratio uenit in capitulo suo.	If, however, bone is seen in the nail, and a fistula has formed: then care for it as described in its chapter.
¶ De uulnere in Spatulis.	Of a nail in the teeth.
Caput LXXXVI.	Chapter 86.
SI Est percussio lanceae, aut cultelli: et uides eius profunditatem, tunc considera.	If there is a percussion of a lance or a knife, and you see its depth, then consider it
Si ergo ex uulnere egreditur uentositas, quando anhelat ex eo infirmus, tunc scias, quia uulnus est mortale.	If, however, from the wound blood comes out when the patient breathes, you know that the nail is deadly
Quod si non fuerit ei profunditas, et est recens cum sanguine suo: tunc non ponas in eo a prima hora puluerem, neque stringas ipsum, ut non retineatur sanguis in profunditate eius, et reuertatur ad cor, et interficiat infirmum: sed pone in ipso unguentum attractiuum, et solue ipsum in die bis.	If it is not of great depth, and is merely bruised with blood, do not immediately grind or bind it, lest you prevent the blood from draining from its depth, but bring the hand to the heart, and cut off the patient: but put in it a pleasant poultice, and leave it for two days
Si uero unguentum non est tibi praesens, tunc pone in orificio uulneris cotum uetustum, ut sugat illud quod egreditur de eo ex humiditatibus: et fac ut dormiat infirmus super uulnus, ut currat quod aggregatur in eo.	If the unguentum is not present, then place in the opening of the wound a wool cushion which has been well-worn, so that it may absorb what is coming out of it from the humilities: and let the patient sleep over the wound, so that it may heal what has aggregated in it.
Si uero iam praeterierint uulneri tres dies, aut plures, et non accidit infirmo spasmus, neque tremor cordis malus, neque strictura in anhelitu, et uides reliquas dispositiones eius bonas: tunc scias, quia uulnus est saluum.	If, however, for three days or more the wound has passed without causing the patient pain, nor spasm of the heart, nor bad tremor, nor stricture of the bowels, and all other symptoms have ceased, then you know that the wound is healed.</start_of_turn>
Cura ergo ipsum et cum liciniis, et reliqua curatione, donec sanetur.	Care for it therefore with care and with medicines, and with the rest of the treatment, until it is healed.</start_of_turn>
Si uero excusatur sanatio eius, et iam aperitur semper, tunc scias, quia iam factum est Fistula.	If, however, the healing is excused, and it always opens, then you know that a fistula has been made.</start_of_turn
Cura ergo ipsam ex capitulo suo.	Care for it therefore from its chapter.</start_of_turn
Et si uulnus est ex incisione ensis, aut cultelli, et est simplex in superficie pectoris, aut dorsi: tunc cura ipsum cum eo quod praecessit ex sutura, si est magnum: aut cum puluere, si est paruum.	And if the wound is from the incision of a sword or a knife, and is simple on the surface of the chest or back: then care for it with that which preceded the suture, if it is great: or with powder, if it is small.</start_of_turn
Si autem iam fecit impressionem in osse, et incidit ex eo frusta: tunc inquire uulnus, et propera ad extrahendum illa frusta, si sunt separata.	If, however, there is an impression made in the bone, and it breaks through from it: then inquire about the wound, and properly remove that which is separated.</start_of_turn
Si uero non sunt separata, tunc dimitte ea, donec putrefiat uulnus, alleuiatur enim extractio eorum.	If, however, they are not separated, then leave them alone, until the wound putrefies, so that the extraction may be easier.</start_of_turn
Reliquorum autem uulnerum accidentium in reliquis membris iudicium in curatione, est iudicium eius quod diximus.	As for the rest of the accidents of wounds in the rest of the limbs, the judgement in their treatment is their own which we have already said.</start_of_turn
¶ De uulneribus Ventris, et exitu intestini, et exitura eorum.	Of wounds of the belly, and the issue of the intestine, and the issue of them.</start_of_turn
Caput LXXXVII.	Chapter LXXXVII.
Disruptio quae accidit uentri, est magna, et media, et parua.	The disruption that occurs at the entrance is great, medium, or small.
Ex magna igitur quandoque egreditur intestinum, aut numerus intestinorum.	From the great there is sometimes the extrusion of the intestine, or the number of intestines
Quare fit intromissio eorum, et eorum sutura uehementior et difficilior.	Therefore the handling of these things is more difficult and more complex
Et disruptio parua etiam fit difficilis ex modo alio.	And even the small disruption is difficult in another way.
Sequitur ergo, ut sit reductio eorum difficilior, si non properas in intromissione sua ad locum suum statim: quoniam inflatur, aperitur, et ingrossatur: quare fit difficilis introitus eius.	Therefore, it is necessary that the reduction should be performed immediately if you do not want to be delayed by the inflation, opening out and swelling of the bowels: for this makes the passage difficult
Propter hoc ergo fit melior disruptionum disruptio media: quoniam cum ea non fit difficilis reductio intestini, sicut fit dissicilis in his duabus speciebus.	For this reason, therefore, the medium disruption is better: because with this one the reduction of the intestine is not difficult, as it is with the great and small disruptions
Scias, quod sutura uenris est secundum quatuor modos.	You know that the suture of the belly is according to four methods.
Duae suturae communes conueniunt in sutura uentris, et in sutura reliquorum uulnerum corporis: et duae suturae aliae proprie communicant reliquis uulneribus.	Two sutures are common to join the sutures of the belly, and in the sutures of the remaining wounds of the body: and two other sutures are proper for the remaining wounds.
Verumtamen sunt magis propriae cum sutura uentris: et ego narro tibi unamquamque cum expositione, et declaratione.	However, these are more proper with the suture of the belly: and I will tell you one and the same with exposure and declaration.
Dico ergo, quia quando uulnus est paruum, et egreditur ex eo aliquid ex intestino, et fit difficile reducere ipsum: tunc illud est propter unum duorum modorum.	I say therefore, that when the wound is small and something from the intestine comes out of it, and it is difficult to reduce it: then that is because of one of the two ways
Aut propter paruitatem disruptionis, sicut diximus: Aut quoniam in intestino est inflatio propter frigus aeris.	Either because of the smallness of the disruption, as we have said: or because there is inflation in the intestine due to the cold of the air.
Quando ergo illud est ita, tunc oportet ut calefacias ipsum, ita ut submergas spongiam, aut pannum humidum in aqua tepida sola.	When this is the case, it is necessary to heat it up, so as to compress the sponge or wet cloth in lukewarm water alone
Aut decoquas in aqua squinantum, et cyperum, et spicam, et embroces cum ea intestinum, donec resoluatur inflatio.	Pour the decoction in water, let there be a squinquit of saffron, a cyperum, a spicam, and embroces with the intestines until the swelling is resolved.
Quandoque facit illud uinum in quo est stipticitas: et est melius quam aqua sola in resolutione inflationis.	When it has been made in that liquid in which there is stickiness: it is better than water alone in the resolution of the swelling.
Cum ergo uides inflationem iam resolui, tunc humecta intestinum cum aqua in qua decocta est altea, aut malua.	When the swelling has been resolved, then moisten the intestines with the water in which the decoction has been made, either hot or cold.
Nam per illud alleuiatur introitus eius cum re parua.	For in this way it will soothe the entrance of it with a little thing.
Si autem excusatur reditus eius post hanc curationem, tunc finde in disruptione parum, cum instrumento quo secantur hemorrhoides.	If however its return is excused after this treatment, then find in a slight disruption, with the instrument with which hemorrhoids are cut off.
Et curatio prima est melior quando praeparatur, quam sectio: et non fit coactio ad secandum post necessitatem et defectum instrumenti.	And the first treatment is better when it is prepared than when it is cut: and it does not cause a forced compression to stop after the necessity and the defect of the instrument
Sit pars eius una quae est torta, acuta, et pars eius altera non acuta, et extremitas subtilis non sit cum subtilitate Spatumilis, imo sit obtusior parumper: et est illa quae similatur caiada, sicut uides.	Let one part be acute and the other not acute, and the extremity not be harsh like that of Spatumilis, but rather be softer: and that which is similar to a chick, like water
Cum ergo amplificatur uulnus, et ingreditur intestinum, tunc oportet, ut sit reductio eius secundum formam suam naturalem in loco suo sibi proprio, si possibile est super illud: quoniam est melius.	When the swelling has been increased and the intestine has entered, then it should be supported, so that there is a reduction of it according to its natural form in its own place, if possible over that: for that is better
Quando uero disruptio est ampla in inferiori parte uentris: tunc oportet ut facias iacere infirmum super dorsum suum, et pone crura sua altiora capite suo.	When however the disruption is wide in the lower part of the belly: then it should be made to lie upon its back, and put its knees higher than its head.
Et si est in superiore parte uentris, tunc pone caput eius, et pectus ipsius altiora quam eius inferiora.	And if it is in the upper part of the belly, then put its head and its chest higher than its lower parts
Et similiter si est disruptio in una duarum partium uentris, tunc pone intentionem tuam, et tuam considerationem semper in hoc, ut pars in qua est uulnus sit altior parte altera.	And in the same way, if there is a disruption in one of the two parts of the belly, then put your intention and your consideration always in this, that the part in which there is a swelling be higher than the other part.
Et ita oportet, ut admimistres illud in uulneribus magnis, et in uulneribus mediis.	And thus it is necessary, that the physicians should consider this in great wounds, and in medium wounds.
In uulneribus autem paruis, pone illud secundum quod praeparatur tibi.	In small wounds, place it according to what is prepared for thee.
Deinde fac ut sit praesens inter manus tuas minister pius, qui teneat disruptionem totam manu sua: et aggrega labia eius.	Then make it so that it be present between thy hands, the minister who holds the whole hand together: and join together its lips.
Deinde detege ex ea ei qui sequitur suturam aliquid post aliquid: et iste est modus suturae communis unius.	Then draw from this that which follows the suture something after something: and this is the way of common suture of one
Et est, ut accipias acum, aut numerum acuum secundum quantitatem amplitudinis uulneris.	And it is, that thou take an awl, or a number of awls according to the quantity of the size of the wound
Deinde dimitte ab extremitate disruptionis quantitatem digiti anularis, id est, medici: et fige acum unam praeter quod intromittas in eam filum in duabus extremitatibuis cutis, cum duabus extremitatibus sifac quod est sub cute ab interioribus, donec facias eam penetrare ab alia parte, et tu iam aggregasti duas extremitates cutis, et duas extremitates sifac: et fiunt quatuor ordines.	Then let go from the extremity of the disruption the quantity of the digit of the ring, that is, the physician: and fix the awl one before which thou intrude into the thread in two extremities of the skin, with two extremities of the fat which is under the skin from the inside, until thou make it penetrate from another part, and thou join together two extremities of the skin, and two extremities of the fat: and there are four orders formed.
Deinde stringe cum filo duplo in circumitu acus aliquotiens a duabus partibus simul, quousque sint aggregata duo labia uulneris aggregatione decenti.	Then string with a double thread around the circumference of the awl several times from two parts simultaneously, until two lips of the wound be aggregated by the gathering of descent.
Deinde dimitte grossitudinem digiti etiam, et fige in eis acum aliam: postea reta eam cum filo, sicut fecisti cum acu prima.	Then let go the length of the digit also, and fix in the flesh another awl: afterwards draw up the thread with the awl, as thou didst with the first awl.
Non ergo cesses facere illud cum eo quo indiges ex acubus, donec compleas constrictionem uulneris totius.	Do not cease doing this until thou hast completed the constriction of the whole wound
Et sint acus mediae inter grossitudinem et subtilitatem: quoniam acus subtiles ualde uelociter incidunt carnem: et grossae sunt difficilis introitus in cutem: propter illud oportet ut sint mediae in subtilitate, et grossitudine.	And the awls be middle between the length and the thickness: because the fine awls slip easily from the flesh: and the thick ones are difficult to enter the skin: for this reason it is necessary that they be middle in thickness, and length
Et non oportet, ut figatur acus in duabus extremitatibus cutis propinquae multum: ut non incidatur caro uelociter, et aperiatur uulnus ante consolidationem sui, et non elongentur etiam cum sutura, ut non prohibeatur uulnus a consolidatione.	Neither must the needle be fixed at either end of the skin in such a way as to pierce the flesh too quickly, for this will open up the wound before it has time to consolidate. Neither must the needle be left too long, even when sutured, for this will prevent the wound from consolidating.
Deinde incide extremitatem acuum, ut non laedant infirmum apud somnum suum: et pone eis puluillos ex pannis ab omni parte, qui teneant extremitates acuum: et dimitte eos, donec scias quod uulnus iam consolidatum est.	Neither must the needle pierce the patient during sleep: and place small plugs of wool around the extremities of the needle, which will hold the needle in place: and remove them when you know that the wound has consolidated.
Et haec quidem species suturae cum acubus taliter est conuenientior in uulneribus paruis.	And thus is the kind of suture which is more suitable for small wounds.
Quoniam sufficit in sutura eorum acus una, aut duae, aut circiter eas.	For in the suture of these wounds, one or two needles or thereabouts are sufficient.
Sutura autem secunda communis est, ut aggreges cum sutura extremitates quatuor: extremitates, duas cutis, et extremitates duas sifac in uice una, cum acu in qua sit filum inuolutum aequale in subtilitate, et grossitudine.	The second kind of suture is common, as it joins together four extremities: two of the skin and two of the fat, with the needle passing through the middle of the thread equal in thickness and width
Deinde quando penetraueris cum acu has extremitates quatuor, reduc acum a parte a qua incaepisti eadem, ut cadat filum retatum a superiori parte uulneris: ut sit sutura, sicut sutura panni quo stringuntur panni, et pone inter omnem suturam quantitatem grossitudinis digiti minoris.	Then when you have pierced through with the needle, reduce the needle from the part from which you began, so that the thread is taut from the upper part of the wound: so that the suture is like the suture of cloth which is used to mend cloth, and put between every suture as much of the thickness of a small finger
Hanc autem suturam sciunt homines.	This kind of suture they know well
Et cum hac sutura ego sui uulnus quod acciderat uiro in uentre suo, qui fuerat uulneratus cum cultello, et erat disruptio uulneris maior palmo uno: et exierat ex intestinis circiter duos palmos ex intestino medio, et erat disruptio in medio uentris.	And when I did this suture to him, his wound which had occurred in his belly, which had been caused by a knife, and which had been burst open with a palm of the hand: and there was a break in the gut about two palms from the middle of the intestine, and there was a break in the middle of the belly.
Reduxi ergo illud postquam stetit intestinum eius extra uulnus xxiiii horis.	I reduced it therefore after I had made the gut outside the wound for twenty-four hours
Consolidatum est ergo uulnus in spacio quod fuit circiter XV dies: et curaui ipsum, et sanatus est: et uixit post illud annis multis, conuersatus in suis dispositionibus.	The limb has been consolidated in a space where it remained for about fifteen days. I cared for it and it has healed: and it has departed after many years, having returned to its normal state.
Et medici iudicauerant, quod non sanaretur.	The physicians had judged that it would not heal
Et ex miraculo fuit, quod non curaui illud cum unguento.	Yet miraculously, it healed without ointment
Quoniam fui in loco in quo non inueniebatur unguentum, neque aliquid ex medicinis.	Because I was in a place where unguentum was not to be found, neither did I use anything from the physicians.
Posui ergo super uulnus cotum uetustum bis in die, et assiduaui ablutionem eius cum aqua mellis, donec sanatum est.	I placed upon the limb a warm compress twice a day, and I diligently washed it with honey-water until it healed
Duas autem species suturae proprias dicam secundum narrationem sermonis.	Two kinds of sutures I shall declare in accordance with the narration of the sermon
Et est, ut incipias cum sutura acuta: et intromittas acum ab exteriori ad interiorem partem.	And it is that you begin with a sharp suture: and you insert the point from the outside towards the inside of the part.
Cum ergo penetrat acus in cutem, et in lacertum euntem secundum longitudinem et latitudinem totius corporis: dimitte extremitatem sifac in latere in quo intromisisti acum, et fac penetrare in extremitatem aliam ab interiori parte ad exteriorem in extremitate altera mirach.	When therefore the needle has penetrated the skin, and in the wound which you have made according to the length and breadth of the whole body: draw out the point in the side in which you inserted the point, and make penetrate from the inside part towards the outside in the opposite extremity
Cum ergo feceris eam penetrare, tunc fac eam penetrare secundum hoc in eadem hac extremitate mirach ab exteriori parte ad interiorem: et dimitte extremitatem sifac, quae est in hoc latere, et fac penetrare acum in extremitatem alteram ab interiori parte ad exteriorem: et fac penetrare cum penetratione tua qua facis eam penetrare in sifac extremitate mirach, quae est in parte eius, donec penetret in ipsum totum.	When you have thus made the needle penetrate, then make it penetrate again following this in the same limb from the outside towards the inside: and draw out the point which is in this side, and make the needle penetrate from the inside part towards the outside in the opposite limb: and draw out the point which is in this side, and make the needle penetrate with the penetration which you are making in the swelling of the limb which is in the part opposite to this one, until it penetrates the whole thing
Deinde incipe etiam ab hoc eodem latere, et sue ipsum cum extremitate, quae est ex sifac in latere alio, et extrahe acum ex cute quam penetrauit.	And begin also from this side and join it with the limb which is from the swelling in the other side, and draw out the point from the skin where it penetrated.
Deinde reduc eam in illam cutem, et sue extremitatem sifac, quae est in latere alio, cum hac extremitate mirach: et extrahe eam ex cute quae est ex parte eius, et fac illud uice una, et alia: et fac illud uice post uicem, usquequo suas extrinsecum totum secundum illud exemplum.	Then reduce the skin to that side, and separate the outer limit which is on the other side, along with this outer limit make a triangle: and extract the skin which is from the part of it, and make it one with the other, and the other make one after the other, until their outer limits are all in accordance with this example.
Et summa huius suturae, est ut suas sutura pellipariorum qua suunt pelles: ita ut suas sifac uice una ex parte una extremitate cutis: et ut dimittas eam uice alia ex parte alia, donec compleas.	And the sum of all these sutures is as the sutures of the skin which are made for the skin: thus as you separate one part from the other extremity of the skin: and as you send one part away from the other part, until you complete them
Secunda species suturae propriae, quam dixit Gale nus.	Second species of sutures, as Gale has said.
Iste eius sermo narratus est, ut suas eam secundum similitudinem, qua suunt eas quidam medicantium, ita quod aggregant omnem partem ad comparem suam conuenientem per naturam: et applicant extremitatem sifac ad eius aliam extremitatem, et extremitatem mirach ad extremitatem eius aliam.	This is the explanation given above: that their sutures are to be like those of certain physicians, who collect every part to the same extent as nature itself: and apply the outer limit to the other outer limit, and the outer limit of the triangle to the other outer limit.
Et illud fit secundum quod narro tibi.	And this is done according to what I have told you.
Oportet ut figas acum in extremitatem mirach propinquam tibi ab exteriori parte, et facias eam penetrare ad interiorem in eo solo: et dimittas duas extremitates sifac.	It is necessary to make the point of the triangle close to the exterior from the inside: and make the skin penetrate to the inside only in this place: and send away the two extremities of the triangle
Deinde reuolue acum, et fac eam penetrare ab exteriori parte ad interiorem in duas extremitates sifac, scilicet utrinque.	Then draw out the point, and make the skin penetrate from the exterior to the inside through two extremities of the triangle, namely on both sides
Deinde reuolue utrasque, etiam fac penetrare utrasque ab interiori usque ad exteriorem, in duas extremitates mirach alias, quae sunt in latere opposito.	Then draw out both of them, and also make them penetrate from the inside to the outside through two other triangles which are on the opposite side.
Et iste modus suturae est melior sutura communi facili, et est sutura cuius praecessit rememoratio.	And this method of suture is better than the common suture, and is a suture whose progress can be remembered.
Iste est ergo sermo Galeni etiam.	This is indeed what Galen has also said
Et dixerunt quidam.	And they said.
Retificatur sutura uentris cum duabus acubus.	The suture within is rectified with two squares.
Quod est, ut intromittas in eis utrisque filum unum: et incipe cum intromissione acus, ex eo quod est apud te, et fac eam penetrare usque ad latus aliud, secundum suturam eorum qui suunt coria aequaliter.	When the suture is inside, it is rectified with two squares. That is, introduce through the flesh on both sides a single thread: and begin with the introduction of the needle from the side towards you, and make it penetrate until it reaches the opposite side, following the suture that is between the tissues equally
Et scias, quod quando disruptio est in medio uentris: tunc sutura eius est difficilior quam reliquorum locorum uentris.	You know that when there is a disruption in the middle of the abdomen: then the suture of that is more difficult than that of the rest of the abdominal cavity
Iudicium uero medicationis uulneris, est iudicium reliquorum uulnerum.	The judgment of the healing of a wound is the judgment of the rest of the wounds.
Quod est, quia quando tu consequeris uulnus recens cum sanguine suo, antequam alteret ipsum aer: et reducis intestinum, et suis ipsum, et aptas ipsum: tunc pone super puluerem incarnatiuum.	When you follow a wound with its blood, before it changes itself with air: reduce the intestine, and hold it in place, and then place above it the powder of burnt incense.
Quod si aer iam alterauit uulnus: tunc pone super ipsum quaedam unguenta, quae sunt tibi praesentia, donec faciant pus: et cadant fila, et consolidentur sifac, et mirach.	When the air has changed the wound: then place above it some unguents, which are for you the presence of these things, until they make pus: and the threads fall out, and solidify the fat, and heal.
Deinde cura illud sicut est curatio reliquorum uulnerum, donec sanetur.	Then care for this as for the care of the rest of the wounds, until it heals
Si autem non sunt tibi praesentes medicinae, tunc pone super ipsum statim, exquo incipit emittere pus, cotum uetus: et permuta ipsum bis in die, sicut docui te, donec sanetur.	But if these things are not present among the medicines, then place above it immediately, from which it begins to emit pus, a moist compress: and change it twice a day, as you have been taught, until it heals
Nam tu non indiges medicatione alia in pluribus dispositionibus, quando uulnera sunt simplicia.	For you do not give any other medicine in many situations when the wounds are simple
Si autem times, quod communicet uulnus membris principalibus in laesione, tunc oportet ut submergas lanam lenem in oleo temperatae caliditatis, aut in oleo rosato: et pone ipsam in circumitu locorum quae sunt inter inguina, et sub ascellas.	If however you fear that the wound communicates with the principal parts in the lesion, then it is necessary that you immerse soft wool in lukewarm oil, or in rose oil: and put it around the circumference of the parts which are between the groin and the armpits
Quod si sentit dolorem, aut punctiones, aut putrefactionem in intestinis suis (nam multotiens accidit illud) tunc clisteriza ipsum cum uino stiptico, nigro, tepido: praecipue si putredo iam peruenit in intestino, et facta est exitura penetrans usque ad concauitatem eius.	If he feels pain, or swelling, or putrefaction in his intestines (for this often happens to him), then let him drink a cluster of wine with black vinegar, warm: especially if the putrefaction has already progressed in the intestine, and an opening has been made through to its cavity.
Et scias, quod illud quod est ex intestino grosso, est facilioris sanationis: et quod ex eis est ex subtili, difficilioris sanationis.	And know that that which is from the great intestine is easier to heal: and that which is from the small intestine is more difficult to heal
Intestinum autem quod nominatur Ieiunum, non suscipit sanationem ex uulnere quod accidit in eo omnino: et illud est propter multitudinem eius, quod est ex uenis, et magnitudine earum, et propter subtilitatem corporis eius, et propinquitatem ipsius naturae neruorum.	The large intestine, however, which is called the Ieiunum, does not suffer healing from a wound that has happened to it throughout: and this is because of its multitude, which is from its veins, and the greatness of its size, and because of the subtlety of its body, and because of its proximity to its own nature of nerves.
Si autem illud quod procedit ex uulnere est zirbum, et consequeris ipsum recens: reduc ipsum secundum reductionem tuam, qua reducis intestina aequaliter.	If, however, the wound proceeds from the intestine, and is a hernia, then follow it up accordingly: reduce it according to your reduction of the intestines equally.
Si uero praeteriit ei spacium, et iam factum est uiride, aut nigrum: tunc oportet ut stringas ipsum cum filo supra locum qui denigratus est ex eo, ut non accidat fluxus sanguinis.	If indeed it has passed beyond that space, and is black, or dark: then it is necessary that you string it with a thread above the place which is degenerated from it, so that the blood does not flow
In zirbo enim sunt uenae et arteriae.	For in the hernia there are veins and arteries.
Deinde incide quod est praeter illud ligamentum, et pone duas extremitates fili pendentes ex inferiori parte uulneris extra ipsum: ut alleuietur super te attractio eius, et extractio ipsius apud casum zirbi, et emissionem pus uulneris.	Then cut through that which is beyond that ligament, and put two hanging threads from the lower part of the wound outside of it: so as to relieve the attraction of that towards the wound, and the evacuation of it at the case of the hernia, and the emission of pus from the wound.
¶ Rememoratio uulneris quod accidit in Intestino.	Remember the wound which has happened in the Intestino.
Quando accidit disruptio in Intestino, et est parua: tunc possibile est, ut restauretur in quibusdam hominibus: propterea, quia ego uidi qui fuit uulneratus in uentre suo cum percussione lanceae, et erat uulnus a dextra stomachi, et antiquatum est uulnus: et factum Fistula, et exiuit ex eo egestio, et uentositas.	When a disruption happens in the Intestino, and it is small: then it is possible, in some people, that it will recover: for I saw that which was wounded in the middle of the stomach with the blow of a lance, and was black: and it had become old: and there was made a fistula, and it went out of itself through egestion, and there was swelling.
Posui ergo curationem, usque quod ego non fui confisus in sanatione eius: neque cessaui subtiliare ipsum, donec sanatus est, et consolidatus est locus.	I remain engaged in treatment until I am relieved from it by the healing of the patient: neither shall I cease until the healing is complete and the locus is firm.
Postquam ego uidi locum iam consolidatum, timui super infirmum, quod accideret super infirmum accidens malum in uentre suo: et non accidit ei ex illo accidens malum.	Once the locus has been solidified, I fear over the patient, for an accident might occur over the patient due to an evil that has happened to him in his body: and it did not happen to him from that evil
Et remansit in melioribus dispositionibus suis, comedens et bibens, et futuens, et intrauit balneum, et exercitatus est in dietis suis.	I remain in better conditions, eating and drinking, hopeful, having bathed, and exercised in my diet.
Et iam dixerunt quidam experimentatorum, quia quando accidit in Intestino uulnus, et est paruum: tunc oportet ut ligetur secundum hunc modum.	And some experimenters have said that when a wound occurs in the intestine and is small: then it is necessary to bind it in this way.
Et est, ut accipias formicas magnorum capitum.	And it is like taking large ants.
Deinde aggrega duo labia uulneris, et pone formicam unam ex eis quae habeant os apertum super duo labia uulneris.	Then join together two lips of the wound and put an ant on one of those which have an open socket over two lips of the wound
Cum ergo capit super ea, et stringit os suum, abscinde caput eius, adhaeret enim, et non soluitur.	When thus the head is above them, and they are bound together, cut off its head, attach it to its companion, and do not break it
Deinde pone formicam aliam prope primam, et non cesses facere illud cum formica post formicam secundum quantitatem uulneris totius.	Then put another ant near the first one, and do not cease doing this until the quantity of the wound is complete
Deinde reduc ipsum, et sue uulnus.	Then reduce it, and its wound.
Illa enim capita remanent annexa in Intestino, donec cibetur Intestinum, et sanetur, et non accidat infirmo nocumentum penitus.	These heads remain annexed to the intestine until the intestine is eaten away, healed, and does not cause pain to the patient
Et iam possibile est, ut ligetur Intestinum etiam cum filo subtili: quod abstersum est ex intestino animalis, annexo cum eo postquam intromittitur in acum.	And it is possible to bind the intestine even with a fine thread: which has been taken from an animal's intestine and is attached to it when it is introduced into the belly
Et est, ut accipias extremitatem huius fili ex intestino, et excarnetur multum.	And it is like taking the end of this thread from the intestine and scraping away a lot of it.
Deinde liga in extremitate eius filum lini subtile inuolutum.	Then the ligature at the extremity is made by passing a fine thread under the tissue.
Deinde intromitte illud filum in acum, et sue cum eo intestinum.	Then insert the thread into the knot, and pass it along with the intestines.</start_of_turn>
Deinde reduc ipsum in disruptionem.	Then tighten the knot.</start_of_turn>
Et iste modus suturae cum formicis et intestino, non est nisi secundum uiam fiduciae et spei.	And thus is the fashion of stitching with needles and intestines, not without trust and hope.</start_of_turn>
Scias, uulnus quod est magnum, amplum, praecipue si est in uno intestinorum gracilium: tunc non est ingenium nisi subtiliatio, neque est eius sanatio omnino.	You know, a large and wide vessel, especially if it is in a narrow intestine: then there is no skill except meticulous handling, and its healing is not at all.</start_of_turn
¶ De cura Zuchemen, et Fistularum.	Concerning the care of ulcers and fistulas.</start_of_turn
Caput LXXXVIII.	Chapter 88.</start_of_turn>
Scias, quod omne uulnus, aut apostema quando ueterascit et antiquatur, et fit ulcus, et non consolidatur, et emittit pus semper, et non abscinditur: tunc nominatur uniuersaliter in quocunque membro fuerit Fistula, et nos nominamus ipsum Zuchemen.	You know that every vessel, or abscess when it grows old and decays, becomes an ulcer, and does not consolidate, and constantly emits pus, and does not burst: then it is called universally in every member 'fistula', and we call it 'Zuchemen'.</start_of_turn
Et Fistula quidem est secundum ueritatem nodatio filtrata, dura, alba: cum qua non est dolor, cui est concauitas pennae auis: et propter illud nominant eam quidam Risati, id est, pennam.	And a fistula is a kind of filter-node, hard, white: which has no pain, with the consistency of a feather from a bird: and for this reason they call some of them 'Risati', that is, feathers.</start_of_turn
Et est in quibusdam horis humida, quae emittit pus.	And sometimes it is in a moist state, which emits pus.</start_of_turn
Et fortasse scinditur humiditas in quibusdam horis.	And perhaps it bursts with moisture in some hours.</start_of_turn
Et quandoque est haec humiditas multa, et est pauca: et est grossa, et est subtilis.	And sometimes it is in great moisture, and little, and is large, and soft.</start_of_turn
Et ego iam praemisi in diuisione, tunc cum dixi uulnera, quod omne ulcus quod non sanatur, neque nascitur in eo caro, non est illud nisi propter unam nouem caussarum.	And I have already spoken in the explanation, that every ulcer which does not heal, neither is born in this body, is not that except for one of these nine causes.</start_of_turn
Quarum una est, aut propter paucitatem sanguinis in corpore: aut propter maliciam eius: aut quoniam inter ipsum, et super labia eius est caro dura, prohibens natiuitatem carnis: aut quia est multae sordis et sordiciei: aut quoniam ulcus in seipso est putridum, et materia quae mittitur ei est malae qualitatis: aut quoniam medicina est inconueniens in curatione eius: aut quoniam corruptio cadens in regione est genus pestilentiae, aut per proprietatem in regione, sicut accidit in Caesaraugusta: in qua fit difficilis digestio aegritudinum, et tardatur in ea sanatio apostematum per naturam: aut quoniam in eo est os unum, aut numerus ossium.	Why one is of such condition, either because of the scarcity of blood in the body: or because of its malice: or because between the inside and outside of the lips there is a hard substance which hinders the birth of flesh: or because there is much pus and slime: or because a wound in itself is putrid, and the matter which comes out of it is of bad quality: or because the medicine is inappropriate for its treatment: or because a corruption falling in the region is a kind of pestilence: or because of a property of the region itself, as happened in Caesaraugusta, in which there is great difficulty in digesting food and the healing of wounds is delayed by nature: or because in it there is only one bone, or a number of bones.
Et ego iam ostendi omnes istas caussas et signa earum, et curationes ipsarum cum medicinis in diuisione: et oportet hic ut faciam te scire curationem Fistulae et Zuken, quae fit per uiam operationis cum manu.	And I have mentioned all these causes and signs and their treatments with the doctors in debate: it is necessary that you write here the treatment of fistula and swelling, which is done by one operation with the hand.</start_of_turn>
Scias ergo, quod Fistula accidit in omnibus membris corporis.	You know therefore that fistula can occur in all parts of the body.</start_of_turn>
Nam ex eis sunt Fistulae quae perueniunt ad uenas magnas et arterias, aut neruos, aut sifac: aut ad intestinum, aut ad uesicam, aut ad aliquam ex costis: aut ad aliquam ex spondilibus dorsi, aut ad aliquam iuncturarum compositarum compositione: sicut manus, et pedis: et ex eis sunt quae uadunt ad propinquitatem membri principalis, et similium.	For from these things are fistulas which arise to great veins and arteries, or nerves, or intestines, or the bladder, or to some of the ribs: or to some of the vertebrae, or to some compound joint: such as the hand, and the foot. And from these things which approach the principal limb and those which are like them.</start_of_turn
Quae ergo ex his Fistulis est secundum hunc modum, est ex aegritudinibus difficilis sanationis, et non recipit curationem, et occupatio cum ea est labor et ignorantia.	What is therefore with these fistulas in this way, is that they are from difficult diseases which do not receive treatment, and which are accompanied by labor and ignorance.</start_of_turn
Quod si est ex Fistulis aliqua cuius profunditas non peruenit ad haec loca quae dixi: et speras, et confidis in curatione eius, et uis peruenire ad cognitionem illius, tunc accipe tentam ex aere, aut ferro, si Fistula tendit secundum rectitudinem, et perquire eam cum ipsa.	If, however, there is some fistula of which the depth does not reach these places which I have mentioned: and if you hope and trust in the treatment of it, and if you wish to be cured of it, then attempt to take air, or iron, if the fistula tends according to its straight line, and inquire about it with the physician.</start_of_turn
Si autem in Fistula est tortuositas, tunc inuestiga eam cum tenta de plumbo subtili.	If, however, in the fistula there is a twisting, then you must investigate the surrounding parts with a fine lead weight.
Quoniam plumbum cum lenitate sui corporis alleuiatur, et curuatur circa tortuositatem.	Since lead is softened by its own body, and is flexible around the twisting
Quod si Fistula est habens orificia multa, non est tibi possibile ut significes super eam cum tenta.	If there are many holes in the fistula, it is not possible to pass a weight over the surrounding area with a hook
Clisteriza ergo ex eis orificium ex orificiis suis.	Therefore close from these holes to the hole of the fistula.
Nam humiditas qua clisterizas ipsum, uadit uersus orificia alia, et currit ex eis.	For the moisture which closes the fistula comes out through other holes.
Deinde exquisite inquire secundum quem modum est tibi possibile: ut cognoscas quod illic est os, aut neruus, et est Fistulae concauitas longinqua, aut propinqua: aut est Fistula una cui sunt orificia multa, et sta super totum illud, cum summa fortitudinis tuae: cum interrogatione tua, qua interrogas infirmum, et inuentione doloris apud compressionem cum manu tua super locum, et similibus ex significationibus et caussis accidentibus apostemati.	Then inquire carefully in what way it is possible: whether it is bone or nerve, or is the fistula long or short: or is the fistula one which has many holes, and lies upon all of this, with the sum of your strength: with your interrogation of the patient, which questions you ask, and the finding of pain in compression with your hand over the place, and similar signs and symptoms following.
Cum ergo steteris super omnia illa statione uera, tunc uade ad curationem secundum confidentiam: et est, ut consideres tunc, si est Fistula propinqua apparens, aut in loco saluo longinquo a iunctura, aut a neruo, aut arteria, aut uena, aut uno locorum quae dixi tibi: tunc seca Fistulam secundum quod praemissum est ex narratione mea, et aufer quod est in ea ex filtratione, et carnibus corruptis, quod nascitur in orificio eius ex carne, aut thelul, et similibus: et cura ipsam, donec sanetur.	When you have stood in all these places truly, then go to the treatment according to your confidence: that is, as you consider, if the fistula is close and apparent, or in a safe place distant from the juncture, or from a nerve, or artery, or vein, or one of these places which I mentioned: then dry the fistula according to what is stated above from my narration, and remove what is in it from the filtration, and rotten flesh, which is born in its hole from flesh, or pus, and similar things: and care for it until it is healed
Si autem Fistula est longinquae profunditatis, et est secundum rectitudinem: tunc oportet ut seces eam in profundo quantum est tibi possibile.	If, however, the fistula is of great depth and is according to the rule: then it is necessary to dissect deeply as much as possible.
Deinde mundifica ipsam ex omnibus carnibus eius corruptis.	Then expose all its rotten flesh.
Deinde administra licinia inuoluta in medicinis acutis: et intromitte ea usque ad concauitatem Fistulae quam comprehendisti cum ferro: fac cum ea illud aliquotiens, donec corrodat medicina acuta totum quod remansit in concauitate Fistulae ex corruptione.	Then administer the lead that has been bound in medicine for acute cases: and introduce it until you have reached the depth of the fistula that you have perceived with the iron: do this in such a way that the acute medicine may corrode the whole of what remains in the depth of the fistula from the corruption.
Deinde restaura ipsam cum unguentis quae generant carnem sanam, donec sanetur.	Then restore the same with poultices which generate healthy flesh, until it is healed.</start_of_turn>
Si uero non sanatur per illud, tunc cauteriza ipsam secundum quod narrauimus.	If indeed it does not heal by this, then cauterize it according to what we have narrated.</start_of_turn>
Si ergo caussa Fistulae est os, et certificatur apud te illud: tunc inquire ipsum, et seca ipsum secundum quod narraui tibi: si non prohibet te aliquid ex uena, aut neruo, aut membro principali, sicut diximus.	If indeed the cause of the fistula is bone, and you suspect that to be the case: then inquire concerning it, and dry it according to what I have told you: if it does not hinder you anything from the bone, or the nerve, or the principal limb, as we have said.</start_of_turn>
Si ergo detegitur tibi os, et est in eo quiddam corruptionis, et nigredinis: tunc rade ipsum, donec auferatur corruptio eius tota.	If indeed it is detected that there is bone, and there is some corruption and blackness in it: then radiate it, until the corruption of it is entirely removed.</start_of_turn
Deinde cura ipsum cum eo quod incarnat ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then care for it with that which nourishes it, until it is healed.</start_of_turn>
Quod si non sanatur, et emittat pus sicut faciebat: tunc scias, quod tu non peruenisti ad totam eradicationem corruptionis.	Which if it does not heal, and discharges pus as it did before: then you know that you have not reached the whole eradication of the corruption.</start_of_turn
Detege ergo super illud secundo, et exquisite fac rasionem eius, et mundificationem ipsius cum ultima fortitudine tua.	Detect therefore above that [the fistula], and inquire concerning its reason, and make a preparation for it with your utmost skill.</start_of_turn
Deinde restaura ipsum.	Then restore it.</start_of_turn
Si ergo sanatur, bonum est: et si non, tunc scias quod illa corruptio est in profunditate longinqua corporis, quam non es consecutus.	If indeed it heals, that is good: and if not, then you know that that corruption is in a profound depth of the body, which you have not been able to overcome.</start_of_turn
Non est ergo tibi in ea ingenium, nisi dimittere ipsam naturae.	It is not indeed in this with cunning, except by sending it back to its natural state.</start_of_turn
Quod si corruptum est os paruum, et est possibile tibi, attrahe ipsum cum forficibus subtilibus quae conueniunt ad illud.	If the small bone is corrupted, and it is possible for you, draw it out with fine forceps which agree with it.
Si autem sunt ossa multa, tunc exquisite fac attractionem eorum omnium, neque dimittas ex eis aliquid cum tua fortitudine.	If there are many bones, then make an exquisite drawing out of them all, and do not leave anything remaining with your forceps
Si uero contrarietatem facit tibi aliquid ex humiditatibus, et non est in incisione eorum timor, uel error: tunc incide illas humiditates et carnes, si sunt illic, et libera ossa.	If, however, there is resistance from moisture in it, and there is no fear of incision, or error: then incisions may be made in those moist parts and the flesh, if there are any, and the bones shall be freed.
Si uero non est tibi praeparatio auferendi ossa ex hora tua, tunc pone super uulnus quod putrefaciat ipsum: et dimitte ipsum, donec putrefiat quod est in circumitu illorum ossium ex carnibus et humiditatibus.	If, however, you are not prepared to extract the bone at this time, then place upon it what will putrefy it: and draw it out when it has putrefied, since it is in the neighbourhood of the bones from the flesh and moisture.
Et custodi uulnus ut non consolidetur.	And keep the bandage so that it does not solidify.
Et constringatur sectio quam tu secuisti in operatione tua.	And let the incision be firm as that which you made in your operation
