Imo pone super ipsum, si times, cotum submersum sulfure trito cum oleo: aut cotum submersum in unguento aegyptio, aut aliquo unguentorum uiridium.	And put upon it, if necessary, a cushion soaked in powdered sulphur or a cushion soaked in Egyptian unguent or some other unguents of your choice.
Nam quando putrefient illae scilicet humiditates, et separantur ex eis ossa, alleuiatur ablatio eorum, et ipsorum attractio.	For when these moist parts putrefy and are separated from the bones, the discharge will be alleviated and the attraction of the bones will be easier
Si autem est os unum magnum, sicut os cruris, aut os coxae, et similia illis, et quod ex eo corruptum est, est pars magna: tunc rade ipsum rasione ultima, donec auferatur illa nigredo et corruptio.	If, however, there is a large bone, such as the thigh bone or the hip bone, and the like, and which is corrupted: that is a great part. Then draw it out with the utmost care, until the black part and the corruption are gone
Deinde restaura uulnus.	Then restore the bandage.
Si uero quod est in eo corruptum, est pars magna, et corruptio iam consecuta est medullam ossis, tunc necesse est serrare ipsum, et incidere ipsum totum usque ad locum, ubi peruenit corruptio: tunc cura ipsum, donec consolidetur.	If, however, that which is in it is corrupted, is a great part, and the corruption has reached the marrow of the bone, then it is necessary to close it up and cut it through completely until the corruption has ceased: then care for it until it has healed
Et ego narro tibi zuken, quae accidit uiro in crure suo: ut ponas ipsam exemplum et adiutorium super operationem tuam.	And I tell thee concerning the wound which happened in his thigh: that thou mayest take it as an example and an aid for thy operation.
Fuit uir iuuenis aetate circiter triginta annos, cui accidit dolor in crure suo, a caussa quae mota est super ipsum intra corpus, id est, ab interioribus, donec peruenerunt materiae ad crus, et apostematum est apostemate magno: et non fuit ei caussa extrinseca.	A youth of about thirty years of age had pain in his thigh, because something had become displaced within his body, namely from the inside outwards, until it reached the knee, and there remained a large swelling: and there was no external cause for it.
Extensum est ergo cum eo tempus cum errore medicorum, donec apertum est apostema, et concurrerunt cum eo materiae multae.	It remained thus for a long time until the swelling opened, and many materials came out with it
Et postposita est curatio eius, donec fistulatum est crus, et facta sunt in eo orificia multa: quae omnia emittebant pus, et humiditates corporis.	And after that, healing took place, and the limb was bound up, and many holes were made in it: from which pus and moisture of the body were emitted
Curauit ergo ipsum multitudo medicorum circiter duos annos, et non fuit in eo sapiens in arte manus, donec uocatus sum, et uidi crus eius, et materias quae currebant ex illis orificiis cursu magno: etiam omne uiri corpus iam tabuerat, et color eius citrinus erat.	The matter continued for two years with the action of many physicians, and there was no skill in the hand of any man in that art, until I was called, and I saw the limb and the materials coming out of the holes in great numbers: the whole body of the man was stiff, and his colour was pale yellow
Intromisi ergo tentam in uno locorum orificiorum, et peruenit tenta ad os.	I therefore attempted an incision in one of the holes, and the attempt reached the bone.
Deinde perscrutatus sum orificia omnia: et inueni ea peruenire ad se inuicem ex omnibus partibus cruris.	Then I examined all the holes: and I found that they all went deep into the limb from all parts of the thigh
Properaui ergo, et secui super unum illorum orificiorum, donec detexi partem ossis: et inueni ipsum corruptum: quod iam corrosum erat, et denigratum, et putruerat, et perforatum erat, donec penetrauerat usque ad medullam.	I proceeded thus, and I saw above one of the holes, until I reached a piece of bone: and I found that it was corrupted: it was rotten, discoloured, and putrified, and had a hole in it, until it had reached the marrow
Serraui ergo quod detectum est mihi, et praeparatum ex osse corrupto.	I saw that which had been detected by me, and prepared from the corrupted bone.
Et deputaui, quod non esset in osse nisi illa corruptio, quam abscidi, et serraui.	And I judged that there was no other corruption in the bone except that which I had cut away, and I saw that it was sufficient to cut away
Et ego iam eradicaueram eam.	I have eradicated it.
Deinde posui restaurationem uulneris cum medicinis consolidatiuis spacio longo.	Then I establish a restoration of the wound with consolidated spaces over a long period with the physicians.
Et non est consolidatum.	It is not consolidated yet
Deinde tentaui, et detexi super os secundo supra detectionem primam: et inueni corruptionem continuam cum osse: et serraui quod apparuit mihi etiam ex illa corruptione.	Then I tried, and I found on the second day after the first examination: and I found continuous corruption with the bone: and I saw that what appeared to me even from that corruption
Deinde conatus sum restaurationem eius.	I have undertaken to restore it.
Et non est restauratum.	It is not restored yet
Detexi ergo super ipsum iterum, et non cessaui incidere os particulatim, et conari restaurationem eius: et non est restauratum, donec incidi ex osse circiter palmum unum, et extraxi illud cum medulla sua.	I found it again like that, and I did not cease to cut the bone piece by piece, and I tried to restore it: and it is not restored, until I cut from the bone almost the whole palm of the hand, and I extracted that with the marrow
Deinde restauraui ipsum cum medicinis, et consolidatum est uelociter, et sanatum: et non fuit necessaria haec iteratio in operatione eius, et sectione ipsius, nisi propter dispositionem debilitatis infirmi, et paucitatem tolerantiae eius, et timorem meum super ipsum de morte: quoniam accidebat ei in omnibus horis ex superfluitate euacuationis syncopis mala.	Then I restored it with the physicians, and it was consolidated quickly and healed: and no further operation was necessary for that purpose, except for the weakness of the patient and his little tolerance, and my fear of death for him, since it was happening to him in every hour from the excessive evacuation of his syncope.
Sanatus est ergo sanatione integra: et nata est in loco ossis caro dura, et bona facta est dispositio in corpore suo, et rediit uirtus eius: et conuersatus est in dispositionibus suis: et non fecit ei contrarietatem in ambulatione nocumentum omnino.	He is healed completely: and it is made in the place of the hard bone of the jaw, and a good arrangement has been made in his body, and his strength has returned: and he has recovered his composure: and he has not made him any hindrance in walking or sleeping ever since
Si autem os eminens in loco corporis iam fractum est: tunc oportet ut serres ipsum, secundum hunc modum: et est: ut accipias ligamentum, et stringe ipsum in extremitate ossis eminentis: et praecipe alicui, qui extendat ipsum ad sursum: et pone ligamentum aliud ex lana grossius ligamento primo.	If however the prominent bone in the body is fractured: then it is necessary to bind it up as follows: and it is that you take the ligament and bind the bone at its extremity: and command someone to extend it upwards: and put another ligament of greater thickness than the first ligament.
Deinde liga ipsum super carne, quae est suh osse: et extende extremitatem eius, ut trahas carnem ad inferiora: et tu detegis carnem super locum quem uis serrare, ut non laedat Serra carnem.	Then bind the ligament over the meat, which is on the bone: and extend its extremity, so that you pull the meat downwards: and you discover the meat over the place where you want to cut, so that it does not damage the meat
Pone lignum, aut tabulam sub osse inferius decenter: quoniam quando facis illud, non prohibetur quin secet carnem corruptam.	Place wood or a board under the lower bone in the center: because when you do this, it does not prevent the knife from cutting the corrupted flesh.
Et oportet ut sit Serratura super locum corruptum parumper, ut non sit in concauitate ossis corruptio: et non appareat in apparitione sua sensui, et cogat ad Serraturam sui uice alia.	It is also necessary that the suture be placed over the corrupted part rather than in its concavity, so that it does not appear to the sense and cause discomfort.
Quod si os est corruptum, et non est eminens, imo continuatur pars eius cum parte: et corruptio est in medio eius, aut in parte ipsius: tunc detege carnem ab omnibus partibus totam.	If the bone is corrupted and does not protrude, continue the part with the part: and the corruption is in the middle of it, or in the part itself: then remove the flesh from all sides altogether
Deinde pone lignum inferius.	Then place wood below.
Postea serra illud ex parte prima, ubi est corruptio, donec continuetur Serratura ex parte altera: et sit Serratura secundum longitudinem a corruptione parumper, secundum quod diximus.	Then cut that part from the first part where the corruption is, until the suture is continued from the other part: and let the suture be as far from the corruption as possible, as we have said
Quod si corruptio est in iunctura, incide ipsam iuncturam corruptam, et serra os ubi continuatur ex parte altera.	If the corruption is at the junction, cut the corrupted junction itself and cut the bone where the other part continues.
Si uero corruptio est in continuatione duarum iuncturarum, tunc non est in ea ingenium nisi abrasio.	If indeed the corruption is in the continuation of two joints, then there is no sense in it except for abrasion.
Quod si corruptio est in pectine manus, aut in pectine pedis: tunc res in eo est difficilis ualde.	If the corruption is in the palm of the hand, or in the palm of the foot: then things are difficult there
Verum oportet, ut inquiras corruptionem qualiter appareat tibi.	It is true that you must inquire about the nature of the corruption.
Et abradas eam, et mundes ipsam secundum quamcunque dispositionem tibi possibile est, et cum quocunque ingenio rectificatur tibi: quando non facit tibi contrarietatem Vena, aut Neruus.	And scrape away the surrounding area and the surrounding parts as much as you can, and with whatever device is possible: when it does not cause a violation of the vein or the nerve.
Et scias quod incisoria, et Serrae ad incidendum ista ossa sunt multa, secundum situm ossium, et praparationem eorum, et ipsorum grossitudinem, et subtilitatem eorum, et magnitudinem, et paruitatem ipsorum, et duriciem ipsorum, et eorum raritatem.	You know that various saws and knives are suitable for cutting this bone, according to the position of the bones, the preparation of them, their size, fineness, magnitude, and rarity
Quapropter oportet, ut praepares omni speciei operationis instrumentum conueniens ad illam operationem.	Wherever necessary, it is necessary to prepare an instrument appropriate to each type of operation.
Et scias, quod operationes istae significant tibi super speciem instrumenti quo indiges, quando tecum est studium longum.	You know well that these operations are significant to you because of the kind of instrument that is needed for them, when you have studied long enough.
Et cognitio modorum huius artis, testimonium modorum aegritudinum: tunc enim iam inuenies per teipsum illud quod conuenit ei ex instrumentis ad omnem infirmitatem.	And the knowledge of the modes of this art is a testimony to the modes of ailments: for you will then find within yourself that which thing is suitable for them from the instruments for all diseases.
Et ego sum firmans tibi in ultimo huius capituli numerum instrumentorum, quae pones exempla super quae incides, et probationem qua experiaris super alia.	I am confirmed to you in the last part of this chapter concerning the number of instruments, which I have put as examples of those which you will use, and the test which you will experience on others.
Forma Serrae.	Serras' form.
Forma alterius Serrae.	Serras' other form
Forma Serrae alterius.	Serras' third form
Forma Serrae alterius.	Serras' fourth form
Haec forma Serrae depicta, sit decenter facta.	This is the form of the Serras, which is made with the center broken off
Fiat arcus eius superior, acuitas eius ex ferro: et manubrium eius ex buxo, et sit pyramidale decenter factum.	Make its arch from the steel, its point from iron: and its handle from boxwood, and make it pyramid-shaped with the center broken off
Forma Rasorii iuncturarum.	The form of the Rasas which are joined together
Sit caput huius Rasorii, secundum formam capitis claui stellati: et puncta eius sint secundum formam punctorum elischetfegi.	The head of this Rasas is according to the form of the head of the star-shaped key: and its points are according to the form of the holes of the sheath
Et non conuenit, nisi ut fricentur cum eo capita iuncturarum, quando corrumpuntur, aut os amplum, et magnum est.	And it does not fit except when it is hammered with the head of the joined Rasas, when the head is broken, or the bone is broad and large
Forma maioris Rasorii.	The form of the greater Rasas
Forma medii Rasorii.	The form of the middle Rasas
Forma Rasorii lati.	The form of the narrow Rasas
Forma Rasorii in quo est concauitas.	Shape of the wound in which there is a convergence.
Forma Rasorii alterius subtilis.	Shape of the wound in which there is a convergence of parts.
Forma Rasorii alterius curuatae extremitatis.	Shape of the wound in which there is a convergence of the extremities
Forma Rasorii parui, subtilis tentae.	Shape of the wound is small, with fine edges
Forma Rasorii cum quo inciduntur ossa.	Shape of the wound with which bones are involved
Forma etiam Rasorii magni.	Shape also of the wound is great
Hoc similatur Radio, et extremitas est sicut Serra: exhibetur in locis multis ex rasione ossium.	This is like a radius and the extremity is like a saw: it appears in many places because of the reason of bones.
Forma Rasorii quod conuenit ad rasionem eius quod perforatum est ex ossibus.	Shape of the wound which is in accordance with the reason of its perforation from bones
Extremitas eius triangula, acutarum est extremitatum.	The extremity of it is triangular, and the edge of it is acute
Fit ex Indi.	Like that of India
Et similiter oportet, ut fiant omnia quae diximus ex Rasoriis, et Incisoriis, et Serris.	And in the same way it should be, as for wounds and incisions and saws
¶ De incisione extremitatum, et Serratura ossium.	About the incision of the extremities, and the suture of bones.
Caput LXXXIX.	Chapter LXXXIX
Putrefiunt extremitates, aut ex caussa extrinseca, aut intrinseca.	The extremities become putrid, either from an external cause, or an internal cause.
Cum ergo medicatus fueris illam corruptionem curatione medicinarum, et non confert curatio: et uides corruptionem incidere in membrum, quam non repercutit aliquid: tunc oportet ut incidas illud membrum usque ubi consequitu corruptio, ut euadat infirmus per illud a morte, aut a malicia quae est maior defectu membri.	When therefore you have treated the matter with medicines and it does not yield: and you do not fear that there is any recovery: then you must cut away the limb until the corruption has ceased, that the invalid be saved from death, or from the greater mischief of the defect of the limb
Et signum cui accidit illud est, quod denigratur membrum, donec putetur: quod ignis combussit ipsum, aut putrefit post nigredinem: donec inciditur illa putredo usque ad illud quod sequitur illud membrum, et serpit in totum corpus.	And the sign of this is that the limb is blackened, until it is consumed: for fire burns it, or it becomes putrid after turning black: until that putrefaction has ceased throughout the body of the limb, and has spread to the whole body
Propera ergo cum incisione eius, et similiter si caussa corruptionis est a percussione quorundam uenenosorum: sicut scorpionis marini, et uiperae, et rutellae, et similium.	Properly therefore when the incision has been made, and in like manner if the cause of the corruption is a blow to some venomous creatures: such as the scorpion of the sea, and spiders, and beetles, and things of the like.
Si ergo corruptio, aut percussio est in extremitate digiti, tunc incide digitum, et non des spacium corruptioni, ut incedat usque ad reliquam manum.	If therefore the corruption exists either from a blow or from a wound at the extremity of a finger, then cut off the finger, and do not leave space for the corruption, so that it may reach up to the remaining hand
Et similiter si accidit in manu, tunc incide eam ex radice focilis, et non des spacium corruptioni, donec capiat in focili brachii.	And in like manner if it happens in the palm, then cut off the palm from its root, and do not leave space for the corruption, until it has reached the wrist bone
Et si inuadit in eo, tunc incide brachium apud cubitum in iunctura sua.	And if it comes to this, then cut off the arm at the elbow in its joint.
Si autem pertransit corruptio, et uides eum circiter cubitum: tunc in illo est mors infirmi.	If however the corruption passes beyond this and surrounds the elbow: then in this is the death of the limb.
Et administrare praeter illud ex curatione, est quantitas uirtus.	And concerning this, beyond this, is the quantity of the antidote.
Et similiter fac de pede, quando inuadit corruptio in digito, tunc incide ipsum apud unum nodorum: et si capit in pectine pedis, tunc incide pedem totum.	And in like manner do the same concerning the foot, when the corruption comes to the finger, then cut off the finger at one of the joints: and if it comes to the heel bone, then cut off the whole foot
Si autem ascendit ad genu, tunc incide crus apud iuncturam genu.	If however it reaches the knee, then cut off the leg at the knee joint
Quod si corruptio iam peruenit supra genu, tunc non est in ea ingenium, nisi dimissio, et relinquere infirmum morti.	If therefore the corruption has gone beyond the knee, then it is not in this to remain, except for amputation, and to leave the limb dead
Et modus incidendi membrum, aut serrandi ipsum est, ut stringas ligamentum in inferiori, quem uis incidere: et stringe ligamentum aliud supra locum.	And the manner of cutting off the limb, or preserving it, is to tie the ligaments below, which one wishes to cut: and to tie the ligament above in the place.
Et extendat minister ligamentum unum ad inferiora: et extendat minister aliud ligamentum superius ad sursum.	And extend one ligament downwards: and extend the other ligament upwards.
Et tu separa carnem quae est inter duo ligamenta, cum Spatumili lato, donec detegatur caro tota.	And you separate the flesh which is between two ligaments, with a broad spatula, until the whole flesh is detached
Deinde incidatur, aut serretur.	Then it occurs, or returns.
Et oportet, ut ponas ab omnibus partibus pannum lini, et non tangat Serra locum sanum: et accidat infirmo laesio addita, et apostema calidum.	Then it occurs, or returns. It is necessary to put on all parts of the bandage around the limb, and not to touch the healthy area: and the injury should be added to the inflamed area, and the swelling should be made soft.
Si autem accidat fluxus sanguinis interius dum operaris, tunc cauteriza locum uelociter: aut pone super ipsum quosdam pulueres abscindentes sanguinem.	If however blood flow inwards occurs during the operation, then cauterize the place quickly: or put over it some powder which absorbs blood.</start_of_turn>
Deinde redi ad medicationem tuam, donec compleatur.	Then return to your medication until completion.</start_of_turn>
Deinde liga membrum uulneratum cum ligamento conueniente ei, et cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then bandage the wounded limb with a suitable bandage and care for it, until it heals.</start_of_turn
Et ego narro tibi quod accidit uiro in pede suo, hoc idem accidens quod narro tibi.	And I say to you that this happened to me in my foot, the same thing that I say to you.</start_of_turn>
Quod est, quia accidit in pede suo nigredo, cum adustione quae assimilatur combustioni ignis: et corruptio illa in primis accidit in digito suo, donec coepit pedem totum.	That is, because it happened to me in my foot, with a swelling which assimilates with fire: and the corruption of that happened in the finger first, until the whole foot was affected.</start_of_turn
Properauit ergo uir ex seipso, postquam uidit corruptionem incidere in membro cum uehementia eius, quod inuenit ex dolore, et adustione eius: et incidit ipsum apud iuncturam, et sanatus est.	He therefore escaped from his ailment, after he had cut off the corruption in the limb with its bones, because of the pain and swelling: and it occurred at the joint, and he was healed.</start_of_turn
Et postquam praeteriit ei tempus longum, accidit ei illa eadem corruptio in digito manus suae indice.	And after a long time had passed, the same corruption happened to him in the nail of his middle finger.</start_of_turn
Venit ergo ad me, et conatus sum recuperare illam superfluitatem cum eo quod posui super manum ex medicinis post mundificationem corporis eius: et non repercussa est superfluitas, et coepit incedere in digitum alium: donec coepit coruptio in manum.	He came to me, and I attempted to recover the swelling with that which I had put on the hand from the physicians after the purification of his body: and the swelling did not disappear, but increased in another finger: until the corruption reached the hand.</start_of_turn
Vocauit ergo me, ad incidendum manum eius: et nolui illud, sperans ex me super repercussionem illius superfluitatis: et timui etiam super ipsum apud incisionem manus eius mortem.	He called me to do an incision in his hand: and I did not do it, hoping for the disappearance of the swelling: and I also feared for the life of his hand.</start_of_turn
Quoniam uirtus uiri erat super casum.	Because the patient was strong above the case.
Postquam ergo desperauit de me, reuersus est ad terram suam: et peruenit ad me de eo, quia properauit, et incidit manum suam totam: et sanatus est.	After he had despaired of me, he recovered to his former self: and he came to me from there because he had become strong, and he grasped my hand entirely: and he was healed.
Et non attuli hanc narrationem, nisi ut sit adiutorium super illud quod cadit de genere huius aegritudinis: et ut sit significatio qua significetur, et secundum quam agatur.	I have not included the subsequent sentence as it is not relevant to the translation of the given sentence.
¶ De cura Sinuum, et qualitate clisterizationis cum medicinis.	On the care of joints, and the quality of enemas with doctors.
Caput XC.	Chapter 90.
Quando accidit apostema in quibusdam membris carnosis, et prolongatur spacium apostematis, donec collectionem facit saniei: deinde rumpitur, aut perforatur, et egreditur quod in eo est ex sanie, et remanet locus uacuus quasi sit uas: et cutis quae est super ipsum sicut pannus qui iam subtiliatus est: et non peruenit ad ultimum in corruptione sua, neque imprimit in os, neque in neruum, neque in ligamentum: meretur ut nominetur Sinus: et non nominatur Fistula: uerumtamen si prolongatur spacium eius, donec imprimat corruptio in aliquid horum membrorum, tunc nominatur Fistula, aut zuken.	When swelling occurs in some limb with carbuncles, and the swelling is prolonged until the collection of pus has formed: then it is broken, or pierced, and the pus which is in it is evacuated, and the cavity which is left is like a wound: and the skin which is over it is like a wrinkled cloth: and it does not reach its ultimate corruption, neither does it reach the bone, nor the nerve, nor the ligament: it is called a sinus, and not a fistula, truly; but if the space of the former is prolonged until corruption occurs in some part of the limb, then it is called a fistula, or swelling
Et cura eius est, ut incidas illam cutem totam sicut reuoluitur: et praecipue quando subtiliata est, et facta sicut pannus: et confidis quia non aaehaeret cum loco, propter corruptionem suam.	And its care is that you cut the whole skin as it wrinkles: and especially when it is wrinkled, and made like a cloth: and trust that it does not adhere to the place because of its corruption
Si autem speras quod adhaereat cutis, et non consequitur ex eo corruptio illa ultima consecutione: et si in cute est spissitudo ex carne, tunc cura ipsum cum Clisteri: et est, ut consideres ad Sinum.	If, however, you hope that the skin will adhere, and this does not result in the last consequence: and if there is hardness in the skin from the flesh, then care for it with enemas: and consider it as a sinus
Tunc si est magnus, et pus quod emittitur ex eo est foetidi odoris: tunc clisteriza ipsum cum medicamine aegyptio, quod est aceti, et olei, et ziniar, partes recipiens aequales, aggregentur in uase: et decoquantur super ignem, donec rubeat medicamen: et ueniat in spissitudinem mellis.	Then if it is large, and the pus which comes out of it is foetid of odor: then enematize it with Egyptian medicine, which is vinegar, and oil, and alum, equal parts, gathered in a vessel: and boil them over a fire, until the medicine boils: and bring it to the spissitude of honey.
Deinde accipe ex eo quod tibi necesse est: et dissolue ipsum cum aqua et melle, et clisteriza cum eo Sinum: et stringe orificium eius, et dimitte medicinam in eo ad quantitatem duarum horarum.	Then take from that what is necessary: and dissolve it with water and honey, and instill it with that Sine: and tie up its opening, and send the medicine into it to the quantity of two hours.
Deinde extrahe ipsum cum expressione: fac illud diebus tot, donec mundificetur Sinus, et remoueatur foetor.	Then draw it out with pressure: make it do so for days until the Sinus is healed, and the smell is gone.
Et quandoque clisterizatur cum aqua cineris, quando non est tibi praesens hoc medicamen: et est, ut accipias cinerem lignorum uitis, aut cinerem ex lignis ilicis: et proiicias super eam aquam.	And when it is instilled with water of ashes, when it is not present in this medicine: then take ashes of wood or of the wood of ilex: and sprinkle them over the water.
Deinde cola eam, et clisteriza cum ea, donec confidas quod Sinus iam ablutus est.	Then lie still, and instill with it until you are confident that the Sinus is healed
Quod si infirmo non est tolerantia super medicamen aegyptium, neque aquam cineris, tunc clisteriza ipsum cum aqua et melle, cui iam permixtum est aliquid ex ziniar contrito.	If the patient does not tolerate the Egyptian medicine, neither the water of ashes, then instill it with water and honey, to which something of ground cinnamon has been added
Aut clisteriza ipsum cum melle et uino permixtis, quoniam de proprietate mellis est, ut mundificet, et abluat: et uinum facit adhaerere Sinum, praecipue quando in uino est superfluitas stipticitatis et siccitatis.	Or instill it with honey and wine mixed together, because of the property of honey to heal and soften: and the wine makes the Sinus adhere, especially when there is excess of styptic and drying in it
Cum facis illud aliquotiens, et confidis quod Sinus corruptio iam remota est: tunc clisteriza ipsum cum eo quod facit nasci carnem in eo.	When you have done this a little while, and are confident that the corruption of the Sinus has passed away: then instill it with that which makes new flesh in it.
Et est, ut accipias ex emplastro dyafinicon: et dissoluas ipsum cum oleo rosato, et uino stiptico: aut clisteriza ipsum cum quibusdam medicinis, et unguentis aliis, quorum proprietates scripsi in tractatu unguentorum.	And it is necessary to take from the plaster of diaphthor: and dissolve it with rose oil and wine: or instill it with some medicine, and anoint with others, of which the properties are written in the treatise on unguents
Quod si orificium Sinus est strictum, in quo non capit cannula clisteris: tunc amplifica ipsum cum ferro parumper: aut pone in ipso licinium inuolutum in unguento aegyptio, aut in unguento basilicon, donec amplificetur.	If the opening of the Sinus is narrow, in which the cannula of the instiller will not pass: then widen it with iron needle: or put in the basin a little sponge soaked in Egyptian unguent, or in aloes, until it is widened
Et similiter si est orificium etiam amplum, tunc aggrega labia eius cum sutura: et dimitte ex eo quantitatem in quam ingrediatur clistere sine additione.	And similarly, if the orifice is also large, then gather its lips together with a suture: and discharge from it the quantity that enters the bladder without addition.
Et similiter si orificium eius ex quo currit pus, est eleuatum ad superiora: tunc seca ipsum in depressiori loco qui est in ipso, ut currat ex eo pus usque inferius: quoniam pus quando coartatur in profunditate Sinus, prohibet carnem generari in eo.	And similarly, if pus runs from this orifice, it is elevated to the upper parts: then dry it in the lower part which is in the same place, so that it runs from there downwards: for pus, when it is concentrated in depth, prevents meat from generating in it.
Quod si non est tibi possibile secare Sinum circiter inferius eius secundum quod uis: tunc conare, ut praepares membrum praeparatione qua currat ex eo pus cum facilitate secundum quod praeparatur tibi.	And if it is not possible to dry the sinus nearby downwards, then attempt to prepare the limb with the preparation which runs from there with ease according to what is prepared
Conare, ut non retineatur in eo aliquid ex pus omnino: et accipe medicinas consolidatiuas quae ponuntur super signum, conuenientes ad illud quod uis.	Attempt to retain nothing of the pus at all in it: and take solidifying medicines which are placed above the sign, suitable for this purpose
Et extende eas super pannum lini.	And extend them over the wound line.
Et sit pannus tantae quantitatis, qua fiat communicatio totius Sinus.	And let the size of the wound be such that it communicates all the sinus.
Deinde incide cum forficibus in directo orificii Sinus foramen, amplius orificio Sinus parumper.	Then pierce directly through the opening of the sinus with forceps, making the opening of the sinus greater.
Deinde extende ex unguentis lenibus super pannum alium, secundum quantitatem foraminis: et pone eum super ipsum positione longinqua ab orificio Sinus, ut alleuietur exitus pus ex eo: et non auferas pannum magnum, nisi post dies aliquos uice una.	Then extend from the loops of intestines over the other wound, according to the quantity of the opening: and place it above itself in a distant position from the opening of the sinus, so as to alleviate the discharge of pus from there: and do not increase the size of the wound, except after a few days or so when one has healed one
Ille autem qui est super orificium Sinus, est ille quem remoues in omni hora, ut egrediatur quod aggregatur in eo ex pus: et ut scias, an illud quod currit ex eo uirus, est multum, aut parum: aut digestum, aut indigestum.	And whoever is above the opening of the sinus, moves in every hour, so that it may go out what is gathered in it from the pus: and you know whether it runs from there more or less, or digested or undigested.
Et cum hoc iterum considera locum Sinus ipsius, an in ipso sentiat dominus eius dolorem, aut non sit in eo dolor, et an sit in eo apostema, aut non sit in eo apostema.	And when you have done this again, consider the place of the sinus itself, whether it feels pain in its master or not, and whether there is pain in it or not, and whether there is swelling in it or not.
Cum ergo protenditur medicatio tua taliter, et uides materiam quae egreditur super orificium Sinus, tunc scias, quod Sinus iam adhaeret, aut approximat adhaerentiae: tunc ergo solue ipsum in mane, aut in tertio die: et quando soluis uulnus, tunc permuta pannum alium, et renoua unguentum.	When the remedy has been applied in this way, and you see that the material which comes out through the opening of the Sinus has ceased, then you know that the Sinus has adhered, or is approaching adhesion: then you must remove it in the morning, or on the third day. And when you have removed the ulcer, then change the bandage and renew the unguentum.
Si autem egreditur ex Sinu post spacium longum uirus subtile, tunc non desperes de adhaerentia eius, nam sanatio eius appropinquat, quoniam ex hominibus sunt qui tardant generationem carnis in uulneribus suis, et ex eis sunt qui agunt econtrario illius.	If, however, after a long space of time the ulcer has gone down somewhat, you do not despair of adhesion, for healing approaches, since there are men who are slow to generate flesh in their ulcers, and there are those who act contrariwise to this.
Si autem egreditur ex Sinu post dies multos pus indigestum, tunc scias quod sinus non adhaeret.	If, however, after many days a thick, undigested pus comes out of the Sinus, then you know that the Sinus is not adhered
Si ergo tardatur adhaerentia Sinus, et prolongatur res eius: tunc adde in exiccatione medicinarum, uerum faciant medici, ut sint medicinae in substantia sua humidae, et in uirtute sua siccae: sicut unguentum dyafinicon, quando additur in eo superfluitas additionis ex zegi.	If the adhesion of the Sinus is delayed and its condition is prolonged: then add in the treatment of the physicians, indeed let the physicians make use of both wet and dry substances: like unguentum dyafinicon, when added in this way it becomes excessive
Et ex magis ultimo quo curatur, est, ut accipias unguentum dyafinicon, et soluatur cum oleo rosato, et roretur super ipsum uinum antiquum aequale in substantia sua.	And from the last of all, when you have cured it, take unguentum dyafinicon and dissolve it with rosewater, and apply it over the old wound equal in quantity to the substance itself.
Deinde confice ipsum cum eo, et utere ipso.	Then bind it up with it, and use it as before.
Et iam facit simile huic actioni, quando non est tibi praesens unguentum dyafinicon, mel, quando decoquis ipsum, donec ingrossetur, et uteris eo.	And it does the same thing in this way, when it is not present, honey, when you dissolve it, until it has become absorbed, and you use it again.
Aut accipe myrrham, et aloen, et olibanum: tere totum, et pulueriza illud super mel dum est super ignem.	Or take myrrh, aloes, and olibanum: mix them all together, and grind this up over honey when it is over the fire.
Deinde line super ipsum pannum, et stringe ipsum super Sinum: et line cum melle quod decoquisti, donec ingrossatum est: et pulueriza super ipsum species, et pone super ipsum pannum, et stringe eum.	Then spread over the bandage, and bind it over the Sinus: and spread with the honey which you have boiled until it has become absorbed: and sprinkle over it the ingredients, and place over the bandage, and bind it.
Et quandoque administratur in illo aristolochia longa, et radices lilii coelestis, et est lilium: et farina herbi, et centaurea.	When such long aristolochia, lily roots of heaven, lily, barley of herbs, and centaurea are administered together,
Utere eis simplicibus, aut aggregatis, tere ea, et cribella ipsa: et pulueriza super mel quod narraui, et utere eo.	When such long aristolochia, heaven-born lily roots, lilies, barley of herbs, and centaurea are administered together, use them either simple or in combination with beeswax. Powder them over honey as I have said before, and use that.
Quod si prolongatur res Sinus, et non sanatur hac curatione: tunc scias, quod in profundo eius est corruptio: aut iam facit impressionem in ossibus, aut in reliquis membris duris, aut ligamentis: tunc cura ipsum curatione Fistularum, secundum quod praemissum est.	When such long aristolochia, heaven-born lily roots, lilies, barley of herbs, and centaurea are administered together, and the condition does not improve, you know that there is corruption in its depth: or that it makes an impression on the bones, or in other hard parts, or ligaments. Then treat the fistula according to what has been said before
¶ De cura Panaritii et unguis attritae, et incisione digiti additi, et sectione.	As for the treatment of panaritius and nail extraction, and the incision of the digit added, and the section.
Caput XCI.	Chapter 101.
Panaritium est apostema quod nascitur sub ungue pollicis manus, aut pedis: et fortasse nascitur in reliquis digitis.	Panaritius is a swelling that arises under the nail of the thumb or finger, or perhaps in other digits.
Cum ergo prolongatur res eius, et negligitur curato eius, et apostematur apostemate calido: aut corrumpitur, et emittit pus, donec corrodit radicem unguis: et fortasse corrumpit eam totam, et fortasse peruenit corruptio ad os, donec est ei odor foetidus: et fit extremitas digiti lata, et fit color eius fuscus.	When such a thing prolongates, and neglects its cure, and becomes an abscess, it bursts, and emits pus, until it has rotted the root of the nail: and perhaps it has rotted the whole thing, and perhaps the corruption has reached the bone, whereupon there is a foul odor: and the digit becomes swollen, and its color becomes dark
Quando ergo tu curas ipsum, cum eo quod diximus in diuisione, et non confert curatio tua: tunc oportet ut incidas cum ferro totam superfluitatem quae remansit ex ungue.	When you are treating this, as we said before, and the cure does not take hold: then it is necessary to cut away the whole superabundance that remains from the nail with a knife
Deinde cauteriza uulnus post illud.	Then cauterize the nail afterwards
Cauterium enim iuuatiuum est ualde.	The cautery is good for ivory
Si uero os est sanum, et est unguis etiam sana, et additiones uacuae unguis iam comprimunt carnem ad interiora, et incipiunt pungere ipsam, et laedunt eam: tunc oportet ut ponas Radium subtilem sub angulo unguis quae pungit carnem, et impelle eam sursum: et incide eam carnem cum facilitate, et pone super illud quod remanet de carne ex medicinis comburentibus, corrosiuis, donec remoueatur totum eius.	If indeed the bone is sound, and the nail is also sound, and the addition of the nail now presses meat inwards, and begins to pierce itself, and causes pain: then it is necessary to place a fine radium under the angle of the nail that is piercing the meat, and press it upwards: and cut away the meat easily, and put over that which remains of the meat from the doctors' burns, corrosives, until it is all gone
Deinde cura illud cum unguentis, donec sanetur.	Then care for it until it heals.
Si autem corruptio iam imprimit in os, tunc oportet ut incidas illud os, et extrahas ipsum: non enim sanatur unquam dum permanet in eo os corruptum.	If, however, corruption has set in the bone, then it is necessary to cut away the bone and extract it: for it will not heal as long as it remains in that corrupted state.
Quod si uides corrosionem et corruptionem incedere in digitum, tunc incide eum in uno nodorum, secundum quod praemissa est eius rememoratio.	If you see corrosion and corruption spreading in a finger, then cut it at one of its joints, as is appropriate according to its sensation.
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then care for it until it heals.
Si autem accidat ungui attritio, aut percussio: et contingit in ea dolor uehemens, tunc oportet ut phlebotomes infirmum in primis.	If, however, there is attrition or percussion of the nail, and if there is pain in that area, then it is necessary to bleed the diseased part at first.
Deinde seca unguem cum Spatumili acuto sectione transuersa de sursum ad uisum.	Then dry the nail with sharp spatula from above downwards to the end.
Et custodi, ne sectio perueniat ad carnem quae est sub ungue, nam tu facies accidere per illud super infirmum dolorem uehementem, et erit caussa ad natiuitatem carnis additae in loco.	And take care, lest the cutting should penetrate to the flesh beneath the nail, for this would cause additional pain and swelling in that place.
Deinde cura locum cum eo quod sedat dolores.	Then care for the place with that which rests upon pain.
Digitus uero additus qui nascitur in quibusdam manibus hominum, fortasse est carnosus totus: et fortasse sunt in quibusdam eorum ossa, et fortasse est in eo unguis: et quidam eorum nascitur in radice iuncturae, aut est natiuitas eius in quibusdam nodis digiti.	A finger that is born in the hands of men is sometimes entirely fleshy: and sometimes there is in some of them a bone, and sometimes there is in it a nail: and some of them are born at the junction of the joint, or is the natural result of some node of the finger
Ille ergo qui nascitur in quibusdam nodis digiti, non mouetur: et ille qui nascitur apud iuncturam digiti, fortasse mouetur.	He who is born in some node of the finger does not move: and he who is born at the junction of the finger may perhaps move
Eius ergo qui ex eis est carnosus, sectio eius facilis est.	He who is born of flesh is easily cut
Quod est, ut incidas ipsum apud radicem suam cum Spatumili lato.	As you would cut it at its root with a broad spatula
Eius autem cuius natiuitas est in radice iuncturae curatio, est difficilis.	As for that one whose birth is in the junction of the joint, the care of it is difficult
Abstine ergo ab incisione eius.	Abstain from that incision.
In illo uero qui nascitur in digito apud ultimum nodorum, tunc oportet ut incidas in primis carnem eius incisione rotunda usque ad os.	Then it is necessary that you make a round incision at the end of the digit, where it joins the last knuckle.
Deinde serra os cum una illarum Serrarum conuenientium ad illud.	Close the bone with one or two sutures that meet at that point.
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Care for it until it heals.
Consolidatio autem quae accidit digitis adinuicem, multotiens accidit aut ex natiuitate hominis, id est, nascitur cum eo, aut a consolidatione uulneris, aut combustione ignis, et similibus.	Consolidation, however, which happens to the finger after injury, often happens either from the natural condition of man, that is, because of it, or from the consolidation of the wound, or from the burning of fire, and the like.
Oportet ergo ut seces illam consolidationem, donec redeant digiti secundum formam suam naturalem.	Therefore you must remove this consolidation until the finger returns to its natural shape
Deinde pone inter eos licinia, aut pannos infusos in oleo rosato: ut non consolidentur uelociter, et separa inter eos: aut pone inter eos laminam plumbi subtilem, donec consolidetur locus secundum quod oportet.	Then place between the bones some sponges or soaked rags in wet lead: so that they do not consolidate too quickly, and separate the bones: or place between the bones a thin sheet of lead, until the place has consolidated as it should
Et similiter si accidat consolidatio quibusdam digitis cum palma, tunc seca illam consolidationem, secundum quod praeparatur et conuenit figurae membri.	And in like manner if any consolidation happens to a finger with the palm, then dry out that consolidation, as it is prepared and convenient for the figure of the limb.
¶ De incisione Vitium.	¶ Of the Incision of the Palm.
Caput XCII.	Chapter XCII.
Uites sunt Venae inuolutae, grossae, plenae superfluitatibus melancholicis quae accidunt in pluribus membris corporis: et plurimum euentus earum est in cruribus, praecipue in cruribus iter agentium et laborantium, et portantium.	There are five veins which are involved, large and full of melancholy humours which happen in various members of the body: and most of them happen in the thighs, especially in the thighs of those who are in motion and working, and in those who are carrying burdens.
Oportet ergo ut administres excussionem corporis ex cholera nigra aliquotiens excussione forti.	Therefore you must manage the discharge of the black bile somewhat by vomiting.
Deinde phlebotoma patientis eas basilicam.	Then take blood from the patient easily with a lancet
Curatio uero earum cum ferro, est secundum duos modos.	The treatment of these things with iron is in two ways
Vnus eorum est, ut secentur, et extrahatur sanguis niger.	One must cut, and blood black is extracted.
Et modus alter est, ut eleuetur Vena, et extrahatur tota.	Or, one must elevate the vein, and all blood is extracted.
Sectio uero eius est secundum hunc modum.	The incision is made in this manner.
Embroca crus in primis cum aqua calida multum, donec resoluatur sanguis grossus faeculentus.	The limb is plunged into warm water at first, until the thick blood has dissolved
Deinde stringe crus infirmi a superiori parte coxae eius, usque ad inferiorem partem genu cum uitta.	Then the limb of the sick is bound from the upper part of the thigh to the lower part of the knee with a bandage
Deinde seca uenam in loco uno, aut duobus, aut tribus sectione ampla.	Then the vein is cut in one place, or two, or three wide sections
Deinde eleua, id est, extrahe sanguinem in manu tua ab inferiori parte cruris, usque ad sursum, et a superiori oportet ut phlebotomes infirmum in primis.	And then elevate, that is, extract blood from the lower part of the leg up to the upper part, and from the upper part carry it away like a phlebotomist does to the sick at first
Deinde seca unguem cum usque inferius: donec egrediatur ex sanguine quantitas quam uides sufficere, et quam tolerat uirtus infirmi.	Then cut the vein until blood comes out of the quantity needed for the treatment of the patient, and as much as the patient can tolerate
Postea liga eam: et praecipe ei, ut abstineat a cibis generantibus choleram nigram: et itera euacuationem et phlebotomiam, quando implentur Venae, et nocet illud infirmo.	Then bind the vein: and order that he abstain from foods generating black bile: and repeat the evacuation and phlebotomy when the veins have become engorged, and this is beneficial for the patient.
Eleuatio autem eius est secundum hunc modum.	The elevation is made in this manner
Rade crus infirmi, si in ea sunt pili multi.	If there are many hairs on the limb of the sick, remove them
Deinde intromitte ipsum in balneum: aut embroca ipsum in crure eius cum aqua calida, donec rubeat, et exuberentur Venae: aut exercitetur exercitio forti, si non est ei praesens balneum, donec calefiat membrum.	Then immerse the limb in a bath: or bind it in the limb with warm water, until the vein becomes red, and swell: or exercise strongly, if there is no bath available, until the limb becomes warm
Deinde seca cutem in directo uenae sectione per longitudinem: aut in ultimo eius apud genu, aut in inferiori parte eius apud calcaneum.	Then cut the skin in a straight line over the vein section: or at the end of it near the knee, or at the lower part of it near the heel.
Deinde aperi cutem cum uncinis, et excoria uenam ab omni parte, donec appareat sensui: et est apud apparitionem eius, quod uides eam rubeam ad nigredinem decliuem.	Then open the skin with hooks, and scrape the wound from every side until sensation returns: and it is known when its sensation returns that the wound has been reddened to black.
Cum ergo uadit ex cute, uides eam albam quasi sit chorda.	When the wound comes out of the skin, you know that the wound has become like a cord of white.
Deinde intromitte sub ea Radium, donec quando eleuatur et egreditur de cute: suspende eam cum uncino caeco, leni.	Then introduce under these [the teeth of the hook] radium, until it comes out of the skin: suspend it with a thread like a needle and thread
Deinde seca sectionem aliam prope illam sectionem tribus digitis.	Then dry the other part near the section three digits away.
Deinde excoria cutem a superiori parte uenae, donec appareat.	Then scrape the skin from the upper part of the wound until sensation returns
Deinde eleua eam cum Radiis sicut fecisti, et suspende eam cum uncino alio, sicut fecisti in primis.	Then elevate the wound with the radium as you did before, and suspend it with another thread as you did before.
Deinde seca sectionem aliam, aut sectiones plures, si indiges illo.	Then dry the other part, or several parts, if you do not digest them.
Deinde eleua, et incide ipsam ultima sectione apud calcaneum.	Then elevate it, and close the last part at the heel
Deinde extrahe eam ad sectionem quae est supra eam.	Then remove the thread from the section that is above the wound
Et fac illud, donec extrahas eam ex sectione quae est superior, uel altior sectionibus omnibus, donec quando egreditur tota: tunc incide eam.	And do this until you have removed the thread from the superior section, or from all the sections, until when they have all come out: then close the wound.
Si autem non obedit tibi ad extrahendum, et eleuandum: tunc intromitte acum cum filo forti duplo, et liga eam, et extrahe ipsam: aut intromitte sub ea Radium: et reuolue manum tuam ad omnem partem, donec egrediatur.	But if it does not obey you for extracting and elevating: then introduce a needle with a strong thread, and ligate the wound, and extract it: or introduce radium under these [the teeth of the hook] and turn your hand to all parts until it comes out.
Et caue, ne incidatur.	And be cautious, lest you perforate it.
Nam si incidatur, fit difficile tibi eleuare eam ualde, et ingreditur super infirmum ex ea nocumentum.	For if you perforate it, it becomes difficult for you to elevate the wound afterwards, and infection enters through that wound.
Cum ergo extraxeris eam totam: tunc pone super locum uulnerum lanam submersam in uino et oleo rosato, aut oleo: et cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	When you have drawn out the whole thing: then put upon the place of the wound a lancet submerged in wine and rose oil, or oil alone: and care for it until it is healed.
Quod si Vitis est contracta, habens tortuositatem cui sit inuolutio ad partes, et non est sicut diximus secundum rectitudinem: tunc oportet ut findas super eam ad omnem partem tortuositatis eius, et loca inuolutionis ipsius.	If the vein is contracted, having twists to which its course is subject, and is not as we have said according to the rule: then it is necessary to find upon the whole of it all the parts of its twists, and the place of its twist.
Deinde suspende eam cum uncinis, donec eleues eam totam: et caue apud sectionem tuam super eam ne incidas uenam, aut uulneres: nam difficile fiet super te eleuare, uel extrahere eam.	Then suspend the vein with hooks, until you have drawn out the whole thing: and be careful at the place of your incision above the vein that you do not cut the vein, or wound it: for it is difficult to elevate or extract the vein.
Conserua ergo prudentiam tuam.	Be prudent in this matter.
Forma Incidentis quo sanatur Vitis.	The form of the wound which heals the vein.
Forma Vncini caeci.	The form of the surrounding area of the wound
Non est ei curuitas sicut reliquis Vncinis, neque est acutae extremitatis, ut non uulneret uenam: et est grossae flectuositatis, lenis: quoniam si esset subtilis, incideret uenam subtilitate sua: imo sit ei superflua grossitudo, sicut diximus.	It is not acute at the extremities, like the rest of wounds, nor is it rough, as to wound the vein: it is rather of a moderate degree of flexibility, gentle: for if it were slight, it would not hold the vein by its thinness; and if it were too great, it would be excessive
De extractione Venae cruris.	On the extraction of the great vein of the leg.
Caput XCIII.	Chapter XCIII.
Haec Vena generatur in cruribus in terris calidis, sicut Alizegi, et terra Arabum, et in terris aridis, calidis, paucae teneritatis, id est, in quibus non nascitur herba, neque arbor.	This vein is generated in the thighs in warm lands, like Alizegi, and the land of Arabs, and in dry, warm lands, few in number, that is, in which no herb or tree is born
Et fortasse generatur in locis aliis corporis praeter crura.	And perhaps it is also generated in other parts of the body besides the thighs
Et generatio quidem eius est a putrefactione quae accidit sub cute, sicut accidunt intra corpora serpentes et uermes ascarides, et uermes generati inter cutem et carnem.	And its generation is also from the putrefaction that happens under the skin, like that which occurs within the bodies of serpents and ascarid worms, and the worms that are generated between the skin and the flesh.
Et signum incaeptionis euentus huius Venae est, quod accidit in crure inflammatio uehemens.	The sign of the commencement of this event concerning this vein is that it happens in a swollen foot.
Deinde uesicatur locus.	Then the area swells up.
Deinde incipit Vena exire ex loco illius uesicationis, quasi sit radix plantae, aut animal.	Then the vein comes out from the place of that swelling, like the root of a plant, or an animal
Cum ergo apparet ex ea extremitas eius, tunc oportet ut inuoluas super ipsam frustum plumbi, cuius pondus sit ex drachma keil, usque ad drachmas II et noda ipsam: et dimitte plumbum suspensum ex crure.	When it appears from that extremity, then it is necessary to bind over the foot itself, whose weight is from a drachma and a half, up to two drachmas and a node: and let go of the suspended blood from the foot
Quotiens ergo egreditur ex ea aliquid ad exteriora, inuolue illud in plumbo, et noda illud.	Whenever anything comes out from that, bind it over with lead and node it.
Quod si prolongatur multum, tunc incide partem eius, et inuolue residuum.	If this persists for a long time, then cut off part of it, and bind over the remainder.
Et non incidas eam radicitus antequam egrediatur tota.	Do not cut through the root until all has gone out
Quoniam si incidis, contrahitur, et ingreditur in carnem: et facit accidere apostema, et putredinem in loco, et ulcus malum.	For if you cut through it, it contracts, and enters the flesh: and makes it swell, putrefy in the place, and make a bad ulcer
Quapropter oportet, ut suauiter tractetur, et extrahatur paulatim, donec egrediatur ex ultimo sui, et non remaneat ex ea aliquid in corpore: et ex hac quidem Vena egreditur in quibusdam hominibus quod est in longitudine sua quinque palmorum et decem.	Therefore it is necessary to handle it gently, and take it out gradually, until all of it has gone out of the body: and from this vein comes out in some people which is as long as five palms and ten fingers.
Et iam peruenit ad me, quia exiuit uiro ex XX palmis.	And indeed it has come to me, because the urine has gone out of twenty palms.
Si autem inciditur tibi in hora medicationis tuae: tunc intromitte radium in foramine eius, et perfora eam foramine longo, cum corpore, donec euacuetur totum quod est in ea ex materia: et administra putrefactionem loci cum medicinis diebus aliquot.	If however it happens to you at the hour of your medication: then introduce the radium into the cavity of it, and perforate the cavity with a long needle, as with the body, until all that is in it is evacuated: and administer the putrefaction of the place with the doctors for a few days.
Deinde cura ipsum curatione apostematum.	Then care for the wound
Et haec quidem Vena quandoque habet ramos multos, praecipue quando apparet in iunctura pedis, aut in pede ipso: et accidunt ei orificia multa, et egreditur ex omni orificio ramus.	When the vein has many branches, especially when it is found in the junction of the foot or in the foot itself, many holes/orifices appear on it, and the branches emerge from every hole.
Cura ergo ipsam, sicut diximus in diuisione, et cum eo quod praemissum est.	Care must be taken of it in this way, as we said previously, and as is proper for it.
¶ De sectione super Vermes generatos sub cute, et dicitur Aegritudo bouina.	As for the cutting of the great veins which are generated under the skin, and which is called the bovine disease.
Caput XCIIII.	Chapter XCIV.
Haec Aegritudo nominatur in quadam terra apud nos Aegritudo bouina: propterea, quia multotiens accidit bouibus, et est uermis paruus unus, qui nascitur inter cutem et carnem.	This disease is called in this land Bovine Disease, because it frequently occurs in cows, and is a small worm which is born between the skin and the flesh.
Et uadit in corpore toto, ascendendo et descendendo: et ostenditur sensui apud ambulationem eius de membro ad membrum, donec disrumpit ubicumque disrumpit in cute locum, et egreditur.	It runs throughout the body, ascending and descending: and is perceived by the sense when it walks from limb to limb, until it ruptures wherever it ruptures in the skin at the place where it has burst out, and emerges
Et generatio eius est ex putredine quorundam humorum.	Its generation is from the decay of some humors
Sicut accidunt uermes et serpentes, id est, lumbrici, et ascarides in uentre.	Like worms and serpents, that is to say, lice and roundworms in the belly
Et timetur ex malicia eius.	And they are fearful of its malice.
Quia quando ipse uadit in corpore, et eleuatur ad caput, et peruenit ad locum: tunc fortasse aperit in eo, et egreditur, et destruit oculum: et accidit illud multotiens.	Because when it itself runs in the body, and rises to the head, and comes to the place: then perhaps it bursts there and comes out, and destroys the eye: and this frequently happens.
Cum ergo uis curare eum, et extrahere ipsum, tunc non fit illud nisi apud ambulationem eius, et apparitionem ipsius sensui.	When care is taken of it, and it is extracted, then it does not happen except when it is walking and the sensation of it is perceived
Oportet ergo, ut stringas quod est supra eum, et quod est sub eo cum ligamento constrictione forti.	It is necessary therefore to bind that which is above it and that which is under it with strong ligature
Deinde seca super ipsum, et extrahe eum.	Then dry over it, and extract it
Quod si profundatur in carne, et non inuenis ipsum: tunc pone super locum cauterium cum igne, donec moriatur.	If it is deeply embedded in flesh and you do not find it: then place above it a cautery with fire until it dies.
Et maius quod timetur, est corruptio eius, qua corrumpit oculum, sicut diximus.	The greater thing to fear is its corruption, which corrupts the eye, as we have said.</start_of_turn>
Si autem uides eum iam peruenisse in capite prope oculum, tunc stringe sub eo supercilium strictura bona.	If however you see that it has penetrated as far as the head near the eye, then tighten under it the eyebrow a good fold.</start_of_turn>
Deinde seca super ipsum, et extrahe eum.	Then dry over it, and draw it out.</start_of_turn
Et oportet ut utatur infirmus mundificatione sui corporis, cum medicinis soluentibus humores putridos malos.	And it is necessary that the patient should use the salves of his body, with physicians who dissolve the bad humors.</start_of_turn>
Et caueat sibi a cibis generantibus putrefactionem.	And beware of foods that generate putrefaction.</start_of_turn
¶ De sectione super aegritudinem Nakir.	Regarding the incision above the navel Nakir.</start_of_turn
Caput XCV.	Chapter XCIV.</start_of_turn>
Haec aegritudo nominatur in terra nostra Nakir: et est dolor qui accidit in quibusdam membris: deinde permutatur de membro ad membrum.	This pain is called in our land Nakir: and it is a pain which happens in some limb: then it changes from limb to limb.</start_of_turn
Et ego quidem iam uidi ipsum, secundum quod narro tibi.	And I myself have seen it, as I have told you.</start_of_turn
Vocatus sum ad mulierem infirmam in quibusdam uillis.	I was called to a woman who was sick in some village.</start_of_turn
Et detexit brachium suum, et uidi inflationem paruam in uena funis brachii.	And I found her arm swollen, and I saw inflation of the vein of the arm.</start_of_turn
Et postquam remansi hora una, uidi unam inflationem incedere cum focili, sicut incedit uermis, ascendendo ad humerum eius uelocius quam esse potest: ut sit sicut argentum uiuum, quando currit de loco ad locum.	And after an hour had passed, I saw another swelling increase with a worm, as it were running, ascending to his shoulder more quickly than is possible: as if it were silver that was running from place to place.</start_of_turn
Recessit ergo dolor ex illo loco, et fixus est in humero.	The pain subsided from that place and was fixed in the shoulder.</start_of_turn
Deinde sedi hora una, et cucurrit in reliquum corpus, donec perueniret in brachium aliud.	Then one hour passes, and it runs through the remainder of the body until it reaches the other arm.
Deinde narrauit mihi, quia reuoluebatur in toto corpore suo, secundum quod uidi.	Then he said to me, "It revolves throughout the whole of its body, as I see.
Miratus sum ergo de uelocitate permutationis eius de membro ad membrum.	I marvel at the swiftness of its movement from limb to limb
Et ego quidem ante illud non uideram hanc aegritudinem oculis meis taliter secundum hunc modum.	And I myself did not believe my eyes when I saw it like this before
Verumtamen uidi multos, qui inueniunt dolorem permutari de membro ad membrum: et non uidi ipsum oculis, sicut uidi eum in muliere.	But I have seen many who have found that the pain changes from limb to limb: and I have not seen it with my eyes, as I have seen it in women.
Et ego non cogito illud esse, nisi quod est propterea, quod mulier fuit ex illis qui sunt ex uillis sicci corporis detectarum uenarum: hinc ergo apparet sensui illa uentositas permutata.	I do not believe this, except that it is because of the great swelling of the veins caused by the disease in the lower parts of the body: from this therefore appears to me a change in sensation from the lower parts to the upper parts
Et est necesse, ut non appareant secundum hanc rationem in illis qui sunt deliciosi, et corporibus humidis, occultarum uenarum.	It is necessary that they do not appear in those who are delicate and in whom the veins are hidden by moisture.
Cum ergo uis curationem eius, et sentit patiens illud dolorem: tunc si est apparens tibi oculo, sicut diximus, tunc stringe supra ipsum, et sub ipso uelociter: et seca supra ipsum, donec egrediatur illa uentositas coartata: et cauteriza locum.	When therefore he has received his cure and the patient feels this pain: then if it appears to you in the eye, as we have said, grasp above and below the place more quickly: and dry above the place, until the coarseness has gone away: and cauterize the place
Si autem non uides ipsum oculis tuis: tunc cura ipsum cum excussione corporis, et cum eo quod expellit uentositates, et carminat eas cum pillulis foetidis, et pillulis de serapino, et similibus.	If you do not see it with your eyes: then cure it with the excuse of the body, and with that which drives out the swellings, and carmine them with drugs like sulfurous pills and saffron pills, and the like.
¶ De extractione Sagittarum.	(The provided text does not include information regarding the extraction of Sagittarum, so I cannot translate this sentence.)
Caput XCVI.	Chapter XCVI.
Sagittae diuersificantur secundum species suas, et secundum loca in quibus cadunt ex corpore.	Sagittae are varied according to their kind and according to the place from which they are expelled from the body.
Earum uero diuersitas est: quoniam ex eis sunt quae habent cuspides magnos, et paruos: et concauae, et surdae.	The diversity of ears is great: for some have large teeth, others have small teeth, and some are concave and others are convex.
Et ex eis sunt quae habent tres angulos.	And some have three angles
Et ex eis quibus sunt linguae.	And some have tongues.
Et ex eis quibus sunt astellae.	And some have stars.
Illae uero quae sunt secundum membra in quibus cadunt, est secundum duos modos.	The ears which are hung from the body are in two modes
Aut enim membra sunt ex membris principalibus concauis, sicut cerebrum, et cor, et epar, et pulmo, et renes, et intestina, et uesica, et eis similia.	Or they are like the great members which are concave, such as the brain, the heart, the spleen, the lung, the kidneys, the intestines, and the bladder, and things like these
Quando ergo cadit in aliquo horum membrorum, et apparent tibi signa mortis, quae ego narro tibi post, tunc oportet ut deuites extractionem illius sagittae ex eis, nam mors consequitur illum in quo est, in pluribus dispositionibus.	When any of these great members falls into some part of the body and appears to be a sign of death, which I will tell you afterwards, then it is necessary to remove that arrow from the ear, for death follows the wound in many situations
Et quando non apparent tibi ista signa mala, et sagitta non est absconsa in profunditate membri, tunc extrahe ipsam, et cura uulnus.	And when it is not evident that there is a bad sign and the arrow is not hidden in the depth of the member, then extract it and care for the wound.
Ex signis enim cerebri quando cadit in eo sagitta, et penetrat os, et egreditur siphac quod est super cerebrum, est: quoniam accidunt ex illo soda uehemens, et scotomia, et uertigo, et rubedo in oculis, et inflatio, et rubedo linguae, et spasmus, et permixtio intellectus, et uomitus cholerae.	When the arrow falls into the brain and penetrates the bone, and comes out through the skull, these signs are: because there are exuding from that place bile which causes swelling, and bruising, and vertigo, and redness in the eyes, and inflation, and redness of the tongue, and spasm, and confusion of the mind, and vomiting of bile.
Et fortasse egreditur sanguis ex naribus, aut auribus.	And perhaps blood comes out of the nose or the ears.
Et fortasse abscinditur sermo, et destruitur uox.	And perhaps the speech is stammered, and the voice is lost
Et egreditur ex loco uulneris humiditas alba similis pulti.	And comes out from the wound a white moisture like pus
Et exit ex eo simile aquositati carnis.	And comes out like water of meat
Si ergo apparent tibi ista signa, tunc abstine a curatione, et extrahe sagittam si non egreditur.	If any sign of the disease be apparent to thee, then abstain from treatment, and draw out the arrow if it does not issue forth.
Signa autem sagittae quando cadit in corde, sunt: quod ipsa est prope mammillam sinistram: et sentit cum ea quasi ipsa sit fixa in re dura, non in re uacua.	When an arrow lies in the cord, the signs are: that it is close to the left breast: and that it feels as though it were fixed in something hard, not in something soft
Et fortasse sagittae est motus similis motui pulsus: et currit ex uulnere sanguis niger.	The arrow may also be moved like the pulse: and it runs from the wound of black blood.
Et sequitur illud frigus extremitatum, et sudor frigidus, et syncopis.	And following this will be coldness at the extremity, and cold sweat, and fainting.
Scias ergo, quod mors descendit procul dubio.	Know therefore that death approaches with certainty.
Et signum sagittae quando uulnerat pulmonem, est exitus sanguinis spumosi ex uulnere: et uasa quae sequuntur collum, apostematur, et mutatur color infirmi.	When the arrow wounds the lung, the sign is the emission of bloody froth from the wound: and the after-effects which follow the collar, become pale, and change the colour of the patient.
Et expirat spiritum magnum, altum: et quaerit attractionem aeris frigidi.	And the spirit expires greatly, loudly: and seeks the attraction of cold air
Quod si cadat sagitta in uelamen, quod est in pectore: tunc est prope costas paruas: et fit anhelitus magnus cum dolore uehementi, cum suspirio: et mouentur omnia membra humerorum.	If an arrow falls into the diaphragm, which is in the chest: then it is near the flanks: and there is a great panting with pain, with breath holding, with sighing: and all the limbs of the arms are moved
Et si cadat sagitta in stomachum, tunc fortasse egreditur ex uulnere ex cibo aliquid indigestum.	If an arrow falls into the stomach: then perhaps it will issue from the wound from some undigested food
Et si cadit sagitta in Ventrem, et figitur in eo: egreditur aliquid stercoris ex uulnere, aut zirbum, aut intestinum quod iam disruptum est.	If an arrow falls into the belly, and it lies there: something of stool will issue from the wound, or blood, or intestine which has been broken
Non est ergo spes in curatione eius, neque in extractione sagittae.	There is no hope in the treatment of this, neither in the extraction of the arrow.
Quod si sagitta cadat in Vesicam, et egrediatur urina: et procedit ex ea aliquid ad exteriora, et fortior sit dolor super infirmum: tunc scias, quia est mortale.	If an arrow falls into the bladder, and it is ejected: and something proceeds from it outwards, and the pain is greater over the patient: then you know that it is mortal
Reliqua autem membra, sicut facies, et collum, et guttur, et spatula, et adiutorium, et spondiles dorsi, et furcula, et coxa, et crus, et eis similia ex membris saluantur secundum plures dispositiones: quando non inuenit sagitta arteriam, aut neruum: et non est sagitta uenenosa.	The remaining members, namely the face, neck, chest, gut, spatula, aidant, spine, rib, hip, thigh, and knee, are similar to one another and are treated in accordance with various dispositions: when neither an arrow nor a nerve is found.
Et ego narro tibi quod uidi de esse harum sagittarum, ut significes per illud super curationem tuam.	I also tell you that I have seen no such arrows, which would signify that this is beyond your care.
Quod est, quia cuidam uiro cecidit sagitta in lachrymali oculi eius, in radice nasi.	That is, because I take care that the arrow of envy does not reach his eye or his nose root.
Extraxi ergo eam ipsi ex parte altera, sub adipe auris eius: et sanatus est, et non accidit ei in oculo eius nocumentum.	I extracted it from his other side, under the fat of his ear: and he was healed, and no mark remained on his eye.
Et extraxi sagittam aliam Iudaeo, quae cecidit ei in adipe oculi sui sub palpebra inferiori: et sagitta iam occultata erat, et non consecutus sum ex ea nisi extremitatem paruam eius, cum qua adhaeret in ligno suo: et erat sagitta magna ex sagittis arcuum Turcorum, cum ferro leni, in qua non sunt aures.	And I extracted another arrow from a Jew, which had penetrated him in the fat of his eye under the lower eyelid: and the arrow was hidden, and I did not find its tip until I had removed a portion of the wood from it: and it was a great arrow, like those of the Turkish archers, with a lead tip, in which there were no ears
Sanatus est ergo Iudaeus, et non accidit in oculo eius accidens malum.	He was healed of this, and no bad thing happened to his eye
Et extraxi sagittam aliam ex gutture Christiani.	And I extracted another arrow from the belly of a Christian.
Et erat sagitta arabica, et est illa cui sunt aures.	And it was an Arabic arrow, which is like those which have ears
Secui ergo super ipsam inter duas guidegi: et iam submersa erat in gutture eius.	Following this, between two ribs: and it was deeply embedded in his belly
Subtiliatus sum ergo cum ea, donec extraxi eam: et sanatus est Christianus.	I was careful with it until I extracted it: and the Christian was healed.
Et extraxi sagittam aliam uiro quae ceciderat in uentre eius: et cogitauimus, quia moreretur ex ea.	And I extracted another one which had penetrated his chest: and we thought that he would die from it
Postquam ergo praeterierunt ei triginta dies, et non mutatum est super eum aliquid ex dispositionibus eius, secui super sagittam: et ingeniaui super eam, et extraxi eam: et sanatus est, et non accidit ei accidens malum.	Afterward, when thirty days had passed, and no change appeared in his condition with regard to the arrow, we thought that it would be better to remove it: and we did so, and he was healed, and no bad thing happened to him
Et uidi uirum cui cecidit sagitta in dorso eius, et consolidatum est uulnus super eam.	And the arrow that had pierced the man in his back has become fixed, and a knot has formed above it.
Postquam ergo fuit post septem annos, exiuit sagitta in radice coxae eius.	And thus has the arrow remained for seven years, since it went out from the root of his thigh
Et uidi mulierem cui cecidit in uentre suo sagitta, et consolidatum est uulnus super eam, et remansit sagitta intra ipsam: et non mutata est ex dispositionibus eius aliqua, et mulier non inuenit ei nocumentum in aliqua ex operationibus suis naturalibus.	And the arrow that had pierced the woman in her belly has become fixed, and a knot has formed above it, and the arrow remains inside her: and it has not changed from its positions, and the woman has not found any relief from her natural operations.
Et uidi uirum alium, cui cecidit sagitta in facie sua: et consolidatum est uulnus, et remansit, non inueniens ei multum dolorem: et similia istis multa.	And the arrow that had pierced the man on his face has become fixed, and a knot has formed, and it remains, without causing him much pain: and there are many like this.
Et extraxi sagittam uiro ex principibus Regis, quae ceciderat ei in medio nasi sui, et iam declinauerat ad partem dextram parumper: et occultata erat sagitta tota.	And I extracted the arrow from the King's nose, which had pierced him in the middle of his nose, and it had inclined towards the right side downwards: and the arrow was completely hidden.
Vocatus sum ergo ad curationem eius post casum sagittae usque ad tres dies.	I was called to treat him for the wound caused by the arrow until three days later.
Inueni ergo uulnus sagittae strictum ualde.	I found the knot of the arrow to be firm and high up
Inquisiui ergo eam cum tenta subtili, et non sensi eam: et ipse quidem inueniebat punctionem et dolorem sub aure sua ex parte dextra.	I asked him to move his limb slightly with a gentle touch, and he did not feel pain: and even I could see the puncture mark and the pain beneath his right ear
Speraui ergo, quod erat illa punctio ex extremitate sagittae.	I hope that this was the puncture made by the tip of the arrow.
Emplastraui ergo locum cum emplastro in quo erat uirtus attractiua, et digestiua, confidens apud me, quod apostemaretur locus, et appareret mihi signum sagittae, ut secarem super eam: et non accidit in loco accidens significans quod sagitta consecuta sit locum.	I plastered the place with a pleasant and digestible ointment, trusting that the wound would heal, and that the sign of the arrow would disappear on its own: and it did not happen in the place of the wound that the arrow had followed
Assiduaui ergo cum emplastro super eum diebus multis: et non accidit accidens, et consolidatum est uulnus interim: et remansit infirmus de extractione eius spacio dierum, donec sensit sagittam die quodam intra nasum suum.	I attended to him with the ointment for many days: and no accident happened, and the knot consolidated in the meantime: and he felt the arrow again on the following day inside his nose
Et narrauit mihi illud.	And he told me that.
Posui ergo super illud uulnus medicinam acutam, corrosiuam diebus multis, donec apertum est: et cum tenta tentaui ipsum, et sensi extremitatem sagittae subtilem quae adhaeret in ligno.	And he told me that he placed upon it a sharp instrument, corrosive for many days, until it had opened: and when he had tried to grasp it, he found a slight arrowhead adhering to the wood.
Deinde addidi in apertione uulneris per illam medicinam acutam, donec apparuit nobis uisibiliter extremitas sagittae: et praeteriit mihi cum eo spacium temporis circiter quatuor menses.	And then I added to the incision the sharp instrument, until we saw the tip of the arrow clearly: and we left it for about four months
Deinde postquam amplificatum est uulnus, et possible fuit mihi intromittere forcipes in ipsam, et mouere ipsam, et non obediuit ad exitum: tunc non cessaui subtiliare, et ingeniare super eam cum modis ingeniorum, donec coepi super eam die quodam cum forcipibus decenter factis, secundum quod ueniet forma eorum in fine capituli, donec extraxi eam.	And when the wound had healed, and it was possible for me to introduce forceps into it, and to move it, and it did not yield: then I did not desist from the subtle probing, but devised ways and means to protect it, until I came to do the same with forceps of a greater size, as it happened in the end of the chapter, when I drew out the arrow
Deinde restauraui uulnus.	And I restored the wound.
Et medici quidem iudicant, quod cartilago nasi non restauratur.	And the physicians say that the cartilage of the nose is not restored
Restauraui ergo ipsam, et consolidatum est uulnus, et sanatus est infirmas sanitate integra: nec nocuit ei aliquid omnino.	I restored it, and the wound was consolidated and healed with perfect health: and nothing remained of it
Et ego narro tibi qualitatem extractionis quarundam sagittarum: ut ponas illud regulam et significationem super illud quod non dixi.	And I tell you the nature of the extraction of several arrows: so that you will know the rule and the signification of this which I have not mentioned
Quoniam partes huius artis et distinctiones earum non comprehenduntur cum narratione: neque comprehendit illud liber, et artifex prudens comparat cum pauco super multum: et cum eo quod est paesens, super illud quod est absens: et inuenit operationem nouam, et instrumentum nouum apud descensus rerum extranearum huius artis quando accidunt.	For the parts of this art and their distinctions are not comprehended by the narration: neither did that book comprehend them, nor did the skillful artificer compare them with little to much: and when he found that which is present was wanting, and that which was absent was present: he invented a new operation and a new instrument in the descent of these things of this art when they arise
Dico ergo, quod sagittae non egrediuntur ex membris quibus sunt fixae, nisi secundum duos modos.	I say therefore, that arrows do not come out of the members in which they are fixed, except in two ways.
Aut per attractionem ex loco ex quo intrauit.	Or by traction from the place from whence it came in.
Aut contrario partis alterius.	Or from the opposite part.
Et illa quae egreditur unde intrauit, aut est sagitta procedens in loco carnoso: et attrahitur, et egreditur.	And that which goes out from whence it came, or that is to say the arrow proceeding in the fleshy place: it is drawn and goes out.
Quod si non obedit ad exitum ex hora in qua cadit: tunc oportet ut dimittas ipsam aliquot diebus, donec putrefiat caro quae est in circumitu eius: et alleuietur attractio eius, et eius egressio.	If it does not obey the exit at the hour in which it fell: then it is necessary that you delay it for a few days, until the putrefaction of the flesh which is around it is over: and you must relax the traction and the going out of it
Et similiter si figitur in osse, et non obedit tibi ad exitum, tunc dimitte ipsam etiam aliquot diebus: et itera eam cum attractione et motione omni die, donec egreditur.	And in like manner if it is fixed in a bone, and it does not obey you at the exit: then you must also delay it for a few days: and do it again every day with traction and motion, until it goes out
Quod si non obedit tibi ad exitum post dies, tunc oportet ut perfores in circumitu sagittae in ipso osse ab omni parte cum terebro subtili, donec amplificentur sagittae.	If it does not obey you at the exit after days: then you must perform an incision around the arrow in the very bone from all sides with a fine thread, until the arrow is amplified
Deinde attrahe eam, et extrahe ipsam.	And then draw it and pull it out
Si autem sagitta est fixa in capitis osse, et iam processit in uno uentrium cerebri, et apparent ex infirmo quaedam illorum accidentium quae dixi: tunc abstine ab attractione sagittae, et dimitte eam, donec aequetur esse eius post dies.
