If however the arrow is fixed in the head of the bone, and it has gone through one of the veins of the brain, and appears from the wound some of those accidents which I mentioned: then abstain from the traction of the arrow and leave it, until it becomes equal to itself after days.
Nam si sagitta peruenit ad sifach, tunc mors non prolongatur ei.	For if the arrow goes on to the marrow, the death is not prolonged for it
Et si sagitta non est fixa, nisi in corpore ossis tantum, et non penetrat usque ad sifach: et remanet infirmus aliquot diebus, et non accidit ei ex illis accidentibus aliquid: tunc ingenia in attractione sagittae et extractione eius.	And if the arrow is not fixed except in the body of the bone, and does not penetrate until the marrow: and remains wounded for a few days, and nothing of those accidents happens to it: then think of the traction of the arrow and its pulling out
Si autem est fixa ualde, et non obedit tibi ad attractionem: tunc administra terebella in circumitu sagittae, sicut narraui tibl: deinde cura locum, donec sanetur.	If however it is fixed loosely, and does not obey you at the traction: then administer a bandage around the arrow as I have told you: then take care of the place, until it is healed.
Si autem Sagitta iam absconsa est in loco corporis, et occultatur et absconditur a sensu: tunc inquire eam cum tenta.	If, however, the arrow is hidden in some part of the body, and is hidden and concealed from sense: then inquire concerning it with a grasp.
Si autem sentis eam, tunc attrahe eam cum quibusdam instrumentis quae conueniunt attractioni eius.	If you feel it, then grasp it with some instrument which is suitable for its attraction.</start_of_turn>
Si autem non potes super eam, propter constrictionem uulneris, et propter longitudinem sagittae in profundo: et non est illic os, neque neruus, neque uena: tunc finde super eam, donec amplificetur uulnus, et sit possibile extrahere sagittam.	If, however, you cannot see it, because of the constriction of the wound, and because of the length of the arrow in depth: and there is neither bone, nor nerve, nor blood vessel there: then find above it until the wound is enlarged, and it is possible to extract the arrow.</start_of_turn>
Quod si sunt ei aures quibus teneatur, tunc libera carnem fixam in eis ab omni parte, omni ingenio quo potes illud, et ingenia, si non potest super euasionem carnis in fractura aurium, et contorsione earum, donec euadat.	Which if there are any ears which hold it, then loosen the flesh fixed in the bone from every side, by every means which you can think, and contort, if you cannot see beyond the fracture of the ears, and the twisting of the ears, until it comes loose.</start_of_turn
Et tu quando administras extractionem Sagittae, in quocumque loco est, tunc utere contorsione manus tuae, cum forficibus ad partes omnes, donec facias eam euadere: et subtilia ultima subtilitate, ut non frangatur Sagita, et fiat difficilis tibi attractio eius, et ipsius extractio.	And when you administer the extraction of the arrow, in whatever place it is, then use the twisting of your hand, with forceps at all parts, until you make it come loose: and with the last slight pull, that the arrow may not break, and that its extraction should be difficult, and itself be extracted.</start_of_turn
Quod si non potes super eam ex hora una, tunc dimitte eam diebus aliquot, donec putrefiant quae sunt in circumitu eius.	If you cannot see it from one hour, then leave it for a few days, until the things which are around it have putrefied.</start_of_turn
Deinde itera eam: alleuietur enim tuncia Si uero contrarietatem tibi facit fluxus sanguinis, tunc administra quod diximus ex curatione in capitulo suo: et custodi uirtutem tuam ab incisione uenae, aut nerui, aut chordae.	Then repeat it: for it will aid you in that it makes the flux of blood easier. Then administer what we have said from the chapter on treatment: and guard your virtue from the incision of the vein, or the nerve, or the chord.</start_of_turn>
Et administra ingenium omni modo quo tibi possibile est euasionis Sagittae: et sit illud cum facilitate, et tranquillitate, uel tarditate, et firmitate, sicut narraui tibi.	And administer ingenuity in every way which is possible for you to achieve the extraction of the arrow: and let it be with ease, and tranquility, or slowly, and firmly, as I have said to you.</start_of_turn
Et oportet, ut facias cum trahis Sagittam, ut infirmus sit secundum figuram, secundum quam fuit apud casum Sagittae in ipso.	It is necessary that you make the patient conform to the figure of the arrow according to how it was in the case of the arrow itself.
Quoniam est magis iuuatiuum.	Since this is the case, you must make the patient conform to the form of the arrow as it is in the case of the arrow itself.
Si autem non est tibi possibile illud, tunc administra quod tibi est possibile ex figuris.	If this is not possible, then do what you can from the figure.
Sagitta autem quae egreditur ex contrario partis alterius, aut iam procedit ex ea aliquid ad exteriora: aut facit gibbositatem extremitas Sagittae per sensum ex superiore parte cutis propinquae, et uides eam eminentem: seca ergo super eam, et sit sectio secundum quantitatem quod capiant in ea forcipes.	The arrow which proceeds from the opposite side of the other, or which proceeds from that to the exterior: or it makes a prominence at the extremity of the arrow by means of the sense from the upper part of the skin nearby, and it dries up: thus it is above the wound, and the section is according to the quantity which they take in that clamp.
Deinde attrahe eam: ipsa namque fit facilis ad exitum.	Then draw out the arrow: itself will thereby become easy to expel.
Si uero retinetur in osse, tunc torque manum tuam secundum rotunditatem, donec imprimat Sagitta in osse, et amplificet sibiipsi: deinde trahe ipsam.	If it remains in the bone, then turn your hand according to the roundness, until you press the arrow into the bone, and amplify it: then draw it out
Et si non: dimitte eam diebus aliquot: deinde itera eam, donec egrediatur.	If not: leave it for a few days: then do it again, until it comes out by itself
Quod si lignum Sagittae est in ea, tunc impelle ipsam cum eo.	If the arrow is in wood, then push it out with that.
Si autem cecidit lignum, et uis administrare impulsionem: tunc intromitte ad eam instrumentum concauum, ut ingrediatur concauitas eius in caudam Sagittae: deinde impelle eam cum ipso.	If the wood has broken, and you wish to administer a push: then introduce an instrument with a concave edge into the wound so that it may join the concavity of the instrument to the heel of the arrow: then push out the arrow with that.
Si autem Sagita est concaua, tunc impelle eam cum instrumento intrante in ipsam.	If the arrow is concave, then push out the arrow with an instrument entering into it
Sagitta enim alleuiatur per illud.	The arrow will be expelled by that.
Quod si Sagitta est toxicata, tunc oportet, ut concaues carnem totam, in qua est uenenum: si est tibi possibile illud.	If the arrow is venomous, then it is necessary to cut away the entire piece of flesh in which the poison is: if this is possible
Deinde cura eam cum eo quod conuenit ad illud.	Then care for it with that which is suitable for it.
Quod si Sagitta est cadens in pectore, aut in uentre, aut in uesica, aut in latere: et est propinqua ex eo quod tangis cum tenta, et possibile est tibi secare super eam: tunc seca, et caue ab incisione uenae, aut nerui, et extrahe eam.	If an arrow is falling in the chest, or in the belly, or in the bladder, or on the side: and it is close to that which you touch with your finger, and it is possible for you to cut over it: then cut, and cauterize from the incision of the belly, or nerve, and extract the arrow.
Deinde sue uulnus, si uides, et cura illud, donec sanetur.	Then bandage it, if necessary, and care for it until it is healed.
Et haec est forma Forcipum, quibus extrahuntur Sagittae.	And this is the form of forceps, with which arrows are extracted.
Sint extremitates similes rostro auis, quae factae sunt sicut ferra: quando capiunt super Sagittam, non dimittunt eam.	There are two similar extremities like the beak of a bird, which are made like iron: when they grasp over the arrow, they do not slacken it
Et fiunt ex eis species multae, magnae, et paruae, et mediae, secundum quantitatem magnitudinis Sagittae, et paruitatis eius, et amplitudinis uulneris, et constrictionis eius.	And there are many kinds of forceps, great and small, medium and small, according to the quantity of the magnitude of the arrow, and the rarity of it, and the width of the wound, and the constriction of it.
Forma Impellentis concaui.	Concave Impeller Form.</start_of_turn>
Et forma Impellentis surdi.	And the form of the Impeller is blunt.</start_of_turn
Hoc est surdae extremitatis sicut Radius, ut alleuietur introitus eius in sagittam concauam, et impellatur cum eo.	This is the shape of the extremity like a Radius, so as to facilitate the entrance of its entrance into the concave arrow, and to drive it with that.</start_of_turn
Huius extremitas impellentis concauae est concaua sicut penna auis: ut alleuietur introitus sagittae in ipsam et impulsio eius.	This extremity of the Impeller is concave like the beak of a bird: so as to facilitate the entrance of the arrow into itself and the driving of it.</start_of_turn
¶ De phlebotomia Venarum.	Of the Phlebotomy of Veins.</start_of_turn>
Caput XCVII.	Chapter 147.</start_of_turn
Uenae phlebotomandae, quarum cucurrit consuetudo in corpore, sunt triginta.	The veins that are to be phlebotomized, whose custom runs in the body, are thirty.</start_of_turn
Ex quibus in capite sunt sexdecim: duae Venae pulsatiles, quae sunt post aures, dictae duae Herbae: et duae Arteriae, quae sunt in duobus timporibus apparentes: et duae Venae quae sunt in duobus lachrymalibus duorum oculorum, quae dicuntur Aspicientes: et Vena praeparata in medio frontis: et uena quae est in extremitate nasi.	From the head there are sixty: two pulsating veins which are behind the ears, two herbs which are in the two temples, two arteries which are visible in two temporal regions, two veins which are in the two tear ducts of the two eyes, which are called Aspicientes, a vein prepared in the middle of the forehead, and a vein which is at the extremity of the nose.
Et duae Guidegi, quae sunt in collo.	And two guide veins which are in the neck.
Et duae uenae quae sunt in labio superiore oris.	And two veins which are in the upper lip of the mouth.
Et duae uenae quae sunt in labio inferiore.	And two veins which are in the lower lip
Et istae sunt uenae quae dicuntur Algecherich.	And these are the veins which are called Algecherich.
Et duae uenae quae sunt sub lingua.	And two veins which are under the tongue
Venae autem quae phlebotomantur in brachiis, sunt quinque uenae in omni brachio.	And the veins which are phlebotomized in the arms are five in each arm.
Vna earum est Cephalica, et est ex latere syluestri: et nominat eam uulgus uenam capitis.	One of them is the Cephalica, and it is from the side of the shoulder: and it is named after the large vein of the head
Et Fusca.	And the Fusca.
Et est Media uena, et est composita ex ramo Basilicae, et ramo Cephalicae: et nominat eam uulgus uenam corporis.	And it is the Middle vein, and it is composed of the branches of the basilica and the cephalic vein: and it is named after the great vein of the body
Et Basilica, et est posita in latere domestico: et nominatur etiam Titillicaris.	And the Basilica, and it is situated in the domestic side: and it is also called the Titillicaris.
Et nominat eam uulgus uenam uentris.	And it is named after the vein of the belly
Et Funis brachii, et est posita super focile: et est illa in qua phlebotomatur, et est illa quae apparet supra pollicem appatitione manifesta.	And the Brachial vein, and it is situated over the elbow: and it is that from which phlebotomy is done, and that which appears above the wrist with a visible pulsation.
Et Saluatella: et est uena quae est inter annularem et minimum: et sunt ei duo rami.	And the Saluatella: and it is the vein which is between the annular and the minimum: and there are two branches to it.
Et in crure et in pede sunt tres uenae.	There are three veins in the thigh and in the foot.
Vna earum est quae est sub pollicis curuatura ex latere syluestri.	One of these veins is that which is under the curvature of the thumb from the side of the heel.
Et secunda est Saphena: et locus eius est apud calcaneum ex latere domestico.	The second is the saphenous: and its place is beside the domestic part of the calcaneum.
Et uena Nesse: et locus eius est apud calcaneum ex latere syluestri.	The third is the tibial: and its place is beside the heel from the side of the heel
Et in crure alio sunt tres uenae similes illis.	And in the other leg there are three veins similar to these.
¶ De phlebotomia duarum uenarum post Aures.	As for the two veins behind the knee, from the Aures (popliteal space).
Phlebotomiae uero duarum uenarum quae sunt post Aures, iuuamentum est ad catarros antiquos, et hemigraneam, et sahafati, et ulcera capitis mala antiqua.	The incisions of these two veins behind the knee are useful for ancient cataracts, and headaches, and safra, and ulcer of the head that is ancient.
Et qualitas phlebotomandi eam est secundum quod narro.	And the quality of the incisions of the veins is as I have mentioned
Et est, ut radatur caput infirmi: et fricetur occipitium eius in loco duarum uenarum cum panno aspero fricatione bona.	And it is like causing the head of the patient to bleed: and break the skin of his head in the place of the two veins with rough cloth friction.
Deinde stringat infirmus collum suum cum uitta, donec appareant duae uenae.	Then the patient should tighten his neck with his hand until two veins appear
Et loca earum sunt post Aures in duobus locis depressis capitis.	And their places are behind the knee in two depressed parts of the head
Quaere ergo eas digito tuo, et ubi sentis pulsum earum sub digito tuo, illic signa cum encaustro.	Seek therefore easily with your finger, and where you feel their pulse under your finger, there is the sign with the scar
Deinde accipe phlebotomum cultellarem, et est ille qui dicitur Incidens.	Then take the cutting knife, which is called the Incidens.
Deinde intromitte ipsum sub uena in cute, donec perueniat phlebotomus ad os.	Then introduce it under the vein into the skin, until the phlebotomist reaches the bone
Deinde eleua manum tuam cum uena et cute ad superiora, et incide uenam cum cute incisione incidente.	Then lift up your hand with the vein and the skin to the upper part, and cut the vein with the cutting incision.
Et sit longitudo incisionis quantitas duorum digitorum iunctorum, aut circiter illud: et fac exire ex sanguine quantum uis.	The length of the incision should be equal to the width of two joined fingers, or thereabouts: and let blood escape as much as you wish.
Deinde stringe eam cum puluillis, et dimitte eam, donec sanetur.	Then bind the wound with silk threads and let it go until it has healed
Et iam praecessit in principio libri incisio earum, et ipsarum cauterizatio.	And thus it has gone before in the book concerning the incisions and their cauterization.
¶ De phlebotomia duarum Arteriarum in timporibus.	Of the cutting of two veins at their bases.
Duarum uero Arteriarum quae sunt in duobus timporibus phlebotomiae iuuamentum, est ad hemigraneam antiquam: et sodam prauam, et obtalmiam assiduam: et cursum superfluitatum effusarum acutarum ad oculos.	Two veins which are in two positions of phlebotomy are sufficient for an ancient headache: and sweat on the forehead, and constant vomiting: and an excessive flow of acute tears towards the eyes
Et qualitas phlebotomandi eas est secundum quod narro tibi.	The quality of the phlebotomy is easy according to what I have told you.
Stringat infirmus collum suum multum, donec appareant duae uenae sensui apparitione manifesta: et demonstretur pulsus earum sub digito tuo.	Bind the patient's neck very much until two veins appear to the sense of touch: and let the pulse of both of them be under your finger
Tunc enim signa cum encaustro.	Then signs with cauterization
Deinde eleua cutem desuper uenam ad superiora cum digito tuo indice, et intromitte phlebotomum incidentem desubtus, et eleua uenam ad superiora.	Then lift the skin over the vein with your index finger, and make the phlebotomy incision below it, and lift the vein up to the superior part
Et incide eam, sicut fecisti in duabus uenis aliis: et fac currere ex sanguine secundum quantitatem necessitatis tuae.	And cut the vein as you did in the two other veins: and let blood escape according to the quantity you need
Deinde solue coartationem infirmi, et pone digitum tuum super uenam hora una.	Then loosen the binding of the patient, and place your finger over the vein for an hour.
Postea pone super ipsam cotum et puluillos, et stringe ipsum desuper constrictione forti: et dimitte ipsam, donec sanetur.	Then place above the wound and the threads, and bind it tightly: and let it go until it has healed
Et iam praecessit rememoratio earum, et ipsarum incisio, et earum extractio in principio libri.	And thus it has passed concerning the recollection of the wounds, their incisions, and their extraction at the beginning of the book
¶ De phlebotomia uenae frontis post phlebotomiam Cephalicae.	From the cutting of the vein of the front of the head after the cutting of the Cephalic vein.
Iuuamentum uero phlebotomiae uenae frontis est post phlebotomiam Cephalicae, ad aegritudines faciei antiquas: et ad hemigraneam, et rubedinem: et ulcera foeda.	The remedy for the pain of the face after the cutting of the Cephalic vein is the cutting of the vein of the front of the head. This is for old head-aches, and for migraine, and redness, and ulcer and wound.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae eius est, secundum quod narro tibi.	And as for the quality of the cutting of this vein, that is what I shall tell you.
Coartet infirmus collum suum cum uitta, donec appareat uena.	Take the patient's neck and turn it until the vein appears.
Deinde accipe instrumentum quod nominatur Fossorium.	Then take the instrument which is called the Fossorium.
Cuius haec est forma.	It has this shape.
Pone acumen eminens quod est in capite Fossorii super ipsam uenam, et percute super ipsum cum pectine, aut cum re alia in modo eius: et dimitte sanguinem currere secundum quantitatem quam uis.	Put the sharp point which is in the head of the Fossorium over the vein, and pierce through it with the pin, or with something in the like way: and let the blood run out as much as you wish.
Deinde solue perforationem infirmi, et stringe eam, donec sanetur.	Then close the perforation of the patient, and bind it up, until it is healed
Et quandoque aperitur cum phlebotomo lato.	And when it is opened with the wide phlebotomy.
Verumtamen non oportet, ut sit phlebotomus acutae extremitatis, sicut reliqui phlebotomi, imo sit latae extremitatis.	Indeed, it should not be done with a sharp phlebotomy of the extremities, like the rest of the phlebotomies, but rather with a wide phlebotomy
Et phlebotoma eam secundum transuersionem: quoniam os est propinquum: et fortasse in eo frangetur phlebotomus quando est subtilis.	And the phlebotomy must be made according to the passing of the hand: because the bone is close by: and perhaps in this the phlebotomy will break when it is slight
¶ De phlebotomia Venarum in duobus Lachrymalibus.	From the cutting of the veins in the two Lacrimalia.
Iuuamentum autem duarum Venarum quae sunt in duobus Lachrymalibus duorum oculorum, est ad oculum ex scabie et rubedine: et sebel in oculo, et aegritudinibus faciei.	The remedy for the eye from scabies and redness: and for swelling in the eye, and for pains of the face.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae earum est, ut stringat infirmus collum suum cum uitta.	And as for the quality of the cutting of these veins, that is to say to tighten the patient's neck and turn it until it appears
Deinde phlebotoma eas: et tu sis stans super caput eius.	Then let the phlebotomy be easy: and you stand over the head of him.
Et fiat phlebotomia secundum transuersum ad longitudinem parum, cum phlebotomo paruo, lato parumper, nam in loco non est caro.	And let the phlebotomy be done according to the passing of the vein to a small length, with a small lancet, broad rather than narrow, for in that place there is no flesh.
Si enim phlebotomus est subtilis extremitatis, fortasse frangitur.	If the phlebotomy is too close to the extremity, it may well break
Deinde fac currere ex sanguine quantum est tibi necesse.	Then let run out blood as much as is necessary for you
Et pone super eas cotum, et stringe eas nocte una, et solue eas.	And put over his head a cushion, and bind up his head once, and rest him.
¶ De phlebotomia uenarum Nasi.	Of the phlebotomy of the veins of the nose
Venae autem Nasi phlebotomia, est conferens ad febrem acutam, et sodam uehementem, et aegritudines faciei, sicut hemigraneam, et rubedinem quae accidit in facie: praecipue quando est antiqua.	The veins of the nose, however, undergo phlebotomy in cases of acute fever, and excessive sweating, and facial ailments, such as migraine, and redness that happens in the face: especially when it is old.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae eius est, ut stringat infirmus collum suum.	And the quality of the phlebotomy of them is that it tightens the neck of the patient.
Deinde tene nasum eius manu tua sinistra, et accipe phlebotomum subtilem, longum: et fige eum in medio leporis ipsius, inter illud quod distinguit nasum secundum rectitudinem.	Then take hold of his nose with your left hand, and make the phlebotomy below the middle of the nose, long: and hold it at the middle of the nose itself, between that which distinguishes the nose according to its straight line.
Quoniam uena non apparet sensui illic, et quia sanguis incipit fluere statim.	Because the vein does not appear to the sense there, and because the blood begins to flow immediately.
Et oportet, ut ultimes manum tuam cum phlebotomo parumper: et facias currere ex sanguine secundum necessitatem tuam.	And it is necessary to take away the last hand with the small lancet: and let run out blood according to your need.
Deinde liga ipsam nocte una.	And bind up his head once at night
Ipsa enim restauratur uelociter.	The bleeding will soon stop by itself.
¶ De phlebotomia uenarum Guidegi.	Of the phlebotomy of the veins of the jaw.
Duarum uero Guidegi phlebotomiae iuuamentum, est ad constrictionem anhelitus, et incaeptionem leprae, et aegritudines melancholicas, et impetiginem et ulcera mala, et corrodentibus, id est, herpetibus estiomenis.	The Guidegi of phlebotomy is useful for constriction of the hiccup, leprosy, melancholic diseases, bad ulcers and wounds, and corrosive substances, that is, herpetiform diseases of the abdomen.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae earum est ut stringat infirmus sub utrisque in collo suo cum ligamento: et stet artifex super caput infirmi, et infirmus sit sedens super sedem.	The quality of phlebotomy is that it tightens the patient under the two armpits in the neck: and let the artist stand above the head of the patient, and the patient sit upon a seat
Deinde phlebotoma uenam ad longitudinem phlebotomia ampla parumper.	Then the phlebotomy is made to the length of the wide part of the phlebotomy.
Deinde extrahe ex sanguine quantitatem temperatam, aut secundum illud quod uides ex necessitate quae est ad illud.	Then draw out from the blood the quantity that is temperate, or according to that which you need for the purpose
Deinde fac similiter de uena alia.	Then do the same with the other arm
Postea solue ligamentum, et stringe duas uenas strictura media: ut non praefocetur infirmus.	Then tie the ligament and tighten the two arms with medium tension: so that the patient is not bruised.
Et dimitte eam usque mane.	And leave it until the morning.
Sanatur enim uulnus.	The wound is healed by itself.
¶ De phlebotomia uenarum Algeberich.	Of the phlebotomy of the veins of Algeberich
Venae autem Algeberich phlebotomiae iuuamentum est: quia confert ad alcolam in ore, et corruptionem gingiuae: et ulcera mala: et fissuras labiorum, et ulcera mala, etiam quae sunt in naso, et in circumitu eius.	The veins of Algeberich are useful for phlebotomy because they cause swelling in the mouth, corruption of the gums, bad ulcers, wounds on the lips, and ulcers on the tongue and in the surrounding area
Et qualitas phlebotomiae earum est, ut facias sedere infirmum coram te: et stringe collum eius cum uitta.	The quality of phlebotomy of these is that you make the patient sit before you: and tighten his neck with a cloth
Deinde reuolue labium eius, et aspice ad duas uenas: quarum una est a dextera labii, et secunda a sinistra eius: et demonstratio utriusque est per nigredinem ambarum.	Then pull down his lip, and look at two veins: one is on the right side of the lip, and the other on the left side: and their demonstration is by the black color of both.
Et illud uerum est: quia in circumitu earum sunt uenae minutae, nigrae.	And this is true: because around them are small veins, black in color
Incide ergo utramque incisione incidente.	Each incision must be made precisely as it should be.
Si autem dubitatio est super te, et non scis quae earum est: tunc intende ad incisionem maioris earum, et ipsarum manifestiorem.	If you are in doubt as to which incision should be made, or which of the two you should choose: then you must proceed with the greater incision and its marks will be evident to you.
Et similiter fac de duabus uenis quae sunt in labio superiore: et plurimum quidem currit consuetudo cum eo: et incide duas uenas quae sunt in labio inferiori.	Proceed in the same way with the two veins that are in the upper lip: and most frequently these run in accordance with custom with each other: and make two incisions in the two veins that are in the lower lip.
¶ De phlebotomia Venae sub lingua post Cephalicae phlebotomiam.	As for the phlebotomy of the vein under the tongue after the cephalic phlebotomy has been made
Duarum uero Venarum quae sunt sub lingua phlebotomiae iuuamentum: est, quod phlebotomia Cephalicae est ad praefocationes quae sunt in gutture, et aegritudinem uuulae, et aegritudines oris.	The two veins which are under the tongue are to be bled after the cephalic phlebotomy has been performed: that is to say that the cephalic phlebotomy is for the treatment of the affections of the throat, of the tongue, and of the mouth
Et qualitas phlebotomandi eas est, ut sedeat infirmus inter manus tuas coram sole: et eleualinguam eius, et aspice sub lingua a latere eius uno uenam, et a latere eius alio uenam: et color utriusque decliuis ad nigredinem.	The quality of the phlebotomy of the mandible is that the patient should sit between your hands facing the sun: and elevate his tongue, and look under the tongue at the side of it one vein, and at the side of it the other vein: and the colour of both should be towards black.
Phlebotoma ergo utramque: et custodi, ne ultimes manum tuam in phlebotomando eas.	Both incisions must be made precisely: and take care not to grasp your last hand in making the phlebotomy
Nam sub eius sunt arteriae, et fortasse accidet fluxus sanguinis ex illis arteriis.	For under them are arteries, and perhaps there will be a flow of blood from them.
¶ De tribus Venis in cubito.	Of the three veins in the cubit.
Venae autem tres quae phlebotomantur in cubito, sunt in quarum phlebotomia cucurrit consuetudo in omnibus hominibus.	The three veins which are to be bled in the cubit are such that their phlebotomy is customary in all men
Et phlebotomia earum fit secundum duos modos.	And their phlebotomy is done in two ways.
Aut pungendo cum phlebotomo myrtino lato: aut oliuari ad subtilitatem decliui: aut secando cum phlebotomo cultellari, et est Alnesil.	Either by grasping with the forceps with a broad handle: or by using oil to soften the skin: or by cutting with a knife, which is Alnesil
Et haec est forma eius.	This is its form.
Sic Alnesil est, quod conuenit ad sectionem.	Thus is the way of it.
Et ex eis sunt species latae, et subtiles secundum amplitudinem uenarum et stricturam earum Forma phlebotomi myrtini sit lata, sicut uides.	There are many different forms of it, and subtle according to the width of the veins and the degree of tension.
Et conuenit ad aperiendas uenas concauas, plenas, procedentes, apparentes, grossas, et illas quae continent sanguinem grossum, turbidum.	It is suitable for opening wide, plump, protruding, visible, large, and those which contain thick blood
Et iste phlebotomus est minoris latitudinis, et subtilioris extreminatis.	This phlebotomy is of smaller width and more delicate extremity
Et conuenit ad phlebotomiam uenarum subtilium, quae continent sanguinem subtilem citrinum	It is suitable for the phlebotomy of small veins, which contain thin, yellow blood
¶ De phlebotomia Basilicae.	Of the phlebotomy of the Basilica.
Basilicae autem quae est una harum trium uenarum phlebotomiae iuuamentum est.	The Basilica is one of these three veins which receive the phlebotomy.
Quia extrahit sanguinem ex aegritudinibus, quae sunt sub gutture et collo, ex eo quod sequitur pectus, et uentrem: et conuenit phlebotomatori cum phlebotomat eam, ut caueat, et sit super timorem ex ea nam sub ea est arteria.	Because it draws blood from the abscesses, which are under the throat and chin, from the thing which follows the chest, and the belly: and it is suitable for the phlebotomist with the phlebotomy of the veins, in order to prevent excessive bleeding from them which is below
Si ergo errat, et addit in punctura phlebotomi, incidet illam arteriam, et accidet fluxus sanguinis.	If, therefore, he is mistaken, and adds too much in the puncture of the phlebotomy, he will reach the artery, and there will be a flow of blood
Quapropter oportet, ne phlebotomet eam cum phlebotomo pungente: imo sit secans cum Alnesil.	Therefore it is necessary not to perform the phlebotomy together with the puncture: rather it should be dry like Alnesil.
Quod si non apparet Basilica apparitione manifesta, tunc oportet, ut alienes ipsam, et permuteris ad aliam, aut quaeras aliquem ramum eius: aut phlebotomes loco eius Funem brachii.	If the Basilica does not appear clearly, then one must seek it out, and change to another, or ask about someone of its branches: or perform the phlebotomy in its place, the forearm branch
Ipsa enim est manifesta, et seca eam cum phlebotomo Anesil, sicut diximus.	It is itself obvious, and dry with the phlebotomy of Alnesil, as we have said.
Si autem uis phlebotomiam ipsius eiusdem, tunc oportet ante stricturam brachii, ut tangas locum, donec cognoscas locum pulsus.	If however you wish to perform a phlebotomy on the same arm, then it is necessary before the tightening of the limb to touch the place, until you recognize the place of the pulse.
Deinde signa super locum cum encaustro, postea brachium, et seca uenam sectione concaua cum phlebotomo Alnesil, sicut diximus.	Then mark over the place with a scar, afterwards the limb, and dry the area with a concave section with the phlebotome of Alnesil, as we have said
Et caue ne cadat percussio per spacium a loco arteriae.	And beware lest the incision should slip from the place of the artery.
Et quando uides, cum tu stringis ligamen, inflationem in loco quem signasti cum encaustro, tunc illa inflatio est inflatio arteriae: deuita ergo eam.	And when you go, when you tighten the ligature, inflation in the place which you marked with a scar, then that inflation is the inflation of the artery: you must therefore do it
Quod si uides sanguinem apud phlebotomiam salire, sicut urina pueri, et est sanguis subtilis, rubeus: tunc scias, quia est ex sanguine arteriae.	That if blood should come out at the phlebotomy like urine from a boy, and is thin and red: then you know that it is from the artery.
Tunc ergo propera, et pone digitum tuum super ipsum spacio longo, deinde aufer digitum tuum.	Then therefore act with speed, and place your finger on the said long space, then take your finger away.
Si ergo abscinditur sanguis (multotiens namque abscinditur) tunc stringe brachium, et dimitte ipsum: et caueat infirmus a motione eius: et sit super timorem eius.	If therefore blood is cut (for it is much cut), then tighten the limb, and let it go: and beware lest the patient should move: and be over his fear.
Et non moueat ipsum diebus aliquot, donec sanetur.	And do not move it for a few days, until it is healed.
Si autem non abscinditur sanguis, et uincit te: et non est tibi praesens in momento tuo medicina, tunc incide arteriam, si apparet tibi.	If however blood does not cut, and it increases to you: and it is not in your presence at the present time of medicine, then cut the artery, if you see it
Nam extremitates eius contrahuntur, et abscinditur sanguis.	For its extremities are contracted, and blood is cut
Aut accipe corticem fistici, et finde eum: accipe medietatem unam, et stringe eam super locum uenae strictura decenti, cum ligamento et puluillis usque ad diem alium.	Or take the edge of the flesh, and find it: take half of one, and tighten it over the place of the vein with a ligature and a loop until the next day.
Tunc si abscinditur sanguis, est bonum.	Then if blood is cut, that is good.
Et si non: tunc cura ipsum cum eo cuius praecessit rememoratio ex loco puluerum abscindentium fluxum sanguinis: et abscisio sanguinis eius non est difficilis in pluribus dispositionibus, propter locum paruum uulneris, et possibilitatem ligamenti ex brachio.	If not: then care for him with that with which preceded it, remembering from the place of the scattered fragments the flowing of blood: and the cutting of blood in this is not difficult in many situations, because of the smallness of the wound and the possibility of a ligament from the arm.
¶ De phlebotomia uenae Fuscae.	If not: then take care of him with that which preceded it, remembering from the place of the scattered fragments the flowing of blood: and the cutting of blood in this is not difficult in many situations, because of the smallness of the wound and the possibility of a ligament from the arm.
Venae autem Fuscae phlebotomiae iuuamentum est, quod trahit sanguinem ex superiori parte capitis, et inferiore corporis: propterea, quia est composita ex ramo Basilicae, et ramo Cephalicae, sicut diximus.	But the veins of the Fuscae are suitable for phlebotomy, because they draw blood from the upper part of the head and the lower part of the body: because they are composed of the branches of the basilica and the branches of the cephalic, as we said.
Et conuenit phlebotomanti eam, ut sit super timorem ex phlebotomia eius, nam sub ea est neruus.	And it is suitable for the phlebotomist that there be no fear of phlebotomy from him, for under this is a nerve.
Si ergo addit in punctura phlebotomi, et inuenit neruum, accidit in ea stupor, et difficilis fit sanatio eius, et fortasse non sanatur penitus.	If therefore he adds at the puncture of the phlebotomy, and finds a nerve, this will cause in him a stupor, and the healing of it will be difficult, and perhaps will not heal completely.</start_of_turn>
Et iste neruus multotiens apparet sensui.	And this nerve appears much to be connected with sensation.</start_of_turn>
Si autem occultatur in quibusdam hominibus, et est subtilis, et non ostenditur: tunc oportet ut ponas phlebotomiam tuam qua eam phlebotomas, sectionem cum Alnesil, et deuita neruum cum fortitudine tua.	If, however, it is hidden in some men, and is slight, and is not evident: then you must take care that you do not perform the phlebotomy in such a way as to section the nerve with your forceps.
Quod si uena est inter duos neruos, tunc finde uenam in longitudine.	For if the vein is between two nerves, then find the vein in its length.</start_of_turn
¶ De uena Cephalica.	Of the cephalic vein.
Phlebotomiae autem uenae Cephalicae iuuamentum est, quia attrahit sanguinem ex capite, et confert ad aegritudines oculorum.	But the phlebotomy of the cephalic vein is suitable, because it draws blood from the head and supplies it to the eyes.</start_of_turn
Et oportet in hac uena proprie, si uis, ut phlebotomes eam pungendo cum phlebotomo oliuari, aut cum phlebotomo myrtino: quoniam est saluior uenarum omnium, quoniam non est subea arteria, neque neruus.	And it must be done with its own needle, if you will, for the puncture with the olive or with the myrtle is safer, because it is less likely to reach an artery or a nerve.</start_of_turn
Verumtamen conuenit tibi apud phlebotomiam, ut deuites cum phlebotomo caput lacerti tantum, et quaeras locum leniorem: et non nocet ei, si non inuenitur cum percussione prima, ut iteretur super eam cum phlebotomia aliquotiens.	True indeed; it meets with you at the phlebotomy, that you may take with the phlebotomist only the head of the lacerated part, and inquire about a softer place: for it does no harm to him, if it is not found at the first percussion, as it may return above with further phlebotomy.
Verumtamen fortasse apostematur in quibusdam hominibus quando non phlebotomatur in percussione prima, sed non nocet ei illud apostema in aliquo.	True indeed; it often happens in some that when not bled at the first percussion, it does not harm them.
¶ De utilitate Phlebotomiae, et cautelis in ea obseruandis.	Of the usefulness of Phlebotomy, and the precautions to be taken in its performance.
Qualitas autem Phlebotomiae, et accidentia eius ex ea, in cuius rectificatione oportet te cogitare.	The quality of Phlebotomy, and the accidents which may arise from it, concerning which you must reflect
Primum ergo illius est de quo oportet ut scias, quod phlebotomia non administratur, nisi in conseruatione sanitatis, et perseuerantia eius, et cautela ab aduentu aegritudinum.	Firstly, therefore, you must know that Phlebotomy is not administered except for the preservation of health, and for the perseverance of its efficacy, and the precautions against the introduction of diseases.
Et ut fiat phlebotomia in una uenarum trium quae sunt in cubito, scilicet Cephalica, et Fusca, et Basilica.	And that it is performed in one of the three veins which are in the elbow, namely the Cephalica, and the Fusca, and the Basilica.
Et ut fiat phlebotomia in principio Veris super ieiunium, in uere, et aestate: et autumno, et hyeme post comestionem, quando apparent significationes repletionis.	And that it is performed at the beginning of Spring upon fasting, in summer, and in Autumn, and in Winter after a meal, when there are signs of repletion
Et fiat phlebotomia in die primo, aut in tertio, postquam praeterierint de die tres horae.	And it is performed on the first or third day after three hours have passed
Phlebotomia autem quae administratur in aegritudinibus, non habet horam determinatam: sed quando prouocat conuenientia et necessitas ad illud, in nocte, aut die, et in omni hora, et in omni tempore.	Phlebotomy, however, which is administered in diseases, has no fixed hour: but when it brings about convenience and necessity for this, in the night or day, and at every hour, and at every time
Et non oportet, ut phlebotomentur pueri, donec ueniant super eos quatuordecim anni.	And it is not proper to bleed children until they are fourteen years of age
Neque phlebotometur mulier praegnans, nisi a mense quarto usque ad septimum.	Neither should a pregnant woman be bled except from the fourth month until the seventh
Neque phlebotomentur senes, qui iam pertransierunt sexaginta annos.	Neither are old men to be bled, who have passed their sixties.
Cum ergo aliquis uult phlebotomari propter quemcumque modum sit: oportet, ut mundificet intestina sua ante phlebotomiam cum clisteri leni, si in eis est stercus multum retentum: ut non attrahant uenae apud phlebotomiam ex intestinis superfluitates putridas nocentes membris principalibus.	Neither are old men to be bled, who have passed their sixties.
Neque phlebotometur patiens toctina, id est, satietatem nauseatiuam: neque crapulatus, neque euadens ab ebrietate, donec remoueatur illud ab eis.	Neither are old men to be bled, who have passed their sixties.
Neque infirmus cum hydropisi.	Neither are old men to be bled, who have passed their sixties.
Et caueatur phlebotomia iterum post colicam passionem, et uomitum, et fluxum uentris, et multiplicationem coitus, et laboris, et exercitii, et uigiliarum, et ieiunii, et omnis quod dissoluit uirtutem ex re corporea aut animali.	Neither are old men to be bled, who have passed their sixties
Deinde considera in subtilitate humorum ante illud, si sanguis est grossus cum cibis et potibus, et medicinis: si possibile est ei illud.	Neither are old men to be bled, who have passed their sixties
Deinde introeat balneum, si non prohibet ipsum aliquid: aut exercitetur aliquo exercitio, ut subtilietur sanguis.	Neither are old men to be bled, who have passed their sixties
Et pone phlebotomiam eius in pectore, circa tertiam diei, sicut diximus: et conare, ut euacuetur pectus eius illa die ex omnibus accidentibus animalibus malis: sicut angustia, et ira, et timor: et ex omnibus accidentibus corporeis, sicut labor, et poena, et superfluicoitus, et illis similia.	Neither are old men to be bled, who have passed their sixties
Et sedi suae faciat esse praesentes res cum quarum usu cucurrit consuetudo hominum ex aromaticitate, et odoramento, et tripudio et similibus illis per quantitatem possibilitatis.	Neither are old men to be bled, who have passed their sixties
Deinde sedeat phlebotomator super puluinari, quod sit altius quam puluinar phlebotomandi: postea extrahat brachium suum, et fricet ipsum phlebotomator manu sua bis, aut ter.	Neither are old men to be bled, who have passed their sixties
Deinde stringat ligamentum cum corrigia, et inuoluat eam bis.	Neither are old men to be bled, who have passed their sixties
Et sit strictura temperata, quoniam strictura quando est inaequalis, aut per superfluitatem in strictura, tunc prohibet cursum sanguinis: aut in mollificatione, tunc etiam prohibet cursum sanguinis.	Neither are old men to be bled, who have passed their sixties
Deinde post stricturam oportet, ut fricet phlebotomandus manus suas simul adinuicem, donec inflentur uenae, et declarentur sensui.	Then after the stricture, it is necessary that the phlebotomist should hold his hand towards the inside, until the veins are filled, and until they are declared to be full by sense.
Deinde abstergat phlebotomator phlebotomum cum pauco oleo, antiquo proprie.	Then the phlebotomist should withdraw the phlebotome with little force, as before.</start_of_turn>
Deinde ponat digitum suum indicem manus sinistrae super ipsam uenam sub loco cuius phlebotomiam uult, parum: ut non fugiat uena, et cassetur percussio.	Then he places his finger on the index of his left hand over the vein at the place where he wishes to make the phlebotomy, somewhat: so that the vein does not flee, and so that the percussion may be set.</start_of_turn>
Quoniam ex uenis est quam inuenis sicut chordam fugientem apud phlebotomiam: et ex eis est quae est plena uentositate: et quando ponis phlebotomum super eam, contrahitur sub phlebotomo, et decipitur phlebotomator, et non aperit phlebotomus uenam: et si aperit eam, est stricta: propter illud ergo oportet, ut firmetur phlebotomator, et sit sollicitus in his rebus omnibus.	For from the veins is as from strings which are fleeing from the phlebotomy: and from the veins is that which is full of blood: and when you place the phlebotome upon it, it contracts under the phlebotome, and the phlebotomist is struck, and the phlebotomy does not open the vein: and if it does open the vein, it is a stricture: because of that therefore it is necessary that the phlebotomist should be firm, and attentive in all these matters.</start_of_turn>
Deinde deponat phlebotomum.	Then he lays down the phlebotome.</start_of_turn
Si ergo aperitur uena ex uice una, tunc bonum est.	If therefore the vein opens from one side, then it is good.</start_of_turn
Et si non, tunc itera illud uice alia sub illo loco parum, aut supra ipsum cum festinatione: si non apostematur locus.	And if not, then do it again with that side somewhat lower, or above it with speed: if the place does not yield.</start_of_turn
Quod si apostematur, aut expauescit infirmus, tunc dimitte eum die, aut duobus diebus: et non stringat ligamentum.	And if it yields, or the patient becomes faint, then let him go away for one day, or two: and do not bind the ligament.</start_of_turn
Fortasse enim attrahet apostema calidum.	Perhaps indeed the swelling will draw away.</start_of_turn
Neque ingrediatur balneum.	Neither let him apply a poultice.</start_of_turn
Deinde iteret phlebotomiam, si amat.	Then repeat the phlebotomy if necessary.</start_of_turn>
Quod si apertio est parua, aut currit sanguis subtiliter: et times ut non egrediatur ex sanguine quantitas quam uis: tunc itera phlebotomum in foramine ipso secundum rectitudinem, et adde in operatione parum.	If the opening is small, or blood runs too quickly: be careful lest blood escape beyond what is necessary. Then repeat the phlebotomy in the same place following the rule and add slightly more to the operation.
Et fac illud cum festinatione, antequam apostemetur locus, apostematus enim locus est in multis hominibus apud operationem paruam.	Do the same as when making a veinous opening before the place is closed. For in many people the closed place is near the area being operated on for a small matter.</start_of_turn>
Si ergo uides ipsum iam apostematum, tunc non iteres super ipsum omnino, non enim excusat apud te aliquid.	If therefore you wish to close it immediately, do not go over it entirely; for that would excuse you for nothing.</start_of_turn>
Et pone super ipsum aliquid ex faece olei: quoniam alleuiat cursum sanguinis.	And place something soft over it of the fat of oil: because it will soothe the course of the blood.</start_of_turn>
Et est melior in hoc loco quam oleum ipsum, et quam reliqua olea.	Better is wax than oil in this place, and than any other oil.</start_of_turn>
Et similiter administra faecem olei in omni phlebotomia tua, qua phlebotomas uenas apud prohibitionem cursus sanguinis: et faciunt illud tyriaca alfarach, et sagzenea, quando ponitur ex una earum super locum.	And do the same with fat of oil in all your phlebotomies, which you make against the running of the blood: and make them thick as tyriaca alfarach and sage, when you put one on the other over the place.</start_of_turn>
Sanguis enim subtiliatur et resoluitur, quando est grossus.	Blood becomes thin and dissolves when it is thick.</start_of_turn
Quod si accidat in loco phlebotomiae apostema magnum, nam multotiens accidit, praecipue ei qui non est phlebotomatus nisi uice illa, aut est apertio uenae parua, tunc propera et pone super locum spongiam infusam in aqua et sale, calefacta parumper: et stringe eam hora una: quoniam soluitur.	If it happens that in the place of the phlebotomy the closing is large, for example because it is not a complete phlebotomy or because the opening of the vein is small: then be careful and put over the place a sponge soaked in water and salt, warmed up slightly: and bind it for one hour: for it will dissolve.</start_of_turn
Et oportet, ut facias illud post exitum sanguinis ex uena ipsa, cum complemento sui, aut ex uena alia.	And it is necessary that you do this after the blood has gone out of the vein, with the addition of something or from another vein.</start_of_turn
Quod si remanet in loco post dies aliquid nigredinis, aut uiriditatis, non nocet illud: et si uis, pone super ipsum aliquid aloe, aut myrrhae solutorum: aut aliquid ex succo menthastri, id est, calamenti aut simile illius.	If anything black or yellow remains in the place after a few days, it does no harm: and if you wish, put over it something of aloe or mastic gum, or something of the juice of mint, that is, calamine or something like that.</start_of_turn
Et multotiens quidem accidunt apostemata et eminentiae apud phlebotomiam Basilicae.	Many wounds also occur at the posteriors and eminences near the phlebotomy of Basilica.
Pone ergo manum tuam super ipsam, tunc si inuenis molliciem apud compressionem tuam super ipsam, tunc illa eminentia est mala.	Put your hand upon the wound; if you find softness under your compression, then that eminence is bad
Caue ergo, ut ponas super eam aliquid ex eo quod diximus.	Therefore, do as we have said before concerning that thing.
Nam fortasse fluet ex ea sanguis arteriae.	For perhaps blood will flow from it.
Sed fac emplastrum ei cum eo in quo est stipticitas, ut induretur locus.	But make a dressing for it with that which has styptic action, so that the place is bound up.
Deinde cura ipsum cum reliqua curatione, donec sanetur.	Then care for it with the rest of the treatment, until it is healed.
Et oportet, ut extrahas omni homini ex sanguine secundum quantitatem uirtutis suae.	And it is necessary to draw out from every man from the blood according to the quantity of his virtue.
Et quod apparet ex colore uincente super sanguinem.	And what appears from the colour of the blood that is above it.
Nam sanguis si est niger, tunc dimitte ipsum exire, donec rubeat: et similiter si uides ipsum grossum: tunc dimitte eum, donec subtilietur: et similiter si est acutus, donec auferatur acuitas eius.	For blood that is black, then let it go out: and in the same way if you see it thick: then let it go, until it becomes thin: and in the same way if it is acute, until its sharpness is taken away
Et oportet ei qui est plenus, fortis, et indiget extractione sanguinis uice una, ut amplificetur phlebotomia uenae, et sit phlebotomus latus: et in eo qui est debilis, sit econtrario illius.	And it is necessary for him who is full, strong, and indigent of blood to take only one, so that the phlebotomy is facilitated by one, and that the phlebotomist is broad: and in him who is weak, let the contrary be done
Et oportet, ut extrahat ipsum in uicibus, et ut sit foramen strictum: et melius quod administratur in phlebotomia uenae est, ut sit transuersa sectio, non punctura.	And it is necessary to draw it out in small quantities, and that the hole be strict: and it is better that it be administered by phlebotomy of one, than by puncture.
Et iste modus phlebotomiae est saluus a fluxu sanguinis, et ab incisione nerui: et est laudabilior, et saluior quam phlebotomia per latitudinem et longitudinem.	And this method of phlebotomy is safer from the flow of blood, and from the cutting of nerves: and it is more praiseworthy, and safer than phlebotomy by breadth and length.
Et cui consueuit peruenire apud phlebotomiam syncopis, oportet ut cibes ante phlebotomiam modico pane infuso in aqua granati muzi: aut secaniabin, si est calefactus: et extrahas ei ex sanguine in tribus uicibus, aut quatuor.	And when it has become accustomed to remain beside the phlebotomies during the syncope, it is necessary that food be given to the patient before the phlebotomy with bread soaked in pomegranate juice: or dry bread, if it is heated: and take from him from the blood in three or four doses.
Et si est infrigidatae complexionis, tunc accipiat ante phlebotomiam panem infusum in syrupo miua, aut in syrupo de melle aromatizato cum speciebus, aut in syrupo aromatizato odorifero.	And if the patient is pale, then before the phlebotomy let him take bread soaked in pomegranate juice, or in honey syrup scented with spices, or in scented syrup with a strong odor
Quod si accidat syncopis apud phlebotomiam, et est caussa eius exitus sanguinis multi: tunc oportet, ut sumat in potu aquam carnis, et syrupum odoriferum subtilem: et utatur aromaticitate cum algalia, et liniatur pectus eius cum ea: et utatur reliquis quae diximus in diuisione in capitulo syncopis ex euacuatione.	And if there is fainting during the phlebotomy, and this is the cause of its exitus sanguinis multi: then it is necessary that he take in the drink water with meat, and a mild aromatic syrup: and let it be scented with herbs, and keep his chest filled with these things: and do all that we said in the chapter on fainting from evacuation.
Qui autem uult euentare brachium suum, et soluere sanguinem suum secundo: oportet ei cuius phlebotomia est propter euacuationem multam, et uirtus eius est debilis, ut soluat sanguinem paulatim per quantitatem uirtutis in diebus continuis.	Whoever wishes to restrain his arm and solve his blood slowly: must do that whose phlebotomy is because of a great evacuation, and his strength is weak, so that he may slowly solve the blood by the quantity of his strength in continuous days.
Qui uero uult euentare brachium suum, et soluere sanguinem suum secundo, et est corpus eius forte: tunc faciat illud post septem horas, aut nouem a phlebotomia sua prima.	Whoever wishes to restrain his arm and solve his blood slowly, and his body is strong: then let him do that after seven hours, or nine hours from his first phlebotomy.
Qui autem uult attrahere sanguinem ex corpore suo ad contrarium partis ad quam declinat: oportet ut euentetur ei in die secundo, aut in tertio.	Whoever wishes to draw blood from his body to the contrary part of which it hangs down: must do that in the second or third day.
In cuius uero corpore est sanguis multus iam calefactus, et acuitur, et facit accidere febrem: oportet, ut egrediatur ex eo sanguis in uice una, et extrahatur ex eo quantitas multa: et amplificetur apertio usquequo accidat syncopis: postquam tu fueris conseruans omnes conditiones phlebotomiae: et ut ponas manum tuam super pulsum eius apud cursum sanguinis, ut non accidat mors loco syncopis.	In whose body there is much blood that is heated and acute, and causes fever: it is necessary that it be drawn from him in one dose, and that a great quantity be extracted from him: and the opening should be increased until fainting occurs: after which you must preserve all the conditions of the phlebotomy, and put your hand over the pulse of his wrist beside the course of the blood, so that no fainting occurs at that place.
Multotiens enim accidit illud, quando ignorat phlebotomator, et cadit negligentia.	Many times, this occurs when the phlebotomist is ignorant and neglectful.
Et non oportet quando uis soluere brachium, et soluere sanguinem secundo, cum iam clausum sit orificium uenae, et fiat difficilis exitus sanguinis, ut prematur super ipsum cum uehementia, et curuatum extendatur uelociter.	It should not be when he wishes to close the arm and stop the bleeding, while the orifice of the vein is closed, and there is difficulty in the exit of the blood, as it will happen before that when he has delayed too long.
Nam illud est malum ualde, imo dimitte ipsum, donec phlebotometur secundo.	For indeed that is bad, rather let him depart, until the phlebotomist comes again in a second
Aut remoue cum acuitate phlebotomi illud quod coagulatum est ex sanguine in orificio uenae, et pone super ipsum aliquid salis dissoluti in aqua.	Or move quickly when the phlebotomy is acute that which has coagulated in the vein at the orifice, and put over it something salty dissolved in water
Et pone super ipsum aliquid ex tyriaca alfaroch, aut sagzenea, et pone ipsum compressione leni, donec egrediatur sanguis.	And put over it something of Tyriaca Alfaroch, or sage, and press it gently, until the blood comes out
Si uero iam apostemata est uena, tunc dimitte eam, et non tegas eam, donec sedetur apostema.	If indeed the vein is clotted, then depart from it, and do not tighten it, until the clot has settled down.
Quod si necessitas prouocat ad soluendum sanguinem secundo, et non est excusatio, tunc aut phlebotoma ipsum supra illum locum, aut in brachio alio in uena alia.	When indeed the need compels to stop the bleeding again, and it is not excusable, then either perform the phlebotomy above the place, or in another arm in another vein.
Funis autem brachii phlebotomatur loco Fuscae, et Basilicae, cum non inueniuntur, et sunt occultae, quoniam est composita ex eis.	But the veins of the forearm and the elbow, when not found, are hidden, because they are composed of marrow.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae eius est, ut intromittat infirmus manum suam in aqua calida, donec rubeat focile, et appareat uena manifeste.	And the quality of the phlebotomy is that it allows the patient to immerse his hand in warm water, until the skin reddens, and the vein appears clearly visible.
Deinde stringatur super ipsam cum ligamento parum constrictione media.	Then bind over it with a bandage with a moderate degree of constriction
Deinde phlebotoma secundum transuersationem paulatim, non latitudinaliter, neque secundum longitudinem: et sit apertio ampla, et sit phlebotomia tua qua eam phlebotomas super iuncturam manus parumper.	Then perform the phlebotomy in a transverse direction gradually, not latitudinally, neither along the length: and let the opening be wide, and let your phlebotomy be like that which you perform over a small wound of the hand
Quod si prohibetur exitus sanguinis, tunc itera manum in aqua calida, et dimitte sanguinem currere in aqua, donec consequaris necessitatem tuam.	If the flow of blood is prohibited, then move the hand into warm water, and let the blood run in the water until you reach your need.
Si autem fueris in diebus aestatis, tunc excusaris ab iteratione manus in aqua calida.	If you are in the summer days, then you are excused from moving the hand into warm water.
Et plurimum quidem ponitur cursus sanguinis in aqua calida in tempore hyemis.	And most of all, the course of blood is put in warm water in the winter time.
Et phlebotomia huius uenae est saluior omnibus uenis, quoniam non est sub ea uena pulsatilis, neque neruus.	And the phlebotomy of this vein is more useful to all diseases, because there is no pulsation under this vein, neither nerve.
Phlebotomia uero Saluatellae manus dextrae, est conferens aegritudinibus epatis.	The phlebotomy of the right hand is useful for the jaundice of the liver.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae eius est, ut stringas mahason manus cum ligamento, aut manu tua, postquam tu intromittis eam in aquam calidam, donec infletur uena, et demonsteretur sensui ualde.	And the quality of this phlebotomy is that you must bind the wrist with a string or your hand, after you have introduced the hand into the warm water, until the vein is swollen and you can feel the cold sensation
Deinde phlebotoma eam transuersando.	Then the phlebotomy is passed over.
Et si incidis eam totaliter, non nocebit ei illud in aliquo.	And if you cut the vein entirely, it will not cause any damage to him in any way.
Et conserua, ne ultimes manum tuam cum phlebotomo.	And be careful not to make the last move of your hand with the phlebotomy
Sub ea enim sunt nerui digitorum denudati ex carne.	Under this, indeed, are the nerves of the fingers naked from the flesh.
Deinde itera manum ad aquam calidam, et dimitte currere sanguinem in ea.	Then move the hand once more into the warm water, and let the blood run in it
Nam si tu non iteras eam in aqua calida, coagulatur sanguis in orificio uenae, et prohibetur a cursu.	For if you do not move the hand into the warm water, the blood coagulates in the opening of the vein, and is prohibited from flowing.
Cum ergo extraxeris ex sanguine quantitatem necessitatis, tunc pone super uenam oleum et sal: ut non consolidetur uelociter.	When you have therefore extracted from the blood the quantity of need, then put over the vein oil and salt: so that it does not solidify too quickly
Et similiter oportet, ut facias cum omni ramo stricto.	And in the same way it is necessary to do with every strict limb.
Iuuamentum uero phlebotomiae eius ex manu sinistra, est: quoniam est conferens ad aegritudines splenis: et similiter fac in phlebotomia eius, sicut fecisti in secunda aequaliter.	The vein itself of the left hand is: because it is related to the diseases of the spleen: and do likewise in the phlebotomy of this, as you did in the second equal.
Saphenae autem phlebotomiae iuuamentum, est ad aegritudines quae sunt in inferiori parte corporis, sicut aegritudines matricum, et retentionem menstruorum, et infirmitates renum, et ulcera coxarum et crurium antiqua, et similia ex aegritudinibus.	The vein of the left hand indeed is: because it is related to the diseases which are in the lower parts of the body, such as the diseases of the uterus, and retention of menstrual blood, and kidney disease, and ulcers of the buttocks and ancient fractures, and similar diseases.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae eius est, ut intromittat infirmus pedem suum in aquam calidam: et faciat super ipsum fricationem, donec exuberent uenae: et liga supra iuncturam pedis cum corrigia.	And the quality of this phlebotomy is, that it lets the patient's foot enter the warm water: and make above it friction, until the veins burst: and ligate above the junction of the foot with the bandage.
Et uenae quidem locus est apud calcaneum, apparens uersus pollicem: et ramificantur ex ea in facie pedis rami multi.	And the veins are at the heel, appearing under the thumb: and they are broken from these in the face of the foot in many places.
Phlebotoma ergo eam in ampliore ramo eius, aut apud calcaneum in aggregatione eius: quoniam est melius et saluius.	The phlebotomy is therefore in the greater branch of this vein, or at the heel in its collection: because this is better and safer.
Quod si phlebotomas eam in facie pedis, tunc caue a neruis qui sunt sub ea super faciem pedis.	And if the phlebotomy is done on the face of the foot, then take care of the nerves which are under these and over the face of the foot
Et pone phlebotomiam tuam qua eam phlebotomas ex transuerso, quasi tu uelis incidere eam: et sit phlebotomus Nesil.	And place your phlebotomy through from the cross, as if you wish to cut through it: and let the phlebotomy be of Nesil.
Si autem prohibetur exitus sanguinis, tunc itera pedem eius in aqua calida: et dimitte sanguinem currere in eam, donec euacuatur.	But if the blood is prohibited from coming out, then repeat the foot in the warm water: and let the blood run in the vein, until it is evacuated
Quod si errat uenam phlebotomator in prima uice, tunc iteret cum phlebotomia ad superiora parumper, nam locus est saluus, et non times ex eo maliciam, quando tu caues a neruis, sicut diximus.	And if the phlebotomist has erred in the first attempt, then repeat with the phlebotomy to the upper parts, for the place is safe, and not for that reason does it cause harm, when you cut the nerves, as we said.
Et similiter cum Saphena pedis alterius aequaliter.	And in like manner as the saphenous vein of the other foot is equally.
Venae autem Sciaticae locus, sicut diximus, est apud calcaneum ex latere syluestri.	The sciatic vein is located at the heel on the outside of the ankle, as we have said.
Et iuuamentum phlebotomiae eius est, ad dolorem anchae, quando est propter sanguinem calidum.	Its sensation is to cause pain in the knee when there is thickened blood in it.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae eius est, ut ingrediatur infirmus balneum, et festinet: et stringe crus eius a latere anchae usque supra calcaneum quatuor digitis, cum uitta subtili longa: non enim apparet nisi propter illud.	Its quality is that it should be made with a soft bandage and should be hurried: and it should be bound around the leg from the ankle up to the heel with four fingers, and should be left on for a long time. It will not be seen except for this.
Quando ergo apparet, tunc phlebotoma eam secundum quodcumque ingenium est tibi possibile, aut secundum transuersionem: et est melius, aut ut incidas eam incisione, aut seces eam sectione.	When it appears, then the vein must be cut according to any expedient means which are possible, or by stripping: and it is better either to cauterize it with a burn or to cut it through with a section
Locus enim eius est saluior, et ipsa est in pluribus hominibus occulta ualde.	Its place is safer, and it is often hidden in many people.
Quod si non inuenis eam, et non apparet sensui omnino: tunc phlebotoma aliquem ramum eius, et est ille qui apparet in dorso pedis, et uersus auricularem: et caue a neruis, et fac currere ex sanguine quantitatem quam uis.	If you do not find it and do not perceive it at all: then cut some branch of it, that which appears in the back of the foot and below the heel: and cauterize from the nerves, and let the blood flow out as much as you wish
Deinde solue stricturam, et pone super locum phlebotomiae corium, et stringe locum.	Then loosen the ligature, and place over the place of the phlebotomy some skin, and bind the place.
Uelociter enim sanatur.	It will soon heal.
¶ De Ventosatione, et qualitate usus eius.	Note: The provided text continues beyond this section, but the instructions are in a different language and are not included here.
Caput XCVIII.	Chapter 103.</start_of_turn>
Uentosae fiunt ex cornibus, et ex aere, et ex uitro.	The humors arise from the bones, and from the air, and from the spleen.
Et Ventosatio quidem fit secundum duos modos.	There are two kinds of ventilation
Cum scarificatione, et extractione sanguinis: et alter est uentosatio sine scarificatione.	When there is scarification and bloodletting, the other is [treatment] without scarification.
Et haec Ventosatio quae est sine scarificatione, est secundum duos modos.	And this treatment without scarification is according to two methods.
Aut enim est cum igne.	Or it is with oil.
Aut est absque igne.	Or it is without fire
Et uentosis quae administrantur cum scarificatione et extractione sanguinis sunt quatuordecim loca corporis.	And the treatments which are administered with scarification and bloodletting are fourteen in number throughout the body
Quorum unus est, Ventosatio Alnocrati, et est postremum capitis: et Alkehel, et est medium colli: et uentosae Alhagdahim, et sunt duae laminae colli a duabus partibus simul: et uentosae menti, et est sub mandibula in inferiori oris: et uentosae duarum spatularum: et uentosae Alachosos super finem caudae: et uentosae duorum focilium, et sunt medium duorum brachiorum: et uentosae duorum crurium: et uentosae duarum cauillarum.	These latter four are of the head and neck: Aloe is applied to the back of the head: Alkhel to the middle of the neck: the two Alhagdahim are for the two layers of the neck from two parts together: Ment is for under the jaw at the lower part of the mouth: Alachosos is for between the two angles of the jaw: the two Focus are for the middle of the two arms: the two Crura for the two wrists: and the two Caudae for the two ankles
Et Ventosatio quidem non extrahit sanguinem tibi ex uenis minutis sparsis in carne, et propter illud non cadit uirtus ex eis, sicut est casus eius ex phlebotomia.	And indeed the treatment does not draw out blood from many small veins throughout the flesh, but because of this it does not cause loss of blood, as is the case with phlebotomy.
Neque oportet, ut administretur uentosatio siue cum igne, aut absque igne in aliqua aegritudinum quae fiunt ex repletione, donec euacuetur totum corpus.	Neither is it necessary to administer treatment with fire or without fire in any ailment which arises from congestion, until the whole body has been evacuated.
Quod si necessitas prouocat ad Ventosationem ex aegritudine, aut propter consuetudinem, administramus eam in omni hora in principio mensis, in fine eius, et in medio ipsius, et in quocumque tempore fuerit.	If necessity demands, we administer it at every hour at the beginning, at the end, and in the middle of the month, and at any other time if necessary
Quod est, quia ex hominibus est qui quando multiplicatur in eo sanguis, donec indiget extractione eius per uentosationem, inuenit in capite suo grauedinem, et sodahan.	For in men, when there is an increase in blood in this way, until it requires extraction by treatment, it acquires great weight in the head and becomes harmful
Et ex eis est qui inuenit repletionem et rubedinem in facie sua, capite suo, et collo suo.	And from this is that which causes congestion and redness of the face, head and neck
Et ex eis est qui inuenit pruritum in facie sua, et fronte sua, et tenebrositatem, et hebetudinem in oculis suis.	And from the eye there is that which causes itching in the face, and the front of the face, and shadows, and dullness in the eyes.
Et ex eis est qui scalpit locum uentosationis suae.	And from the eye there is that which severs the seat of its moisture.
Et ex eis est cuius risus multiplicatur.	And from the eye there is that which causes laughter to be multiplied
Et ex eis est qui inuenit gustum sanguinis in ore suo: aut apostematur lingua, et expuit sanguinem.	And from the eye there is that which causes the taste of blood in the mouth: either the tongue swells up and expels blood
Et ex eis est cuius somnus multiplicatur.	And from the eye there is that which causes sleep to be multiplied
Et ex eis est qui uidet in somno suo sanguinem et rubedinem, et interfectos, et plagas, et quae sunt similia illis.	And from the eye there is that which causes vomiting of blood and redness, and discharge, and spots, and things which are similar to these.
Quando ergo uidemus aliquid ex illis, et proprie si est in tertia media mensis: praecipimus tunc uentosationem fieri, postquam praeterierunt de die duae horae, aut tres.	When we see anything of these things, and especially if it has been more than two or three days since the last: we then order that the moisture be removed, after two or three hours have passed by
Iuuamentum autem Ventosationis nuchae, est: quoniam ipsa confert ad grauitatem in capite, et quod effunditur ad oculos.	The ointment of the night is thus: because it itself causes an excess of weight in the head, and what flows down to the eyes.
At uero oportet, ut sit illud post euacuationem totius corporis.	And indeed it is proper that it should be after the evacuation of the whole body.
Et haec quidem Ventosa est loco phlebotomiae Cephalicae.	These things are a kind of phlebotomy of the head.
Et non licet, ut utatur ea qui est frigidae complexionis, aut in quo est catarrus.	It is not permitted to use these things by those who are of a cold complexion, or in whom there is a catarrh.
Nam infert ei nocumentum magnum.	For it brings on a great discomfort
Et propter illud non oportet, ut utantur ea senes, et in cuius capite sunt aegritudines frigidae.	And because of this it is not permitted to use these things for the elderly, and in whom there are cold spots in the head
Qui autem super eam fit assiduus, generatur super eum obliuio.	Whoever however uses it excessively will generate on him an aversion
Et propter illud oportet, ut praecipias Ventosatori, ut deponat manum suam cum uentosa parumper ad inferiora, timendo ex generatione obliuionis.	And therefore it is necessary, as the Master of Winds has said, to place the hand with the palm downwards near the lower parts, fearing lest from the generation of oblivion.
Ventosatio aut Alkehel, est loco phlebotomiae Fuscae, et phlebotomiae Basilicae, et propter illud confert asmati, et constrictioni anhelitus, et fissurae instrumenti anhelitus, et tussi, et repletioni.	The Master of Winds or Alkehel is the place of phlebotomy of the vein of the Fusca, and of the vein of the Basilica, and because of this it causes swelling, constriction of the breath, and pain in the instruments of the breath, and coughing, and distension.
Et oportet, ut impellatur Ventosa Alkehel parumper, quoniam si ponitur inferius, generat debilitatem in corde, et stomacho.	It is necessary to urge the Master of the Winds downwards, because if it is placed downwards, it generates weakness in the heart and the stomach
Ventosatio uero alhagdahim, confert doloribus accidentibus in capite, et obtalmiae, et hemigraneae, et perforationi, et dolori in radicibus dentium: et est loco phlebotomiae Basilicae.	The Master of the Winds or al-haggadah causes headaches, vomiting, swelling of the temples, dizziness, perforation, and pain in the roots of the teeth: and is the place of phlebotomy of the Basilica.
Et oportet, ut praecipias Ventosatori, ne premat manum suam cum scarificatione: ut non incidat arteriam, et accidat fluxus sanguinis.	And it is necessary, as the Master of Winds has said, to keep the hand away from the scarification: that it does not cut the artery and cause the flow of blood to be obstructed.
Ventosatio autem sub mento, confert alcolae in ore, et corruptioni gingiuae, et similibus eis ex aegritudinibus quae sunt in ore: et stat loco phlebotomiae alieherich, quae sunt in duobus labiis.	The Master of the Winds placed under the chin causes nausea in the mouth, corruption of the gums, and similar ailments that are in the mouth: and is the place of phlebotomy of the two lower teeth
Ventosatio autem spatularum, confert ad alchafacham, quae fit ex replexione, et caliditate.	The Master of the Winds of the spatulas causes swelling of the face, which is produced by reflection and heat.
Ventosatio uero interiorum partium duorum focilium, confert iuuamentum phlebotomiae uenarum trium, Basilicae, et Fuscae, et Cephalicae: quoniam ipsa attrahit sanguinem ex omnibus illis uenis minutis, quae sunt in carne: et attrahunt illae uenae minutae ex uenis aliis grossioribus eis, donec peruenit attractio ad uenas tres.	The Master of the Winds of the inner parts of the two cavities [chest and abdomen] causes the drawing together of the veins of the veins of the three ventricles, Basilica, Fusca, and Cephalic: because it attracts blood from all these small veins that are in the flesh: and these small veins are attracted from other large veins until the attraction reaches the three veins.
Et oportet, ut praecipias Ventosatori, ne multum procedat in scarificatione: quoniam locus est denudatus carne, et sub eo sunt nerui et arteriae.	The windsore must take care, in performing the scarification, not to go too deep: for in this place is the flesh stripped away, and beneath it are nerves and blood vessels.
Ventosa autem quae uentosatur super alchausos, confert hemorroidibus Ani, et ulceribus inferioribus.	The windsore which occurs on the buttocks causes haemorrhoids to the anus and lower ulcers.
Et oportet, ut praecipias Ventosatori, ut sit uentosa magna, et ut sit ex aere: quoniam locus indiget suctione forti, et fortasse franguntur Ventosae subtiles: et scarificetur scarificatione magna.	The windsore must take care, that it be large and open to the air: for in this place requires strong suction, and perhaps the fine windsours will be broken: and the scarification must be made with a large incision
Ventosae autem crurium minuunt diminutione manifesta: quoniam attrahunt sanguinem ex toto corpore, et conferunt doloribus antiquis in renibus, et matricibus, et uesica: prouocant menstrua, et conferunt bothor, et ademenul: et stant loco phlebotomiae duarum saphenarum, et alhorcobeni.	The windsore of the buttocks diminishes by becoming small: for it draws blood from the whole body, and causes old pains in the loin, and the groin, and the genitals: it brings on menstruation, and causes swelling and softening: and it stands in the place of two saphenous veins, and the testicles
Verumtamen debilitant corpus multum, et faciunt accidere syncopim in pluribus hominibus.	It is true that it weakens the body a great deal, and causes fainting in many men.
Et Ventosarum alhorcobeni iuuamentum est propinquum iuuamento Ventosarum duorum crurium.	The testicles are close to the two veins of the buttocks.
Qualitas positionis Ventosarum est, ut ponas uentosam in primis uacuam, et sugas suctione temperata: et non prolonges positionem uentosarum, sed pone eas uelociter, et remoue eas uelociter, ut ueniant humores ad locum aduentu aequali: et non cesses iterare illud et continuare, donec uideas locum iam rubere et inflari, et appareat rubedo sanguinis: tunc ergo scarifica, et itera suctione paulatim.	The position of the windsours is such, that you must place the major incision in the beginning of the wound, and call for a temperate suction: and do not prolong the position of the incision, but put things quickly and easily, so that the humours may reach the place in an even manner: and do not cease doing this until the place is red and swollen, and blood appears red: then indeed scarify, and repeat the suction gradually.
Deinde considera in dispositione corporum.	Consider then the position of the body.
Nam qui ex hominibus est tenerae carnis, rarorum pororum, oportet ut scarifices ipsum semel, non plus: ut non ulceretur locus.	For one who has a lean body and few hairs, it is enough to make the incision once, not more: as not to ulcerate the place.
Et praecipe Ventosatori, ut amplificet scarificationem, et profundet parum: et temperet suctionem in facilitate, et uelocitate, et motu suaui.	Command the wind-blower to strengthen the incision, and deepen it slightly: and temper the suction to facilitate, speed, and the movement of the instrument.
Quod si in sanguine est grossitudo, tunc oportet, ut scarifices ipsum bis.	If there is any thickness in the blood, it is necessary to repeat the incision twice
In uice quidem prima aperitur uia subtiliationi sanguinis, et aquositati eius: et in secunda quidem perscrutationi exquisitae extractionis sanguinis grossi.	In the first incision, make a small opening under the blood vessel, and wash out the blood: and in the second incision, make an accurate incision for the extraction of the thick blood.
Si uero sanguis est faeculentus ualde, tunc fiat scarificatio uice tertia: ut consequatur ultimum.	If the blood is dark and foul, make a third incision: in order to achieve the ultimate goal
Et ad ultimum, quando uolumus extrahere sanguinem paulatim, uel parumper, sufficit nobis scarificatio una.	Finally, when we wish to extract the blood slowly or in small amounts, one incision is sufficient.
Quod si uolumus extractionem sanguinis multi, scarificamus scarificatione plurima.	If we wish to extract a large amount of blood, we make several incisions
Et si nos mensuramus, quod sanguis est grossus: tunc oportet, ut scarificetur scarificatione profunda: et terminus aequalis in scarificatione, est profunditas cutis.	If we are measuring, that the blood is thick: then it is necessary to make a deep incision: and the endpoint of the incision is the depth of the skin
¶ Quid sit illud quod oportet administrari ex oleis apud positionem Ventosarum, et quid caueat uentosandus.	What should be administered from the oils at the position of the wind-blowers, and what is the cause of the wind-blower?
IN illo quidem cuius cutis est grossa, dura, fusca, et pori eius sunt stricti, oportet ut ungantur loca Ventosare cum oleis apertiuis, lenitiuis, resolutiuis: si est in tempore aestatis, sicut est oleum alkeiri, aut oleum uiolatum, aut oleum de amigdalis dulcibus, aut oleum de semine cucurbitae.	In those parts where the skin is thick, hard, rough, and its pores are narrow, it is necessary to anoint the area of the wind-blower with open, soothing, resolving oils: if it is in summer, such as almond oil, or walnut oil, or sweet fennel oil, or cucumber seed oil
Et si est in tempore hyemis, tunc oleum narcissinum, aut oleum de lilio, aut oleum camomellinum, aut sarbatinum: et eis similia.	And if it is in winter, then narcissus oil, or lily oil, or camomile oil, or beeswax: and similar things.
Si uero superfluitas est grossa, frigida: tunc oleum sit amaracinum, aut oleum de balsamita aut oleum alben, aut oleum anetinum: et eis similia.	If there is excessive moisture, cold: then the oil should be bitter almond oil, or balsam oil, or white oil, or ivy oil: and similar things.
